editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: TREATISE COLLECTED OUT OF the Statutes of this Commonwealth, and according to common experience of the Lawes, Concerning THE OFFICE AND AUTHORITIES OF CORONERS AND SHERIFES.
Together with An ea≈øie and plaine method for the keeping of a Court Leet, Court Baron, and Hundred Court, &c.
By JOHN WILKINSON of Bernards Inne, Gent.
To which is added the returne of writts by John Kitchin E ≈øq Now all publi≈øhed in Engli≈øh.
London, Printed for W. Lee, D. Pakeman, R. Best,and G. Bedell and are to be ≈øold at their ≈øhopps in Fleet≈øtreet and Grayes In-Gate. 1651.

div.head: To the Courteous Reader.
div.p: WHereas many wi≈øe and learned men have written of things that they have gathered by reading, I doe publi≈øh what I have practi≈øed, warranted by authorities in Law. And becau≈øe the end of writing books is to benefit others, I know it will bee acceptable to all that are not deeply ≈øtudied, to make u ≈øe of the≈øe things which I have collected: neither can it offend the be≈øt learned, to ≈ø ee that plainly ≈øet out, as it were by demon≈ø tration: which they by learning already under≈øtand.

The Office of a Coroner, the Office and dutie of a Sherife, and the Office of a Steward, and and the manner of keeping of Courts in Hundreds, Leetes, Baronies, are daily exerci≈øed by many, yet few know the true formes that are to bee kept in keeping of tho≈øe Courts: For their ≈øakes therefore I have undertaken this paines, and dare be bold to ≈øay, that they ≈øhall not much erre, if they follow what is here in this Booke ≈øet downe, for direction for them herein. To which I have added the Returne of
writts, Originally written by the learned John KitchinE≈øquier, as generally u≈øefull, as any of the former Tracts (which with much care and diligence, are now all Tran≈ølated into Engli≈øh, for thine, and the publique good. If thou finde≈øt in this worke any ≈ømall errours, be plea≈øed to excu≈øe it, beeing the fir≈øt that hath adventured in this untrodden path: And your good acceptance may further incourage mee to continue

div.head: A COMPENDIOUS TREATISE, WHEREIN is ≈øet forth the Office and authority of a CORONER.
THE FIRST BOOKE.

div.p:
A Coroner is an ancient Officer of this common- wealth, and ordained to be a principall pre≈øerver of the Peace, and to carry the Records of the Pleas of the capitall Office of the upper Bench, and of his owne view, and of abjurations, outlawries, appeales, &c. And this definition of him is given by Britton an ancient writer, fol. 3. with the which agreeth the booke de tit Coron in Fitz. Nat Br. pag. 186. where he amplifieth his power more largely, viz. That he ≈øhould carry Records of his owne view, Abjurations, Outlawries, Appeales, accu≈øements of theeves done before him, and of all non ≈øuits in appeales, and of all other things done in the County, that appertaine to the coroners office: and al≈øo in the court of freemen, which have franchi≈øes of infangtheef, &c. And in the pre≈øence of the Coroner ≈øhall all appeales of Robberie and Larceny bee framed. The ≈øe things doe declare the office of a Coroner
to be an Office of tru≈øt, and of great authority: and for that cau≈øe it is requi≈øite that it be committed to a wi≈øe man, and of good behaviour, as it was well perceived by our ancient Fathers and predece≈ø≈øors, and chiefely by tho≈øe that made the Statute at We≈øtmin≈øter the 1. chp. 10. which rehear ≈øeth, for that that people of ≈ømall condition, and not of the wi≈øe≈øt, be now lately cho ≈øen to the office of Coroners, and much meeter it were, that wi≈øe men, loyall, and ≈øage, ≈øhould intermeddle with that office, It is provided, that through all Counties be cho≈øen ≈ø ufficient men to be Coroners, of the mo≈øt loyall and mo≈øt ≈ø age≈øt Knights, which be≈øt know, can or will attend to that office, and that they lawfully keepe and pre≈øent the pleas of the Capitall office of the upper Bench: And that the Sherifes have counter-rolles of the Coroners, as well of Appeales as of Inque≈øts concerning Attachments or other matters appertaining to that office. And that no coroner ≈øhal demand any thing, or take any thing to execute his office, upon paine of a great forfeiture to the Keepers of the liberty of England by authority of Parliament to the u ≈øe of the common-wealth.

The Statute committeth this Office to Knights, and not to any others, and therefore it was held to be a maine cau≈øe to remove and di≈øcharge a coroner from his office, if he be not a Knight: but Ma≈øter Fitzherbet in his Natura brevium in his writ de Coronator. eligend would not allow the ≈ø ame for a ≈øufficient cau≈øe at this day, alledging; That tho≈øe words were put into the Statute, to the intent that a Coroner ≈øhould have ≈øufficient within the county to an≈øwer for all that he doth or ought to doe by his ≈øaid office.

Al≈øo this Statute requireth ≈øuch a Coroner as can, will, & may attend to execute the ≈øaid office. And therfore if ≈øuch a Coroner be elected & ch≈øen as cannot, will not, nor may not attend the execution of the ≈øame office, he is to be removed & di≈ø charged by Writ from the ≈øame office: & the cau≈øe of his not attendance or in≈ø ufficiency mu≈øt bee rehear≈øed in the writ, viz. that he is occupied in other of the
common-wealths affaires, or that he is not in health, or aged, or unapt for the ≈øame Office, or that he is in≈øufficient in lands, or that he hath the pal≈øie, or that his abode is in the uttermo≈øt parts of the county, or that he is nominated Sherife, or Ranger of a Forre≈øt: but if any of the≈øe cau≈øes be untrue, and the Coroner thereby di≈øcharged of his office by a fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtion, Then hee may if he will goe to the Chancery, and there by petition pray a Commi≈ø≈øion to inquire of this fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtion, the which if it bee found, and returned to the Chancery, then the Keepers of the Libertie of England by the authority of the Parliament may grant a Super≈øedeas to the Sherife of that County, that hee remove not the ≈øaid Coroner from his office, and if hee bee removed before the Super≈øedeas come, then that he permit the Coroner removed to execute his office as he did before his removall, as it appeareth in Ma≈øter Fitzh. Nat. Bre. in and by the writs de Coron. elegendo, & de Electione viridariorum.

But it ≈øhall be farre more commendable for him that is cho≈øen a Coroner, that if he perceive any of the ≈øaid impediments to bee in him≈øelfe, that he then doe purcha≈øe a Writ to di≈øcharge him≈øelfe from the ≈ø aid office, which Writ he ≈øhall finde in the Regi≈øter, fol. 177.

This Statute al≈øo willeth that no Coroner ≈øhall take any thing for doing of his office, &c. for this purpo≈øe, that he wholly may be at liberty to doe and execute Ju≈øtice and Right, and therefore within twelve yeares after there was a Statute made to puni≈øh that corruption and extortion, which is called Statutum Exoniae, made the fourteenth year of E. 1. which you ≈øhall finde in the book called ≈ø ecunda pars veterum Statutorum, by the which al≈øo it appeareth that a Coroner ought to take nothing for executing of his office, which I finde not altered by any Statute untill 3 H. 7. cap. 1. which giveth him in murder 13.≈ø. 4. d. of the goods of the murderer, if he have any goods, but if he have none, then the Coroner is to have his Fee by amercing of the village for ≈øuffering the Murderer to e≈øcape, and if any particular per≈øon ≈øhall bee
found guilty of ≈ø uch e≈øcape, the Coroner hath power to enquire thereof by the ≈øame Statute.
But I finde, tit Cor. in Fitz. fol. 321. & 371. that a Coroner hath a Fee belonging to his office, viz. of every Vi≈øne one penny, when they appeare before the Ju≈øtices of Eyre.
But that Fee is not repugnant to the Statute of We≈øt. 1. for he receiveth not the ≈øame to doe his office, but as a right due to him though that he executeth no part of his office, &c.
Al≈øo the Statute of 1 H. 8. cap. 7. prohibiteth a Coroner to take any thing for doing of his office, upon paine of 40. ≈ø. for every default.
And al≈øo upon like penalty, where he giveth not his attendance when he is ≈øent for and required to make Inqui≈øition upon the death of any dead corps, &c.

And ≈øince the Stat. of We≈øtmin≈øter the fir≈øt, it was ordained and enacted by a Statute made An 14. Ed. 3. cap. 7. that no Coroner bee cho≈øen if hee have not lands ≈øufficient in the ≈øame County wherewith he may an≈øwer all manner of people. This Statute is in the negative, and therefore the not ≈ø atisfying of the ≈øame Statute, is good cau≈øe to remove him from his office, by the Writ before remembred, the which Writ declareth how he ≈øhall be ≈øaid, to bee ≈øufficient, and in what ≈øort the ≈øame ≈øhall be examined, viz. if hee have lands in the county upon the which he may dwell agreeable to his degree, for the exerci≈øing of the ≈øame Office.

Al≈øo after by another Statute made anno 28 Ed.3. cap. 6. it was enacted, That all Coroners of every County ≈øhould be cho≈øen in the open Counties by the Freeholders of the ≈øaid county, of the mo≈øt conveniente≈øt and mo≈øt loyal≈øt people that may bee found in the ≈øaid Counties, to execute the ≈øaid Office: alwaies ≈øaving to the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of the Parliament, to the u≈øe of the Commonwealth, and other Lords their Seigniories and Franchi≈øes.

And note, that when a Coroner is cho≈øen, he ≈øhall remaine Officer ≈øo long as he behave him≈øelfe well therein
and is not changeable every year, as the Sherifes and E≈øcheators are, qd vid. Hil 4 E. fol. 44.
Al≈øo when he is elected, the Sherife of the ≈øame County, or his Under≈øherife, mu≈ø t give him his oath thus as followeth.

div.head: His Oath for the due execution of his Office.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ≈øweare that you well & truely ≈øhall ≈ø erve the commonwealth in the office of a Coroner, & as one of the Commonwealths Coroners of this County of Southampton, & therein you ≈øhall diligently & truely doe & accompli≈øh all and every thing and things appertaining to your Office, after the be≈øt of your cunning, wit, and power, both for the Commonwealths profit, and the good of the inhabitants within the ≈øaid County, taking ≈øuch fees as you ought to take by the Lawes and Statutes of this Weale publique, and not otherwi≈øe. So help you God, and the holy contents of this booke. And ≈øo let him ki≈ø ≈øe the book to affirm his Oath.

Fir≈øt, when he hath notice to take the view of the body of any per≈øon ≈ølaine either with his will or again≈øt his will, hee mu≈øt then make his precept to the Con ≈øtables and Tythingmen of the Hundred where the party lyeth dead, to ≈øummon a Jury to appeare before him at a day and a place certaine, to enquire thereof upon a paine of 40. ≈ø. before remembred. And the form of his Precept is thus: viz.

South.By vertue of mine office, the≈øe are in the Keepers of the Liberty of England by the Authority of Parliament name, to will and require you immediately upon the receit hereof to ≈øummon and warne 24 able and ≈øufficient men to be and appeare before me at A. the 10. day of February next comming after the date hereof, or to morrow being Tue≈øday the 10 day of February at the Townhall there, if there be any, or at any other place certain, then and there to doe and execute ≈øuch things as on the Commonwealths behalfe ≈øhall be given them in charge, whereof faile you not, as you and every of you will an≈øwer
the contrary at your perils. Dated under my hand and ≈øeale this ninth of February, ann Dom. 1638.

closer.signed: Per me Io. W. unum Coron. Reipub. com.prad.

div.p: To the Con≈øtables and Tithingmen of the Hundred of B. in this behalfe, jointly and ≈øeverally greeting.
div.q: ANd when he commeth to the place appointed, he mu≈øt then call for the Con≈øtable and Tythingmen to whom hee did direct his warrant for their returne, and when he hath that, then he mu≈øt cau≈øe one of them, or ≈øome other for them to make three proclamations or Oyes, and call the Jury thus: You good men which be returned to appeare here this pre≈øent time, to enquire for the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament, an≈øwer to your names as you ≈ø hall be called, every man at the fir≈øt call, upon pain and perill that may fall thereon. This done, when you have a full Jury of 14. or 15. call the foreman to the Book, and ≈øweare him thus; You ≈øhall duly enquire, and true pre≈øentment make of ≈øuch things as ≈ø hall bee given you in charge, according to your evidence, ≈øo help you God, and the contents of that Book.
div.p: Then call the re≈øt of the Jury, and ≈øwear them by four at once, and ≈øwear them thus.
div.q: ALL ≈øuch Oath as A.B. your Foreman hath taken before you on his part, you and every one of you ≈øhall well and truely ob≈øerve and keep on your parts, ≈øo God you help, and the contents of that book.
div.p: And when they are all thus ≈øworn, call them again, and let the Crier count them after you, and then bid them ≈ø tand together and hear their charge.
Then begin your Charge thus.

div.head: The Charge.
div.p:
SIrs, you that be ≈øworne, you ≈øhall under≈øtand what the cau≈øe of our meeting is here now at this pre≈øent, It is to inquire and pre≈øent or find, how A.B. came to his death: for when any man, woman, or child doe come to to their death by any ca≈øualty, or untimely meanes, then the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament have appointed Coroners in every County to inquire thereof by the oathes of men: And therefore by vertue of mine Office, I have cau≈øed you to bee called hither, and have impannelled and ≈øworne you to that purpo≈ø e, to the end that the Keepers of the Liberty of England afore≈øaid, and their immediate Officers may be truely certified how and by what meanes a member of this Common-wealth is lo ≈øt: Therefore now your charge is, to inquire how and by what meanes the ≈øaid A.B. came to his death, that a true record may be made thereof; If he was ≈ølaine in fight, then you mu≈øt inquire by whom, when, and where, & in what manner, and with what weapon, as neere as you can, & what goods, chattells, lands or hereditaments the offender had at the time of the fact committed, or at any time ≈øithence, and whether hee bee fled for the ≈øame or no; For I mu≈øt tell you, that Coroners have authority to enquire by their Office of all maner of homicids and ≈ø laughters of men, e≈øpecially above all other things, and that by the oathes of men ≈ø uper vi≈øum Corporis, and not otherwi≈øe: And the≈øe homicides and ≈ølaughters of men are of divers kinds or degrees, but they are all comprehended within two kinds, viz. ≈øpirituall homicide, and corporall homicide: the fir≈øt is the ≈ølaughter and de≈ø truction of the ≈øoule, which is Gods part, if he dye in the faith of Chri≈øt: and the other is the ≈ølaughter of the body, which is the Commonwealths part, that mu≈øt take his end by the due execution of Ju≈øtice for the offence committed again≈øt the Law: and a corporall homicide is twofold, that is to ≈øay, Lingua, & facto, Tongue and Fact; Lingua, by the Tongue is three
fold, viz. in commanding, in giving of coun≈øell, and in de≈øending: Facto, by Fact, is foure fold, viz. in execution of Ju≈øtice, Homicide willingly done, Homicide done by chance, and Homicide done by nece≈ø≈øity: Homicide done by Ju≈øtice, is when a man is ju≈øtly condemned and executed for his offence: Homicide willingly done, is either murther, or at the lea≈øt man≈ø laughter: Homicide done by chance, is by ≈øome accidentall means, as where one is killed by ca≈øting of a ≈øtone unawares, or ≈øhooting of an arrow, or ≈øuch like, and killeth one again≈øt the will or intent of him that ca≈øteth or ≈øhooteth. And Homicide of nece≈ø≈øity is when a man cannot chu≈øe but he mu≈øt either kill or be killed, and that will be taken to be in his owne defence: then there is Homicide inevitable for the advancement of Ju≈ø tice; And that is where a Sherife or other officer by warrant pur≈øues a Felon which will not obey or yeeld him≈øelf, but offereth violence, and ≈øo is killed in apprehending, or where a man killeth a theefe which would rob him: In the≈øe ca≈øes he which committeth ≈øuch Homicide ≈øhall be acquitted, and neither lo≈øe life, lands, or goods for the ≈øame. There are other Homicides which are no Felony, and that is where a mad man either kills him≈ø elfe or any other per≈øon when he is mad, or where a child is killed in the mothers belly not in rerum natura, and that for two cau≈øes, viz. one becau≈øe it had not the name of Bapti≈øme, and the other becau≈øe it cannot be certainely known whether the mother killed it by ≈øome other meanes or no; but if an Infant of nine years old kill a man, woman, or child, if ≈øuch Infant then knew good from evill, it is felony in ≈øuch an Infant, and that will be well knowne and perceived by the an≈øwer of ≈øuch an Infant to ≈øuch que ≈øtions as may be demanded of him: or here al≈øo if a man take upon him to be a Phy≈ø itian or a Surgeon, and not allowed to u≈øe and practi≈øe ≈øuch faculty, if he take upon him a cure which dyeth under his hands by his ignorance, it is held to be Felonie in ≈øuch Phy≈ø itian or Surgeon. Al≈øo if a man keep a dangerous bea≈øt, as a Bull, a Beare, a Dog, or ≈øuch like, he knowing
them to be dangerous, and yet doth not keep them tied, but wilfully ≈øuffereth ≈øuch bea≈øts to goe at large without a keeper, if ≈øuch bea≈ø t kill a man, woman, or child, it is held to bee Felony in the owner of ≈øuch Bea≈øt: Al≈øo there is another kinde of Homicide, which is a kinde of Murder called Felo de ≈øe,and that is where one hangs, or kills, or drownes him≈øelfe for lack of grace: for as it is Murder and Felony for one man willingly and wilfully to kill another; ≈øo likewi≈øe it is murder and felony for a man to kill or drowne him ≈øelfe willingly & wilfully, yet they are not both in one ca≈øe and predicament; for the fir≈øt doth forfeite by that fact both his lands, and his goods, and the other forfeites but goods and chattels, and no lands. There is al≈øo another kinde of Homicide, not done by man, but by ca≈øuall means, and that is called Homicide by mi≈øadventure or misfortune, by a Hor≈øe, or a Cart, or a Bough of a tree, or ≈øuch like: and in this ca≈øe, omne quod movet cum eo quod occidit hominem deodand e≈øt Reipublicae; every thing that moveth with that which kills a man is Deodan, unle≈ø≈øe the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament have formerly granted the ≈øame away to ≈øome Lord of a Liberty, as is commonly done, then if it happen to be within ≈øuch liberty, it belongs to the Lord of the Liberty. But if any of the≈øe Homicides fall out to be wilfull Murder, which is a mo ≈ø t bloody and a crying ≈øinne, and cannot be too ≈øeverely puni≈øhed, and therefore by the Law, the offender herein ought to lo≈øe both life, lands, and goods, an eye for an eye, and a tooth for a tooth. And if Man≈ølaughter, if the offender can read well, then he may in favour of life, by the Keepers of the Liberty of England afore≈øaid mercy, have the benefit of his Clergy, and ≈øo ≈øave his life, but he ≈øhall lo≈øe and forfeite both his lands and goods, and yet the Law of God not therein ≈øatisfied: The goods mu ≈øt be found, apprai≈øed, and valued, of ≈øuch offendors, and left in the Town≈øhip or Village where ≈ø uch offendor dwelleth, by them ≈øafely to be kept, until the offendor be acquitted or convicted by due cour≈øe of Law; in
the meane time the offender mu≈øt be maintained with his goods, ≈øo as he may be kept alive to an≈øwer his fact, and what ≈øhall remaine when he is convicted, tho≈øe to whom ≈øuch goods doe belong by the Law mu≈øt have them, and not before, and thereof di ≈øcharge the Town≈øhip or Village which had the cu≈øtody of ≈øuch goods. And as for the offendors Free land, if he have any, immediately after conviction, the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament to the u≈øe of the Commonwealth mu ≈øt have annum, diem, & va≈øtum therein, and after the Lord of whom it is holden ≈øhall have it as an E≈øcheat. And thus having di≈ø cour≈øed at large of all the≈øe things incident to my office for your in≈øtruction, I will make an end and trouble you no more at this time: and ≈øo you ≈ø hall heare your evidence.
Then if the evidence be ready, they mu≈øt be called and ≈øworn thus.
div.q: THe evidence that you ≈øhall give to this enque≈øt, ≈øhall be the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, ≈øo helpe you God, and the contents of this booke.
div.p: And if the evidence be not ready, then you mu≈øt appoint the Jury a day and a place to come to you to receive their evidence, and le≈øt they or any of them ≈øhould faile to come to the plac at the time appointed, you may bind them by recogni≈øance in x.li. or xx. li. a piece, and in the meane time you may ≈øend your Warrant for the witne≈ø≈øes to come before you to bee examined, and to deliver their knowledge concerning the matter in que≈øtion, & be ≈øure to take their examinations in writing under their hands, & if it be about the triall of any mans life, then you mu≈øt bind over all the witne≈ø≈øes in xx. li. a piece at the lea ≈øt, to appeare at the next Affi≈øes then following, to deliver their knowledge therein viva voce, if they ≈øhalbe thereunto required.
The forme of which Recogni≈øance is thus;

div.opener: South.The third day of October, &c. the yeare, &c. James S. of B. in the County afore≈øaid, acknowledges him≈øelfe to owe, &c. vnder condition, &c.
div.p: That if the ≈øaid I.S. doe per≈øonally appeare before the Ju≈øtices of A≈ø≈øi≈øe and Goale delivery, at the next A≈ø≈øi≈øes to be holden at the Ca≈øtle of W. for the ≈øaid County, and then and there deliver and ≈øet forth his knowledge touching the death of A.B. and doe not depart thence without licence of the ≈øaid Court. That then this pre≈øent Recogni≈øance to be void and of none effect, or el≈øe the ≈øame to ≈øtand, remain, and continue in force, ≈ø trength, and vertue.

closer.signed: Taken and acknowledgedthe third day of October in the yeare 1617. afore≈øaid before me J.W.Gent. one of the Coroners of the county afore≈øaid. J.W.

div.head: Of wilfull Murther.
div.p: This office is the highe≈øt and greate≈øt offence that a Coroner is to meddle withall by his office, and it is defined by Bracton to bee ≈øecret killing of ≈øtrangers and men knowne, none knowing or ≈øeeing it be≈øides the murtherer and his aiders, ≈øo that no Hue-and-cry of the County pre≈øently follow, &c. And ≈øo you may ≈ø ee how that Englechery, that is, that he is Engli≈øh, &c. was pre≈øented in ancient time untill the fourteenth yeare of E. 3. At which titme by a Statute made the 14. Edward 3. cap. 4. the pre≈øentment of Englechery was wholly abrogated and adnulled, the letter of which Statute is thus, viz.

Item, for that there are many mi≈øchiefs happened in many countries in England, which knew not how to pre≈øent Englechery, for which cau ≈øe the Commons of the Counties oftentimes were before the Ju≈øtices in Eyre amerced, to the great grievance of the people; It is therefore agreed that at no time hereafter any Ju≈øtice of
any Eyre ≈øhall put any article or oppo≈øition pre≈øenting Englechery to the Commons of the Counties, nor again≈øt any of them. But that for ever Englechery and the pre ≈ø entment thereof to be wholly omitted and made void; ≈øo that none for this cau≈øe be from henceforth impeached: By the words of this Statute it appeareth, that the pre≈øentment of Englechery was ≈øo divers by the divers cu≈ø tomes of ≈øeverall countries, that the countries knew not well how to ≈øatisfie the Ju≈øtices in the pre≈øenting thereof, but for the undue pre≈øenting thereof, they were often amerced and ≈øore grieved: And yet Bracton ≈ø aith, Becau≈øe in divers Countries Englechery is differently pre≈ø ented in every Eire, the cu≈øtome of pre≈øenting it is to be inquired from the beginning. Al≈ø o hee putteth there in his Booke many things which excu≈ø eth the Country by the Common Law from that amerciament or payment of lxvj. markes, for he ≈øaith in this manner, That is weighed ≈øometime, &c. And that al≈øo was the common Law appeareth in Britton fol. 15. which agreeth throughout with that which Bracton hath here written, the which common Law is changed as I have ≈øaid before by the ≈øaid Statute made in the 14. yeare of E. 3. wherefore a man at this day may define murther in other manner than Bracton and Brittondid, viz. It is murther when any man of malice prepenced killeth another felloniou≈ø ly, having no regard whether he kill him openly or ≈øecretly, or whether he be an Engli≈øhman or not, ≈øo that hee live in the Weale publique under the Parliaments protection, and Homicide that is done in ≈øuch manner is called Murder at this day; for the name of Murder was not at any time changed, but the Law retained the ≈øame continually, for the hainou≈ønes of the crime, to put a difference between homicide Chance-medley and Murder: And therefore if a man be indicted of Murder, at this day, a pardon of all Felonies will not helpe him, and that is by the Statute of 13 R. 2. cap. 1. the letter whereof you may ≈øee hereafter: And al≈øo the Statute of 1 Edw. 6. cap. 12. which in≈ø ueth, videlicet. Provided al≈øo, and be it enacted by the
authority afore≈øaid, that all wilfull killing by poy≈øoning of any per≈øon or per≈øons that at any time hereafter ≈øhall be done, perpetrated or committed, ≈øhall be adjudged, taken, and deemed wilfull Murder of malice prepenced, and that the offendors therein, their ayders, abettors, procurers, and coun≈øellers ≈øhall ≈ø uffer death, and forfeite in every behalf, as in other ca≈øes of wilfull murder of malice prepenced.

Of Man≈ølaughter.Man≈ølaughter is where one killeth another having no malice prepenced ≈øo to doe, yet it is felony, and he ≈ø hall lo≈øe his lands and goods, and his life too, if he cannot read well, as is ≈øaid before in the charge: The which thing if a mad man doe, it is no felony in him, nor he ≈øhall not be arraigned for it, when he is of good memory, as it appeareth in Fitzh. fol. 33. and 21 Hen. 7. tamen in the Eyres of Northampton in 3 E. 3. It appeareth there, that he ≈øhould purcha≈øe his pardon of cour≈ø e: And with that agreeth 26. li. a≈ø≈ø. And the ≈øame Law which ≈øerveth for a man lunatick, ≈øerveth for a man that is deafe, and dumbe, as yee may finde in the ≈øame Plea. And if one of the age of 12 years or more, kill another, that is Felony: the ≈øame Law is if he be but nine yeares old at the time of the killing; ≈øo that it may be perceived that he under≈øtandeth good from evill, as by his excu≈øe, or by any act done ≈ø ince the killing, videlicet, in hiding the dead corps in any ≈øecret place to the intent it ≈øhould not be found and knowne, Becau≈øe in ≈ø uch ca ≈øe malice ≈øupplyes age. 3 H. 7. & tit coron 51. And there they re≈øpited execution of him to the intent they might procure his pardon. And Bract. ≈øaid in tho≈ø e ca≈øes of Lunaticks, & of the infant, one the want of judgement ≈ø aves, the other the weakne≈ø≈øe of fact excu≈øes.

And if a Surgeon or a Phy≈ø itian allowed, have one in cure, which dyeth pre≈øently after, or within a ≈øhort time after, that is no Felony, for that he did nothing feloniou≈øly: but if he killed him with Phy≈øick or Surgery, it was done again≈øt his will, quod vide titulo Coronae 163. et Britton fol. 14. c. Contr.

Al≈øo if a man have a Bull, a Beare, or a Dog, which is accu≈ø tomed to doe hurt, and his ma≈øter or owner well knowing the ≈ø ame, yet doe not tie him but ≈øuffer him to goe at large, and being ≈øo at large, he killeth a man, this is held by Fitzherbert, 311. to bee Felony in the owner of the bea≈øt, by rea≈øon of the ≈øufferance, for thereby the owner ≈øeemeth to have a will to kill: And note that in ancient time, the will was ≈øo materiall, that the ≈øame was taken for the fact, ut patet titulo 1. E. 3. where one compa≈ø≈øing the death of another, woundeth him ≈øo grievou≈øly that he leaveth him for dead, and afterward flyeth, and the man wounded reviveth: And yet notwith≈øtanding, it was then adjudged to be felony, in≈øomuch as the will appeareth to have killed him; the will ≈øhall bee taken for the deed. And with the ≈øame agreeth Bracton,who ≈øaith, In things ill done, the will, not the end is looked upon, not materiall whether any man kills, or be the cau≈øe of death. But this Law is not now in force, for he mu≈øt be dead indeed before it be adiudged Felony. And if a man hurt another with an intent to beate him, but not to kill him, yet notwith≈øtanding if he die of ≈øuch beating, it is felony in him that ≈øo did beate him, wherefore at this day a man may convert the text to Bractons opinion, and ≈øay, The end in things ill done, not the will alone is looked upon, as in the ca≈øe next before, &c. vide titulo memorato, where for the malitious words of a woman 2. men fought, and the one killed the other, the woman in this ca≈øe was arraigned of the death of him that was ≈ølain: The like ca≈øe if three men goe together to make a di≈ø≈øame, and one of the ≈øe three doth kill a man, the other two in this ca≈øe are taken to be principall Felons, and yet they did it not of any evill will, but onely came in one company together, quod vide titulo Fitz. 305. So that many ca≈øes may be found, where the end is looked upon, not the will only, as before is ≈øaid; wherefore to conclude, we may ≈øay, that the will, unle≈ø ≈øe the fact en≈øueth the ≈øame, maketh no offence at this day, but in trea≈øon given by Statute, &c.

It is a generall opinion, and commonly agreed upon, that if a man have judgement to be hanged, and commandement given to the Sherife to ≈øee execution done according to the judgement, if the Sherife after of his owne authority doe behead the pri≈øoner which was appointed to be hanged, then this is felony in the Sherife, becau≈øe the order of the Judgement is not ob≈øerved, in putting the pri≈øoner to death. The ≈øame Law is, if one that is not the Sherife will kill a pri≈øoner as he is going to the gallowes to bee hanged, of his owne head, and authority, quod vide 35 H. 6. And for this Felony the wife of the pri≈øoner may have an appeale again≈øt him that killed her husband: But Scrope is of opinion that it ≈ø hall be otherwi≈øe, if hee that is killed bee attainted by outlawry, as it appeareth 2 E. 3. where he that is indicted alleadgeth, that he for who≈øe death he is indicted was and is outlawed of Felony, Scrope, It may be that that outlawry is rever≈øed, or that he had his charter of pardon, wherefore he mu ≈øt make ≈øearch and ≈øend into the Chancery, to under≈øtand there if he had a charter of pardon, and in the meane time he ≈øhall be let to bayle till a certaine day that the truth be knowne; and he ≈øaid further, that if he found that the outlawry was not rever≈øed, nor that the pri≈øoner had not any charter of pardon, that that then the def. ≈øhall not an≈øwer any further but bee di≈øcharged of the Indictment: Al≈øo it ≈øeemeth to bee lawfull for any to kill a man attainted in a Praemunire, becau≈øe the Statute of 25 Edw. 3. cap. 21. de producionibus willeth that a man doe again≈øt them, as again ≈øt the enemies of the Weale publique without any Impeachment, &c.

Of homicide done by nece≈ø≈øity inevitable ju≈øtifiable.A Sherifes Bailife, or any other Officer that hath warrant to arre≈øt any man that is indicted for Felony, may ju≈øtifie the killing of him, if he will not ≈øuffer him≈øelfe to be arre≈øted, but in ≈øuch ≈øort ≈øtandeth in his defence, that the Officer cannot arre≈øt him without killing of him, in this ca≈øe the Officer ≈øhall be di≈øcharged without ≈øuing forth of his pardon of cour≈øe, ut patet22. lib.
A≈ø≈ø. & 22. E. 3. where Thorpe ≈øaith, that any man may take and arre≈øt a theefe, and if hee will not yeeld, but ≈øtand in defence of him≈øelfe, or el≈øe flye, in ≈øuch ca≈øe he may kill him without blame, ergo he that hath no warrant as well as he that hath a warrant, by this authority may kill and ju≈øtifie. And there he reciteth, that where a Gaoler came to the Gaole with a Lanthorn in his hand, to ≈øee his pri≈øoners, which had broken their Irons, and ≈øtanding all ready to have killed him, they beate him, and wounded him very ≈ø ore, but killed him not: and he having a hatcher in his hand, therewith he killed three of the pri ≈øoners, and being called in que≈øtion for it, was di≈øcharged thereof, for it was adjudged by all the Councell, that the Gaoler had done well, &c. And therefore note ye, as a man may ju≈øtifie the killing of a man before an arre≈øt, even ≈øo he may ju≈ø tifie the ≈øame after an arre≈øt, ≈øo that the ≈øame doe ari≈øe upon an inevitable nece ≈ø≈øity, as before is ≈øaid. And therefore one is arre≈ø ted of Felony, and as he is carying to the Gaol he maketh debate and flyeth, and the other in ≈øuch ≈øort pur≈øueth him, that he cannot take him againe without killing of him: this manner of killing is ju≈øtifiable, qd vide 3. E. 3, &c. And the ca ≈øe is there, That a man did fly to a Church for felony, and after in the night he went from thence, and the village that did watch him in the Church did pur ≈øue him, and killed him, for that he would not yeeld him≈øelf, and it was allowed as well done, tamen in codem tituto 3. Ed 3. Lowth doth doubt of this killing, in that it may be that he that was arre≈øted was nor guilty of the felony, although he was indicted thereof; and nothing like the ca≈øe where one is pur≈øued upon a robbery done, and the theefe killed. But by the book afore≈øaid it appeareth that ≈øuch killing is not felony, nor that any thing ≈ø hall be forfeit for the ≈øame, nor that any pardon is needfull, ≈øed vide ibid. fol.344. that in that ca≈øe it is finable, and a fine of xl. ≈ø. was payd for the ≈øame, ≈øed quaer. whether the ≈øame was for the killing, or for the e≈øcape. And note, that if hee which killeth another by rea≈øon of any matter inevitable ut ≈ø upra to be found before
him by rea ≈øon of any juri≈ødiction that hee hath to inquire of Felonies, he ≈øhall not be di ≈øcharged upon ≈øuch indictment found, untill ≈øuch time as he be arraigned upon the ≈ø ame, and the matter al≈øo found by verdict, ut patet eju≈ødem titulo, for that hee him≈øelfe was Judge thereof. Otherwi≈øe it is if the finding of the ≈øame be before other Commi≈ø≈øioners, vide le Statute de malefactoribus in parcis, made the one and twentieth year of Ed. 1. which giveth power to Forre≈øters, Parkers, and Vvarrenners to kill the offendors if they will not bee ju≈øtified, &c.

Homicide in a defending of a mans hou≈øe and his goods again≈øt theeves, lawful and ju≈øtifiable for the urgent nece≈ø≈øity therof.As for example: Many doe come to burne my hou≈øe, my ≈øelfe beeing within the ≈øame, and they compa≈ø≈øe about the hou ≈øe, but they burne it not; and I ≈øhoot out of the ≈øame hou≈øe and kill one of them, this is not felony, ut patet 26. lib. A≈ø≈ø.The ≈øame law is if they come to my hou≈øe and rob me, and my boy or my man that is with me in my hou≈øe killeth one of them, quod vide in Fitzh. ritulo Coron 3 E. 3. per Lowth & ibidem p. 505. where it was pre≈øented that a man had killed another in his owne hou ≈øe defending him≈øelf, and it was demanded of tho≈øe that made the pre≈øentment, if he that was ≈øo ≈ølaine did come to robbe him, for in that ca≈øe one man might kill another, though that it be not in defence of him≈øelfe, &c. And in all ≈øuch like ca≈øes a man ≈øhall goe quit without any forfeiture, or without expecting any pardon, in that my hou≈øe is unto me as my Ca≈øtle, out of which the Law will not con≈øtraine me to flye, &c. The ≈øame Law is, if one come unto me when I am out of my hou ≈øe, and will robbe me, wherefore I kill him: for in 26. lib. A≈ø≈ø.the ca≈øe was that a theefe a≈ø≈øailed a man in his ≈øhip, and he pur≈ø ued him ≈øo hardly, that the man killed him, and generally it was affirmed, that the man ≈ø hould be di≈øcharged and quit without pardon. And note well this latter booke, for that maketh expre≈ø≈øe mention that he ≈øhall goe quit without pardon; but the other bookes ≈øpeake nothing neither of pardon, nor yet of the ≈øorfeiture; wherefore it may be doubtfull to ≈øome, whether he ≈øhall forfeit his goods, and whether it ≈øhall be needfull
to have a pardon or not, and therefore to take away all doubts, a Statute was made Ann 24. H. 8. the letter whereof is this, Fora≈ømuch as it hath been in que≈øtion and ambiguity, that if any evill di≈øpo≈øed per≈øon or per≈øons doe attempt ≈øeloniou≈øly to robbe or murder: and ≈øo ≈øee the Statute at large, that it is lawfull to kill him.

How nece≈ø≈øity ≈øhal be interpreted in Homicide in defence of ones ≈øelfNote, that the nece≈ø≈øity ought to bee ≈øo great, that it ought to be e≈øteemed not avoydable, or otherwi≈ø e hee ≈øhall not be excu≈øed, for in this ca≈øe ye have not to doe with, as in the ca≈øe before, but with a ju≈øt man. And whether the per≈øon that is ≈øo killed, or the per≈øon that doth kill, doth beginne the affray, it is not materiall, but the whole matter con≈øi≈øteth in the nece≈ø≈øity inevitable, without which the killing by any means is not excu≈øable: wherfore to make a definition of Homicide done in a mans owne defence, we mu≈øt ≈øay, that properly it is when A. doth make an affray upon B.and hurteth him, and A. flyeth as much as he can for ≈øafeguard of his life, ≈øo that hee is come to a ≈øtrait, beyond the which he cannot flye, and A. continueth, whereby B hurteth and killeth him: this is called Homicide in a mans own defence. For if B. might have avoyded the ≈øame and did not, but when A. had hurt him, he then had hurt A. againe even to death, then was it man≈ølaughter, and ≈øo felony in B. ut patet in Fitzh. 226. But when A. hurteth B.B. hurteth him again but not deadly, and afterward B flyeth, ut ≈øupra, and A. pur≈øueth him till that he commeth into a ≈øtraite ut ≈ø upra, and then B.doth kill him, that is not felony, but in his owne defence. And ≈ø o yee may note, that although B. gave to A.divers wounds, that is not materiall, becau≈øe he flyeth from him as much as he can before he gives to A. the deadly wound. And that yee may ≈øee in les Eyres of North. &c. 3 E. 3. And Bracton hath a ca≈øe for the confirmation of this Law, Of Law it is, that what a man does for the ≈øafety of his body, he ≈øhall be e≈øteemed to doe ju≈øtly. And note, that it appeareth before in 43. li. a≈ø≈ø. before noted. And it is not a ≈øufficient verdict to ≈øay that
the pri ≈øoner killed another in his owne defence, but they ought to ≈øhew the matter, e≈ø pecially in what manner it was done. And although it be ≈øpecially found upon the indictment, yet notwith≈øtanding he ≈øhall not thereby be di≈ø charged untill he have purcha≈øed a charter of pardon for the ≈øame, the which is a confe≈ø≈øion by amplification of the indictment, or el≈øe otherwi≈øe wholly to e≈øtrange him≈øelfe from the fact, and to plead not guilty, and ≈øo to be found. And this is ≈øo done to the intent to induce the forfeiture of his goods, being forfeite by the ≈øame offence, ut patet 4 H. 7. And where the Statute of Glouce ≈øt. cap. 9. ≈øaith, that he ought to put him≈øelfe upon an Enque≈øt for good and evill, that it is to be under≈øtood when he is indicted of Murder, or Homicide, and not where in the indictment the ≈øpeciall matter is ≈ø ound; for to ≈øuch an indictment of Murder or Homicide, it ought to be pleaded not guilty; for to plead the ≈øpeciall matter, viz. that he killed him in his own defence, it is no plea, in that it ≈øhould be as a ju≈øtification; whereas ≈øuch kinde of Homicide is not in any manner ju≈øtifiable, wherefore he ought to plead not guilty, and then that ≈ø peciall matter found by verdict ≈øhall give him advantage, &c. Contrariwi≈øe it is in Tre ≈øpa≈ø≈øe, for there the party ≈øhall not take advantage of a ju≈øtification found by verdict, if it bee not pleaded by the party. And ≈øo note, that he ≈øhall not be di≈ø charged of this ≈øpeciall matter, till ≈øuch time as he hath purcha≈ø ed his pardon, or el≈øe be acquitted thereof by verdict: and then his di≈øcharge ≈øhall be in this manner, viz. if he require to purcha≈øe his pardon, hee ≈øhall fir≈øt bee letten to Mainpri≈øe, and then he ≈øhall ≈øue forth his Writ of Certiorari directed to the Judges of A ≈ø ≈øi≈øe, before whom the indictment lyeth, to certifie the Record to the Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners of the great Seale of England, who will make him a Charter of pardon, in ≈øuch a ca ≈øe of cour≈øe. And for the ≈øe matters vide tit. 44 Ed.3.15. E. 3.15. & 3 E. 3. where it is ≈øaid, that when a man is acquitted before the Judges of A≈ø≈øi≈øe, of the death of a man in his owne defence,
he ≈øhall have a Writ from the chiefe Ju≈ø tice, within which ≈øhall be contained the whole Record of his acquitall, to the Commi≈ø≈øioners, who will make his Charter of pardon. And note ye before, that in the Eyres of Northampton the Jury did finde that he fled for the Felony, for which cau≈øe he ≈øhall forfeite his goods, qua≈øi diceret,that he ≈øhould not forfeite his goods unle≈ø ≈øe ≈øuch a flying away had been found; but the Law is not ≈øo as it appeareth. 44. & 15. Ed. 3. & 1 H.7. before noted, wherefore we are to think, that the inquiry of a flying was ≈øurplu≈ø age and voyd, &c And con≈øider well the words of the Statute of Glouce≈øter,which be the≈øe; It is ordered and agreed, that hereafter no Writ ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue out of the Chancery to enquire for the death of a man, if a man hath killed another by mi≈øadventure, or in his owne defence; or in any other manner without Felony, but hee ≈øhall be impri≈øoned untill the comming of the Ju≈øtices of Gaole-delivery, if he cannot finde pledges for his appearance before them, and then he ≈øhall put him≈øelfe to his tryall by the country de bono & malo. And if it be ≈øound by the country that he did the ≈øame in his own defence, or by mi≈ø adventure, then the Ju≈øtices of A≈ø≈ø. are to certifie the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament thereof into the Chancery, and from thence he ≈øhall have his pardon of grace. This Statute maketh mention of Ju≈øtices errant, and of Ju ≈øtices of Gaole-delivery: wherefore it ≈øeemeth that if any be indicted before them, that he killed one in his own defence, that that Indictment is as good as if the ≈øame had been found before the Coroner, upon the view of the dead body, otherwi≈øe it is if ≈øuch Indictment be found before Ju≈øtices of P. for that they have not any authority to to take any ≈øuch indictment. And note, that it appeareth 44. E. 3. before cited, that there is one ca ≈øe where one ≈øhall be killed by Chancemedly, and yet he that killeth him ≈øhall not forfeite any thing; As if A. ≈øtriketh B. to the ground, and thereupon A. draweth his knife to kill B. and B. lying upon the ground draweth his owne
knife, and A. is ≈øo ha≈øty to kill B. that he choppeth him≈øelfe upon the knife which B. had in his hand, and ≈øo A. was ≈ølaine. And it was adjudged in this ca ≈ø e, that the ≈øayd B. was not culpable of the death of A. nor ≈øhall forfeite his goods, becau≈øe A. in a manner killed him≈øelfe, &c. And as it is in the Eyres of North. before pag. 286. and 297. there is a ca≈øe not much unlike to this ca≈øe, which hath a contrary judgement, and yet if collation between them be made, ye ≈øhall finde that they are not both alike, for there he did not lie upon the ground, but ≈øtood upon his feet, in≈øomuch that hee might have made other defence for the ≈ø aving of his life then the other could that did lye upon the ground. And the ca≈øe there was this, viz. A. did ≈ø trike B. and B did flye till that hee came to a ≈øtraite, as it is afore ≈ø aid, and then B. perceiving that A. would kill him, did hold a pitchforke between him and A. and A. was ≈øo fierce that hee ranne upon the pitchforke, and ≈øo was ≈ølaine; and yet notwith≈ø tanding this matter, B. was put to purcha≈øe his pardon of cour≈øe, and be≈ø ides forfeited his goods, &c.

Homicide by mi≈øadventure or misfortuneAnd that is, if a man without any evill intent ca≈øt a ≈øtone or ≈øhoote an arrow whereby one is hurt unawares and ≈ølaine, going to the market or about any other nece≈ø≈øary and lawfull bu≈øine≈ø≈ø e, this manner of killing is Homicide by mi≈øadventure, for the which the offendor ≈øhall have his pardon of cour≈øe in the like ≈øort as before in the ca≈øe where a man ≈øhall have it for killing of a man in his owne defence. And that is by the ≈øaid Statute of Gloc. ut patet 3. E. 3. and he ≈øhall forfeit his goods, as before in the ca≈øe of killing a man in his own defence, vide the Statute of Marlebridge cap. 15. that ≈øaith, Mi≈øfortune hereafter before the Ju≈øtices ≈øhall not be adjudged Murder, Murder is to bee taken onely of tho≈øe that are killed by Felony. By which Statute it appeareth, that mi≈øadventure by the Common Law was adjudged for Murder; But that ought to be with a di≈ø tinction which Bracton hereafter hath made, That is to ≈øay, where one
hath done a thing lawfull and where not, for if hee have done an unlawfull thing, and if any mi≈øadventure doe thereof in≈øue, whereby any one is ≈ølaine, that is Felony at this day, if it be not Murder; And therefore if A. ≈øtrike B. and C. comes betweene them to part them, and is deadly wounded by the ≈øaid A. or B. without any evill intent, yet notwith≈øtanding if C. upon that hurt do dye within a yeare and a day next after ≈øuch hurt given, it is Felony in him which hurt C. and not a mi≈øadventure, for that the fact which A.and B. did was unlawfull, ut pat tit Coron 22. libr. A≈ø≈ø. And if A. and B. did intend one to kill the other, then it is Felony in them both, ut pat. 22. Ed.3. And note that the ≈øame order is to bee ob≈øerved in pleading the verdict, forfeiture, and pardon of one that killeth any by mi≈øadventure as is afore≈øaid, to bee of one that killeth another in his owne defence, and the ≈øaid Statute of Gloc. extendeth as well to the one as to the other.

Homicide called Felo de ≈øe

Bracton defineth felo de ≈øe in this manner, viz. in the ≈ø ame manner that a man may commit Felony by killing another, may he commit Felony by killing him≈øelfe, if any man taken for ≈øome crime done, viz. for the death of man, manife≈øt theft, becau≈øe he is outlawed or any other wickedne≈ø≈ø e, and fearing the puni≈øhment over him, ≈øhall kill him≈øelfe, he commits Felony of him≈ø elfe; he ≈øhall have no heire, he has convinced him≈øelfe of the Felony before done, viz. theft, death of a man, or ≈øuch like, and the feare of Con≈øcience in the guilty is as much as the confe≈ø≈øion; Agreeing to Bracton, yee ≈øhall ≈øee the book titul Coron in Fitz. 259. where a Felon of him≈øelfe ≈øhall forfeite his lands, but whether he had before he killed him≈øelfe committed Felony or not appeareth not by the booke, Ideo quaer. if this di≈øtinction that Bracton hath made be Law at this day, for it appeareth in divers other bookes, that a felo de ≈øe ≈øhall forfeite his goods onely, and no lands, as pag. 301. 362. 420. tit jam dicto, and there al≈øo it appeareth, pag.324. That if one that is Franticke from day to day doe kill him≈øelfe, that
≈øuch a man ≈øhall forfeite no goods or chattels, but otherwi≈øe it is if he be not franticke from day to day, but onely at ≈ø ome times. Al≈øo there pag. 244. was pre≈ø ented, A certaine Lnnaticke ≈øtruck him≈øelfe with his knife, recovered his wits, after the Church Rites performed to him, dyed of his wound, his chattels were not forfeited. The contrary whereof you ≈øhall finde pag. 142. But the Law is cleare, that if a man which is of good memory, committeth the ≈ø ame fact in ≈øuch manner and afterward recovereth, and yet notwith≈ø tanding dyeth of the ≈øame plague that he gave to him≈øelfe, he in that ca≈øe ≈øhall forfeite his goods, vide ibid. the ca≈øe pag. 94. that was before remembred, That is to ≈øay, where A. ≈øtriketh B. to the ground, and thereupon A. plucketh out his knife to kill B. and B. lying upon the ground plucketh out his knife, and A. is ≈øo ha≈øty to kill B. that he choppeth him≈øelfe upon the knife of B. and ≈ø o is ≈ølain, in this ca≈øe A. is a Felon of him≈øelfe, and that ca≈øe agreeth with Bracton heretofore.

Deodand. e≈øt where any per≈øon commeth to his death by mi≈øadventure of any thing that ≈øhall fall upon him, or by mi≈øadventure of a fall that hee taketh from a Cart or a hor≈øe, or any other thing, the ≈øame not being occa≈øioned by any other per≈øon, the thing that ≈øo occa≈ø ioned the death ≈øhall be forfeited, and taken as a Deodand. to be di≈øtributed in almes, for the benefit of the ≈ø oule of the dead per≈øon; And note that it is not materiall whether the thing that killeth him be moving at the time that he was killed or not, for although that it bee not moving, yet notwith ≈øtanding it ≈øhall bee called a Deodand. as well as that which was there moving, as it ≈øhall be hereafter expre≈ø≈øed; And therefore when you ≈øpeak of a thing moving, that it is only to this intent, viz. That all things moving with the thing that is the occa≈øion of the death, ≈øhall be forfeited, as well for a Deodand. as the principall thing, quod vide tit. Fitz. 403. where it is ≈øayd, that every thing which moves, with that which kils a man, is a Deodand to the King, or to the ≈øee of the
Clerke; and therefore yee ≈øhall finde ibid. pag. 398. where a man did cut downe a tree, the which did fall upon the bough of another tree, which bough did fall upon a man and killed him, and was adjudged that as well the tree as the bough ≈øhould be a Deodand. And the ≈øame Law is, where a man doth ride upon a Cart, and the Cart falleth upon him and killeth him, here as well the Hor≈øes which drew the Cart, as the Cart it ≈øelf, ≈øhall be Deodans, ut pat. ibid. pag. 388. and yee ≈øhall finde, pag. 397. That a man being upon a cart loaden with fagots, and binding it, fell with the motion of one hor≈øe in the cart by the which he dyed, and the hor≈ø es and the cart were adjudged for Deodans. Al≈øo pag. 405. A beame on which did hang a bell, did fall upon a man and killed him, the bell as well as the beame were adjudged for Deodans, notwith≈øtanding they were goods of the Church, but of grace, and out of honour to the Church, the chiefe Ju≈øtice gave them back. Et pag. 326. A man falleth out of a cart loaded with hay, and the wheele of the cart doth breake his legs, whereof he dyeth, and the hay was adjudged to be a Deodand as well as the cart, tamen pag. 342. A man falleth out of a cart, and breaketh his neck, as hee was loading of it with ≈øtraw, by the moving of the hor≈øe, the hor≈øe and cart were all adjudged Deodans, and not the ≈øtraw, by rea≈øon that the ≈øtraw was not the occa≈øion of his death, quaere differentiam, &c. Et pag. 401. One riding his hor≈øe drownes him≈øelfe, the hor≈øe is adjudged a Deodan,&c. Hitherto we have ≈øpoken of things moving which doe cau≈øe Deodans;Now let us ≈øpeake of things not moving, and yet ≈øhall be De ‚Ä¢ dans. Vide titulo jam dicto pag. 409. Where a Carter clyming upon one of the wheels of his cart to gather plums, and falleth from the cart whereby he dyeth, and becau≈øe it is witne≈ø≈øed, that neither the hor≈øes nor the cart moved, onely the wheele is a Deodand. and killed, and the wheele onely in this ca≈øe was adjudged a Deodand, ut patet ibidem pag. 389. Vide ibidem pag. 348. where it is ≈øayd, if a man fall from a loade which is worth a C. pound, by the which he receiveth his death, all the ≈øame ≈øhall be a Deodand. And al≈øo it appeareth by the≈øe ca≈øes, that Deodans ≈ø hall be as well of things that move under a man and kill him, as of things which doe not move, but the man all moveth him≈øelfe from them. So in like manner, all things not moving with the thing which is the occa≈øion of the death ≈øhall not be forfeited, as in part you may perceive by the ca≈øe of the cart and the ≈øtraw before cited, Et titulo Forfeitures in Fitzh. 12 R. 2. wherein a ma≈ø≈øe of earth fell upon a man and oppre≈ø ≈øed him in ≈øuch ≈øort that he dyed, and it was adjudged that the ≈øayd ma≈øsa terrae onely ≈øhould be forfeited, and not the hole or pit where he was killed. The ≈ø ame Law is where a man falleth from his hor≈ø e, and qua≈øheth his head again≈øt a block, whereof he dyeth, the hor≈øe onely ≈øhall be adjudged for a Deodand, and not the block, in that it moved not at all, quod vide ibidem pag. 341. And al≈øo Briton titulo Coron fol. 6. ≈øaith, That if a man fall out of a Ship ≈øayling, nothing is the occa≈øion of his death but onely the Ship, and yet the things moving may bee ≈øayd to be the cau≈øes of his death, the merchandi≈øe lying at the bottome is not any cau ≈øe of his death. Et nota, that it ≈øeemeth to one by the bookes before pag. 389. That if hee dye by mi≈ø adventure, and be within the age of 14. yeares, that then nothing ≈ø hall be forfeite for a Deodand,
for there pre≈ø entment was that A. the ≈øonne of B. above an. &c. tamen quaere & vide Fitz. titulo de Indictments pag. 27. That where a man was ≈ø ound dead in the field, Belknap ≈øaid that his appeale ≈ø hould bee given to the Church to pray for his ≈øoule, and ≈øhould not bee taken for a Deodand, and note that every Deodand the Sherife ≈øhall an≈øwer, viz. he ≈øhall be charged to levy the price thereof of the village, notwith≈øtanding the thing was not delivered to them to keep before, quod miruÃÑ ut patet ibid. pag. 298. It is requi≈øite that the thing that is killed be in rerum natura; And therefore if a man doe kill an infant in the mothers belly, that is not felony, nor he ≈ø hall not forfeit any thing for it, and that for two cau≈øes; one is, for that the thing that is killed had not the name of bapti≈øme, the other is, for that it is hard and difficult to judge whether he killed it or no: That is to ≈øay, whether the infant dyed of the beating of the mother, or by any other occa≈øion, ut patet titulo Corone, &c. pag. 263. & vid there pag. 146. A man did beate a woman great with child of two children, ≈øo that immediately one of the in≈øants dyed, and the other was borne alive and bapti≈øed by a name, and two dayes after, for the hurt that ≈øhe had received ≈øhe dyed, the opinion was as before, that it was not felony in the man, & vide the ≈øame ca≈øe in Fitz. titulo Judictments. pag. 4 But it ≈øeemeth that the rea≈øon where it hath no name of bapti≈øme, is not of any force, for ye may ≈øee titulo Corone before pag. 418. that it was pre≈øented, A certaine woman going toward the Chappel, brought forth a ≈øon, and pre≈øently cut his throate and ca≈øt him into the pond and fled, therefore

It is a common erudition among≈øt us, That if a Statute Law give a remedy for any offence, we may under≈øtand thereby, that before there was no remedy for the ≈øame offence at the Common Law, other then is not expre≈ø≈ø ed in the ≈øaid Stat. except we have read any thing that may induce us to beleeve the contrary. The Statute of We≈øtmin≈øter the fir ≈øt, cap.13. defendeth Rape in this manner, viz. The keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament defendeth that none ≈øhall ravi≈ø h nor take by force a maide within the age of eleven yeares with her con≈øent, or without her con≈øent, nor any dame or maide of age, nor other woman again≈øt their wils, and if any ≈ø o doe, the Keepers of the Liberty of Engl. afore≈øaid ≈øhall doe him common right, and if none commence the ≈øuit within 40. dayes, then the Keepers of the Liberty of England may ≈ø ue, and tho≈øe that ≈øhall be found culpable ≈øhall have two yeares impri≈ø onment, and afterwards ≈øhall be arraigned at the Keepers of the Liberty of England afore≈ø aid plea≈øure, & if he be not araigned, he ≈øhal be puni≈ø hed by more longer impri≈øonment, according to the quality of the tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe. The Readers of this Stat. if they have not read Glanvill & Bracton do think that by the common Law Law Rape was but tre≈øpa≈øs, where in truth it was ≈øelony, or other more grievous crime, & fir≈øt Bracton in his 2.
book of Rape ≈øaith in this manner, Rape of ∆≤irgins is a certaine crime which a woman layes upon any, by whom ≈øhe ≈øhe ≈øayes ≈øhe was violently oppre≈ø≈øed again≈øt the peace, and which offence if it bee convicted, puni≈øhment followes, to wit, lo≈ø≈øe of Members, that there may be member for member, when the Virgin is deflowred ≈øhe loo≈øes a member, hee that deflowred her ≈øhall be puni ≈øhed in the part offending. Here I have expounded that which was the common Law in Rape before the Statute of We≈ø tm. 1. wherewith Glanvill agreeth, fol. 113. Al ≈øo I finde among≈øt the Lawes of St. Edwin, once King of this weale publique, this Law, If any man has to doe with a Nune, let him bee puni≈øhed as a Homicide.By the which it appeareth, that he which hath committed but fornication with a Nun, or with a holy woman, he ≈øhould be puni≈øhed as a Homicide, A multo forciori, then ≈ø hould he be puni≈øhed if hee had ravi≈ø hed. So that Rape at the beginning was much dete≈øted, and abhorred, and very great and greivous puni≈øhment adjoyned thereunto, till the time of King Edward 1. who ≈ø eemeth by his law made at We≈øt ‚Ä¢ . 1. to have mitigated the paine of the ≈øame, and afterward e≈øpying the great enormities that en≈øued the ≈øame Law; At his next Parliament holden at We≈øtmin≈øter, called We≈øtm. 2. cap. 34. did make the ≈øame offence of Rape to be felony: The words of which Statute be the≈øe; It is enacted, that if a man doth ravi≈øh a woman e≈øpou≈øed, a damo≈øell, or any other woman hereafter, whereunto ≈ø he neither hath a≈ø≈øented before nor after, he ≈øhall have judgement of life and members. And in like manner, where a man ≈øhall ravi≈øh a woman, dame e≈øpou≈øed, damo≈øell, or any other woman by force, although ≈øhe a≈ø≈øent to the ≈øame afterwards, hee ≈øhall have the like judgement as before is ≈øaid, ≈øo that he be attainted at the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament ≈øuit, and in that ca≈øe the keepers of the Liberty of England afore ≈øaid ≈øhall have their ≈øuite.

The Statute maketh no definition of rape, but leaveth the ≈øame to the common Law. Al ≈øo it ≈øeemeth to make a difference between ravi≈øhment with force, and ravi≈øhment
without force, And therefore quaere what manner of fact he intendeth, Britton≈øaith, fol. 45. that if a woman at the time of the Rape conceiveth with childe by the Ravi≈øher, that it is no Rape, for that, that no woman can conceive if ≈øhe a≈ø≈øent not thereunto. Al≈øo Bracton ≈øaith, That it is a good plea in an Appeale of Rape, to ≈øay, that before the time of the Ravi≈ø hment ≈øuppo≈øed to be done, he held and u≈øed the Plaintife as his Concubine; Al≈øo it is a good Plea for him to ≈øay, that though he did lye with her, yet he knew her not carnally, for that is the force of a declaration in an Appeale of Rape. And al≈øo note, that if a man bee to bee charged with Rape by way of Indictment, or otherwi≈øe, he ought to bee charged expre≈øly by this word Rapuit, and not by any other words, though they amount to as much as this word Rapuit doth, ut puta carnaliter cognovit & hujufmodi, as it appeareth 19.E. 4. fol. 27. Al≈øo there is another Statute concerning Rape, made an 6. E. 2. the which doth put great penalties and forfeitures upon the woman which con≈ø enteth to the Ravi≈øher after the Ravi≈øhment, and yet neverthele≈ø≈øe doth give an Appeale of Rape to the Husband of the wife that is ravi≈øhed, and if ≈øhe have no husband, then to her father or to her next of her blood, and that the def. ≈øhall not gage battell in ≈ø uch appeales.

Of trea≈øure trove. Bracton≈øaith of Trea≈øure found in this manner, There is among≈øt the re ≈øt a grievous Mi≈øpri≈øion again≈øt the K. which is as the crime of Theft, ≈øc. fraudulent hiding found Trea≈øure, &c. Et ibidem eodem titulo pag. 446. It appeares Trea≈øure belongs not to the King, but when it is not knowne who hid it. So that if it be knowne to whom the property

Of a Mayhem.Note, that Britton ≈øaith, that Mayhem is properly ≈øayd where any member of a man is taken away, whereby he is the more unable to fight, as if the eye, the hand, the foot, or by brui≈øing of the head, or knocking out of the foreteeth, but cutting off the eare or no≈øe is no Mayhem but a blemi≈øh of the body. Item 8. H. 4. ye may ≈øee there that it is no Mayhem to cut off, the eare of a man, by the which he lo≈øeth his hearing, but the knocking out of the teeth is a Mayhem, for that with them he may defend him≈øelfe in battell. Note that the≈øe places and territories here expre≈ø≈øed and declared, are allowed for Sanctuaryes for Felons, if they can get to them before they be taken, viz. Wells in the County of Somer≈ø et, We≈øtmin≈øter, Manche≈øter, Northampton, Norwich, Yorke, Darby, and Launce≈øton, for all ≈øuch Felons as may have the benefit of their Clergy by the Laws of this Weale publique, & for none el≈øe; For Trea≈øons, Rapes, Burglaries, Robberies by the high way, or in a hou≈øe where any are put in feare: burning
of hou≈øes or barnes wherein corne is layd: robberies of Churches, Chappels, or other hallowed places: ≈øtealing of Hor≈øes, or Mares, and Murder, with their abbettors, procurers, and coun≈øellors: All the≈øe offences are excepted by the Statute of 26 H. 8. cap. 13. & 32. cap. 11. H. 6.

Of principall and acce≈øiarie.Note, that in high Trea≈øon there is no acce≈ø≈øary, but all are principals ut pat. 3 H. 7. fol. 9. So that what offence ≈ø oever maketh a man acce≈ø≈øary in Felony, the ≈øame offence in high Trea≈ø on maketh him principall, therefore it is to be ≈øeen who ≈øhall be acce≈ø≈øaries in petty Trea≈øon, or Felony, or in other like crimes, in which acce≈ø≈øaries may be.

Of acce≈øsaries before the offence committed.Note, that if one procure or command another to do a Felony, but is not pre≈øent there when the other doth the ≈øame: This procurer or commander is but Acce≈ø≈øary before the Felony done, ut patet 7 H. 4. fol. 30. but otherwi≈øe it is if he be pre≈øent at the time and place, when and where the Felony is committed, for in that ca ≈øe he is a principall, ut pat. 7. H. 4. f. 13.

The ≈øame Law is, if a man bee pre≈øent at the death of a man, and hee moveth and ≈øetteth on others to wound him and kill him, in this ca≈øe hee is as farre forth a principall as he that killed him, quod vide 13. H. 7.

The ≈øame Law is, if hee were pre≈øent, and commeth ‚Ä¢ hither for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, though that at the ≈øame time he moveth not the other to ≈øtrike him, or kill him, nor doth any thing him≈øelfe, yet he ≈øhall be adiudged as a principall, ut pat. 21. Ed. 4. Al≈øo vide tit. Co
‚Ä¢ on. in Fitz. fol. 309. where it was found that one that was pre≈øent, yet did nothing, but would have ayded his companion, if the dead per≈øon had made any re≈øi≈øtance, and for that hee was adjudged a principall. And according to this vide ibidem pag.314.350. & 433. That all tho≈øe that come in company in any place, or any a≈ø≈ø embly where any evill is done, bee it homicide, robbery, or any other tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe, they ≈øhall all bee accounted as
principall doers, though that they doe no hurt at all. And therfore a man was condemned in that he was a di≈ø≈øei≈øor where a man was killed, and it was ≈øaid by twelve that he came not thither to doe any evill. And note, that as it was of homicide, or murder, even ≈øo it is of any other felony, as of rape or robbery, qnod vide titulo Coron in Fitzh. 228. & 11 H. 4. where in an appeale of Rape again≈øt two as principalls, whereas one did not the act, but a≈ø≈øi≈øted and ayded his companion to doe the ≈øame, & titulo Coron in Fitzh. fol. 350. & 324. where onely one did the robbery, and the other were in his company, and came with him for the ≈øame purpo≈øe, &c. But if one doe chance to be pre≈øent when another is ≈ølaine, or when another felony is committed, and commeth not in the Company of the felons, nor is of their confederacy, although he with≈øtand not, or di≈øturbeth not the ≈øelon, nor levyeth hue and cry, yet hee ≈øhall not be ≈øaid either principall or acce≈ø≈øary: for it is not felony in him but finable as a tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe. And if ≈øuch a man bee within age, he ≈øhall have no puni≈øhment, quod vide titulo Coron 395 & 14. H. 7. f. 33. & vide titulo praed. 293. where ≈øuch a man that was of full age, was but amerced in ≈øuch a ca≈øe, &c. Tamen 314. ibid, it appeareth that ≈øuch ≈ø ufferance is felony, & ≈øo was the opinion of Shard 197 but it is again ≈øt the law, as it appeareth in the books before cited, &c.

Al≈øo if A. hold B. in his armes till ≈øuch time as C. killeth him. A. for that cau≈øe is principall ut pat. 15. E. 3. And note ye, that the law at this day as concerning acce≈ø≈øaries, is as you have heard before, though that in ancient time ≈ø ome judges did varie in their opinions for Law, in that point: for it appeareth, tit. Corone in Fitz. 90.216. That in the 40. yeare of Edward the third, they tooke the Law to be, That he that was pre≈øent when any was ≈ølaine, and aiding and commanding the Killer, ≈ø hould not be principall, but acce≈ø≈øary, &c. and in that they did agree with Bracton, who ≈øaith in this manner, viz. If tho≈øe that were pre≈øent joyned in the force and fact, &c. And after the attainder of the principall fact, he goeth to tho≈øe
that be appealed of ≈øorce, and maketh the appeale in this manner, viz. A. appeales B. of force, that when the ≈øaid A. and C. his brother were in ≈ø uch a place, &c. Al≈øo hee ≈øaith in another place. That if two bee appealed as Acce≈ø≈øories to a third per≈øon, ≈øcilicet, one of force, and the other of commandement, they ≈øhall wage battell, before he ≈øhall that is appealed of commandement, force in a manner comprehends the fact which commands not. And ≈øo by him that is pre≈øent when one is killed, and being coun≈øelling, aiding, or in any other manner a≈ø≈øi≈øting, ≈øo that he ≈ølayeth him not him≈øelfe, he is then but acce≈ø≈øory, &c. And with him agreeth the Statutes called Officium Coron, made the third year of King Ed.the fir≈øt at We≈øt. 2. but the Law is not ≈øo at this day; and yet the account in every appeale again≈øt the principall is, that every one principally did helpe, and did ≈øtrike the parry ≈ølaine, deadly; but to that may be ≈øaid, That tho≈øe words bee but words of forme, and al≈øo it is his helpe in Law, &c. If I command one to take another, and he goeth from me, and taketh him and robbeth him: If I be ab ≈øent when he doth the ≈ø ame, that is not ≈øelony in me, ut pate tit. Coron in Fitzh. for that he exceedeth my commandement, and my commandement might have beene performed without Robberie, &c.

But if I command one to beate another, and thereupon hee beateth him to death, that ≈ø hall bee Felony in me that commandeth, ut pat. ibidem 314. for it is difficult and hard to beate a man in ≈øuch ≈øort, that it ≈øhall be ≈øayd hee ≈øhall not dye of ≈øuch beating, &c. therefore in ≈øuch ca≈øe I am acce≈ø≈øory to him that killeth him, by rea≈øon that it was done upon my commandement, &c.

Acce≈ø≈øories after the offence committed.That is, where one receiveth a Felon, well knowing of the Felony that he hath committed, or favoureth him, or by aideth him, hee there ≈øhall be ≈ø ayd to be an Acce≈ø≈øory after the fact. But di≈ø tinguend. e≈øt, of this ayde or councell; for if he ayde him with his good word, and ≈øueth for his delivery, or ≈øendeth Letters for his deliverance, that maketh him not to bee acce≈ø≈øory to the Felony: ut
patet titulo Corone in Fitzh. pag. 195. &c.Nay, this definition is to be made of an Acce≈ø≈øory, it extendeth onely to tho≈øe that be Acce≈ø≈øories to a principall atteinted; for if after the atteinder one receiveth and aydeth him, That is, after he be convicted of the Felony by verdict, outlawry, or confe≈ø≈øion, he ≈ø eemeth to be an Acce≈ø≈øory, though that he knew him not to be a Felon, in that hee is a Felon by matter of Record, of the which every ≈øtranger is driven to take Cogni≈øance, tamen quaere; for yee ≈øhall finde titulo praed. pag. 377. one note, which is thus, ≈øcilicet, Note ye, That when a man is indicted for the receiving a man outlawed for Felony in the ≈øame county, then he ≈øhall lo≈øe both life and members, Secus e≈øset in alio com &c. Ergo thereof en≈øueth, That if one be outlawed for Felony in one Countie, and another receiveth him in another County, he ≈ø hall not be Acce≈ø |≈øory, for that he cannot take Cogni≈øance of that which was done in another County, though that it bee matter of Record, &c, And agreeable to this note, I finde in Bracton written thus, If any man ≈ø hall give meate to ≈øuch one after Outlawry, ≈øhall entertaine or receive him, nay but hide him, he ≈øhall be puni≈øhed in the manner the Outlaw ≈øhould. So that it ≈øeemeth he maketh no difference betweene matter in fact and matter of record, &c. in that he maketh Scientermateriall in the ca≈øe, &c. And note yee, that by the common-Law, if one commit Felony in one County, and before his atteinder one other receiveth him feloniou≈øly in another County, that was not felony in the receiver for default of tryall, in that tho≈øe of the County where the Acce≈ø≈øory offended, could not have Cogni≈øance of the principall offence committed in another County, quod vide titul Corone pag. 33. & 43 Ed. 3. wherefore a Statute Law was made annis 2, & 3. Ed. 6. which is in this manner: Fora≈ømuch as the mo ≈øt nece≈øsary office and duty of Lawes, is to pre≈øerve the life of man, and condignely to puni≈øh ≈øuch per≈øons that unlawfully and wilfully murder, ≈ølay, and de≈øtroy men, &c: Note the preamble of this Statute.
And al≈øo it is a common practi≈øe among≈øt arrant Theeves and Robbers in this Commonwealth, that after they have robbed and ≈øtolne in one county, they will convey their ≈øpoyle, and part thereof ≈øo ≈ø tolne, to ≈øome of their adherents in another County, where the principall offence was not committed, nor done, &c. By this preamble it appeareth, That if one feloniou≈øly received parcell of the Goods ≈øtolne, that he ≈øhall thereby be an acce≈ø≈øory, &c. quaer. thereof; for yee ≈øhall finde titulo Coron. in Fitzh. pag. 126. That one ≈øhall not be Acce≈ø ≈øory for receiving of goods ≈øtolne only, if he receive not the Felon him≈øelfe al≈øo. And therefore the Indictment was there, That knowing and ≈øeloniou≈øly received the Theefe, &c. and he was di≈øcharged thereof ratione jam dict. But if he had as well received the Felon him≈ø elfe, as the goods, then otherwi≈øe it were, ut patet 9 H. 4. fol. 1. & tit. Coron. in Fitzh. pag. 427. where a Felon did flye to his brothert hou≈øe, and his brother did ≈øhut the doore, and the Country that pur≈øued him were deceived thereby „Äà‚óä„Äâ for they did conjecture that hee had continued in the hou≈øe, when he did flye thence to the Church; whereupon his brother was adjudged acce≈ø≈øory to that Felony, &c. ut pat. ibidem pag. 196. That a man may be an Acce≈ø≈øory to an Acce≈ø≈øorie: As if a man feloniou≈ø ly do receive him that is an Acce≈ø≈øory to a Felon, &c. Al≈øo it appeareth there pag 48. That hee that receiveth an acce≈ø≈ø ory of a Felony, is principall, and not acce≈ø≈øorv, &c. And the rea≈øon thereof as I under≈øtand, is, for that by this receite a new Felony is committed by him, though that it dependeth upon the ancient and former Felony, &c. And note ye, that Bracton counteth an Acce≈ø≈øory, a receiver of bad men, &c. ut ≈øupra c. 19. fol. 26. and ≈øaith, that a woman cannot bee acce ≈ø≈øory to her husband.

Acce≈ø≈ø ories by ≈øtatute.I have already intreated of Acce≈ø≈øories by the Common Law, now therefore I will entreat of Acce≈ø≈øories by the Statute-Law. It ≈øeemeth though an offence bee
made Felony by Statute, though the ≈øame Statute doth not ≈øpeake exprefly of abettors, procurors, coun≈øellours, and receivers, yet it be ≈øhal taken to be within the compa≈øse of that Statute, as it appeareth in the Title of Trea≈øon, 19. H. 6. where the con≈øenter and ayder to the counterfeiting of the great Seale, or the Commonwealths money, was adjudged a Traitor: And yet the words of the Statute are, if a man doe counterfeite, &c. the which thing the other ≈øeemeth not to have done, in that hee ‚Ä¢ as not but con ≈øenting and ayding to the ≈øame, &c. The ≈øame Law is in ca≈øe of Rape, where one did the fact, and another a≈ø≈øi≈ø ted him, and ayded him to commit the Rape, he thereby is a Ravi≈øher as far forth as his companion which did the Rape indeed, as it appeareth 11 H. 4. & tit. Coron. in Fitzh. pag. 120. And yet notwith≈øtanding the words of the Statute of We≈øtm. 2. cap. 3.4. are, If a man ravi≈øh a woman, &c. but that was the cau≈øe of the Rape, without which perhaps the Rape had not been committed: and pincipall doer, in that hee was pre≈øent when the fact was done, and therefore as well culpable of the fact as the principall doer is. And if any be acquitted of a principall fact, hee is then acquitted of all offences as acce≈ø≈øory before the principall fact committed, but not of offences perpetrated as Acce≈ø≈øory after the principall fact done, as it ≈øhall appear after: And therefore ≈øome will argue in this ca≈øe, as though that Acce≈ø≈øories before the offence committed, be taken to bee within the compa≈ø≈øe of a Statute that maketh Felony, though they be not expre≈ø ≈øed, for the rea ≈øon before made: yet notwith≈øtanding that proveth not, that acce≈ø≈øory after the offence perpetrated, ≈øhould be within the compa≈ø≈øe of ≈øuch a Statute if it be not expre≈ø≈øed. But how≈ø oever it be, tho≈øe of the Parliament in the time of King H. 8. provided for the ≈øame, as it appeareth as well by the Statute of Hunting, anno 32. H. 8. as by other Statutes which at this in≈øtant are not in force. And by a Statute made in the fir≈øt and ≈øecond yeare of P. & M. again≈øt unlawfull and rebellious a≈ø≈ø emblies,
which Statute is yet in force. And by a-Statute made 1. M. concerning Egyptians as yet al≈øo being in force. The which Statute providech as well for Acce ≈ø≈øories before the offence perpetrated as after, vide the Statute of 3. H. 7. of tho≈øe that take maides, widdowes, or wives again≈øt their wills, where the words are, that ≈øuch taking, procuring, and abetting to the ≈øame, and al≈øo receiving wittingly the ≈øayd woman ≈øo taken again≈øt her will, and knowing the ≈øame, is Felony: And that ≈øuch mi≈ødoers, takers. procurers, and receivers to the ≈øame, knowing the ≈øayd offence in forme afore≈ø ayd, hee henceforth reputed and judged as principall Felons. Note, as it ≈ø eemeth there is no Acce≈øsory in this offence upon the Statute, in that by the words they be reputed and judged as principall Felons, which maketh them as it ≈øeemeth all principals, &c.
Note, that in an appeale of Mayhem, the Plaintife may chu≈øe to make every of them principals, or him onely that did hurt him, to be principall, and the others Acce≈ø sories, ut patet 215.221. & 199.

How the principal ≈øhall fir≈øt be attainted, and after the acce≈ø≈øories.There are three ≈ø orts of attainders, viz. by confe≈ø≈øions by verdict, and default or outlawry, and in all the≈øe ca≈øe the principall ought to be attainted before the Acce≈ø≈øory: but in the manner of proceeding to this attaint, there are diver≈øities of opinions; for Bracton ≈øaith upon the attainder by proce≈øs in this manner, the cau≈øes of Outlawry may bee many, &c. So that it appeareth, that at that time there was diver≈øities of opinions about the manner of atteinder of Acce≈øsories by Outlawry, which diver≈øity was taken away by the Stat. of We≈øtmin≈øter the fir≈øt, the which is thus, viz. And for that, that men have u≈øed in ≈øome countries to Outlaw the people appealed of commandement, force, ayde, and receiptment within the ≈øame terme, in which a man ≈øhould Outlaw him that is appealed of the fact as principall. It is provided and commanded, That none be Outlawed for appeale of commandement, force, ayde, or receiptment, untill he that is appealed of the fact bee attainted: ≈øo that one
onely Law thereof be throughout the whole Land, &c. But hee that will appeale, ≈øhould not therefore cea≈øe to continue his appeale at the next County again≈øt tho≈øe, as well as again≈øt the Appellees of the fact, but the Exigent again≈øt them ≈øhall ≈øtay untill ≈ø uch time as the Appellees of the fact bee attainted by Outlawry or otherwi≈øe.
