This Statute is not to bee under≈øtood of Appeales commenced by Bill: for Appeales commenced by Writ, there appeareth not any to bee Acce≈ø≈øary till ≈ø uch time as the count bee made, the which is not made, till ≈øuch time as there bee al≈øo appearance for the Acce≈øsory, ut patet 43. Edw. 3. fol. 15. wherefore in that ca≈øe where an Appeale is commenced by Writ, if the Plaintife will pray the Exigent again≈øt all, he is thereby concluded to count after, again≈øt any one of them as Acce≈øsory, for if otherwi≈øe, &c. hee ≈ø hould not have the Exigent again≈øt all them untill the principall had been outlawed, for in that ca≈øe he is concluded, ut patet tit. Coron. in Fitz. pag. 80. This Statute willeth that the appellee of the fact be attainted before the Acce≈øsory ≈øhall be Outlawed: Admit then, that at the time when the Acce≈øsory is at the Exigent, the principal appeareth, if then the Exigent ≈øhall be awarded again≈øt the Acce≈øsory, till that the Proce ≈øs again≈øt the principall be determined, &c. It ≈øeemeth not, for notwith≈øtanding that the Proce≈øs be determined, yet the principall is not attainted; and untill ≈øuch time as he be attainted, the Acce≈ø≈øory ought not to be Outlawed, ut ≈øupra 7. H. 4. fol. 31. That which is ≈øayd, extendeth to that where the Acce≈øsory doth not appeare but maketh default: Wherefore now let us ≈øee what ≈øhall be done when the Acce≈øsory appeareth in judgement, and the Principall al≈øo, and in re≈øpect thereof, note you that by the ancient Law, the Acce ≈øsory ≈øhould not be put to an≈øwer, till ≈øuch time as the principall had been attainted, ut patet per Bracton, If all be pre≈øent, tho≈øe as well of force as of fact, the proceeding mu≈øt bee again≈øt all in order, but tho≈øe of force are not, to an≈øwer till the fact
be convinced, &c. And agreeable unto him is the booke of 44. Edw. 3. fol. 9. & tit. Coron. in Fitz.216. but ≈øince that time the Law hath been changed, &c. For now, be it that the principall appeare, or make default, the Acce≈ø≈øory, if he appeare, ≈øhall an≈øwer, but if hee plead to an i≈ø≈øue, proce≈øse ≈øhall cea≈øe to bee awarded again≈øt him for his tryall, untill the principall doe appeare, or or be attainted of Outlawry, ut pat. & 9. H. 4. & 7. H. 4. but yet tho≈øe Proce≈øs again≈øt the Jury ≈øhall not cea≈øe, unle≈øs the Acce≈ø≈øory will, for if the Acce≈øsory will pray Proce ≈øs again≈øt the Inque≈øt, before the principall be attainted, hee ≈øhall have them, in that it is domage to none but him≈øelfe. And whether he be attainted or acquitted, it is good, and he ≈øhall not be againe arraigned for that offence; for the taking of the Inque≈øt or verdict is not erroneous for the rea≈øon before made, ut patet titulo Coron. 463. The ≈øame Law is if the Acce≈øsory will wage his battell with the appellant before the Principall doth come, ut patet ibidem pag. 8. for he may waive the benefit that the Law doth give him therein, &c.

Note ye that if the plea which the Acce≈ø≈øory doth pleade, be a plea in abatement of the whole writ, the principall therein ≈øhall have the advantage, notwith≈ø tanding his ab≈øence, ≈øo that the Exigent that is to bee awarded again≈øt the principall ≈øhall ≈øtay till it be known whether the whole writ ≈øhall abate or not, ut patet 9 H. 4. but if they both doe appeare, viz. the principal and the acce≈øsory, then the principall mu≈øt fir≈øt an≈øwer, and after the acce≈øsory, for ≈øuch an≈øwer the principall may make, that the acce≈øsory ≈øhall not bee put to an≈øwer till the an≈øwer of the principall bee tried. And that is where the principall doth not pleade directly to the felony, but ≈øome other plea; As if he plead that he was once before attainted of the ≈øame Felony, and the appellant to the contrary that is not ≈øo, and ≈øo they are at i≈øsue, in this ca≈øe the Acce≈øsory ≈øhall not an≈øwer before that i≈ø sue be tryed, 9 H. 7. Quaere if the like Law bee where the principall pleadeth in abatement of the whole writ,
&c. But if the Principall pleade to the Felony, the Acce≈ø≈øory then pre≈øently after ≈øuch plea ≈ø hall pleade al≈øo: And if they be at i≈ø≈øue, a venire fac may bee awarded again≈øt them all, ut patet tit. Coron. where Forte≈øcue≈øaith, that if at the day in the Court the principal maketh default, the Inque≈øt ≈øhall not be taken for the acce≈ø≈øory, but that the Inque≈øt ≈øhall goe without day, and the principals, manucaptors or ≈øureties, ≈øhall make their fine, &c. And that agreeth with that which was ≈øayd before, ≈ø cilicet, that the Inque≈øt ≈øhall ≈øtay for the Acce≈ø≈øary till ≈øuch time as the principall commeth to bee attainted by outlawry, &c. Note, when I ≈ø peake of the principall, I meane then all the principals; for if there be divers ≈øued as principalls, and ≈ø ome of them doe come, and ≈øome doe not, yet the Inque≈øt ≈øhall ≈øtay untill all the principals doe come, or bee attainted of Outlawry, if it bee ≈øo that hee bee appealed or indicted as acce≈ø≈ø ory unto them all: otherwi≈øe it is if hee not appealed or indicted as acce≈ø≈øory to one of them; for there it ≈øufficieth tho≈øe principals onely to come, or to bee attainted for whom hee is appealed or indicted as acce≈ø≈øory, without having regard to the re≈øidue, quod vid. 7. H. 4. fol. 30. & tit. Coron. in Fitzh. 216. Al≈øo note yee, that it is requi≈øite that this attainder of the principall be in the ≈øame ≈øuite in which the acce≈ø≈øaryes be ≈øued, for if it bee in another ≈øuite, that will not permit the Acce≈øsorie to proceed in his Inque≈øt till ≈ø uch time as the principall that is ≈øued with him doe come in, or be attainted by Proce≈øs as afore≈øayd. And in an appeale of death, again≈øt the principall and the acce≈ø≈øory, the principall before that time is attainted of the very ≈øame death, upon an Indictment at the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament ≈øuite, ut patet 7.H.4. fol. 30. Quaere, if the acce≈ø≈ø ory ≈øhall pleade for his di≈øcharge the acquittall of the principall in another ≈øuite, ut patet 277. Al≈øo it ≈øeemeth, that if the principall ≈øince that attainder is dead, and the Ju≈øtices before whom ≈øuch Acce≈ø≈øory is ≈øued, have before them the record of the attainder, that then they
may proceed again≈øt the Acce≈øsory, otherwi≈øe not, 7. H. 4. fol. 23. Wee have ≈øayd before that the Inque ≈øt ≈øhall not proceed again≈øt the Acce≈ø≈øory, till ≈øuch time as the principall doe come in, or be attainted, &c. Admit then that the principall doth come in, and will ≈øay nothing, but ≈øtand mute; What ≈ø hall in that ca≈øe bee done with the acce≈ø≈øory? Hu≈ø≈øey ≈ø aith, 3. H. 7. That, that notwith≈øtanding, the Acce≈øsory ≈ø hall be arraigned, quod vide titulo Corone 36. & 51. where the principall challengeth above the number of 36. which was peremptory to him, therefore hee was hanged without farther triall, becau≈øe he ≈øhould challenge but ju≈ø t 36. or under, and not above, and in that ca≈øe the acce≈ø≈øory was tried and found guilty; and the ju≈øtices did advi≈øe with them≈øelves, what ≈øhould be done in that ca≈øe, for they were of divers opinions, &c. This attainder whereof wee have ≈øo often ≈øpoken, though that it be erronious, yet not with≈øtanding that court ≈øhall proceede with the acce ≈ø≈øory, for the acce≈ø≈øory ≈øhall utterly take advantage of that error, quod vide anno 2 R. 3. f. 21. Al≈ø o there is one ca≈øe, that although the principal be not attainted, yet the Acce≈ø≈øory ≈ø hal be hanged, As if one Abjure as Acce≈ø≈øorie, and afterward the Principall cometh, not being attainted, Tamen-the Ju≈øtices in favore vitae, did inquire if the Acce≈ø≈øorie was attainted or not. The ≈øame law ≈øhall be in the ca≈øes above≈øaid, as it ≈øeemeth where the Acce≈ø≈øory of his own good will will wage battaile, or have the inque≈øt proceed before the Principall doth come, &c.

Whether the acquitall of the principall di≈øcharge the acce≈ø ≈øory, or not.Note, That if the principall be acquitted, the Acce≈ø≈øory, is thereby di≈øcharged, for Bracton ≈øaith, where no fact was, no force, no command ought to hurt, where the wrong had no effect, &c. Wherefore it is clear, that the acquital of the principal, is al≈øo the acquitall of the Acce≈ø≈øory, or if it happen that the principall cannot bee tried, as if hee dye in pri≈øon before hee be attainted, thereby the Acce≈ø≈øory is di≈øcharged, otherwi≈ø e it is if he die after the Attainder, &c. The ≈øame law is, if before the principall be attainted of the felonie, he is attainted of another
felony and hanged, the acce≈ø≈øory hereby is di≈øcharged,ut patet tit Coron in Fitz. 378. The ≈ø ame law is though he be not hanged after the attainder, in that ca≈øe he ≈øhall an≈ø wer to any other felony, unle≈ø≈øe it be robbery or Trea≈øon. The ≈øame Law is, if it be found that the principall killed him ≈øe defendendo, the acce≈ø≈ø ory is thereby di≈øcharged, ut patet 116. Et tamen there the principall purcha≈øeth his Pardon, &c. But that Pardon argueth not that hee is culpable in any other manner than ≈øe defendende. But of other pardons otherwi≈øe it is, for if the principall doth pleade his pardon to a felony generally, without any ≈øpeciall matter found, the which ≈øhould cau≈øe the pardon, and is thereby di≈øcharged, yet that ≈øhall not di≈øcharge the Acce≈ø≈øory, but hee ≈øhall bee found guilty of the felony, ut pat. tit. pred. 260. for by ≈øuch a pardon the felony is confe≈ø≈øed, of which felony he prayeth to be di≈øcharged ex gratia Cu≈øtod. Libertatis Angliae Authoritate Parliamenti, and not by cour ≈øe of the Law, as it was done in the other ca≈øe, Quaere tamen,for the contrary is agreed by way of argument, 3. H. 7 tit. pred. 53. And al≈øo by the opinion of Thyrn. 7. H. fol. 13. And this rea≈øon is, that when the life of the principall is given him by the law, in what manner ≈øoever it be, the felony is extinct in his per≈øon, & by con≈ø equence acquited.

And ≈øo it ≈øhall be where the principall taketh him to be his Clergie. And with this ca≈øe agreeth the booke of 3. H. 7. fol. 2. tamen Fitz. tit praed. 53. hath reported that booke of 3. H. 7. to the contrary, ≈øc. that not with≈ø tanding that the principall ≈øhall have his Clergy, yet the acce≈ø≈øory ≈øhall be hanged. And according to that ye ≈øhall finde ibi. 270. & 266. Sed di ≈øtinguendum e≈øt, of the ca≈ø e of the Clergy, ≈øc. whether he be Clerke convict, or clerke attaint, for if he be clerke attaint, by the ancient Books the Acce≈ø≈øory ≈øhall be hanged, for that the principall in that ca≈øe cannot at any time make his purgation, and otherwi≈øe perchance, if hee were Clerke convict, in that the Clerke convict may make his purgation, wherefore in that ca≈øe they did u≈øe to let acce≈ø≈øories to mainepri≈øe,
untill ≈øuch time as the principall had made his purgation, &c. ut patet tit. Coron. 145, 176, 252, 376, 193, & 7. H. 4. fol.13.& 13. Ed. 4. fol. 3. and then upon his purgation to di≈ø charge the Acce≈ø≈øory, and if he died or e≈øcaped before purgation, &c. then to proceed to the attainder of the Acce≈ø≈øory, &c. Quaere if the difference will hold place at this day in that, in the new books before they have expugnancy of opinion in the ca≈øe where purgation is to be done, That is to ≈øay, in the ca≈øe of a Clerke convict, for ≈øome would in that ca≈øe that the acce≈øsory ≈ø hould be di≈øcharged, and ≈øome would not. So that in that ca≈øe of the Clergy, and of the pardon, the new bookes and the old agree not.

Note where it is ≈øaid before, that the Acquittall of the Principall, is al ≈øo the acquittall of the Acce≈øsory, That is to be under≈øtood, if it be not in an appeale when the acce≈ø≈øory is to recover damages, for if hee will recover damages, hee ought to bee tryed notwith≈øtanding the acquittall of the principall, ut patet in Fitzh. pag.223. Quaere if that be Law now, by u≈øe, for it ≈ø eemeth rea≈øonable that he ≈øhould have his damages upon the acquitall of the principall without being tryed, or otherwi≈øe ≈øhould en≈øue that the Court would admit an Acce≈ø ≈øory whereto then it appeareth that there is no principall, which ≈øhould be inconvenient; for as Bracton hath well ≈øaid, The Appealers cannot omitting the fir≈øt and principall Appellee, wage battell with the Appellees of force and command, &c. Quod nota. In my Lord Cookes 4. booke of Reports, fol.44. In an appeale brought by one Bibithes, Termino Pa≈øchae, anno 39 Eliz. It is there re≈øolved for Law, that although the principall was convicted by verdict, yet in≈ø omuch that he had his Clergy, his acce≈ø≈øories both before and after the Felony were di≈ø charged, and the ≈øame Law is there re≈øolved, if a principall upon his arraignment confe≈ø ≈øe the felony, and before judgement gets a pardon or hath his Clergy allowed him, the acce ≈ø≈øory thereupon is di≈ø charged. 2. E. 3.27.22. E. 3. tit. Coron. 260. 5. H. 4.16.19. H. 4.5.3. H. 7.1. & 3. H. 7. tit. Coron. 53.

div.head: An Appeale of Murder and Robbery.
div.p: South. A.G. viz. the late Wife of R.G. in proper per≈øon in≈øtantly appeales M. D. late ofN. in the County of S. Yeoman, and I.B. late of A. in the County afore≈øaid Yeoman, in the cu ≈øtody of T.P. Knight Sherife of the County afore ≈øayd, and to the barre brought in her owne per≈øon. of the death of the afore≈ø ayd R. lately her husband, of that, that where the ≈ø ame R.G. 28. day A. the yeare, &c. was in the peace of God, and the ≈øayd Commonwealth working and labouring in burning of Coales in the land of I.G. Knight, called S. in a certain place there called a Coale place, at C. in the county afore≈øayd, where there came the afore≈øayd M.D.and I.B. as Felons of the ≈øayd Commonwealth, and by a≈ø≈øault, and of malice forethought, the afore≈øayd R.G. of his goods and moneyes to robbe and ≈ø poyle, upon the ≈øame R.G. afore≈øaid, 28. day of A. and yeare,&c. afore≈øayd, about the ninth houre after noone of the ≈øame day, by force and armes, viz. with ≈øtaves, knives, &c. at C. afore≈øayd, in the place afore≈øayd, a≈ø≈øaults made, and the ≈øame R. G. then and there feloniou≈øly and wilfully ≈ølew, and murdered, and the ≈ø ame R. ≈øo ≈ølaine incontinently carryed away to a certaine wood called, &c. di≈øtant from the afore≈ø ayd place about 10. perches, in the pari≈øh of T. in the ≈øame county, and him there in a woody place of Oakes hid and ca≈øt downe, and his throate then and there cut again≈øt the peace publique, and as ≈øoon as the ≈øame Felons the Felony and Murder afore≈øayd had done, they fled, and the afore≈ø ayd A. then fre≈øhly pur≈øued from towne to towne, as farre as foure townes next and farther, untill &c. And if the afore≈øayd M.D. and I.B. the Felony and Murder afore≈øayd, in forme afore≈øayd done, will deny, then the afore≈øayd A. is ready the Felony and Murder afore≈øayd again≈øt them to prove, as the Court here, &c. and ≈øhe found pledges of pro ≈øec. of this Appeale, viz. I.W. & C.E. &c.

E.P. of H. in the County afore≈øayd Yeoman, in his own per≈øon, according to the forme of a Statute in the Parliament of the L. King R. late King of Engl. the ≈øecond after the Conque≈øt, at We≈øtmin≈øter the ≈øixt yeare of his reign held, made, in≈øtantly appeals I.B. lately of H. in pri≈øon,&c. of that, that where I. the Wife of the afore≈øayd E.P. was in the peace of God and the Commonw. now at H. in the County afore≈øaid, the afore≈øayd day, &c the yeare, &c. about the houre, &c. There came the afore≈øayd I.B. as a Felon of the Commonwealth. Now of treachery and a≈ø≈øault forethought again≈øt the peace of the publique, the day, year, houre, and place afore≈øaid, the afore≈øaid A. then and there feloniou≈øly ravished, and with her then and there carnally lay, and the ≈øoyd I. to the ≈øame I.B. after the rape afore≈øayd, in forme afore≈øaid done, viz. and the day and yeare, &c. as to the doing the ≈øaid rape con≈øented, and him for the ≈ø ame rape according to due forme of Law refu≈øed to puni≈øh, and as ≈ø oon, &c.

div.head: Appeale of Rape by the next a Kin.
div.p: VV.L. next of bloud to I. daughter and heire of T.L. now dead, viz. brother of the afore≈øaid T.L. father of the afore≈øaid I. feloniov ≈øly ravi≈øhed, in his proper per≈øon in≈øtantly appeales R.P. of K. in the county of S. Yeoman, and in the cu≈øtody, &c. according to the form of the Statute of the L.R. lately King of Engl. the ≈øecond after the Conque≈øt, the ≈øixt yeare of his reigne, held, made, of the rape of the afore≈øaide I. and of the peace of the Commonwealth, now broken, of that that where the ≈øaid I. was in the peace of God and the Commonwealth at M. in the county of E. the day, &c. the yeare, &c. about the houre, &c. there came the afore≈øaid R. as a Felon of the commonwealth, now by treachery and a≈ø≈øault fore thought, again≈øt the peace publique, the day, yeare, houre, and place a fore≈øaid, and the afore≈øaid I. feloniou≈øly ravi≈øhed again ≈øt the forme of the Statute afore≈øaid. And as ≈øoon, &c.

I A. in his proper per≈øon appeales R.L.of D. in the County of S. Yeoman, of that, that where I. A. was in the peace of the Commonwealth now at C. in the County afore≈øayd, the day, yeare, &c. about the eigth houre afternoone of the ≈øame day, where came the afore≈ø ayd R. feloniou≈øly as a Felon of the Commonwealth there by treachery and a≈ø≈øault forethought again≈øt the peace publique, the day, yeare, houre, and towne afore≈øayd, with a certaine arrow ≈øhot the afore≈øayd I.A. in the left knee, by which the veines and nerves were dryed up, and ≈ø o him feloniou≈øly he mayhemed, and as ≈øoon, &c. and if &c. the ≈øame I. this is ready again≈øt him to prove as the Court, &c.

D B. in his per≈øon in≈ø tantly appeales R.E. of cutting out the Tongue of him D. and the peace publique broken, for that, viz. that when by a certaine Statute in the Parliament of H. 4. lately King of England, the fifth yeare of his reigne, at We≈øtmin. held, made; It is ordained, that Malefactors who ≈øhall cut out the tongues, or pluck out the eyes of the people of the Commonwealth, this duely proved and found, that ≈øuch fact was done out of malice forethought, ≈øhall incurre the paine of Felony, as in the Statute afore≈øayd more fully is contained, and where the afore≈øayd D. was in the peace of God and the Commonwealth now at H. in the County afore≈øayd, the day and yeare, &c. about the houre, &c. there came the afore≈øayd R.E. feloniou≈øly as a Felon of the Commonwealth, by treachery and a≈ø≈øault forethought, again≈øt the peace publique, the day, yeare, houre, place, and county afore≈øaid, and with a certaine knife, which he held in his right hand, the tongue of him D. feloniou≈øly he cut out; and at ≈øoon, &c.

div.head: A Felon appeales and calls for the Coroner.
div.p:
MEmorand. that on Tue≈øday, &c. I. R. lately of L.&c. diver≈øe Felonies before the Keepers of the Liberties
of Engl. by authority of Parliament in the upper Bench at We≈øtm. acknowledges to have committed, requiring a Coroner of the Commonwealth for the good of the Commonwealth to be a ≈ø≈øigned him; and an Approver the ≈øaid R. became, upon which I I.W. Coroner of the Commonwealth was a≈ø≈øigned to him by the Court, to record tho≈øe things which the ≈øayd Approver would ≈øoy or acknowledge before me, and dayes were given to the ≈øame approver by the Court for his dayes of appeale, viz. Munday, Tue ≈øday, Wedne≈øday, then next following, and after, viz. on Munday afore≈øayd, before me the afore≈ø ‚Ä¢ yd Coroner, at W. came the approver under the cu≈ø tody of the Mar≈øh all of the Keepers of the Libertyes of England by authority of Parliament in his proper per≈øon and appealed T.C. lately of L. and H. lately of S. of that that the afore≈ø aid T.C. with the approver about the fir≈øt day of S. in the year, &c. at B. in the County of M. one peece of Silver to the value of 30≈ø. of the goods and chattels of A.B. feloniou≈øly ≈øtole, and the afore≈øayd H.R. knowing themT.C. and the approver ≈øo to have committed that Felony, then at B. the afore≈øaid fourth day then next following received, and the peece of ≈øilver afore ≈øaid, of them bought, &c.
Let the ≈øame manner be ob≈øerved in others alike.

Otherwi≈øe, viz. Thur≈øday next, &c. the year, &c. at O. I.B lately of H. Yeoman, before L. M. and his companions Ju≈øtices, &c. a≈ø≈øigned the peace in the County afore≈øayd to con≈øerve, was indicted of this, that he the day and yeare &c. (reciting the Indictment) again≈øt the peace publique, &c. being before the afore≈øaid Ju≈øtices asked How hee would acquit him≈øelfe of it? Acknowledged the Felony afore≈øayd, and an Approver of the commonwealth became, and reque≈øted a Coroner of the Commonwealth to bee a≈ø≈øigned unto him, upon which I I.W.one of the Coroners of the Commonwealth of the County afore≈øayd, was as≈øigned to heare and record tho≈øe things which for the good of the Commonwealth,
he would ≈øay, or before me acknowledge, and after, viz. ≈øuch a day, &c. ≈øayd before me the afore≈øaid Coroner at E.the afore≈øayd approver, that W.I. of L. in the County of L.Yeoman, and the ≈øame approver in the way publique betwixt W. and B. the di≈øtance of ten miles from B. afore≈øayd, the tenth day, &c.yeare, &c. upon a certaine I.B. a≈ø≈øault made, beate, and ill treated him, and ≈øix markes ≈øterling in ready money of the Goods and Chattels of his I. B. then and there found, feloniou≈øly tooke and robbed, whence the ≈øame approvor the afore≈øaid W.I. appeales.

THis you heare Sir Coroner that I B.C. am a Theefe of one hor≈øe, or ≈øomething el≈øe, or an homicide of one man or more; As a felon of the King, &c. And becau≈øe many mi ≈øchiefes and robberies I have committed, I abjure, &c. and I ought to ha ≈øte me to the Port from ≈øuch place as you have appointed me, nor ought I to divert to any other way, and if I doe, I will that I bee taken as a Theefe and Felon of the King, and that at ≈øuch a place I will ≈øeek diligently my pa ≈ø≈øage, and will not expect but one flow and ebbe, if I can pa≈ø≈øe, and if in ≈øuch ≈øpace I cannot goe over, I will goe every day into the ≈øea up to my knees, and trying to pa≈ø≈øe, and if I cannot doe this within forty dayes together, I will put my ≈ø elfe into the Church as a Theefe and Felon of the King. So help me God and his doome.

But it ≈øeemeth by the Statute of 22. Hen. 8. that this kind of Abjuration is taken away, and that it was the Kings plea≈øure that ≈øuch per≈øon which did abjure, ≈ø hould be abjured from all his ability, to ≈øome Sanctuary within this Realme there to continue during his life, and that hee ≈øhould bee burnt in the right hand with this letter A.to the end he might be knowne to bee an abjured per≈øon, and if after hee was taken abroad out of the Sanctuary, then hee ≈øhould undergoe ≈øuch puni≈øhment as per≈øons abjured did before the making of the ≈ø aid Statute: And if any Felon refu≈øe to abjure before
the Coroner, he ≈øhall lo≈øe the benefit of the Sanctuary by the Statute of 21. H. 8. c.2.

This heare you Sir Coroner, that I J.M. of H. in the county of S. am a Popi≈øh Recu≈øant and in contempt of the Lawes and Statutes of England, I have and doe refu≈øe to come to their Church, I doe therefore according to the intent and meaning of the Statute made in the 35 yeare of Queene Elizabeth late Queen of this Realm of England, abjure the Realme of England. And I ≈øhall ha≈øte mee towards the port of P. which you have given and a≈ø≈ø igned to me, and that I ≈øhall not goe out of the Highway leading thither, nor returne backe againe, and if I doe, I will that I bee taken as a Felon of the Commonwealth: And that at P. I will diligently ≈øeeke for pa≈ø≈øage, and I will tarry there but one flood and ebbe, if I can have pa≈ø≈øage, and unle≈øse I can have it in ≈øuch ≈øpace, I will goe every day into the Sea up to my knees, a≈ø≈øaying to pa≈ø≈øe over: ≈øo God me helpe and his holy judgement, &c.

div.head: The forme of a Certificate of an Abjuration.
div.p:
MEmorand. what happenned at E. in the County of S. on Saturday, viz. the twentieth day of I. the year, &c. a certaine R.S. lately of P. in the County of L.Yeoman, tooke the Church Parochiall of P. for freedome and tuition of holy Church there to bee had, by occa ≈ø ion of diver≈øe Felonyes by him before committed, and reque≈øts a Coroner of our Lord the King to be brought to him, upon which I I.W. one of the Coroners of our Lord the King of the County afore≈ø ayd, came to him to the Church afore≈øayd being, and hee before mee the ≈ø ayd Saturday in the Church afore≈øayd confe≈ø≈øed and voluntarily acknowledged that hee the 27. day of May then la≈øt pa≈øt at L. in the Pari≈øh of Saint S. in the Ward of F. one Mazer coverect with ≈øilver of a certaine I.B. in the hou≈øe of him I. being, to the value of thirty ≈øhillings feloniou≈øly ≈øtole, for
which felony hee required of mee the afore≈øayd Coroner the Realme of England to abjure; upon which the book being delivered to him by me the afore≈øayd Coroner, the ≈øame R. the Realme afore≈øaide before me the afore≈øaid Saturday, in the Church afore≈øaid abjured, into the ≈øame Realme never to returne, without ≈ø peciall lycen≈øe and reconciliation of the King of England, and a≈ø ≈ø igned was to the ≈øame R. for his pa≈ø≈øage out of the Realm, the port of Dover, the cro≈øse in his hand put, as the Law and cu≈øtome of England is.

div.head: One taken out of the Sanctuary petitions for re≈øtitution.
div.p: UPon this came the afore≈øaid E. and ≈øayes that hee the 14. day of I. the year, &c. tooke the Church of Saint G. at S. in the County afore≈øayd, for diver≈øe Felonies by him before committed, for ≈øafety of his life, and tuition of holy Church, and reque≈øts the priviledge of that Church. And that I.L. and others to the ≈øame G. unknowne, him then and there out of the Church afore≈øaid violently and again≈øt his will tooke and carryed away, and this &c. and he ≈øues to bee re≈øtored, &c. and &c. to the Felonies not guilty.

div.head: An Inqui≈øition in Murder.
div.p:
AN Inqui≈øition by Indenture taken at B. in the County afore≈øayd, Tue≈øday, viz. the 21. day of December, the yeare, &c. before me I.S. Gent. one of the Coroners of the Commonwealth of the County afore≈øayd, upon view of the body of a certain E.S. Gentl. there dead lying, by the oath of I.S. &c. Jur. trie. and charged to enquire in what manner and how the afore≈øaide E. to his death came, who ≈øay upon their oath, that I.H. of S. in the County afore≈øayde, Yeoman, the fourth day of Augu ≈øt,the yeare, &c. at B. afore≈øayd, in the County afore≈ø ayd, a bout the houre of ten before noon of the ≈øame day. God before his eyes not having,
but by in≈øtigation diabolicall ≈øeduced and moved, of his malice forethought, feloniou≈øly as a felon of the Commonwealth, in and upon the ≈øaid E.S. in the peace of God and the Commonwealth being; then and there by force and armes a ≈ø≈øault and affray made, and that the afore≈øaide I.H. with a certaine ≈ø word of the value of five ≈øhillings which the ≈øame I.H. in his right hand then and there held, then and there the afore≈øaide E.S. feloniou ≈øly ≈øtroke, and with the ≈øword afore≈øaid gave the ≈øame E.S. then and there one wound mortal upon the left knee of him E. wholely cutting off a certaine bone of the afore≈øaide knee of him E. called the panne of the knee, the length foure inches, bredth two inches, and depth two inche ‚Ä¢ , of which wound mortal, the ≈øame E.S. the twentieth day of December, the yeare above≈øaide, at E. afore≈øaid in the Countie afore≈øaid dyed, and ≈øo the Jurors afore≈øaide, upon their oath afore≈øayde ≈øay, that the afore≈øaide I.H. in manner and forme afore≈øaide the afore≈øaide E.S. feloniou≈øly, and of his malice forethought ≈ø lew, and murdered, again≈øt the peace publique, and further the Jurors afore≈øaide, upon their oath afore≈øaide ≈øay, that the afore≈øaid I.H. at the time of the felony and Murder afore≈ø aide done had no goods nor chattels, lands, nor tenements in the Countie afore≈ø aide within their knowledge. In te≈øtimony of which thing, as well I the afore≈øaid Coroner, as the Jurors afore≈øaide, to this Inqui≈ø ition our ≈ø eales alternately have ≈øet, the day, year, and place above≈ø aide.

closer.signed: By I.S. one of the Coroners of the ≈øaid Commonwealth, of the ≈øaid Countie.

div.head: Murder.
div.p:
South.AN inqui≈øition by indenture taken at H. in the County afore≈øaide before me I. W. Gentleman, one of the Coroners of the Commonwealth of the Countie afore≈øaide, Tue≈øday, viz. the twentieth day of Ianuary, the yeare, &c. upon the view of the body of a certaineC.B. lately
the wife of P.B. of H. afore≈øayd at H. afore≈øaid, feloniou≈øly ≈ølaine, then and there dead lying, by oath of good and legall men of the towne of H. and of three other townes near viz. S.N. and C. as the manner is, &c. To enquire in what manner and how, the afore≈øaide C. to her death came, viz.by the Oath of A.B.C.D. &c. to the number of twelve at lea≈ø t, who ≈øay upon their Oath, that where the afore≈øayde C. the day, yeare, place, and County afore≈øayd, about the houre of two after noone of the ≈øame Tue≈øday, was in the peace of God and the Commonwealth at H. afore≈øaid, there came a certaine W.B. lately ofC. in the County of W. Gentl. feloniou≈øly as a felon of the Commonwealth, by treachery and a≈ø≈øault forethought, again≈øt the peace publique, the day, yeare, houre, place, and County afore≈øaid, upon the afore≈ø aide C. his Mi≈øtris then bigge with childe, and neare her time of Childbirth, a≈ø ≈øault made, and with a certaine Hatchet of the value of foure pence, which the ≈øaid W. then and there in his hands held, on the left part of her head feloniou≈øly ≈øtruck, giving her a wound mortall, of which wound mortall the ≈øame C. in≈øtantly dyed, and ≈øo the Jurors afore≈øaid upon their oath afore≈øaide ≈øay, that the afore ≈øaide W.B. the afore≈øaid C. his Mi≈øtris, then and there feloniou≈øly ≈ølew and murdered a
‚Ä¢ ain≈øt the peace publique, &c. In te≈øtimony of which, &c.

AN Inqui≈øition, &c. upon the view of the body of a certain J.S. there dead lying, by oath ofA.B.C.C. &c. to the number of twelve at lea≈øt of Jur. trie. and charged to enquire in what manner and how I.S. to his death came, who ≈øay upon their oath that it ≈øo happened, at M. in the County afore≈øaid, the day, &c. year, &c. about the hour, &c. that where the afore≈øaid I.S. was in the peace of God, and the Commonwealth at M. afore≈øaide, the ≈øame day, yeare, place, and houre, there came W.L. of M. afore≈ø aide, and S. T. of S. in the Countie afore≈øayd Teoman, as Felons of the Commonwealth of their malices fore thought, upon I.S. then and there a≈ø≈øault made, and the afore≈øaid W.L. with a certaine Ponyard, which in his right hand then and there hee held the ≈øayd I.S. upon the left part of his body, viz. upon his armehole
≈øtruck to his heart, giving him a wound mortall, upon which the ≈øame I.S. in≈øtantly died. And ≈øo the Jurors afore≈øaid, upon their Oath afore≈øaide ≈øay, That the afore≈øaid VV.L. the afore≈øaid I.S. at M. afore≈øaid, in manner and forme afore ≈øaid, feloniou≈øly ≈ølew and murdered again≈øt the peace publique, and further the Jurors afore≈øaid, upon their oath afore≈øaid ≈øay, That the afore≈øaid T.S. the day, yeare, place, and houre afore≈øaide was pre≈øent a≈ø≈øi≈øting, abetting, precuring, comforting, and maintaining the afore≈øayde W.L. to the Felony and Murder afore ≈øaid, in forme afore≈øaid doing and committing. In te≈øtimony of which, &c.

div.head: Man≈ølaughter.
div.p: AN Inqui≈ø ition, &c. afore≈øaid. Who ≈øay upon their oathes That R.S.lately of D. in the County afore≈øaid yeoman, the nineteenth day of December, the yeare, &c. by force and armes, viz. with ≈ø words, &c upon a certaine T.G. at D. afore≈øaid, in the County afore≈øaid, with a certain Candle≈øtick of the value of twelve pence, which the ≈øame R. in his right ha ‚Ä¢ d then and their held, the ≈ø ame T. upon his head feloniou≈øly ≈øtruck, giving to the ≈øame T. then and there one wound mortall of the length of two inches, the breadeth of one inch, and the depth of three inches, and after, viz. the ≈øame day, yeare, and place. T. then and there to the ground thronne, with his hands and knees ≈øo fiercely and violently hee ≈øhooke, that the afore≈øaid T. of the wound and ≈øhaking afore≈øaide dyed. And ≈øo the Jurors afore≈øaid, upon their oath afore≈øaide ≈øay, That the afore≈øayd R. the afore≈øaid T. in manner and forme afore≈øaide, then and there feloniou≈øly ≈ølew again≈øt the peace publique, &c. And further the Jurors afore≈øaid, upon their oathes afore≈øaid ≈øay, That the afore ≈øaid R. at the time of the Felony afore≈øaid, by him as afore≈øaid done, had no goods or chattels, lands, or tenements in the County afore≈øaid, nor el≈øewhere within their knowledge. In te≈øtimony of which, &c.

div.head: Robbery and Murder by a man unknown.
div.p: South.AN Inqui≈øition, &c. Who ≈øay upon their oath that the twenty fourth ofS. the year, &c. ≈øo it happened, that a certaine man unknowne, God before his eyes not having, but by in≈øtigation diabolical ≈øeduced, and moved; with force, and armes, viz. with ≈øwords, &c. betwixt the houres ≈øeven and eight of the ≈øame day, at L. in the County afore ≈øaide, in the highway, there in and upon the afore≈øayde S.B. then and there in the peace of God and the Commonwealth being, feloniou ≈øly as a Felon of the Commonwealth a≈ø≈øault made, and the afore≈øayd man unknowne with a ≈øword afore≈øayd, of the value of foure pence which the ≈ø ame man unknowne in his right hand then and there held, the afore≈øayd S.B. upon the brea≈øt then and there feloniou≈øly ≈øtruck, giving the ≈ø ame S.B. then and there with the ≈øword afore≈øayd, one wound mortall of the breadth of one inch, and depth of ≈øix inches, of which wound mortall the ≈øayd S.B. then and there in≈øtantly dyed, and ≈øo the Jurors afore≈øayd upon their oath afore≈øayd ≈øay, that the ≈øame man unknowne the ≈øame S.B. in manner and fore≈øayd feloniou≈øly ≈ølew and murdered again≈øt the peace publique, and further the Jurors afore≈ø ayd upon their oath afore≈øaid ≈øay, that the afore≈øaide man unknown after he the felony and murder afore≈øaid, viz. in form afore ≈øaid had done and committed Fled again≈øt the peace publique. In te≈ø timony of which, &c.

div.head: Murderer of him ≈øelfe who hangs him≈øelfe; no forfeiture of Lands.
div.p:
AN Inqui≈øition, &c. Who ≈øay upn their oath, that the afore≈øayd H.W. the fourth day of April, the year, &c. above≈øaid, about the fourth houre after noone of the
≈øame day, God before his eyes not having, but by in ≈øtigation diabolicall ≈øeduced and moved, at T. afore≈øayd in a certaine Medow, of the ≈øame H. called Edes Meade, then and there alone being, with one girdle of Leather of the value of one penny which he then and there in his hands had and held, and one end thence about his neck then and there put, and one end thence about the bough of a certain willough tree bound, and him≈øelfe then and there with the girdle afore≈øayd willingly and feloniou≈øly hanged and ≈øtrangled. And the Jurors afore≈ø ayd upon their oath afore≈øayd ≈øay, that the afore≈øayd H.W.in manner and forme afore≈øayd willingly and feloniou≈øly as a felon of him≈øelfe, him≈øelfe murdered again≈øt the peace publique, and further the Jurors afore≈øayd upon their oath afore≈øayd ≈øay, that the afore≈øaid H.W. the time of the felony afore≈øayd, no goods or chattels had in the county within their knowledge. In te≈øtimony of which, &c.

AN Inqui≈øition, &c. as above. Who ≈øay upon their oath, that the afore≈øayd A. ‚Ä¢ . the third day of October, the yeare, &c. above≈øaide, about the houre, &c. God before his eyes not having, but by in≈øtigation diabolical ≈øeduced and moved, of his malice forethought, at S. afore≈øaid, in the County afore ≈øayd, then and there alone being, in a common brooke there him≈øelfe willingly and feloniou ≈øly drowned: And ≈øo the Jurors afore≈øayd upon their oath afore≈øayd ≈øay, that the afore≈øayd A.P. in manner and form afore≈øayd, then and there willingly and feloniou≈øly as a felon of him≈øelfe, him≈øelfe ≈ølew and murdered, again≈øt the peace &c. In te≈ø timony of which, &c.

div.head: Of a mad man who drownes him≈øelfe, it is not Felony.
div.p:
AN Inqui≈øition, &c. upon view of the body of a certaine G.P. there dead lying, by the ‚Ä¢ ath of A.B. &c. ≈øworne to
inquire in what manner, and how the afore≈øaid G. p. to his death came, who ≈øay upon their oath, that the afore≈øaid G. P. the fourth day of May, the yeare, &c. above≈øaid at H. being then and there not ≈ø ound of minde, him≈øelfe into a Spring wilfully ca≈øt, and ≈øo the Jurors afore≈øaid, on their oath afore≈øaid ≈øay, That the afore≈ø aid G. B. from the cau≈øe afore≈øaid, in manner and forme afore≈øaid to his death came. In te≈øtimony of which, &c.

div.head: Of a pri≈øoner who died in the Gaole.
div.p: AN Inqui≈øition, &c. upon view of the body of a certaine H.C.lately of O. in the County afore≈øaid Husbandman, there dead lying, who before then committed was thither by B. T. Knight ome of the Ju≈øtices of peace of the County afore≈øaid, for ≈øu≈øpition of Felony, by oath of A.B. &c.who ≈øay upon their oath that the afore≈øayd H.G. the tenth day of Ianuary, the yeare above≈øaid, in the Gaole afore≈øayd, of the vi≈øitation of God dyed, and ≈øo the Jurors afore≈øaide, upon their oath afore≈øaid ≈øay, that the afore≈øaid H.G. in manner and form afore≈øaid to his death came, not otherwi≈øe within their knowledge, In te≈øtimony of which, &c.

AN Inqui≈øition, &c.Who ≈øay upon their oath that the fourteenth day of April, the yeare, &c. above≈øaid at C. in the County afore≈øaid, betwixt the houres ≈øeven and eight before noon of the ≈øame day, with one Axe which the ≈øaid L.H. then and there in his hands had and held, hee cut and threw downe one Oake then growing in a certaine wood called, the Cha ≈øe, by rea≈øon of which throwing downe afore≈øaid, the afore≈øaid Oake, then and there by misfortune fell upon the head of the afore≈øaid L.H. giving the ≈øame L.H. one wound mortall of the length of three inches, and the depth of one inch, of which wound mortall of the length of three inches, and the depth of one inch, of which wound mortall, the afore≈ø aid L.H. th ‚Ä¢ n and there in≈øtantly died, and ≈øo the Jurors afore≈ø aid, upon their oath afore≈øaid ≈øay, that L.H. in
manner and forme afore≈øaid, by misfortune to his death came. And further the Jurors afore≈øa ‚Ä¢ d ≈øay, that the afore≈øaide Oake is of the value of eight ≈øhillings, and that it lyes in the wood afore≈ø aide, now in the tenure, cu≈øtodie, or occupation of a certaine I.S. In Te≈ø timony of the which, &c.

div.head: Otherwi≈øe by misfortune by a Cart with its Loade.
div.p:
AN Inqui≈øition by Indenture, &c. who ≈øay upon their oaths, that the afore≈øayd R.VV. the eleaventh day of October, &c. the yeare, &c. above≈øaid, at P. afore≈øaide in the County afore≈øaide, going with his Cart from Redding in the County of B. to Ba ≈øing≈øtoke in the County of Southamp. afore≈øaide, by the way betweene R. and B. afore≈øaide, viz. at P. afore≈ø aide, in the County afore≈øaid, his ≈øaide Cart with the loade fell upon the bodie of the afore ≈øaide R.W. and ≈øo broke his body, that of that breaking the afore≈øaide R. then and there in≈øtantly died. And ≈øo the Jurors afore≈øaid, upon their oath afore≈øaide ≈øay, that the afore ≈øaide R. W. in manner and forme afore≈øaid, by misfortune to his death came. And further the Jurors afore≈øayde, upon their oath afore≈øaid ≈ø ay, that then and there three Hor≈øes and two Oxen, with the Cart afore≈ø aide, and their Loade, viz. ≈øix Packs of wooll, containing in them by e≈øtimaion twenty four Tods of Wooll, moved to death the afore≈øaid R.W. and that the afore≈øaide three Hor≈øes and two Oxen are of the price of foure pound and tenne ≈øhillings, and that the afore≈øaid Hor≈øes, Oxen, and Cart, remaine in the cu≈øtody of I.W. of P. afore≈ø aid, viz. the late wife of the afore≈øaid R.W. and that the afore≈øaide ≈øix Packs are of the value of ≈øixteen pound, whence they ≈øay, that two of the afore≈øaide ≈øix Packs are of the value of foure pound thirteen ≈øhillings and foure pence, and remaine in the cu≈ø tody of H. P. of B. afore≈øaid, Clothier; and that other three packes of the afore≈øaid ≈øix, are of the value of eight pounds, and remaine in the cu≈øtody of T.
B. of Rom≈øey, in the County of S. Clothier, and the afore≈øayd one other pack, re≈øidue of the afore≈øayd Packs, is of the value of ≈øixty ≈ø hillings and eight pence, and remaines in the cu≈øtody of W.B.of R. afore≈øayd Clothier. In te≈øtimony of which, &c.

div.head: The Sherifes Oath for the due execution of his Office.
div.p:
YOu ≈øhall ≈øweare, that well and truly ye ≈øhal ≈øerve the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament, in the Office of the Sherife of the County of Southampton, and do the Commonwealth profit in al things that belongeth to you to doe by way of your office as farre forth as you can or may: you ≈øhall truly keepe the commonwealths right, you ≈øhall not a≈ø≈øent to decrea≈øe, or le≈ø≈øing, nay, to concealment of the commonwealths rights or of its Franch≈øes, And what≈ø oever you have knowledge that the commonwealths right have been concealed or withdrawne, to be in lands, rents, franchi≈øes, or ≈øuits, or any other things, ye ≈øhall doe your true power to make them to bee re≈øtored to the commonwealth againe: And if you may not doe it, ye ≈øhall certifie the Keepers of the Liberty of England, or ≈øome of them thereof, ye ≈øhall not re≈øpit the Commonwealths debts for any guift or favour, where you may rai≈øe them wihout great grievance to the debtors: ye ≈øhall truely and rightfully treat the people of your Sherifwicke, and doe right as well to poore as to rich, in all that belongeth to your Office: ye ≈øhall doe no wrong to any man for any guift, or other behe ≈øt or promi≈øe of goods for favour nor hate: ye ≈ø hall di≈øturbe no mans right: ye ≈øhall truely acquit at the Exchequer all tho ≈øe of whom ye ≈øhall any thing receive of
the Commonwealths debts: ye ≈øhall nothing take whereby the Commonwealth may lo ≈øe, or whereby the right may bee letted or di≈øturbed, and the Commonwealth delayed: yee ≈øhall truly returne, and truely ≈øerve all the Commonwealths Writs, as farre forth as ≈øhall be to your cunning: yee ≈øhall not have to bee your Under≈øherife any of the ≈øherifes of the la≈øt yeare pa≈øt: yee ≈ø hall take no bailife into your ≈øervice, but ≈ø uch as you will an≈øwer for: you ≈ø hall make each of your bailifes to take ≈ø uch oath as you make your ≈øelfe in that belongeth to their occupation, you ≈øhall receive no Writ by you nor any of yours un≈øealed, or any ≈ø ealed under the ≈øeale of any Ju≈øtice, ≈øaving the Ju≈øtice in Eire, or Ju≈ø tice a≈ø≈ø igned in the ≈øame ≈ø hire where ye be ≈øherife, or other Ju≈øtices having power and authority to make any Writs unto you by the Law of the land, or of the Ju≈øtices of Newgate: you ≈øhall make your bailifes of true and ≈øufficient men in the countrie. Al≈øo ye ≈øhall doe all your power and diligence to de≈øtroy and make to cea≈øe all manner of here ≈øies and errors, commonly called Lollaries, within your bailiwick from time to time to all your power, and a≈ø≈øi≈øt and be helping to all the Ordinaries and Commi ≈ø≈øaries of the whole Church, and favour and maintaine them as often as you ≈øhall be required by the Ordinaries Commi≈ø≈øaries: ye ≈øhall be dwelling in your owne proper per≈øon within your bailiwicke for the time yee ≈ø hall be in the ≈øame office except yee
be otherwi≈øe licen≈øed by the Keepers of the liberty of England by authority of Parliament: yee ≈øhall not let your ≈ø herifewick, nor any bailiwick thereof to any man: yee ≈øhall truely ≈øet and returne rea≈øon and due i≈ø≈øues of them that be within your bailiwick after their e≈øtate and behaviour, and make your pannels your ≈øelfe of ≈øuch per ≈øons as be next, mo≈øt ≈øufficient, and not ≈øu≈øpect, nor procured, as it is provided by the ≈øtatutes. And over this, in e≈øchewing and re≈øtraint of man≈ølaughters, robberies, and other manifold grievous offences that be done daily, namely by ≈øuch as name them≈øelves ≈ø ouldiers, and by other vagrants, the which increa≈øe in number, and multiplie ≈øo that the people of this Commonwealth may not ≈øurely ride nor goe to doe ≈ø uch things as they have to doe, to their intollerable hurt and hinderance: Ye ≈øhall truely and effectually with all diligence po≈ø≈øible to your power execute the ≈øtatutes, as the ≈øtatutes of Winche≈øter and for Vagabonds. Allthe≈øe things ye ≈øhall truly ob≈ø erve and keep, as God you help, and by the contents of this booke.
Or thus;
You ≈øhall well and truely execute the office of Sherife of the countie of A. during ≈øuch time as you ≈øhall be ≈øherife.

div.head: OF THE AVTHORITY OF A SHERIFE, And how and in what manner he ought to execute his Office in all things that are in u≈øe.
THE SECOND BOOKE.

div.p:
FIr≈øt of all, when hee is appointed to be Sherife, he is then Keeper of the County, and his power and authority is very great, as hereafter I will ≈øet forth and declare at large: And at the entrance into his Office, the fir≈øt thing that hee mu≈øt doe, is to go into the Exchequer, into the Remembrancers office there, and to enter into Recogni≈øance there with ≈øureties, or ≈øome for him, for the payment of his proffers, at or before men≈øe Pa≈øchae, and men≈øe Michael then next following. That done, his Attourney there, will write him a note, thereby ≈ø ignifying that he is Sherife of ≈øuch a county, and that hee hath entred Recogni≈øance for his proffers, the which note the Sherife mu≈øt deliver to one of the ≈øix Clerkes in the Chancery, for his warrant to make the Sherifes
tent by, with his Writ of a≈ø≈øi ≈øtance, and a Writ of di≈øcharge to be de ‚Ä¢ ivered to his predece≈ø≈øor, to di≈øcharge him
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ his office, the which would bee delivered with all ≈øpeed, for his owne benefit or his under≈øherifes; for un ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ it be delivered unto his predece≈ø≈øor, the precede ‚Ä¢ . Under≈ø herife may doe execution of Proces. And this being done, then if he be ≈øo well provided, hee may take his Under≈øherife with him, and goe either to a Ma≈øter of the Chancery, or to one of the Judges of the A≈ø ≈øi≈øes of that Shire, whereof he is Sherife, and take their oathes for the due execution of the ≈øayd Office, or el≈øe hee mu≈øt have a Dedim pote≈øtat.out of the Chancery, from the Clerk which made his Patent, directed to two Ju≈øtices of the Peace of the ≈øame County, whereof one mu≈øt be of the Quorum, to give him his oath in the country; but his Under≈øherife may be ≈øworne by two Ju≈ø tices of Peace, whereof one mu≈øt be of the Quorum, without Commi≈ø≈øion: and untill they bee thus ≈øworne, they may not intermeddle with the execution of any proce≈ø≈øe by the Law.

A Sherife at or before his fir≈øt County Court, mu≈øt take over from the old Sherife his predece≈ø≈øor, all his pri≈øoners, and writs, preci≈øely by view and by Indenture to bee made betweene them, wherein all the cau≈øes which he hath again≈øt every pri≈øoner (at the perill of the old Sherife) mu ≈øt be ≈øet forth and declared, or el≈øe the new Sherife needs not to take any notice of any thing that is omitted, and left out of the Indenture: for he is not chargeable with it, but the old Sherife, as it appeareth of late in a ca≈øe adiudged in my L. Cookes 3. booke of Reports, Wesbies ca≈øe fol. 72. again≈øt the She
‚Ä¢ ife of London:For although they ≈øet him over by In
‚Ä¢ enture, yet they ≈øet not over all the cau≈øes which they ‚Ä¢ ad again≈øt him, but omitted an Execution, which after was recovered again≈øt the old Sherifes by the plaintife, and Wesby was at liberty, and the Sherifes were ≈øans remedy.

All the VVrits which are ≈øet over in the Indenture
betweene the Sherifes, if they have beene executed by the old Sherife, then they mu≈øt bee returned by him, and indor≈øed under by the new Sherife thus,
I ≈øend the Writ as it is indor≈ø ed, to mee delivered, it was by R.VV. Knight lately Sherife if my next predece≈ø ≈ø or, in his going out of his office.
H.C. Knight Sherife.

And a Sherife at the fir≈øt County Court which ≈øhall happen to be after his election, and di≈øcharge of the old Sherife, mu≈øt read his Patent and his Writ of A≈ø≈øi ≈øtance, and nominate his Under≈øherife, the County Clerke, and four deputies of Replevins at the lea≈øt for ea≈øe of the Country, who ought to dwel 12 miles one from another: in every quarter of the County one, to grant Replevins when need ≈øhall require.
div.q: The fir≈øt County of F.P. Knight of the County a fore≈øayd, and ≈øo next ≈øecond County, the next County Court, held at the Ca ≈øtle of Winche≈øt. ≈øuch a day and yeare, ≈øetting the Keepers of the Liberties of England Stile at large.
div.p: Then the Bailife mu≈øt make an O-yes, and ≈øay thus, E≈ø≈øoines and Proffers (before the Court three times) for this day. And then ≈øay, if any man will bee e≈ø≈øoined or enter any plaints, let them come in and they ≈øhall bee heard.
div.q: A.B. Is e≈ø≈ø oined becau≈øe he is ≈ø ick, or ≈øuch like.
A.B. Complaines again≈øt C.D. of a plea of Debt, unju≈øt de tinue of his Cattell, or of a plea of Debts unju≈øt detinue, tre≈øpa≈øs, or ≈ø uch like, as the ca≈øe is.
div.p: This Court ought to be kept every moneth upon a day certain of nece≈ø ≈øity by rea≈øon of the Keepers of the Liberty of Engl. by authority of Parliament writs of Exigents which mu≈øt be read there.

And the Actions mu≈øt be called there as they are in a
Hundred Court, or Court Baron, and it will not hold plea where the debt or damage is fourty ≈øhillings, unle≈ø≈øe it be by Writ of Iu≈ø ticies out of the Chancery, which is a commi≈ø≈øion to the Sherife to hold plea of any ≈øumme what≈øoever, and yet it is but in the nature of a Di≈øtringas, to di≈ø traine a man by his goods to an≈øwer there to the plaintifes action, for his body cannot be touched with it by law, nor his lands.

And the like entries, plaints, an≈øwers, barres, and i≈ø≈ø ues are to be put in there, as are u≈øed in a Hundred Court, or Court Baron; for this Court is but a Court Baron. And although it be the Sherifes Court, yet the Freeholders of the County are the Judges there in all Actions. And the Commonwealths County Coroners of the afore≈øaide Keepers are onely Judges to give Judgment upon the Writs of Exigents, and none el≈øe; and if they be Freeholders as they ought by the Law to bee, they are al≈øo Judges of their actions; if they bee not, they may bee removed from their places for lack of Freehold, it is a ≈øufficient exception in Law to bee taken again≈øt them in that ca≈øe.
And the like Proce≈øs or Precepts as are out of a Hundred Court, changing things to be changed, are to be made out of this Court, viz. ≈øummons, attachment, and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe infinite

Election for Knights for the Parliament, and of Coroners and Verderers, are alwaies made by the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament Writ in the open County Court, and the day and time when, and by whom, viz. by the Freeholders of the County, and the Knights are to bee cho≈øen between 8. and 9. of the clock in the forenoon, the Court ≈øitting. And the names of ≈øuch Freeholders as are at the election of Coroners and Verderers ought to be ≈øet down in the County Court booke, for to te≈øtifie ≈øuch election, and the Sherife is to mini≈øter unto the Coroners and the Verderers their ≈øeveral oathes for the due execution of their offices.

div.head: A Replevin.
div.p: South. F P. Knight Sherife of the County afore≈øayd, to the Bailey of the Hundred of H. al≈øo to I.S. my Bailey for this time, and to both, and jointly and ≈øeverally greeting. Becau≈øe W.P. has found me ≈øufficient ≈øecurity, as well for the pro≈øecution of his claime, as for his cattell, viz. one Gelding, three Hor≈øes, &c. which I.C. tooke and unju≈øtly deteines (a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s ≈øayd) to bee returned if the returne bee thence adjudged. Therefore of the part of the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament, you and both of you jointly and ≈ø everally I command, that you Replevie and delivery make, or one of you replevie and delivery make to the afroe≈øaid W.P. of his cattell afore≈øaid, and that he put or, &c. by ≈øurety and ≈øafe pledge the afore≈øayd I.C. So that hee bee at my next County Court at the Ca≈øtle of Winche≈øt. to bee held, to an≈ø wer the ≈øayd W.P. a plea of taking and unju≈øt detinue of his Cattell afore≈ø ayd, and in what manner, &c. to me at my next County certifie yee, or, &c. ∆≤nder the perrill incumbent. Given under the Seale of my Office, the la ≈øt day of Decemb. the year, &c.

closer.signed: By mee Rich. W. Knight, Sherife.

div.p: And if this Replevin bee granted by a Deputy to the Sherife, then hee mu ≈øt ≈øet his name to the Replevin thus.
div.q: By mee I.W. one of the Deputies of the ≈øayd Sherife, according to forme of Stat.
div.p:
And if the fir≈øt Replevin bee not executed, then the Sherif or his deputy may grant an alias Replevin, and ≈øo a
plur. Replevin, vel cau≈øam mihi ≈øignifices, and after toties quoteis if need be. And upon all the≈øe Replevins, there mu≈øt bee a Bond of tenne pound at the lea≈øt taken of him to whom the Replevin is granted for his appearance at the next Court after, and pro≈øecution of his ≈øuite with effect again≈øt the taker of the cattell, and to make returne thereof, if returne bee adjudged, the forme of which Bond and Condition thereof mu≈øt bee thus.

div.head: Obligation.
div.p: KNow all men by the≈øe pre≈øents, that I W. P. of C. in the County of South. Gentleman, am held, and firmely obliged to F.P. Knight, Sherife of the County afore ≈øayd in tenne pounds of good and lawfull money of England, to bee payd to him the ≈øame Sherife, or his certaine Atturney, Executors or A≈ø≈ø ignes, to which payment well and truely to bee made, I oblige my ≈øelfe, my Heires, Executors and Admini≈øtrators firmely by the≈øe pre≈øents. Sealed with my Seale.

div.head: Condition.
div.p: THe Condition of this pre≈øent Obligation is ≈øuch, that if the above bounden W.P. doe appeare at the next County Court to bee holden at the Ca ≈øtle of Winche≈øter, and then and there doe pro≈øecute his action with effect again≈øt I.C. for the wrongfull taking and detaining of his cattell, videlicet, of one Gelding, and three Hor≈øes as it is alledged. And doe al≈øo make returne thereof, if returne thereof ≈øhall bee adjudged by Law, and al≈øo doe ≈øave and keepe harmele≈ø≈øe, and indempnified the above named Sherife, his Under≈ø herife, and Bailifes, for, touching and concerning the delivery of the ≈ø aid cattell, that then this pre≈øent Obligation to be voyd and of none effect, or el≈øe the ≈ø ame to ≈øtand, remaine, and continue in force, ≈ø trength and vertue.

And if in this ca≈øe the taker of the cattell ju≈ø tifie the taking as in his freehold, then this Court can proceede no further therein, but the cau ≈øe mu≈øt be removed from thence by the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament writ out of the Chancery called a Recordare fac loquelam, directed to the Sherife retornable the next terme following, either in the Upper bench, or in the court of Common Pleas, which the party will, for they are both common Law, but they are more properly belonging to the court of Common Pleas, and this writ ought to be openly read and allowed in the ≈øaid Court, to the end that notice may be given thereof to the plaintife in the Replevin, that he may appeare at the day of the returne thereof, and declare again≈øt the taker of his cattell, or el≈øe the taker will have A retorn hahend. aver, and ≈øo put him to ≈øue forth the ≈øecond deliverance, which is a di≈ø advantage to the plaintife, for he ≈øhall then have no more ≈øecond deliverance, otherwi≈øe he might have another, and let the Attorney for the plaintife ≈øee well to the ≈ø ealing of the writ of ≈øecond deliverance with Retorn hend. averior. or el≈øe it will fall out to be manife≈øt error, and overthrow the cau≈øe, be it never ≈øo ju≈øt, when it is an exec, becau≈øe the writ of R.D. is an originall writ, but the def. therein ≈øhall have no co≈øts, it was the ca≈øe of Nic. M. Gent. again≈øt Tho. Newman in a Replevin for an annuitie adjudged in the upper Bench, Term. Trin. ann. xv. I.R.

Now next, the high Sherife will looke for his ≈øecurity from his under Sherife before he will tru≈øt him with his office, becau≈øe he will ≈øleepe quietly, and take his repo≈øe in ≈ø afty: and for that commonly he hath bonds and covenants of the under≈øherife and his friends. That men make not void all the≈øe bonds and covenants taken of their under≈øherifes, Let them looke to the ≈øtat. 5. E. 6. c. 16. And that gentlemens Clerkes may ≈ø ufficiently know how to execute the office of an under≈øherife, I have taken occa≈øion to ≈ø et forth this booke of directions, ≈øufficiently to teach and in≈ø truct any Clerke that is willing to undergoe
the burden of this office for his Ma≈øter, rather then a Gentleman of worth ≈øhall for a little money hazzard his oath or his credit in his country, for by this meanes hee had better (in di≈øcharge of his duty both to God and his Country in the execution of his office) keepe his office in his hou≈øe, ≈øo that hee may take a continuall ≈øurvey of it him≈øelfe, then tru≈øt a ≈øtranger upon bonds and covenants with the whole execution of his Office, which by the Statute of 23 H. 6. ca. 10. are thought by many opinions to be voyd or voydable, for the words of the Statute are the≈øe, That no Sherife, nor none of his Officers or Mini≈øters ≈øhall take or make any Obligation for any cau≈øe mentioned in the ≈øayd Statute, or colour of their office, but onely to them≈øelves, of any per≈øon, or by any per≈øon which ≈øhall be in their ward, by cour≈øe of the Law, but in the name of their office, and upon condition written, That the ≈ø ayd pri≈øoners ≈øhall appeare at the day contained in their writs, bill, or warrant, and in ≈ø uch places as the ≈øayd writs, bils, or warrants ≈øhall require. And if any Sherife, or any of his officers take any Obligation in any other forme, by colour of their office, that it ≈øhall be voyd: And in this cour≈øe there can be no lo≈ø≈øe to the Sherife, if his Under≈øherife bee carefull to follow the directions here layd before him, for he ≈øhall hereby both get good knowledg and experience and ≈øome profit, and his ma≈øter may give him good allowance, and yet ≈ø ave ≈øufficient out of the hone≈øt gaines of the office, to pa≈ø≈øe his accounts, and to defray part of his other charge, and have his countrymen well dealt withall, and gently intreated according to his oath; wheras now as the office is u≈ø ed otherwi≈øe by under≈øherifes which buy their offices, they pay for it, or el≈øe the under ≈øherife mu≈øt go away a beggar.

div.head: The forme of an Indenture for ≈ø etting ever of Pri≈øoners and Writs, betweene two Sherifes.
div.p: THis Indenture made, &c. betweene J.K.E≈ø quire, late Sherife of the County of South. of the one party, and Sir H.W. Knight, now Sherife of the ≈ø aid County on the other party, witne≈ø≈øeth, that the ≈øayd I.K. by vertue of the Keepers of the Libertie of England by authority of Parliament Writ of di≈ø charge of his late office to him directed, hath delivered and ≈øet over unto the ≈øaid Sir H.W. the≈øe Writs following,viz. A Capias, again≈øt W.F. returnable the Oct. of Hil. at the ≈øuite of Andrew Limbon,&c.
Together with the bodies of I.S. in execution at the ≈ø uite of G.H. for a debt of 22. l. and I.H. at the ≈øuite of C.D. in execution for 10. l. &c. In witne≈ø ≈ø e whereof, &c.

div.head: The forme of an Indenture made betweene the High ≈ø herife and his under-≈øherife.
div.p:
THis Indenture made, &c. between I.H. of D. in the county of S.E≈øquire, on the one party, and H.R. of G.in the ≈øaid County, Gentleman, of the other party, witne≈ø≈øeth, that whereas the ≈øayd I.H. being by the Keepers of the liberty of England, by the authority of Parliament appointed to be high Sherife of the ≈øaid County of S. for this year to come, hath upon ≈ø peciall affiance, confidence, and tru≈øt that hee hath and beares in and towards the ≈øayd H.R. promi≈øed and granted to the ≈øaide H.R. the u ≈øe of the exerci≈øing of the office of his under≈øherifwick of the ≈øaid C. together with all fees, fines, forfeitures of Bonds, profits, commodities, advantages, ca≈øualties, allowances, liberties, franchi≈øes, courts, tornes, leets, perqui≈øites of Courts, and other emoluments certaine and uncertain what≈øoever, to the office of ≈øherifwick or under≈øherifwick belonging, or in any, wi≈øe appertaining
that any ≈ø herife or under≈øherife of the ≈øaide County hath heretofore ju≈øtly and lawfully claimed or had, to have and to enjoy during, and by all ≈øuch time as he the ≈øaid I.H. ≈øhall be, remaine, and continue high Sherife of the ≈øaide C. of this appointment or election not di≈øcharged. In con≈ø ideration whereof, the ≈øayd H.R. covenanteth, granteth and agreeth, and faithfully promi≈ø eth for him, his heires, executors, and admini≈øtrators, that hee the ≈øaid H.R. his heires, executors, or admini≈øtrators, ≈øhall and will di≈ø charge, or otherwi≈øe ≈øufficiently ≈øave and keep harmle≈ø≈øe as well the ≈øayd I.H. his heires, executors, and admini≈øtrators, as al≈øo his and their and every of their goods, cattels, lands, tenements, and hereditaments, of and from all and all manner of troubles, vexations, ≈øuits, actions, informations, complaints, contempts, fines, forfeitures, amerciaments, penalties, pains, ≈øum and ≈øums of mony payable or levyable to or for the Keepers of the liberty of England by authority of Parliament, or any other per ≈øon or per≈øons what≈øoever, for any matter or thing to be done in or about the ≈øayd office, and of and from all lo≈ø≈øes, hindrances and damages, that ≈øhall or may bee lawfully moved, ≈øtirred, procured, commenced, prohibited, pro≈øecuted, happen or fall, or lawfully asked, demanded, or levyed upon the ≈øayd I.H. his heires, executors, or admini≈øtrators, or of or upon his or their, or of any of their goods, chattels, lands, tenements, or hereditaments, for or by rea≈øon of the ≈ø ayd office of Sherife, either by non- ≈øuing, or unlawfull returning, ≈ølow returning, or mi≈øreturning of any Precepts, Writs, Warrants, or Proces to the high Sherife directed, or to bee directed, or for, by cau≈øe, or meanes of any exce≈ø≈øive or unlawfull extortion or exaction, or taking of any money, or other gaine or commodity, for the ≈øerving or not ≈øerving of any ≈øuch Writs, Warrants, Precepts, or Proces, or for or by rea≈øon of any mi≈ødemeanour, mi≈øu≈øing, or mi≈ø government, negligence, lack of skill, or of ignorance that ≈øhall be in the ≈øayd H.R. in or about the doing exerci≈øing, or executing of the ≈øayd office of under≈ø herife, and
the ≈øaid H.R. for him≈øelfe, his heires, executors, and admini≈øtrators, by the≈øe pre≈øents doth covenant, and grant to and with the ≈øayd I.H. his heires, executors, and admini≈ø trators, in like manner to di≈øcharge, or otherwi≈øe to ≈øave harmele≈øs and indempnified, as well the ≈øayd I.H. his heires, executors, and admini≈øtrators, as al≈øo all their goods and cattels, lands, tenements, and hereditaments, of and from all manner of e≈øcapes, both wilfull and negligent, of traitors, felons, and other pri≈øoners committed, or to bee committed to his or their ≈øafe keeping or charge, in breach of pri≈øons, and of and from all fines, forfeitures, amerciaments, ≈øums of money, and penalties that he or they or any of them ≈øhall or may incur, beare, pay, or ≈øu≈øtaine for any e≈øcape or breach of pri≈øon during all the time of his continuance in the ≈øayd office of high Sherife of this appointment, and moreover the ≈øayd H.R. ≈øhall give attendance convenient, and requi≈øite upon the Courts at We≈øtm. upon the Judges of A≈ø≈ø. and Iu≈øt. of the peace, and other Commi≈ø≈øioners and officers within the ≈ø ayd County, upon whom the ≈øayd I.H. or the ≈øaid H.R. in re≈øpect of the ≈ø aid office of Sherifwick ought by the Lawes of this nation to attend; and furthermore ≈øhall within one yeare next after the di≈øcharge of the ≈ø ayd I.H. from his ≈øayd office, ju≈øtly and truely make a perfect account in the Exchequer or el≈øewhere of all the ≈øums of money, and other things wherwith the ≈øayd I.H. ≈øhall or may be charged ‚Ä¢ s Sherife of the County of S. and ≈øhall within the ≈øayd time deliver unto the ≈øayd I.H. his heires, &c. a ≈øufficient acquittance or quietus e≈øt.And it is further agreed upon by the ≈øaid parties to the≈øe pre≈øents, that every one of the Bailifes of Hundreds, and all other the officers under the Sherife, ≈øhall enter into ≈øufficient bond by obligation, that they and every of them ≈øhall truely and diligently deale in, exerci≈øe, and execute their offices during the time afore≈øayd, and if any ≈øhall refu≈øe to enter bond, or mi≈ødemeane him≈øelfe, that then it ≈øhall be lawfull to and for the ≈øaid H.R. in his di ≈øcretion to place another meet for that office
in the roome of ≈øuch per≈øon that ≈ø hall refu≈øe or mi≈ødemean him≈øelfe as is afore≈øayd. In witne≈ø≈øe whereof, &c.

The Bonds are commonly taken of the under ≈øherife and his ≈øureties for the performance of the≈øe covenants, and they are ordinary as all other bonds are for performance of covenants, and therefore here needs no prefident for them.

div.head: A condition for a Gaoler to enter into the Sherife, for the ≈øafe keeping of his pri≈øoners.
div.p:
THe condition, &c. That whereas the above named S.H.W. hath at the ≈øpeciall in≈øtance and reque≈øt of the above bounden W.V. con≈øtituted and appointed the ≈øayd W.V. to bee his Keeper of all ≈øuch pri≈øoners as ≈øhall be arre≈øted or attached by any manner of Writ, Warrant, or Precept, made or to bee made, by or in the name of the ≈øaide S. H.W. or by or in the name of I.W. his under≈øherife. If therefore the ≈øayd W.V. his deputy or deputies, a≈ø≈øignee or a≈ø≈ø ignees, or any of them ≈øhall and do well and ≈øafely keepe all ≈øuch pri≈ø oners as ≈øhall bee committed to him or them, or any of them, and therein ≈ø hall ≈øave and keep harmele≈ø≈øe, and indempnified the ≈øayd ≈øherife, his heire ‚Ä¢ , executors and admini≈øtrators, at all and every time and times hereafter, of and from all and all manner of e≈øcapes of all manner of pri≈ø oners that ≈øhal be committed to the cu≈øtody and ≈øafe keeping of the ≈øaid W.V. or left under the cu≈øtody or charge of any of his deputies or a≈ø ≈ø ignees, and of and from all manner of judgements, executions, fines, charges, troubles, and incumbrances what≈øoever, which ≈øhall or may hereafter grow or happen to be taxed, impo≈øed, e≈øtreted, or levyed upon, of or again ≈øt the ≈øayd ≈øherife, as ≈øherife of the C. afore≈øaide, or by rea≈øon of any ≈øuch E ≈øcape, or E≈øcapes, as afore≈øayde. And if al≈øo the ≈ø ayd W.V. his deputy or a≈ø≈øignee, ≈øhall not di≈øcharge or ≈øet at liberty out of his
or their cu≈øtody and ≈øafe keeping, any pri≈øoner or pri≈øo≈øoners which now are, or that hereafter ≈øhall or may bee by the ≈øayd ≈øherife, or by his under≈øherife or deputy, or by any of their Bailifes taken, committed, delivered, or left in the cu≈øtody of the ≈øayd W. V. his deputy or ≈øervant, without the ≈øpeciall warrant in writing under the hand and ≈øeale of the officer of the ≈øayd Sheri≈øe in that behalfe fir≈øt had and obtained. That then, &c.

div.head: A condition for a Bailife to enter into, to the Sherife.
div.p:
THe Condition, &c. That whereas the above named S.B.T. at the ≈øpeciall in≈øtance, earne≈øt intreaty of the above bounden I. P. hath authorized and appointed the ≈øayd I.P: to be one of his Baylifes within the Co. of S. above≈øaid, and in more particular hath committed to his charge the Bailiwick of the Hu. of M. and B. if therefore the ≈ø ayd I.P. and all ≈øuch per≈øons, &c. for and about the executing of ≈ø uch things as ≈ø hall bee given him in charge to doe and execute, as Bailife of the Hun do ju≈øtly &c. execute his ≈øaid office according to the effect and intents of ≈øuch warrants and precepts as ≈øhall be directed unto him, and come to his hands, from the above named ≈øherife, or from his under≈ø herife to bee executed, and ≈øhall and doe upon the view of every warrant upon meane proces from the ≈øayd ≈øherife, take ≈øufficient bond with two ≈ø ureties for the appearance of the defendant arre≈øted according to the ≈øtat. in that ca≈øe made and provided, and ≈øhall ≈øafely convey or deliver every ≈øuch bond, uncancelled unto the ≈øaid Sherife, or his under≈øherife, before ≈øuch time as the proce≈øs whereupon the ≈øaid warrant is made is returnable, and al≈øo ≈øhall at all times, and from time to time, during the continuance of the ≈øayd ≈ø herife in office of ≈øherife of the ≈øayd county, bee ready and attendant both upon the ≈ø avd ≈øherife, and upon his under ≈øherife, as well at every A≈ø≈øi≈øe and ≈øe≈ø≈øions, as al≈øo at
every C. court to be holden, &c. then and there to execute his ≈øaid office as appertaineth. And al≈øo ≈øhall well and truly pay, or cau≈øe to bee payed to the ≈øayd ≈ø herife or his under≈ø herife, at the Fea≈øts of Ea≈øter and S. Mich. the Archangel now next comming after the date above written, all and every ≈øuch ≈ø umme and ≈øummes of money as hath been accu≈øtomed yearly to be payed to the Sherife of the ≈øayd county for the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament out of the ≈øayde Hundreds, upon the account of every Bailife of the ≈øayd Hundreds, commonly called ≈øherifes turne money: And doe in like manner before the ≈øayd fea≈øt of S. Mic. collect and gather of the inhabitants within the ≈øayd Hundreds, all ≈øummes of money due to the Keepers of the liberty of England, upon the ≈øummons and ≈ø cedule of the green Wax, a ≈øufficient warrant being in convenient time delivered unto him to that end and purpo≈øe, and doe accordingly pay the ≈øame to the ≈øaid ≈øherife, or to his under≈øherife within one moneth next after he hath gathered and collected the ≈øame, without covin or ≈øurther delay. That then, &c.

A Sherife is to make warrants upon meane proce≈øs, or to execute them him≈øelfe, which is not po≈ø≈øible for him to doe execution of all: and they mu≈øt be made according to the ≈øeverall natures of his Writs, which for the ≈øub≈øtance will direct him, but not for the form thereof, and that doth differ in many counties, but all to one effect, as in the county of Southampton, thus:

div.head: A generall VVarrant.
div.p:
SS. F.P. Knight, Sherife of the County afore≈øaid to the Baily of the Hundred of Hou≈øholt, greeting, of the part of the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament, I command thee that thou take≈øt A.B. if &c. and him ≈øafely &c. ≈ø o that I may have his body before
the Ju≈øtices of the Common Bench at We≈øtmin≈øt. in the Oct. of Saint Hillarie, to an≈øwer C.D. of a plea of debt (or Tre≈øpa≈øs, according to the Writ,) and this, &c. Given under the ≈øeale of mine Office, the twentieth day of December, the year of our Lord one thou≈øand ≈øix hundred forty eight.

div.head: A ≈øpeciall Warrant.
div.p: SS. F.P. Knight, ≈øherife of the County afore≈øayd, to the Baily of the Hundred of H. al≈øo to J.W. and T.B. my Bailifes for this time, and to every of them greeting, of the part of the Keepers of the liberties of England by authority of Parliament, you and every of you jointly and ≈øeverally I command that you take, or &c. A.B. &c. and him ≈øafely, &c. ≈øo that I may have his body before the Keepers of the libertyes of England by authority of Parliament, in the upper Bench at We≈øtm. on Thur≈øday next after the Oct of Saint Hil to an≈øwer C.D. a plea of Tre≈øpa ≈øs, &c. given, &c. as above.
20. day of Decemb. the year of our Lord, 1638.

By vertue of the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament Writ to me directed, Ret. before the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament, in the upper bench at We≈øtmin≈øt. Thur≈øday next after the Quindene of Saint Hil. Or if it be out of the Court of Common pleas, then, Ret. before the Ju≈øtices of the Common bench at We≈øtm. in the Oct of Saint Hil, you ≈øhall arre≈øt A.B. if he may bee found within my Bailiwick, to an≈ø wer to C.D. in a plea of Tre≈øpa≈øs, or a plea of Debt, according to the Writ. Given under my ≈øeale of office, the day and year above≈øaid, &c.

closer.salute: To I.P. and R. S. my ≈øpeciall Bailifes in this behalfe, jointly and ≈ø everally greeting.

div.p: And in Yorke they u≈øe to make their Warrants thus, upon their meane Proces.

opener.signed: George S. Knight and Baronet, Sherife of the county afore≈øayd,
opener.salute: to all my Bailifes, or to all my Bailifes within the County afore≈øaide, as well within liberties as without, al≈øo to I. B. and C.D. my bailifes this time onely Itiner. greeting,

div.p: of the part of the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament, you and every of you jointly and ≈øeverally, I command, that he take, or &c. A.B.if &c. And him ≈øafely, &c. ≈øo that I may have his body before the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament, in the upper Bench, (if the Writ come out of the upper bench) at We≈øtmin≈øt. Thur≈øday next after the Quinden of Saint Hil, but if the Writ come out of the court of Common pleas, then it is, before the Ju≈øtices of the Common bench at We≈øtm. in the Oct. of ≈øaint Hil. to an≈øwer C.D. a plea of Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe, or Debt, according to the Writ.

closer.dateline: Given under the ≈øeale of my office, ≈øuch a day and year, as above.

div.p:
And this ≈øeemes to be the be≈øt forme of Warrants to have them ≈øerved: and there they u≈øe to make Warrants upon all their Executions in this forme, ≈ø ave onely there is added the≈øe words before the Te≈øte of the Warrant, Provided alwaies that this pre≈øent Warrant is to be executed at the Perill of the Plantife onely. And thereupon the Plaintife will not only pay down the Fee for the Execution, as much as the Statute allows, but al≈øo give bond without condition, for the ≈øaving of the ≈øherife harmle≈øs of the e≈ø cape, if any ≈øhould happen to bee, onely they will ≈øet downe under the Bond, the cau≈øe wherefore the Bond is taken, and the Bond is taken to a ≈øtranger, and yet never que≈ø tioned, which makes execution to be the
better done, or el≈øe the country is ≈øo ≈øpatious, the Sherife would not bee able to doe a quarter of his worke. And I ≈øee no rea≈øon but it may bee u≈øed in any other country as well as there, and it will make the Sherifes work much the ea≈øier to be done, and all things con≈øidered the more for his profit.

Al≈øo they u≈øe there to make warrants upon Capias utlagat. in the like form, and to take Bond, with condition, to bring the defendant to pri≈øon if hee be arre≈øted, which makes good execution of the≈øe Proce ≈ø≈øe; and it were good this were u≈øed in all Countries, then there would not bee ≈øo much extortion and indirect dealing u≈øed by Under≈øherifes and Baylifes, to the Weale publique, as there is, or if they take any man upon a Capias utlagatum, they will not onely take money of the Plaintife for to take the Defendant, but when they have taken him, for money they will let him goe againe, and they will alledg for a colour, it is to rever≈øe the Outlawry, which they have nothing to doe withall. He ought to bee brought to pri≈øon, and there remaine untill one Attorney or other have rever≈øed the outlawry for him, and not the Sherife; for although he be an Attorney, he ought not when he is ≈øherife to practi≈øe as an Attorney; but yet notwith≈øtanding they do fore≈øtall the Market again≈øt the Law and the high ≈øherifes oath, and it is pitty that it is ≈øuffered to go unpuni≈øhed.

div.head: The forme of a bond for appearance.
div.p:
KNow all men by the≈øe pre≈øents, that wee A. B.of C. in the county of ≈øouthampton Gent. E. F. of G. in the County afore≈øayd Yeoman, and H.T. of R. in the county afore≈øayd Yeoman, are held, and firmely obliged to F.P. Knight, Sherife afore≈øayd, in fourty pounds of good and lawfull money of England to be payd to the Sherife or his certaine Attorney, Executors or A ≈ø≈øignes, to which payment well and truely to bee made, wee binde our ≈øelves, and every one of us by him≈ø elfe, for the whole and in the
whole, the heires, executors, and admin≈øtrators of us, and of every one of us, firmely by the≈øe pre≈øents.

closer.dateline: Dated the 20. day of Decemb. in the year of our Lord 1616.

div.p: The Condition of this pre≈øent Obligation is ≈øuch, that if the above bounden A.B. doe appeare before the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament, in the upper bench at We≈øtmin≈øter, Thur≈øday next after the Quinden of ≈øaint Hil, if the Writ bee out of the upper Bench, according to the returne of the Writ: but if the Writ bee returned in the Court of Common pleas, then the words in the condition mu ≈øt bee for the defendant to appeare before the Ju≈øtices of the Common bench at We ≈øtm. in the Oct. of ≈øaint Hil. or ≈øuch other returne, according to the Writ, to an≈øwer to C.Din a plea of Tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe or Debt, as it is in the Writ, that then this pre≈øent Obligation to bee voyd, and of none effect, or el≈øe the ≈øame to ≈øtand, remaine, and continue, in force, ≈øtrength and vertue.

closer.signed: Sealed and delivered to the u≈øe of the above named ≈øheri≈øe in the pre≈ø ence of A.R. and T.S. Two witne≈ø≈øes at the lea≈øt.

div.p: A Sherife before he returne any writ into the Chancery, the upper Bench, the court of common pleas, and the Exchequer, ought to have an Attorney or Deputy in every one of tho≈øe Courts of Record, to an≈øwer for him by warrant of Attorney. And if any Sherife doe contrary to this ordinance in any point, he forfeits 40 li. every time, and treble damages to the party grieved: one moity thereof to the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, and the other moity to him that will ≈ø ue, by a ≈øtat. law made anno 23. H. 6. ca.10.

You ≈øhall finde in this Book good returnes for all manner of writs now in u≈øe, her ≈øet downe to your
view, when≈øoever you ≈øhall have occa≈øion to u≈øe them, and al≈øo apt returnes of all your Excheq. proces, with apt and due formes of all ≈øorts of Inqui≈øitions to be returned there, or el≈øewhere, with your proces.

Sherifes and Under≈øherifes ought to receive all manner of writs in any place within the County, without taking of any thing, and making thereof warrant: and if he refu ≈øe to do it, if he make not a return of tho≈øe writs, he ≈øhall be puni≈øhed, and render damages to the party grieved by the Statute of 2 Ed. 3. cap. 5.

Al≈øo a Sherife may arre≈øt men which goe or ride armed, and commit them to pri≈øon, there to remaine at the Keepers of the Libertie of England by Authority of Parliament plea≈ø ure by the ≈øame ≈øtatute. And Al≈øo Sherifes and Gaolers mu≈øt receive theeves indicted or taken with the manner, without taking any thing for their receit, by the ≈øtatute of 4. E. 3 cap. 16.
Sherifes mu≈øt returne ≈øufficient and rea≈øonable i≈ø≈øues upon ≈øuch per≈øons as have Lands and goods ≈øufficient: according to the ≈øtatute of We ≈øt. 2. ca. 39. & 1. E. 3. ca. 5.
Sherifes ex officio may arre≈øt within their County ≈øu≈ø |pected per≈øons which walke by night or day, and which are of evill name and ≈øame, by the ≈øtatute of 5. E. 5. ca. 14.
A Sherife ought to have but one Bailife errant within his County, by the ≈øtatute of 14. E. 3. cap. 8.

Sherifes ought to keep their Torns twice every yeare, viz. one within a month after Ea≈øter, and the other within a moneth after the Fea≈øt of S. Michael the Archangell, by the ≈øtat. of 31. E. 3. ca. 14.
