Sherifes mu≈øt leavy their i≈ø≈øues and amerciaments by their extracts under the ≈ø eale of the Exchequer, otherwi≈øe they ≈øhall render to the party damnified, treble damages, and al≈øo make fine to the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament for their offence, which is determinable before the Ju≈øtices at their Se≈ø≈øions, by the ≈øtat. of 43. E. 3 ca. 9.

Sherifes ought to returne their pannels for the ≈øe≈ø≈øions 4 dayes before the ≈øe≈ø≈øions, at lea≈øt upon the pain of 20 li. and the Bailifes of liberties ought to make returne of their warrants ≈øix dayes before the Se≈ø≈øions at the lea≈øt, upon the like pain, by the ≈øtatute of 41. E. 3. cap. 11.
Sherifes ought foure times in the yeare to proclaime the Statute of Winche≈øter in every hundred of his Bayliwick, for it is parcell of their oath, yet they never doe it.

Sherifes ought to take the ≈øwords, daggers, and weapons from ≈ø ervants labourers, and from ≈øervants of Artificers, and Victuallers, if they find them bearing of any, except it be in time of war, or when they travel abroad into the Country with their Ma ≈øters, or goe in their me≈ø≈øages, and they may keep ≈øuch weapons untill the next ≈øe ≈ø ≈øions, and there pre≈øent them with the names of tho≈øe that bore them, by the ≈øtat. of 12 R. 2. ca. 9.

Sherifes may ex officio apprehend labourers, ≈øervants begging and wandring abroad, and commit them to pri≈øon without bayle or mainpri≈øe, but they can take no ≈ø ees of ≈øuch per≈øons, neither upon receit or delivery of them, upon paine of a C. s. to the Keepers of the liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, by the ≈øta ‚Ä¢ . of 12. R. 2. ca. 9.

Sherifes and other of the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament Officers, when they have notice of unlawfull A≈ø≈øemblies and Riots, ought to rai ≈øe the Country, and with all their power to apprehend ≈øuch malefactors, and commit them to pri≈øon, there to remain untill due execution of the Law be done upon them, and all Lords of Seigniories, and all other people ought to bee attendant to the Sherife and other officers, with all their power and force herein, by the ≈øtat. of 17. R. 2. ca. 8.
A Sherife ought to dwell within the County in his per≈øon during the time of his Sherifewick, and he ought not to let his office to farme, both by his oath and by the ≈øtatute of 1. H. 4. ca. 5.

A Sherife ought to fore≈øee and provide, That neithe ‚Ä¢ his Under≈ø herife, nor any of his Clerkes, Baylifes, or Receivers, be an Attorney in any of the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament Courts, during the time of his Sherivalty, both by his oath, and al≈øo by the ≈øtat. of 1. H. 5. ca. 4.

Every Sherife ought to proclame the ≈øtatute of Purveyors four times in his yeare, upon paine of a hundred ≈øhillings for every time failing therein, and he ought al≈ø o to deliver that to his ≈øucce≈ø≈øor to proclaim upon the like paine, by the ≈øtat. of 1. H. 6. ca. 2. but this is never done.

Sherifes ought to make due election of Knigh ‚Ä¢ s for the Parliament by the Freeholders of the County, and in open County Court, and between 8. and 11. of the clock in the forenoone of the ≈øame day, by the ≈øtat. of 6. H. 6. c. 6. upon paine of a C.li.and a yeares impri≈øonment without bail or mainpri≈øe.

Sherifes ought to returne upon every precept directed unto them from Ju ≈øtices of P. to enquire of forcible entries, upon every Jury twenty ≈øhillings i≈ø≈øues a the fir≈øt day, and Ju≈øtices of Peace have power and authority to hear and determine tho≈øe defaults by Bill or Indictment, and Sherifs ≈øhall forfeit for every default twenty pounds, whereof he that will ≈øue ≈øhall have the moity by the ≈øtat. of 8. H. 6 cap. 9.

And Sherifes ought to returne in writs of Attaints, in plea of Land of the yearly value of forty ≈øhillings, or in actions for deeds concerning lands to ≈øuch value, and in actions of forty pounds or more, ≈øuch per≈øons inhabiting within his Baylywick, which can di ≈øpend 20. li. per annum, be≈øides all charges, for terme of life at the lea≈øt, and out of ancient deme≈øne, Gavelkind, and Cinque ports, and upon the fir≈øt di≈øtre≈ø≈øe 40 s. and upon the ≈ø econd C. s. and after double i≈ø≈øues upon the Jurors, upon paine of 10.li. to the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, and 10. li. to the party grieved, and if there be not ≈øufficient per≈øons inhabiting within
the County, which can expend 20. li. per annum, then they ≈øhall impanell other per≈øons of the mo≈øt ≈øufficient in po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of yearly value of lands, under the value of 20. li. per annum, upon pain of 10. li. to the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, and 10. li. to the plaintiffe, by the ≈øtatute of 15. H. 6. cap. 5.
A Sherife may not occupy his office above a yeare, and if he doe he ≈ø hall forfeit two hundred pound, and be di≈øabled ever to be Sherife of any County after, by the ≈øtat. of 23 H. 6. cap. 8.
No Sherife ought to let to farme his County, nor any of his Baylywicks, Hundreds, or Wapentakes, for it is both again≈øt his oath, and contrary to the ≈øtatute of 23 H. 6. cap. 10.
No Sherife, Baylife of Liberty, nor any other Officer ≈øhall returne in any pannell or Jury any of his Bailifes, Officers, or ≈øervants to any of his Officers, by the Statute of 23 H. 6.

Forfeiture x. li. No Sherife, nor any to his u≈øe, ≈øhall take any thing of any per≈øon to be arre≈øt ‚Ä¢ d or attached, nor for ≈øparing of any arre≈øt or attachment, for fine, fee, ≈øuit of pri≈øon, mainpri≈øe, letting to bai ‚Ä¢ e, or for ≈øhewing any ea≈øe or favour to any ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øo arre≈øted, but onely for the Sherife twenty pence, the Baylife which maketh the arre≈øt foure pence, and the Gaoler (if the pri≈øoner be committed to pri≈øon) four pence, by the ≈ø tatute of 23. H. 6. cap. 10.
And a Sherife ought to take but foure pence for the copy of a pannell, and two ≈øhillings for returne of a pannell, by the Statute of 27 El. cap. 12.

Sherifes ought to let to bayle all per≈øons being in their keeping, by force of any Letter, Bill, or Warrant, in any per≈øonall action, or upon Indictment of Tre≈øpas upon rea≈øonable ≈ø urety, having ≈ø ufficient in the County to appear at the day and place, as tho≈øe letters, bils, or warrants require, except ≈øuch per≈øons as are in their guard or cu≈øtody upon a capias ad ≈øatisfaciend. utlagary or excommunication, or for ≈ø urety of the peace, or by commandment of any Ju≈øtices, and vagrants which refu≈øe to ≈ø erve‚ñ™
vide Dyerfol.324. He is of opinion that the Mar ≈ø hall of the upper Bench is within the compa≈øs of the ≈øtat. of 23 H. 6. cap. 10: But the Warden of the Fleet, and the Keeper of the pri≈øon at We≈ø tm. are not within the compa≈ø≈øe of that ≈øtatute, for they are excepted.

Note, that a ≈øherife ought to take Bond for the appearance of his pri ≈øoner, with two ≈øureties, having ≈øufficient within the ≈øame County, otherwi≈øe the obligation is held to be voyd, and it mu≈øt bee made to the ≈øherife by the name of the ≈ø herife, and not to the under≈ø herife, and there mu≈øt bee nothing in≈øerted into the condition of that bond, but that the defendants ≈øhall appeare in the court from whence the writ i≈ø≈øued at the day of the return thereof to an≈ø wer to the plaintife in his action. Plo. Comment. fol. 68.
If more bee in≈ø erted into the Obligation, then is for the appearance of the party bound, the bond is voyd, per Mountague chiefe Ju≈øtice Comment. 68. s. in Manninghams ca≈øe there.

A Bond entred into by a pri≈øoner, to any per≈øon ≈øave onely to the Sherife for the inlarging of a pri≈øoner, is not not good, but meerly voyd in law, by the ≈ø tatute of 23. H. 6. cap. 10. And ≈øo it is where a Bond is given to the ≈øherife by a ≈øtranger for the inlargement of a pri≈øoner that is not baileable, per 37. H. 6. & Dyer, 2. & 3. P. & M. fol. 119.

A ≈øherife having an Attachment retor ‚Ä¢ . coram dicto Rege & con≈øilio ≈øuo in camera ≈øtellat. apud We≈øtm. in quindecim Pa≈øchae ad re≈øpond. dicto Domino Regi & con≈øilio ≈øuo de quodam contemptu & ad fac & re≈øp. ulterius, &c. Return. before the ≈øayd King and his Coun≈øell in the Starre Chamber in 15. of Pa≈øche, to an≈øwer the ≈øayd Lord the King and his Coun≈øell a contempt, and to doe and an≈øwer further, &c. doth arre≈øt the party and takes bond for his appearance indor≈øed with ≈øuch condition, that if the party arre≈ø ted ≈øhall per≈øonally appeare before the Kings Maje≈øty, and his coun≈øell at We≈øtmin≈øter in Quindecim Pa≈øchae, and then and there ≈øhall an≈øwer
to a contempt by him committed, that then, &c. It was a que≈øtion whether this Bond and Condition was good in Law or no, becau≈øe the≈øe words then and there were added unto the condition, which was more than the ≈øtature of 23. H. 6. would warrant; and it was demurred on in Law, but by the opinions of Dyer and Windham, it was thought to bee a good Bond and Condition, notwith≈øtanding tho≈øe words were added, yet Mead was of a contrary opinion. But Termino Mich. Anno 2 & 3 El.judgment was given for the Plaintiffe, Dyer 364.

Sherifes ought to take no obligation for any thing what≈øoever it be, or by colour of their office, but onely to them≈øelves, nor of any per≈øon being in their cu≈ø tody but by the name of the office, naming him ≈øherife in the obligation, this upon condition that the party ≈øhall appear at the day and place in the writ or warrant ≈øpecified, and if any obligation bee taken by colour of their office in any other form it is voyd, 23. H. 6. c. 10.
And ≈øherifes ought to take no more but 4. d. for making of any obligation, warrant, or precept, by the ≈øame Law.

And ≈øherifs ought to make proclamation when they have received letters for the levying of expence of the knights of the Parliament, at the next County-court after the receipt of the ≈øe Letters: and the Coroners ought to bee there to ≈øe≈ø≈øe the wages, upon paine of 40.≈ø. and they ought to a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øe every Hundred at a certaine ≈øumme by it ≈ø elfe, and after every village within the Hundred with a certain ≈øum: and if they doe it otherwi ≈øe, they ≈øhall forfeite for every default twenty pound, and he that will ≈øue ≈øhall have the moity thereof with treble damages. 23. H. 6. c. 11.

And every ≈øherife after the receipt of the Kings writ for ≈øummoning of the Parliament for the election of Knights for the Parliament, ought forthwith to make out his warrants under the ≈øeale of his office, to every Major and Bailifes of Cities and Boroughs within the County, commanding them thereby to chu≈øe Citizens and Burge≈ø≈øes
to come to the Parliament: and tho≈øe Majors and Bailifes mu≈øt make a lawfull returne of that precept to the ≈øherife by Indenture made betweene them and the ≈øherife, of their election, and of their names which are elected: And the ≈øherife mu≈øt ≈øet his hand and ≈øeale of Office to the one part of the Indentures, and then deliver it to the Major or Burge≈ø≈øes, or Citizens to bee kept, and to the other part the Major, and Citizens, or Burge≈ø≈øes mu≈øt ≈øet their hands and ≈øeales, and deliver it as their deeds, to the ≈øherife to bee certified and returned by him with the writ of ≈ø ummons to the clerk of the Crown, who will have 4. ≈ø. for his fees for every Indenture, as I do take it.

div.head: The form of an Indenture for the Knights of the Parliament.
div.p:
THis Indenture made in the full County of South held at the Ca ≈øtle of Winch. Munday the la≈øt day of May, the yeare, &c. betwixt F.P. Knight, Sherife of the County afore≈ø ayd of one part, and C.H. Knight, H.D. E≈øq. and D.B E≈øq. &c. and many other per≈øons of the County afore≈øayd, and Electors of two Knights, to the Parliament, in the Writ to this Indenture annexed ≈øpecified, of the other part: who as the greater part of the whole County afore≈øaide, then there being, ≈øworne and exomined, according to the force forme and effect of diver≈øe Statutes thereupon put forth and provided, cho≈øe H. W. and E.M. Knights within the County afore ≈øayd Commorant, girt with ≈øwords, Knights able and mo≈øt fit and di≈øcreet, giving and granting to the two afore≈øayde Knights full and ≈øufficient power for them≈ø elves and the whole County afore≈øayd, to doe and con≈øent to tho≈øe things which at the Parliament in the ≈øayd Writ contained by the Common Coun≈øell, &c. ≈øhall happen to bee ordained, in bu≈øine ≈ø≈øes in the ≈øayde Writ ≈øpecified. In te≈øtimony of which, the one part of the Indenture remaining
with the Keepers of the Libertyes of England by authority of Parliament, the parties above≈øayde have put their ≈øeales, to the other part of the ≈øame Indenture, the afore ≈øayd Sherife has put his ≈øeal Dated the day, year and place above≈øayd, &c.

div.head: The forme of the Indenture for the Citizens and Burge≈ø ≈øes.
div.p: THis Indenture made, &c. reciting the day, year, &c. Witne≈ø≈øeth that by vertue of a Warrant to mee directed from Sir F.P. Knight, Sherife of the county of Southampton. for the electing and choo≈øing of two Burge≈ø≈øes, men of good under≈øtanding, wit, knowledge, and di≈øcretion, for cau≈øes oncerning the Weale publique of this Nation, to bee at the high Court of Parliament to be holden at the City of We≈øtmin≈øter, the 27 day of October next comming, I I.F. Major of the Burrough of C. in the County of S. with the whole a≈ø≈øent and con≈ø ent of the re≈øt of the Burge≈ø≈øes there; have made choice and election of H. M. of the Middle Temple E≈øquire, and W.S. of L. E≈øquire, to bee Burge≈ø≈øes of our ≈øayd Burrough of C. to attend at the ≈ø ayd Parliament, according to the tenor of the ≈øayd Warrant to me directed in that behalfe. In witne≈ø≈øe whereof I have to the≈øe pre≈øents ≈øet our common ≈øeale of our ≈øaid Burrough, the day and yeare fir≈øt above written.
A Sherife ought not to execute the office of a Ju≈øtice of Peace during the time that hee is Sherife, 1. M. cap. 4.

Where any man by di≈ø≈ø imulation, flattery, or by any cunning, ≈ølight, meanes, or practi≈øe doe make them≈øelves to be beloved of any ≈øole woman, as maide, or widow, which maide or widow have great po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, or great ≈øtore of goods or money, and to deceive them of it, and to gaine it for them≈øelves, doe by fraud gaine the po ≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion
of ≈øuch woman, and doe convey and keep them in ≈øuch places where they will not ≈øuffer them to goe from them at liberty to di≈øpo≈øe of their owne as they li≈øt, unle≈ø≈øe ≈øuch maide or widdow will enter into Bond or Statute to pay ≈øome great ≈øumme of money; or el ≈øe bind them from marriage with any but ≈øuch as they will nominate and appoint, for remedy hereof it is ordained, that the party ≈øo bound ≈øhall have a Writ in the Chancery, containing all the matter of ≈ø uch unrea≈øonable dealing, called a ≈øpeciall Supplicavit directed to the Sherife of that County where ≈øuch wrong is offered, commanding him thereby to make proclamation at his next County Court after receipt thereof, that the defendant appeare at a certaine day and place prefixed in the ≈øayde Writ before the Lords Commi≈ø≈ø ioners of the great Seale, or before the Judges of A≈ø≈øi≈øe of that County, or before ≈ø ome other per≈øon a≈ø≈øigned by the ≈øaid Lords Commi≈ø≈øioners, and the ≈øherife is bound to execute ≈øuch Writs according to the tenor of them, upon paine of 300. l. the one moity thereof to the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament, and the other halfe to him that will ≈ø ue by action of Debt, where no wager of Ia „Äà‚óä„Äâ , protection or forreine plea ≈øhall be allowed, by the Statute of 31 H. 6. cap 9.

Upon information made to a Ju≈øtice of P. or other Ju≈øtices again≈øt any per≈øon for retaining or giving livery to any, or again≈øt any which is retained, the Ju≈ø tices ought to make proces upon this information as upon a recovery in debt or tre≈øpa≈ø≈ø e, and the Sherife ought to returne no le≈ø≈øer i≈ø≈øues in any ≈øuite brought hereupon again≈øt any per≈ø on that is ≈øufficient, then 20. ≈ø. at the fir≈øt day upon the di≈øtre≈ø ≈øe, and at the ≈øecond day 30. ≈ø. and at the third day 40. ≈ø. and ≈øo at every day after, more by ten ≈ø hillings in i≈ø≈øues, upon pain for every retorn 20. ≈ø. ann. 8.Ed. 4 cap. 2.

The ancient Sherifes may returne Writs, and execute their office during the Termes of Saint Michael and Hilarieafter the yeare their office is ended, if they bee not
before that time lawfully di≈øcharged of their office, 17. Ed. 4. cap. 7.

No Sherife or any other Officer ought to relea≈øe or take from any per≈ø on arre≈øted or impri≈øoned for Felony, his goods, untill the ≈øame per≈øon arre≈øted or impri≈øoned bee duely convicted and attainted of the ≈øame Felony by due cour≈øe of Law, viz. either by tryall, confe ≈ø≈øion or outlawry, upon paine to forfeite the double value of the goods ≈øo taken, to the party grieved, to be recovered by action of debt, wherein no wager of Law, e≈ø≈øoine, or protection lyeth, an. 1. R. 3. cap. 3.

Sherifes which have the cu≈øtody of the Gaole, ought to certifie the names of their pri≈ø oners which are in their cu≈øtody for Felony, to the Ju≈øtices of the next generall Gaole delivery in a Kalender, upon paine of a hundred ≈øhillings for every default, an. 3. H. 7. c. 3.

Al≈øo a ≈øherife nor no other per≈øon in his name, or by his commandement, ≈øhall enter any plaints into their Bookes in any mans name, unle≈ø≈øe the plaintife bee there in his proper per≈øon, or el≈øe by his ≈øufficient Attorney or Deputy, that is well knowne to be of good name and behaviour, and the Plaintife ought to finde pledges, ≈øuch per≈øons as are knowne in the Court to pur≈øue his plaint. And a Plaintife ≈øhall have but one plaint for one Tre≈øpa≈øs, or one contract, and if the Sherife, or any of his Officers cau≈øe to bee entred any more plaints then the Plaintife hath cau≈øe of Action for, then the ≈øherife or his clerk that doth contrary to this act, ≈øhall forfeite for every default 40. ≈ø. the moity to him that will ≈øue and prove the ≈øame matter by action of debt or information.

Al≈øo the ≈øherife ≈øhall make ≈øufficient Precepts after ≈øuch plaints entred, but not before, again≈øt the defendants, directed to the Bailife of the Hundred, to attach or warne the defendant to appeare at the next County Court, and an≈øwer to the ≈øayd plaints, and if there be any default in the ≈øayd Baylifes in the execution of their offices according to the tenor of their precept, then they are to forfeite forty ≈øhillings, and to be convicted thereof
by examination of the Ju≈øtices of P. or by any of them.

Al≈øo the ≈øame ≈øherife, nor his deputies ≈øhall make any extracts to levy the ≈øhire amerciaments, untill that two Ju≈øt. of P. whereof one to bee of the Quorum, have the ≈øight of their bookes, and the extracts to be indented between the Ju≈øt. of Peace, and the ≈øherife and under≈øherife, ≈øealed with their ≈øeales, the one part thereof to remain with the ≈øayd Ju≈øtices, and the other part with the ≈øherife, for his warrant to levy the amerciament by.

And that tho≈øe per≈øons that ≈øhall be gatherers of the ≈øayd amerciaments, ≈øhall be ≈øworne by the ≈øayd Ju≈øtices, That they take no more money than is forfeite, and certified in their extracts, ≈øealed with the ≈ø eales of the Ju≈øtices to the ≈øame, upon the ≈øame paine of forfeiture as is above rehear ≈øed, to be convict by examination of the ≈ø ame Ju≈øtices, or one of them. And the ≈øame Ju≈øtices of Peace ≈øhall bee appointed at the ≈øe≈ø≈øions holden at Mich. by him that is Gu≈øtos Rotulorum,or in his ab≈øence by the elde≈øt of the Quorum, to have the controlement of the ≈øayd Sherifes, Under≈øherifes, Shire-Clerks, and others of their ≈øayd Officers, and the ≈ø ayd ≈øherifes amerciaments, and the ≈øayd Ju≈øtices of Peace upon ≈øugge≈øtion ≈øhall make proce≈ø≈øe again≈øt the Sherife, Under≈ø herife, Shireclerk or other officers, to appeare before them to an≈øwer ≈øuch ≈øugge≈øtion or information, as is u≈øed in action of Tr ‚Ä¢ ≈øpas, by the Statute of 21. H. 7. cap. 15.

Al≈øo every Sherife upon a precept to him directed from the Ju≈øtices of Peace to return them a Jury to enquire of any Ryot, or unlawfull A≈ø≈øembly committed, ≈øhall returne foure and twenty per≈øons dwelling in the Shire, every one of them having 20. ≈ø. per annum of Freehold, or 26. ≈ø. 8. d. per annum, copyhold, or of both, be≈øides all charges, and to returne in i≈ø≈øues upon every per≈øon which maketh default, twenty ≈øhillings at the fir≈øt day, and at the ≈øecond day forty ≈øhillings, and if default bee in the Sherife for returning of per≈øons in≈ø ufficient, or for not returning of I≈ø≈øues in forme afore≈øayd, then hee
doth forfeite twenty pounds, anno 19. Hen. 7. cap.13.

Al≈øo if any Ryot, or unlawfull A≈ø≈øembly be in any part of the Nation, the Ju≈øtices of Peace, or two of them at the lea≈øt, and the Sherife, or Under≈ø herife may come with the power of the County, if need bee, and arre≈øt and re≈øtraine ≈øuch mi≈ødoers; and the≈øe Ju≈øtices and the Sherife have power to record that which they finde done in their pre≈øence again≈øt the Law. And ≈øuch mi≈ødoers ≈øhall be convict by that Record: And if they be gone before the coming of the Ju≈øtices and the Sherife, or under≈øherife, then the ≈øame Ju≈øtices, or two of them, ought diligently to enquire thereof within one moneth after ≈øuch Ryot or A≈ø≈øembly made, and if the truth cannot be found out within one moneth then next in≈øuing, then tho≈ø e Ju≈øtices, or two of them, and the Sherife or Under≈øherife, ≈øhall certifie the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament therof, and of all the circum≈øtances thereof, which Certificate ≈øhall bee as an Indictment of twelve men, whereunto they ≈øhall be compelled to an≈øwer, anno 13 H. 4. cap. ultimo.

And if the ≈øayd Ryot or unlawfull A≈ø≈øembly bee not found by rea≈ø on of any Imbracery or maintenances of the ≈øavd Jury, then the ≈øayd Ju≈øtices of Peace, and the Sherife, and Under≈øherife, over and be≈øide ≈øuch Certificate that they mu≈øt make, according to the Statute of an. 13. H. 4. ≈øhall in the ≈øame Certificate certifie the names of the ≈øame Maintainers and Imbracers in that behalfe, if any be, with their mi≈ødemeanours that they know, upon paine of every the ≈øayd Ju≈øtices, and Sherife, and Vnder≈øherife twenty pound, if they have no rea≈øonable excu≈øe for non certifying of the ≈øame: which certificate ≈øo made ≈øhall bee one Indictment in the Law, and every per≈øon duely proved to bee a Maintainer or Imbracer ≈øhall forfeite twenty pound, and be committed to Ward there, to remaine by the di≈øcretion of the Ju≈øtices, Anno decimo nono Hen. ≈øept. cap.3.

Al≈øo that no Sherife upon Writs and Precepts directed unto him to returne before E≈ø cheators or Commi≈øsioners
≈øhall returne any per≈øon to enquire of any lands or tenements, except he have lands or tenements of the yearly value of forty ≈øhillings, above all charges in the ≈øame ≈øhire, upon paine of forfeiture for every per≈øon ≈øo returned, an hundred ≈øhillings, anno 3. H. 8. cap.2.

Al≈øo all pannels put in by the Sherife before any Ju≈øtices of Gaole delivery, or before Ju≈øtices of Peace, wherof one to bee of the Quorum in their open Se≈ø≈øions, to enquire for the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament, may be reformed by putting to, and taking from, of the names ≈øo impannelled by di≈øcretion of the ≈ø ame Ju≈øtices, and that the ≈øame Ju≈øtice or Ju≈øtices ≈øhall command every Sherife and their Mini≈øters in their ab≈øence to put other per≈øons in the ≈øame pannels by their di≈øcretion, and the ≈øame pannel ≈øo returned by the Ju≈øtice to bee good, and if any Sherife doe not returne the ≈øame pannels ≈øo reformed, then every ≈øherife ≈øo offending ≈øhall forfeite twenty pound, half to him that will ≈øue by action of Debt, bill, or complaint, where ≈øuch ≈øhall happen to bee, and no wager of Law, E≈ø≈øoine, or Protection to be allowed, tertio Henr. octavi cap. duodecimo.

Al≈øo upon every Exigent where Writs of Proclamation are to bee awarded, the ≈øame Writ of Proclamation is to have the ≈øame day of returne that the Exigent hath, and to be delivered of Record by the Exigenter of every ≈øhire. And the ≈øherife is to make a Proclamation three ≈ø everall dayes in his county, whereof one proclamation is to be made at the generall Se≈ø≈ø ions in tho≈øe parts where the party is ≈øuppo≈øed to be dwelling, there to yeeld his body to the ≈øherife of the forreine ≈øhire, that that ≈øherife may have the body at the day of the returne of the Exigent to an≈øwer to the plaintife. And that the ≈øherife of the County that hath ≈øuch writ of proclamation duely execute, and returne the ≈øame, at the day, upon paine to forfeit ≈øuch amerciament as by the Ju≈øtices before whom the ≈øaid Writs ≈øhall be returnable ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed. Ann. 6. H. 8. c. 4.

Al≈øo Sherifes which have the cu≈øtody of goales ≈øhall make ≈øeales to be graven with the name of the Ca≈øtle that they keepe for to give and ≈øeale letters to pri≈øoners acquitted to beg for their ≈øees within the hundred where they be delivered by the ≈øpace of ≈øix weekes next after their delivery, and then to goe to the Hundred where they la≈øt dwelled by the ≈øpace of three yeares, or where they were borne: the Sherife ≈øhall not ≈øuffer ≈øuch pri≈øoners to begge for their fees, nor to depart out of pri≈øon to doe ≈øervice and labor, untill he deliver to them ≈øuch letters, and the Clarke of the Peace is to make ≈øuch letters within one day after the Se≈ø≈øions, when ≈øuch pri≈øoner is acquitted, upon pain of 12. d. to the keepers of the liliberties of England by authoritie of Parliament by the ≈øtatute of 22. H. 8. cap. 21. & 5. El. ca. 4.
Sherifs ought to keep their County court every moneth if it hath bin accu ≈øtomed to be ≈øo kept. Magna chart. c. 33.

The Keepers of the liberties of England by authoritie of Parliament command that Sherifes and their Officers which receive the debts, ≈øhall acquit the debtors upon their account when they have received the debts, and then it ≈øhall be allowed upon their accompts in the Exchequer: and if the Sherife do otherwi≈øe, and be thereof convicted, he ≈ø hall then pay three times ≈øo much as he hath received to the party grieved, and al ≈øo be fined at the Keepers of the liberties of England by authoritie of Parliament plea≈øure, We≈øtm. 1. ca. 20.

Sherifes and other which have levyed the Keepers of the liberties of England by authority of Parliament debts, and given acquittances to the debtors, and yet doe not acquit them, it is accorded and ≈øet downe for a Law, that when the Sherife is impleaded for it in the Exchequer, if he come not in upon the fir≈øt di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, then ≈øhall goe out another with proclamation, which mu≈øt bee made in full county, that the defendant doe come in at a day certaine, and acquit the debtor of the money which he did receive, and if he come not in then, he ≈øhall be convicted by default, and the debt levied
upon him as a debt recovered again≈øt him in the Court of exchequer and the plaintife ≈øhall have therein damages according to the di≈øcretion of the Barons, by the ≈øtat. of 14. E. 3. c. 1.

And it is the Keepers of the liberties of England by authoritie of Parliament commandement, that all Sherifes and Baylifes which have received their debts of the ≈øummons of the exchequer, if they acquit not the debts upon their account, that then they ≈øhall be puni≈ø hed according to the ≈øtatute de Di≈ø trictionibus Scaccarij ca. 5.

And it is ordained that execution of writs which are brought to Sherifes, ≈øhould be done by the Bailifes of hundreds ≈øworne and known, and in full county, and not by others, unle≈ø≈øe tho≈øe Bailifs will not, or cannot execute them, then they are to be done by other convenient per≈ø on or per≈øons ≈øworne by the ≈øtat. of Lincolne cap. ultimo.

No Sherife ≈øhall ≈øuffer a Barretor to maintaine any actions or quarrels in their Countie Courts, nor ≈øtewards of great men or others, which is not Atturney to his Lord or Ma≈øter; nor they ≈øhall not pronounce judgements there, unle≈ø≈øe they be thereunto required by all the ≈ø utors, We≈øtm. 1. ca. 23

It ≈øhall be lawfull for every Sherife, Ju≈øtice of Peace, and E≈øchea or to ≈øei≈øe to the Keepers of the liberties of England by authoritie of Parliament u≈øe all ≈ø uch goods and chattels as Egyptians have, within their charge, and thereof to give an account to the keepers of the libertie of England by authority of Parliament in the exchequer for the moitie thereof, and to detaine and keepe the other moitie to his owne u≈øe, and to pay no fees for the account, nor for the charge the reof.

In the≈øe ≈øtatutes it appeareth what things Sherifes ought to doe by rea≈øon of their office, and that they ought to take nothing for doing of their office, but that onely which is appointed for them to take by the ≈øame ≈øtatutes, if they doe otherwi≈øe, it is extortion in them, and it ought to bee inquired of by the Ju. of P. and by them puni≈øhed accordingly.

And it is ordained by the ≈øtat. 1. H. 4. c. 5. that if any ≈ø herife doe any extortion to the people, and thereof be duelyattainted, that he ≈øhall be puni ≈øhed for the ≈øame extortion at the Keepers of the liberties of England by authoritie of Parliament will.

A Sherife may and ought at his turnes to enquire of common Nu≈øances done to all the people of this common wealth, but not of A≈ø≈øaults made to a ≈øole per≈ø on Per Martin Anno quarto Hen. ≈øexti, octavo Edw. quarto, quinto. Dyer 234.

A Sherife ought to keepe his turnes within a moneth after Ea≈øter, and within a moneth after Michaelmas, and if he keepe it at any other time after the moneth, it is void by the Statute of 13. Ed. 3. cap. 19, and all indictments and pre≈ø entments taken there after the monethes are expired, are void by the ≈øtatute of 38. H. 6.

A Sherife may inquire of blood ≈øheds in his turne, for if any thing be omitted in a leete, it may be enquired of at the Sherifes turn, for all leets were derived and taken out of the Sherifes turne, Pa≈øch. 8. Ed. 4.26.43. Ed. 3. &. 20. E. 3.3.

And all the Ju≈øtices were of opinion, that a Sherife hath authoritie to enquire of all things in his turnes, that ‚Ä¢ s either tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe or felony at the common Law, except of the death of man, but he cannot enquire of tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe or felony by ≈øtatute in his turne, 28. E.3.95 21. E. 4.

If a Sherife inquire of Nu≈øance in his Turne, and it is there found, which ≈øhould have beene inquired of in a Leete: now the Sherif cannot di≈øtraine for his amercia ment, for if he doe, he is a tre≈øpa≈ø≈øor. But if default bee ‚Ä¢ n the Lord of the Leet, for that he did not inquire therethereof, it ≈øeemeth then that the Sherife by the Lords default may inquire thereof in his turne, 28. E. 3.95.2.9 E. 3.27. 10. H. 21. E. 3.3.
If a man have a Faire or a Market by grant or by pre≈ø cription, and doth not keep his faire or market as he ought to doe, the Sherife may inquire of this in his Turne.

Vpon a pre≈øentment of a Nu≈øance in the ≈øherifes turn, the offendor ≈øhall be amerced, there the ≈øherife may di≈øtraine for that amerciament. And if a Purpre ≈øture bee pre≈øented there, the ≈øherife may abate it and returne it Pa≈øc 25. E.3.

It appeareth by Ma≈øter Britton, that all the Freeholders and Terre Tenants inhabiting within the Hundred, ought to come to the ≈øherifes Turn, none excepted, but Knights and Clergy men, their wives and children. And there, twelve at lea≈øt of the ≈ø ufficiente≈øt Freeholders within the Hundred ought to bee impanelled and ≈øworne to inquire and pre≈øent all things there inquirable, and pre≈øentable, and all the re≈øt which appeare there, ought to be ≈øworne by the dozeners and villages to pre≈øent to the ≈øayd Jury all ≈øuch things as ≈øhall bee given them in charge, and it ≈øeemeth that the ≈øherife ought to keep his turne in every hundred within his County, and there puni≈øh all things which have been omitted at the Leets or law dayes there.

Al≈øo by the ≈øame Law it ≈øeemeth, that they ought to Inquire there of petty Trea≈ø ons, Homicides, Rapes, Robberyes, Burglaries, and of all manner of Felonyes by the Common Law, and of all other things inquirable at a Leete, according to the ≈øtatute of 18. Ed. 2.de Vic. Franc. Pleg.

And when the dozeners and villages have delivered their pre≈øentments to the ≈øayd Jury, and the Jury, when they are agreed of their Pre≈øentments, then they mu≈øt give up to the Steward or Court-keeper ≈øuch pre≈øentments, as they will ≈øtand to, and avow, and if there be any of Felony, they mu≈øt deliver up the≈øe by them≈øelves to the ≈øteward privily, and the re≈øt openly.

But this Court is now almo≈øt out of u≈øe, ≈øince ≈øherifes have u≈ø ed to ≈øell both their ≈øherifwickes, and bailiwickes to men of meane e≈øtate that will not regard the good of the Common wealth, but altogether their owne private gaine and profit, whereby the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authoritie of Parliament are many times
much wronged, and deceived, betweene the Vnder≈ø herife, and the Bailifes, of all their waifes, ≈øtraies, and ≈øelons goods, which are taken up by the Bailifs, and never accounted for, which may touch the Sherife in his credit and reputation, for when he entreth into his account for the payment of the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament debts, he is then ≈øworne to an≈øwer and account for all waifes, ≈øtraies and felons ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ods, debts, perqui≈øites, and profits which he ≈øeldome or never knowes of, becau≈øe tho≈øe ancient Courts are not kept as they ought to be, and therefore how he may di≈øpence with his oath herein is the que≈øtion.

There is a Writ in the Regi≈øter, fol. 174. whereby a Sherife may remove all his Bailifes of Hundreds, Wapentakes, Tythings, and Liberties, which have not Lands or Tenements ≈øufficient within the Countie. And ≈øherifes bailifes one yeare, ought not to be in that office in three yeares after, by the ≈øtatute of 1 H. 5. cap. 4. becau ≈øe by their continuall being in that office, they grow ≈øo cunning that they are able to deceive both the Keepers of the liberties of England by the authority of Parliament, the ≈ø herife, and the countrie.
And ≈øherifes bailifes ought to be ≈øworn to the Keepers of the liberties of England, by authority of Parliament, to exerci≈øe their office duly and truly by the ≈øtatute of 27 Eliz. capitul. 12.

div.head: The nature of Executions, and of how many ≈ø orts they are.
div.p:
THey are of ≈øix ≈øorts or degrees, viz. upon a Statute Merchant, a ≈øtatute Staple, a Recogni≈øance, an Elegit, a Capias ad ≈ø atisfaciend, and a fieri fac, and a ≈øherife cannot lawfully break any mans hou≈øe to do execution upon any of the≈øe ju≈øtifiable, except the Keepers of the liberties of England by the authority of Parliament be a party, for every mans hou≈øe is his ≈øafe≈øt refuge, as hereafter
≈øhall appeare. If a man be bound in a ≈øtatute Merchant, execution ≈øhall be done thereof thus. Fir≈øt a Writ of Certiorare mu≈øt be ≈øued forth of the Chancery, directed to the place where the Statute was acknowledged, to certifie the acknowledgement of the ≈øtatute into the petty bagge office in the Chancery, and upon that certificate ≈øhall goe out a Capias again≈øt the body onely, ≈øi laicus ≈øit, returnable in the Court of Common pleas, or in the upper Bench: And upon the returne of that, with the ≈øherife of that ≈øhire to whom it was directed, that hee is a Lay man and is not found in his ≈øhire, then within a quarter of a yeare after ≈øhall goe out an Exigent again≈øt all the cogni≈øors lands and goods, and again ≈øt his body, and for your better ≈øatisfaction herein, ≈øee the Statute de Mercat ‚Ä¢ ribus 37. Hen. 6. fol. 6. and Fitzherbert 130. G.

A ≈øtatute ≈øtaple mu≈øt bee certified in the like manner as ≈øtatute Merchant, and upon that ≈øhall goe forth a writ of exe cution, both again≈øt body, land, and goods, returnable in the Chancery in the Petty bagge office there, and not in the Court of Common pleas, or upper Bench, as the Writ of execution upon a ≈øtatute Merchant ≈øhall: and upon the returne of this Writ ≈øuch lands and goods as are taken in execution ≈øhall be delivered to the cogni≈øee by the ≈øherife by another Writ called a Liberate, and not before. And note that all the Fee ≈øimple lands, which the cogni≈ø or had at the time of the acknowledging of the ≈øayd Statute, or at any time after, are lyable to both the ≈øayd ≈øtatutes, but no intailed Land, but during the cogni≈øors life, nor no copihold land, nor no goods, nor lea≈øes for life, or years, but ≈øuch as the cogni≈øor hath in his owne u≈øe and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion at the time of the execution done, Fitz.131. D.
Note, that if a ≈øtatute ≈øtaple be returned and filed, the cogni ≈øee can have no Liberate into any other county. 2 R. 3. fol.7.

Vpon a Recogni≈øance there ≈øhall not goe out a Capias,
but Scire fac.returnable in the Chancerie, and upon the returne thereof they doe u≈øe to a ward a Capias, a Fierifacias, or an Elegit, at the choice and election of the cogni≈øee. 48. E. 3. fol. 14.

By an Elegit the ≈øherife may take in execution one halfe of the land of the cogni≈øor, and all his goods, be≈øides oxen and bea≈øts of the plow, A Capias ad ≈øatisfaciendum is onely again≈øt the body, which the Sherife mu≈øt be ≈ø ure to keepe ≈øafe, or el≈øe he may perhaps pay the debt, if his pri≈øoner doe e≈øcape either with his leave or con≈øent, after that he is once in execution, for then the Sherife hath ≈ømall remedy or none at all, but if he doe e≈øcape again≈øt the Sherifes will, and without his con≈øent, then the ≈øheri≈ø e may take him againe if he can finde him by „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ Writ before the returne thereof, or by ano ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ after, though it be in another ≈øhire, ≈øo that he be foll ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ fre≈øh ≈øuit, and taken againe before the action bro ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ by the plaintife again≈øt the Sherife, for the e≈øcape, h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oever the Sherife in this ca≈øe may have his remedy again≈øt his pri≈øoner by his action upon the ca≈øe, if he be able to make him ≈øatisfaction, otherwi≈øe he may keepe his body, and his pri≈øoner in this ca≈øe ≈øhall not be delivered by ≈øuper≈øed upon audita querela, becau≈øe he cannot take any benefit of his owne wrong. But otherwi≈øe it is when a pri≈øoner e≈øcapes with the con≈øent of the Sherife or goaler, for then he ≈øhall have and maintaine if he will in Audita querela again≈øt a Sherife, or a goaler, „Äà‚óä„Äâ appeareth in my Lord Cookes 3. Booke of Reports fol.43. & 44. in Boytons ca≈øe there.

And in my Lord Cookes ≈øaid third booke of Reports, it is re ≈øolved for Law, That if a Sherife die in the time of his Office, having divers per≈øons in his cu≈øiody, and after a new Sherife is cho≈øen in his place, in this ca≈øe it behoves the new Sherife to take notice at his perill of all the executions which are again≈øt any per≈øon which hee findes in the Goale, and that is a matter of nece≈ø≈øitie, for in that ca≈øe there is no man in rerum natura to deliver the pri≈øoners unto him.

Al≈ø o in the ≈øame ca≈øe it is re≈øolved, that if a Sherife die in the time of his office, and before another bee appointed to that place and office, a pri≈øoner which was in the pri≈ø on in execution, breakes the pri≈øon, and ≈øo is at large, this is no e ≈øcape, and the rea≈øon is there alledged, becau≈øe when the ≈øherife died, all his pri≈ø oners were in the cu≈øtodie of the Law, untill a new ≈øherife was cho≈øen, and ≈øet in his place. And therefore although that the pri≈ø oners be in the interim out of the walls of the pri≈øon, yet the Law hath the cu≈øtodie of them, and pre≈øerves them in execution without any fre ≈øh ≈øuit made after them, where≈øoever they be, and they may be fetched againe in execution at any time after, if they can bee found, and no e≈øcape in this ca≈øe can prejudice the plaintife.

Note al≈øo that if a pri≈øoner die in execution before payment or ≈ø atisfaction made to the plainti≈øe for his debt for which he is in execution upon a Capias ad ≈øatisfaciend. i ‚Ä¢ this ca≈øe the pl. ≈øhall have an Elegit again≈øt the defendants lands and goods, if he had any lands, in fee ≈øimple, at or any time after the Judgement was had again≈øt him, or any goods at the time of his death. And it is Bloumfields ca≈øe, in the fift booke of ≈øir Edward Gookes Reports, f. 87. and Fitz. nat. br. fo. 246.

Al≈øo when a man is in the Sherifes cu≈øtody by the proces of Law, and after another Writ is delivered to the ≈øherife again≈øt the body of him which is then in his cu≈øtody, the ≈øherife in this ca≈øe mu≈øt be an≈øwerable for his pri≈øoner, although he doe not arre≈ø t him by the ≈øecond Writ, by the judgment of the Law, for Lex non praecipit inutilia, And this in Fro≈øts ca≈øe in the fifth booke of Reports, fol, 89, and with this agreeth 7. H. 4.30.

If a Capias, viz. a meane proces be executed and not returned, the arre≈øt is tortious and a wrong, for the arre≈øt is made to that end that the def. ≈øhould appeare to an≈øwer to the plaint his action, but in all Writs of execution except an Elegit, if the execution be duely done, althoughthe Writ be never returned or filed,, it is no
great matter if the pl. have his demand; for then he hath no cau≈øe to proceede any futher herein: but in ca ≈øe of an Elegit, becau≈øe the extent is to be made by an Inque≈øt, and not by the Sherife alone, that ought to be returned, or el≈øe it is nothing worth, as it appeareth in Hoes ca≈øein the ≈øaid 5. booke of Reports, fol. 90. and by Fulwods ca≈øe in the 4, booke, fol. 65.

Al≈øo it is re≈øolved in Seymans ca≈øe in the ≈øaid 5 booke of Reports fol. 91. that a mans hou≈øe is to him his Ca≈øtle, as well for his defence again≈øt in jurie and violence, as for his re≈øt and repo≈øe, and that a ≈øherife cannot ju≈øtifie the the breaking of any mans hou≈øe to execute a Capias ad ≈ø atisfaciendum, or a Fieri fac, but if he doe, it is at his perill, and he is therein a tre≈øpa≈ø≈øer, if the Keepers of the liberties of England by authoritie of Parliament be not a party, for every mans hou≈øe is his ≈øafe≈øt re≈ø uge: but if the Keepers of the liberties of England afore≈øaid be a party, then the Sherife may ju≈øtifie the breaking of a hou≈øe to doe execution of his proces, if he cannot otherwi≈øe execute his proces, but fir≈øt he ought to make reque≈øt to open the doore by the ≈øtat. of We≈øtm. 1. c. 17. & 41. of the A≈ø≈øi≈øe placit. 17. if hee breake the do ‚Ä¢ res when hee may enter otherwi≈øe, yet in the ≈øaid Seymans ca ≈øe, it is re≈øolved, That a ≈øherife upon an habere fac ≈ø ei≈ø inam or po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øionem may breake a hou ≈øe and deliver ≈øei≈øon and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof to the plaintife, and the rea≈ø on therein is, becau≈øe that after judgment, it is not the defendants hou≈øe in right and judgement of Law.

Al≈øo whether it be for felonie or ≈øu≈øpition of felonie, the Keepers of the liberties of England by authority of Parliament officer may breake another mans hou≈øe to apprehend a theefe, and that for two rea≈ø ons, viz. one for the good of the Common-wealth, and the other is for the ≈øervice and duty which he owes to the weale publique, for in every felony, the common- wealth hath an intere≈øt, and where the common-wealth hath any intere≈øt, the Writ is A non omitt propter aliquam libertatem, and therefore the liberty or priviledge of any mans
hou≈ø e will not hold again≈øt the Keepers of the liberties of England by authoritie of Parliament but where the common wealth, hath no intere≈øt, but onely a common per≈øon. A Sherife although he make reque≈øt to open the doores, and deniall is made, if he ≈øhould then breake them, and ≈øo enter and doe execution: that men in the night as well as in the day, ≈øhould have their hou≈øes broken upon any fained matter, for although that a Sherife be an Officer of great authority and tru≈øt, yet it appeareth by daily experience, that all or the mo≈øt part of the Keepers of the liberties of England by authority of Parliament Writs, are executed, and ≈øerved, by under≈ø herifes and Bailifes, which mo≈øt commonly are per≈øons of ≈ømall value and account. And all the authorities which doe prove that when the Proce≈ø≈øe concerne the afore≈øaid Keepers of the liberties of England, that the Sherife may then breake the hou≈øe of any man to execute them, if otherwi≈øe hee cannot execute them, implyeth that at the ≈øuit of a common per≈øon, the hou≈øe cannot be broken ju≈øtifiably, and with this re≈øolution agreeth the booke in 6. Edw. 4 fol. 9. A fieri facias is onely again≈øt the goods and chattels of a man, as moveable goods, or Lea≈øes for yeares, and the ≈øherife had need to be very carefull how, and after what manner he doth execute this Writ, le≈øt he burne his fingers, for if the goods or Lea≈øes which he taketh in execution be not the defendants owne goods, or Lea≈øes, although he may finde them in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the defendant, which is the be≈øt colour in Law to prove them, his, if he u≈øe them and take the profit and benefit of them as appeareth in Twynes ca≈øe in ≈øir Ed. Cookes 3. booke of Reports.

Al≈øo ≈ø ometimes it doth fall out, that the goods and chattels which a Sherife upon ≈øuch a Writ taketh in execution, are not the defendants, and then the Sherife is a tre≈øpa≈ø≈øer to the Owner of the goods, as if the Lands be pawned to the defendant, they are none of his untill the day of the redeeming of them be pa≈øt, 34. H. 8. Pledges,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ 28. & 4. Edw. 6. di≈øtr. 75. So if a man bona fide make
a Lea≈øe of his Oxen for yeares, and after is condemned in a per≈øonall Action, the≈øe Oxen during the time ≈øh
‚Ä¢ ll not be taken in execution, 22. E. 4. fol. 10.

In debt where three are bound jointly, and ≈øeverally, and three Judgments are had again ≈øt them, in this ca≈øe if execution be done again≈øt one of them, the others ≈øhall have a Super≈øedeas: But in Tre≈øpas again≈øt three, execution again≈øt one of them ≈øufficeth not, and the ≈øame Law is in a joynt debt, 4. El. fol. 39.

If goods taken in execution upon tryall are found to be none of the defendants, then the Sherife ≈øhall pay damages to the owner of the goods, to the value of the goods ≈øo taken, and co≈øts of ≈øuit, although he hath delivered them to the plaintife in execution, if he have returned his Writs, that he hath taken ≈øo much goods of the defendants, and that he hath tho≈øe monies ready to tender &c to the plaintife, then he is at a double mi≈øchiefe; for although the value of the goods be recovered again≈øt him by the owner of the goods, yet the plaintife in the action may within the yeare after execution done, have a Scire facias upon the judgment and returne, and thereby compell the Sherife to bring the money into the Court, and after the yeare he may have an action of debt again≈øt the ≈øherife for it, if he be not otherwi≈øe ordered by the Court where the Judgment is depending. And therefore in this ca≈ø e the ≈øure≈øt cour≈øe for the Sherife, is either to keepe the goods untill the parties bee agreed, or el≈øe to take good ≈øecurity of the plaintife to defend him and ≈øave him harmele ≈ø≈øe, and to ≈øtay the returning of his Writs, untill he may be well advi≈øed what to doe therein, for if he take a bond of the plaintife, it is que≈øtionable whether it be good or no in Law, and not with in the compa≈ø≈øe of the ≈øtatute of 23. H. 6. to be taken color. officii: ≈ø ed hoc quere.

It is re≈øolved in Mi ‚Ä¢ tons ca≈øe in my Lord Cookes 4. booke of Reports, fol. 33. & 34. that both the County C. and the goale are appertinent and belonging to the Sherifes office, and ought not to be ≈øevered, no more
than the Sherifes turne from the office, and it was the opinions of Poph. and Ander≈ø. the 2. L. chiefe Ju≈øtices, and with that agreeth the Judgments of the Parliament ann. 14. E 3. ca. 10.

Now next I will ≈øay ≈øomething as concerning a ≈øherifes account, which will trouble him mo≈øt of all, if he be never ≈øo skilfull therein, it is ≈øo tedious and ≈øo chargeable, for if he get by his office, he will goe nigh to bee ≈øtripped cleane out of his paying of Exchequer fees, and other extraordinarie charges which he cannot avoid, as experience hath taught me, and there is no way to helpe it as I thinke, but by an act of Parliament, and therefore it is no marvell that the Under≈øherifes make ≈øhipwrack of their con≈øciences, to catch what they can to ≈øave them≈øelves, and that which they had before they entred into that office, for what betweene ≈øome of their high ≈øherifes covetou≈ønes in taking money for their office: and extremitie ≈øhewed to them and their ≈øureties upon every light and ≈ømall occa ≈øion, and the extreme taking of ordinary and extraordinary fees of Exch. ‚Ä¢ en, a poore under≈øherife is ≈øtripped out of all that ever he hath, or can make, if he doe not hedge ≈øo, as he may be ≈øtill in action every yeare, as a Fox is ≈øtripped out of his skinne; and yet few or none will pittie him, for in every Court where he is called in que≈øtion, the name of the under≈øherife is ≈øo odious, and many times not without ju≈øt cau≈øe, that oftentimes an hone≈øt man is condemned to be a knave; before he is heard ≈øpeake for him≈øelfe; nay, he is ≈øo odious (I meane a lewd extorting under≈øherife) that a Theefe by a generall Pardon, receives more favour then he can, for a theefe is thereby pardoned of all felonies, for the which he might have the benefit of his Clergie, although he cannot reade, but all mi≈ødemeanors committed by an under≈øherife, are commonly excepted out of the Generall pardon, which is ≈øomewhat har≈ø h, that all ≈øhall be condemned for ≈øome, for there is never an Officer the Keepers of the liberties of Lngland by authoty of Parliament have, taketh more paines, and undergoes
more perils, and doth the Keepers afore≈øaid better ≈øervice, than an hone ≈øt, under≈øtanding and a carefull under≈øherife doth, but commonly the≈øe doe die beggers, by rea≈øon of the cau≈øes before alledged.

div.head: The entrance into the Sherifes Account.
div.p:
FIr≈øt, in Hillarie Terme next after they are out of office, the high Sherife and under≈ø herifes of mo≈øt Shires are ≈øworne to yeeld and give a ju≈øt and true account to the Keepers of the liberties of England by authoritie of Parliament and their officers in the publique Excheq. which they ≈øhall be charged withall, by the greene wax of the Exchequer, and of all way≈øes, ≈øtreyes, and felons goods, which happened within the compa≈ø ≈øe of their office, and of all other profits what≈øoever, due and belonging to the weale publique, and chargeable by them to an≈øwer for, by rea≈øon of their office, or much to this effect. Now when this is done, the high Sherife commonly takes no further care, beeau≈øe he thinkes him≈øelfe ≈øecure, by rea≈øon of his ≈øecuritie which he hath of his under≈øherife, for thereupon he relyes, and ≈øeldome or never remembers what oath he hath taken, and ≈øo commits all to his under≈øherife; then if his under≈øherife be a carefull and an hone≈ø t man and have skill and regard to doe his be≈øt endeavour to levie the Keepers of the liberties of England by authoritie of Parliament debts, and to pay them into the receit duely and orderly, as they ought to be, then the high Sherife may doe well enough, and therein di≈ø charge both his oath and and his Oath and dutie, but if otherwi≈øe, a lewd, or an ignorant under≈øherife, may both undoe his high Sherife, and him≈øelfe, both in this world, and in the world to come, by totting and nichling, that is, in charging or di≈ø charging, unorderly, unhone≈øtly, or or ignorantly, for if if be totted, that is charged, though it can never be levied: it will now hardly be avoided, but it mu ≈øt be paid, and if it be nichiled, if it be i≈ø≈øues of Jurours,
though they be never ≈øo bad, and cannot be levyed, betweene the old Sherife which returned them, and the new ≈øherife which nichi≈øed them, they mu≈øt bee payed, though it be ≈øeven yearer after, if there come no pardon in the meane time, by an old Statute made in the 27 yeare of Ed. 1. and to prevent this, it behoves all Sherifes before they take upon them to returne any Jurors, to get them a perfect booke of all the ≈øufficient Freeholders names in the ≈øhire, and e≈øpecially of all which dwell in the gildable, how≈øoever they doe of tho≈øe which dwell in liberties, but of both is be≈øt, that the one may help the other, and to returne ≈øew or none that be meane Freeholders in the gildable, le≈øt by the ≈øayd Law they bee enforced to pay their i≈ø≈øues for them, which is a thing very hardly to be brought to pa≈ø≈øe, unle≈ø≈øe the Ju≈øtices of P. in every quarter of the countrie, do cau≈øe the Con≈øtables and Ballifs to bring a true certificate thereof to the fir≈øt quarter ≈øe≈ø≈øions that ≈øhall be holden in the ≈øhire, after the election of the new ≈øherife, to be delivered unto him there, and this will hardly bee done, unle≈ø≈øe the Judges of A≈ø≈øi≈øe of every ≈øhire will be plea≈øed to write their letters to that end and purpo≈øe to the Ju≈ø tices of peace of every divi≈øion.

Now next the Under≈øherife mu≈øt go to the forren Appo≈øer, and with him hee mu≈øt either tot, nichil, or ≈øet over into liberties all the debts and ≈ø ums of money contained in the ≈øummons of the green Wax, and in the Extracts of the P. of the Co. where hee was Vnder≈øherife, wherein he mu≈øt be very careful what he doth, le≈øt he do that which he cannot undoe againe, and to prevent the danger thereof, his be≈øt way is to examine his book which hee is to make of all the charge contained in his ≈øummons and ≈øcedules before and with the Baylife of the ≈øhire to have their direction, which are good debts, and which are not, and which are in liberties, and which are not, if he him≈øelfe doe not know it before he come to his account, and then make his booke accordingly, and then he ≈ø hall be the better able to perform the duty of an hone ≈øt man, when hee comes to his Appo≈øals; but herein
if the Sherife know not well the Country, and the Kee
‚Ä¢ ers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament debtors him≈øelfe, hee is many times abu ≈øed by the Baylifes, who mo≈øt di≈øhone≈øtly will mi≈ø-informe him, and for bribes and rewards which they receive of the Freeholders, will tell him that they are either long ≈øince dead, or nothing worth, when as they are living, and very ≈øufficient, and they will al≈øo ≈ø erve him ≈øo, with the Recogni≈øances, and by that meanes di≈øhone≈øt Bailifes doe cau≈øe ≈øherifes to deceive the Keepers of the liberties of England afore≈øayd of many of their debts by their ignorance again≈øt their wills, in tru≈øting of the reports and informations of their Baylifes; and this cannot bee helped onle≈ø≈øe the Sherifes will levy the Keepers of the liberties of England by authority of Parliament mony them≈øelves, which they cannot po≈ø≈øibly doe, by rea≈øon of their other bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, or had tru≈øty ≈øervants about them to do it truly and hone≈øtly, without grievance of the countrey, as i ‚Ä¢ ought to be.

div.p:
All the≈øe five la≈øt payments are allowed upon the She
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ fes account, out of the Keepers of the liberties of Engl
‚Ä¢ y authority of Parliament mony, which otherwi≈øe ≈øhould ‚Ä¢ ee payd to them.

list.item:
Item, to the forren Appo≈øer for his ≈øee for allowance
of Ju≈øtices wages to the Sherife upon the Extracts of the Peace, xl. s.

div.p: And herein the Sherife of the ≈øayd County is wronged by the Clerk of the Peace of the ≈øayd County, for the Clerk of the Peace there receives all the fines, and payes the wages, and if there be any ≈øurplu≈øage he puts it up in his owne pur≈øe, and the Sherife payes it into the Exchequer, and never hath it, becau ≈øe the fines are all certified in the Extracts of the Peace, and many times the fines doe exceed the wages of the Ju≈øtices which are allowed to the Sherife for the wages, for hee is allowed but foure ≈øhillings a day a peece for eight Ju≈øtices, and therefore accounting the fees which hee payes to the Officers in the Exchequer for his allowance, he is a great lo≈øer by it, and the Clerk of the peace goes away with the gains, therefore this would be remedyed.

Item, if the ≈øherife take the benefit of a generall pardon, then he mu≈øt gee to the Clerke of the Extracts to have ≈øcedules made of all, ≈øuch i≈ø≈øues as are pardoned, and they will co≈øt him for every ≈øcedule (as I remember) xx. d. which may come to foure or five pound, or thereabouts

div.p: And this mu≈øt all goe out of the Sherifes pur≈øe, without any allowance: and it is better then to oppre≈ø≈øe the country when they may bee ea≈øed by the pardon. For if the Sherife levy any, he mu≈øt pay it into the receit, or el≈øe he is for≈øworn.

Then if you carried any pri≈øoners by Writ or commandement from the Judges of A≈ø≈øi≈øe, you mu≈ø t goe to the chiefe Judge of A≈ø≈øi≈øe for his warrant, and get your allowance under his hands as good cheape as you can, for ≈øome of his men will have money of you for it, x.s. at the lea≈øt.
And then when you have his hand for it, you mu≈øt goe to the Chancellor of the Exchequer for his hand to it, and his man will looke to have for his paines therein taken, at the lea≈øt x. s.

Al≈øo in the Alienation office it will co≈øt you for making
of the bond and acquittance, with the ≈øcedules of ≈øei≈øures again≈øt ≈øuch as have ≈øold land held of the Commi ≈ø≈øioners without lycen≈øe of alienation, x. ls. vj.d.

div.head: A Return of Summons of A≈ø≈øi≈øes.
div.p:
Return of Writs.BY vertue of this precept to me directed, I made to come before the Ju≈ø tices under written, at a day and place within contained, all the Writs of A ≈ø≈øi≈øes and Juris, certified in the County of S. under written, before what≈øoever Ju≈øtices, as well by the divers Writs of the L. P. and M. lately King and Queen of England, as by the divers Writs of The Keepers of the Liberties of England by Authority of Pa liame ‚Ä¢ t, together with the Panes, Attachments, Reattachments, and all others helps of A≈ø≈øi≈øes, the Juries, and tho≈øe Certificates what way ≈øoever corcerning.
I have al≈øo made to come before the fore≈øaid Ju≈ø tices to the Gaol of the Keepers afore≈øaid, of the Ca≈øtle of Winch, a≈ø≈ø igned for the delivery out of Pri≈ø ons there, at the day afore≈øaid, all Pri≈øoners in the Gaol afore≈øaid, being together with their Attachments, Re-attachments, and all other helps tho ≈øe pri≈øoners any way concerning, and of the vi≈øne of every Town and place, where the felonie for which the pri≈øoners ≈øtand indicted, appealed or arraigned was committed, as well within the liberties as without, twenty four good and legal men, by whom the truth of the matter may be known and inquired, ≈øuch as are not of any affinity with the pri≈øoners; together with four men, and the chief of the town and place of tho≈øe, to do tho≈øe things which then and there to them of the part of the Keepers of the Liberties of England by Authority of Parliament, now ≈øhall be enjoyned. Publickly al ≈øo have I proclaimed through my ≈øhire, that all tho≈øe who will pur≈ø ue again≈øt tho≈øe pri≈øoners, that then and there they ≈øhall be as ju ≈øt it may be to pro≈øecute. Al≈øo I have made known to all Co ‚Ä¢ oners, Ju ≈ø tices of peace, ≈øene≈øcals of Lords and great men, Bailies of Liberties and Hundreds of the County afore≈øaid: That there they be with their rolles, records, indictments, and other their memorandums, to do tho≈øe things which to their offices belong, as within is commanded me.
The re≈øidue of the execution of this precept, appears in certain≈øcedules to this precept annexed.

And the warrants which the Sheriffe mu≈øt make by vertue of this Precept for the ≈øummoning of the A≈ø≈øi ≈øes to the Bailiffes of Liberties, and Bailiffes of Hundreds, mu≈øt contain in them the whole ≈øub≈øtance of this Precept, but whether it be in Latin or Engli≈øh, it is not materiall, ≈øo that it be in due form: And it is needfull that the Sheriffe keep for him≈øelf a particular note of the names of ≈øuch per≈ø ons as he nominateth
in his warrant to be ≈ø ummoned to ≈øerve in the grand Jurie, and not to leave it to the di≈øcretion of Bailiffes to put in and out whom they li≈øt in that ≈øervice.

div.head: The form of a Warrant.
div.p: ≈ø≈ø. RObert O. E≈øq. Sheriffe of the County afore≈øaid to the Baily of the Liberty of C, or the Baily of the Hundred of A. greeting, By vertue of a certain precept directed to me, I require thee, that thou cau≈øe to come before L.T and L.H. Ju≈øtices of A≈ø≈øi≈øe in the County afore≈øaid, to the A≈ø≈øi≈øes at the Ca≈øtle of Winch, the teuth day of Augu≈øt next to be held, ≈øeveral per≈ø ons under written, to do tho≈øe thing which then and of the part of the Keepers of the Liberties of England now, ≈øhall be to them injoyned. Publiquely al≈øo proclamation make thou, thy whole Bailiwick through, that all tho≈øe who will pur≈øue again ≈øt the pri≈øoners in the Gaol of the Keepers of the Liberties of England, and of the County afore≈øaid, be there again≈øt them as ju≈øt it ≈øhall be to pro≈øecute; Al ≈øo known make to all Coroners, Ju≈øtices of Peace, ≈øene≈øchales of Lords and great men, that then there they be with their Rolls, Records, Indictments, and other memorandums, to do tho≈øe things which to the ‚Ä¢ r ≈øeveral Offices belong‚ñ™ And that thou thy ≈øelf bee≈øt then there, to do all tho≈øe things which to thy office belong, together with this precept under the peril incumbent: Given under the Seal of my office ≈øuch a day and year, &c.

Then here at the end of the Warrant under, the Sheriffe mu≈øt ≈øet down the names and dwelling places of ≈øuch as he will have warned to ≈øerve in the grand Jurie in particular, and keep a note of them, that he may be able to ≈øhew to the Court, if need ≈ø hall require, who he had determined to have returned for that ≈øervice if they had come, and if the fault f ‚Ä¢ ll out to be in the Bailiffe, then he ≈øhall be puni≈øhed, and the Sheriff excu≈ø ed.

div.head: Return of Summons to the Se≈ø≈øions of peace.
div.p: BY vertue of this Writ to me directed, I have cau≈øed to come before the Ju≈øtices under written at the Ca≈ø tle of Winch, &c. within ≈øpecified, the day, year, and place within contained all Con ≈øtables, and Bailies of Hundreds within the County ≈øpeci ≈ø ied. Al≈øo from every of the ≈øaid Liberties and Hundreds, twenty four Jurors to do tho≈ø e things which of the part of the Keepers of the Liberties of England to them then and there ≈øhall be injo ‚Ä¢ ned, And al≈øo I have made known to all Con≈øtables, Bailies of Hundreds of the County within written, that then there they be, having with them all the names of Artificers, Labourers, and ≈øervants in husbandry within the Hundred a fore≈øaid, again≈øt the form of the Statute thereupon put forth and provided, And moreover ≈øufficient proclamation within my Shire have I made, that all tho≈øe, who as well for the Keepers of the Liberties of England, &c. as for them≈øelves, again≈øt ≈øuch like Artificers, Labourers, and ≈øervants any complaints again≈øt the form of the Statute and Ordinance afore≈øaid, will complain or pro≈øecute, that then there they be, their Bills to pro≈øecute, and ju≈øtice there to undergo, if they ≈øee it expedient for them, as within to me is commanded.

The Warrant mu≈øt begin in the ≈øame form as the other, that to come you cau≈øe before the Ju≈øtices of the publick peace in the County afore≈øaid at, &c. all Con≈øtables, &c. according to the ≈øub≈øtance of the matter contained in the Writ, and to conclude it as the other is concluded.
The return of this Writ is ≈øometimes thus.
THe execution of this Writ appears in certain Pannels to this Writ joyned or annexed.

were exacted and appeared not, At my County of S. there held, on Mundav, viz. the tenth day of S. the year afore ≈øaid, the afore≈øaid I.C. and the other defendant within named, the third time were exacted and appeared not, At my County of S.there held, viz. the twelfth day of O. the year afore≈øaid, the afore ≈ø aid I C. & the re≈øt of the defen. within named, the ≈ø ourth time were exacted and appeared not, And at my County of S. there held on Munday, viz. the third day of N afore≈ø aid, the afore≈øaid I.C. and the re≈øt of the defendants within named, the fifth time exacted were and appeared not, therefore I.C and the re≈øt of the defendants within named by judgement of I.W. and W.R.gent. AT my Court, &c. the afore≈øaid I.B. has appeared, and rendred him≈øelf to the pri≈øon of the Keepers of the Liberties of England of the Ca≈øtle of Winch, within the County of S. afore≈øai ‚Ä¢ , and in the ≈øame pri≈øon now remains langui≈ø hing, by divers infirmities withheld, ≈øo that becau≈øe of the weakne≈øs of his body and danger of death he cannot be carried, and therefore the body of I.B. afore≈øaid, before the Ju≈øtices within written at the day and place within contained, for the pre≈øent have I cannot, according to the form of this Writ.

div.head: Return of the exigent where one renders him≈øelf, another brings a Super≈øed. the third is dead, and the fourth waved.
div.p: BY virtue, &c. at my County of S. there held on Munday, viz. the tenth day of A. the year afore≈øaid, I H. R.S. A.C. and D.P. were the fifth time exacted, and the afore≈øaid R.S. rendred him≈øelf to the pri≈øon of the Keepers of the Liberties of England, &c. of the Ca≈øtle of Winch, in the County afore≈øaid, who≈øe body before the Ju ≈ø tices within written, at the day and place within contained ready I have, to do that which the Writ afore≈øaid demands and requires, and the afore ≈øaid D. P. brought me the Writ, &c. of Super≈øed, annexed to this Writ, ≈øo that as to him farther proceed I could not, and the afore≈øaid I.H.dead is, and the afore≈øaid A.C. waved, Therefore by the judgement of I.W. and W.R.Coroners of, &c. of the County afore≈øaid, the afore≈øaid I.H. is outlawed, and A.C.waved.

div.head: Return of allowance.
div.p: THere were allowed to him four days, at which the within named T.C. exacted was and appeared not, and further by vertue o ‚Ä¢ this Writ at my County held at the Ca≈øtle of Winch, in the County of T. within written Munday, viz. the eight day of N. the year, &c. the afore≈øaid D. the fifth time exacted was, and appeared not, Therefore by judgement, &c. as above, he is outlawed.

Coroners of the Commonwealth of the County afore≈øaid, further proceed he could not, and then upon this return, the Coroners will be fined for every Writ, unle≈øs they can make a good excu≈øe.

written as by the Indenture bearing date the ≈øame day and year, more fully is manife≈øt, and appears, of our Me≈ø≈ø uage or farm with the appurtenances, ≈øcituate, lying and being in L. in the Pari ≈øh of F. within my Shire, called or known by the name of B. together with all and ≈øingular Lands, Medowes, Pa≈øtures, Woods, underwoo ‚Ä¢ s waters, &c. with all their appurtenances, ≈øcituate lying and being within the Village of the Pari≈øh and fields of F. afore≈ø aid and O. viz. in my Shire, And the afore≈ø aid demi≈øe, and all and the whole right, ≈øtate, title, term of years, po≈ø ≈øe ≈ø≈øion and demand which the ≈øaid I.H. now has, of and in the afore≈ø aid premi≈ø≈øes, by vertue or vigor of the ≈øame demi≈øe and grant, or otherwi≈øe, to ≈øale I have expo≈øed and ≈øold to a certain P.H. gent. for the ≈øum of ≈øeventy ≈øix pounds thirteen ≈ø hillings four pence, and al≈øo I have made execution of the other goods and Chattels of the afore≈øaid I H. to the value of ≈øixty five pounds ≈øix ≈øhillings eight pence, which ≈øums of monies ≈øo in form fore≈øaid by me levied, in the whole amount to the ≈øum of one hundred thirty two pounds twleve ≈øhillings, and tho ≈øe ≈øums before the Keepers of the Liberties of England, &c. at the day and place within contained I have ready, to render to the within named E.P. and I. his wife in part of ≈øatisfaction of their lo≈ø≈øes within written, as by this Writ within to me is commanded, and that the afore≈øaid I.H. no other or more goods or Chattels in my ≈øhire has, whence the re≈øidue of the afore≈øaid debt of one hundred ≈øixty five pounds ≈øix ≈øhilings two pence, rai ≈øe or levie I may, according to the exigent of this Writ.

I R.O. E≈øq. Sher. of the County of S. to the Keepers of the Liberties of England, &c. at the day and place in this Writ to this ≈øcedule annexed, contained certifie, that before the coming of this Writ, A.O. in the ≈øaid Writ named was taken within the County afore≈øaid by W.A. E≈øq. lately Sher. of the County afore≈øaid, and in the pri≈øon, &c. of the Ca≈øtle of Winch. in the County afore≈øaid, ≈øafely under the cu≈øtody of the ≈øame lately Sher. detained, by vertue of a certain Writ of the ≈øaid Keepers of the Liberties of England of Cap. again≈øt the ≈ø aid A. gent. witne≈øs at We≈øtmin≈øter,
the ninth day of Oct. the year, &c. and return before the Ju≈ø tices of the Common Bench at We≈øt. the day of Saint Martin, fifteen dayes then next following, to ≈øatisfie T.D. Gent. as well of a certain debt of forty pounds, as of thirty ≈øhillings for damages, of which the ≈øame A. before the Ju≈øtices at We≈øt. convict was, The body of which A. ≈øo taken and in pri≈øon afore≈øaid, under the cu≈øtody of the ≈øaid lately Sher. for that occa≈øion being determined, I the afore≈øaid R.O. now Sher. of the County afore ≈øaid, received o ‚Ä¢ the afore ≈øaid lately Sher. in his going out of his Office, and his body, by me of the afore≈øaid lately Sher. So received in pri≈øon afore ≈øaid, ≈øafely to be kept have I cau≈øed, untill after, viz. the tenth day of December the year, &c. I received a certain Writ of the ≈øaid Keepers, &c. of Super≈øedeas to me directed the Tenor of which Writ follows in the≈øe words, The Keepers, &c. by vertue of which Writ of Super≈ø. becau≈øe there was not any other cau≈ø e to detain the afore≈øaid A. the ≈øaid A. to go at la ‚Ä¢ ge I ≈ø uffered, The ≈øaid Writ of Capias ad ≈øatisfaciendum notwith ≈øtanding, as by the ≈øaid Writ of Super≈øedeas to me thence was commanded, Therefore the body of the ≈øaid A. before the Keepers at the day and place, in the ≈øaid Writ to this ≈øcedule annexed contained, ready to have I cannot, as the ≈øame Writ wills and requires.

div.p:
AN Inqui≈øition by Indenture taken at B. in the County afore≈øaid, the tenth day of I. the year, &c. before me R.O. E≈øq. Sher. of the County a ‚Ä¢ ore≈øaid, By vertue of the Writ of the Keepers of the Liberties of England to me directed, and to this Inqui ≈ø ition annexed, By the Oath of T B.&c (and ≈øo on to twelve more at lea≈øt) who ≈øay on their Oath, that B.C. in the Writ afore≈øaid, named ≈øuch a day and year, &c. was ≈øei ≈øed in his d ‚Ä¢ me≈øne as of Fee, of and in one Me≈ø≈øuage called, &c with the appurtenances, lying and being in the City of Winch afore≈øaid; now in the occupation of A.G. widow of the clear yearly value in all i ≈ø ≈øues ov ‚Ä¢ r and above the repri≈øes forty ≈øhillings, And al≈ø o o ‚Ä¢ and in one Garden with the appurtenances, called, &c. in the City and County afore≈øaid, of the clear yearly value in all i≈ø≈øues over and above the repri≈øes of twenty ≈øhillings, and al≈øo of and in one other Me≈ø≈øuage with the appurtenances in the County and City afore≈øaid, ≈ø cituate lying and being near the Church there, called Saint Clements Church, lately the land of a certaine R.A. decea≈øed, now in the occupation
of B.C. or his a≈ø≈øignes, together with all the gardens and aedifices to the ≈øame Me≈ø≈øuage belonging or appertaining of the clear yearly vaelue in all i≈ø≈øues over and above the repri≈øes of five pounds, And al≈øo of and in one other Me≈ø≈øuage called, &c. in the City and County afore≈øaid, in the tenure of the afore≈øaidB.C. of the clear yearly value in all i≈ø ≈øues over and above the repri ≈øes of ten ≈øhillings, which all and ≈øingular the afore≈øaid B.C. lately purcha ≈øed to him and his heirs of certain N.S. and A.L. his wife, one of the daughters of E. coheir of the ≈ø aid R.A. which Me≈ø≈øuage in the tenure of the afore ≈øaid B.C. together with a garden to the ≈øame Me≈ø≈øuage lying and belonging, with all and ≈øingular the appurtenances, for the mediety of all the Lands and Tenements afore≈øaid, I the afore≈øaid Sher. have cau≈øed to be delivered to R.S. in the Writ afore≈øaid named, to be held to him and his a≈ø≈øignes, according to the form of the Statute thence provided as his Frank-tenement, untill his debt of one hundred pounds together with his dammages in the Writ afore≈øaid mentioned, fully thence he ≈øhall have levyed, as the Writ afore≈øaid wills and requires, And further the Jurors afore≈ø aid on their Oath afore≈øaid ≈øay, that the afore≈ø aid B.C. no other or more has, or after the recogni≈ø ance of the debt afore≈øaid, had goods or Chattels, Lands or Tenements, in the County afore ≈øaid within their knowledge: in Te≈øtimony of which as well I the afore≈øaid Sh ‚Ä¢ r as the Jurors aforefaid to this inqui≈øition our ≈øeals alternately have put the day of A. and place above ≈øaid, &c.

AN Inqui≈øition by Indenture taken at the City of Winche ≈øter in the County afore≈øaid, the twelfth day of January, the year, &c. before me R.O. E≈øq Sher. of the County afore≈øaid, By vertue of a Writ of the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament to me directed, and to this Inqui≈øition annexed by Oath of T.B. &c (as above) who ≈øay upon their Oath, the W.W. in the Writ afore≈øaid named the day of the recogni ≈ø ance of the debt in the ≈øame Writ ≈øpecified, was ≈øei≈øed in his deme≈øne as of fee, of and in the manner of A. in the County afore≈øaid, of the clear yearly value in all i≈ø≈øues, over and above the repri ≈øes 100. l. and of and in the manner of C. in the County afore≈øaid, of the clear yearly value in all i≈ø≈øues over and above the repri≈øes 100. l. and further, the Jurors afore≈øaid on their Oath afore≈øaid ≈øay, that the afore≈øaid W.W. the day of the reconu≈øance of the debt afore≈øaid, or at any time after no goods or Chatte ‚Ä¢ s had, nor other or more Lands or Tenements in the County afore≈øaid, within their knowledge, which extended, apprized, or into the hands of the ≈øaid Keepers taken or ≈øei≈ø ed may be, which Mannors, Lands, and Tenements afore≈øaid with the appurtenances, I the afore≈øaid Sher, the day of the taking of this Inqui≈øition took into the hands of the ≈øaid Keepers, by extent afore≈ø aid. In Te≈øtimony of which, as well I the afore ≈øaid Sher. as the Jurors afore≈øaid to this Inqui≈øition our Seals alternately have put, the day, year, and place above ≈øaid, &c.

AN Inqui≈øition &c, Who ≈øay on their Oath a cre≈øaid, that H.A. and I. his wife, in the ≈øame Writ named, have made wa≈ø t, ≈øale and de≈øtruction in all things in that Writ ≈øpecified, viz by ≈øuffering one Hall o ‚Ä¢ the price of 30.s. two Chambers of the price of 3. l. one Stable of the price of twenty ≈øhillings, to be uncovered for default of reparation of the ≈ø ame hou≈øes, and by tempe≈øts with rain upon them de≈øcending,
became rotten and corrupt, &c. again≈øt the form of the provi≈ø ion in the ≈øame Writ contained, and further, the ≈øaid Jurors on their Oath afore≈øaid ≈ø ay, that the afore≈øaid A. and I. no other nor more wa≈øte, ≈øale, or de≈ø truction have made, in the hou≈øes afore≈øaid, in Te≈øtimony of which, &c. as above.

And that ≈ø ix years and three quarters of one year are pa≈ø≈øed, from the time of the death of W.K. af re≈øaid, And that the within named I.D. has ≈øu≈øtained damages by occa≈øion of her dower within ≈ø pecified, to the value of ten pounds, in Te≈øtimony of which, &c. as above

div.head: Return of Scire fac. ≈øcire fec.
div.p: BY vertue of this Writ to me directed by A.B. and C.D. good and lawfull men of my Shire, I have made to know to A.D.that he be before the Ju≈øtices of the Common bench, or before the Keepers of the Liberties of England, &c, or before the Barons of the E≈øchequer at the day and place within contained, to ≈ø hew and propound, if what for him≈øelf he has or to ≈øay knows why, &c. (according to the matter contained in the Writ) As within to me is commanded.

div.p: The within named A.B. has nothing in my Shire by which him I might make know, nor is he ≈øound in it.

div.head: Return of Deve≈øtavit again≈øt exec.
div.p:
BY vertue of this Writ to me directed, I have taken into my hands diver≈øe goods and Chattels which were to H.S. at the time of his death, in the hands of the with in named R.O. andK. hi ‚Ä¢ wife exec. of the Te≈ø tament of the a≈øor ≈øaid H. to be admini≈øtred, being to the value of thirty ≈ø even pounds parcel of the debt within written, which goods and Chattels remain in my cu≈ø tody for default of buyers, and further to the Ju≈øtices within written, I certifie, that the afore ≈øaid R.O. and K. divers goods and Chattels which were to the ≈øaid H. at the time of his death, to the value of the ‚Ä¢ e≈øidue of the debt, and the dammages within ≈øpecified
≈øold and wa≈øted, and the monies thence ari≈øing to their proper u≈øes converted, ≈øo that the re≈øidue of the debt and dammages within ≈ø pecified, of the goods and Chattels of the ≈øame H.S. Levie or execute I cannot, And further to the Ju≈øtices a fore ≈øaid I certifie, that the afore≈øaid R.O. and K. his wife, no goods have or Chattels of their goods, and Chattels proper, within my Shire whence the re ≈øidue of the debt and the dammages within ≈ø pecified, or any parcell thence execute I may, as within to me is commanded.
