div.p: Then count them.

This done, then command the Bailiff to make Proclamation, and ≈øay thus after the Steward: You good men that are impannelled to inquire for the keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, and for the Lord of this Leet or Law-day, draw neer and hear your charge, and the Court commandeth all others to keep ≈øilence while≈øt the charge is given, upon pain of impri≈øonment.

div.head: An exhortation to the Jury before the charge.
div.p:
MY ma≈øters you that be ≈øworn, before I enter to give you your charge, I ≈øhall exhort you in the fear of God, fir≈øt of all to remember your duties to Almighty God, next to the keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliament, and la ≈øtly to the Lord of this Leet or Law-day, and therein to have a ≈øpecial regard for the good of the Commonwealth, here within the precinct of the Leet or Law- day. God delivered to his ≈øervant Mo≈øes in the Mount Sinai ten Laws or Commandments, which are divided into two tables, the four fir≈øt which are the fir≈øt table, do teach us our duties to God, the other ≈øix which are the ≈øecond table, do teach us our duties one towards another: as the body of man is ≈øubject to many ≈øickne≈ø≈øes and di≈øea≈øes, ≈øo the Commonwealth is ≈øubject to many mi≈øchiefs and inconveniences, and as the one is often curable by phy≈øick, ≈øo the other is
to be redre≈ø≈øed and reformed by the due execution of Laws which are as the ≈øinews of the Commonwealth, to keep it in good order, and the execution of the Law is the life of the Law, otherwi≈øe it is but as a dead thing, and therefore good Rulers and Magi≈ø trates are ≈øaid to be as fo≈øtering fathers and mothers to the Commonwealth, as well as natural parents are to their own children, and the people that honor their Governors, the child that honoreth his parents, and the ≈øervant that honoreth his or her ma≈øter or mi≈øtris, ought to honor them of duty in ≈øinglene≈øs of heart, and not for fear of puni ≈øhment, or hope of reward.

England long ≈øince was divided into Counties, and ≈øo into Hundreds, Ridings, Lathes, Leets, and Wapentakes, which are all one in effect, though they differ in name according to the cu≈ø tome of every Country. And there is no man living within this Nation, but he is re≈øident and abiding within the precinct of ≈ø ome one of the≈øe and there he ought to appear twice every yeer, if he be not otherwi≈øe priviledged by his place or office, and if any wrong be done unto any man under the value of forty ≈øhillings, there he ought to have redre≈øs, and not el≈øwhere. Then the≈øe Laws were afterwards confirmed by the Statute of Mar ‚Ä¢ ebridge ca. 38. before the making of which Statute, a Lord of a Leet or Law day might have kept as many Leets or Law-days in a yeer as he would, and as few. But by that Statute men were limited and appointed to keep but two every yeer, viz. one within a moneth of Ea≈øter, and the other within a moneth of Michaelmas. And afterwards becau ≈ø e men were of ≈øundry opinions, what things were inquirable at Leets or Law- days, and what were not, there was another Statute Law made in the ≈øeventeenth yeer of E. 2. by which it appeareth what things are inquirable at a Leer or Lawday, and what are not; and ≈øithence that time there have been divers other Statutes made, whereby divers other Articles are inquirable at Leets or Law- days, which before the making of the Statutes were not. Now therefore
con≈øidering that the≈øe Leets or Law-dayes were fir≈øt ordained for the cau≈øes already delivered by me unto you, con ≈ø idering al≈øo, that the redre≈øs of all wrongs, and the puni≈øhment of all offendors here within the precinct of this Leet or Law-day re≈øteth in you who are here e≈øpecially elected, ≈øworn and put in tru≈øt as the mo ≈øt meete≈øt, and worthie≈øt men within the precinct of this Court for that ≈ø ervice, it therefore behooveth you to have a ≈øpecial regard to your oathes therein that you may the better perform the tru≈øt which is repo≈øed in you, for now it is your parts and duties to try right from wrong, and truth from fal≈øhood, and to puni≈øh off ‚Ä¢ ndors, and to defend the innocent. The Prophet „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ teacheth you a good le≈ø≈øon, and that is this,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ his ≈øaith he, in veritate, in judic & in Ju≈øticia & amovere morem &
‚Ä¢ merem odium & ≈øpem, that is, you mu≈øt ≈ø wear in truth, judgement and ju≈øtice, not regarding the ≈øub≈øtance, authority or power of a rich man, nor the imbecility or poverty of a poor man, but rather you mu≈øt follow the rule of that wi≈øe Phylo≈øopher Plato, who ≈øaith thus, That Ju≈øtume≈øt judicium ubi non per≈øona ≈øed opera con≈ø iderant. that is a right wi≈øe judgement, where the per≈øon of a man is not regarded, but his offence; Et ex co ‚Ä¢ dibus v ‚Ä¢ ≈øtris omnent affectionem expellite, & memores e≈øtore quantas minas deus in ≈øtituit pro Juramenti violat. You mu≈øt if you would do as you ought to do, remove all affection out of your mindes, and call to remembrance what threatnings God hath laid upon ≈øuch as have violated their oaths, for it is written in the 14. Chap. of Leviticus,thus, Qui bla ≈øphemat nomen Dom. morte morietur, that is, he that bla≈ø phemeth the name of God ≈øhal die the death; and in the fifth Cha ‚Ä¢ ter of the Acts of the Apo≈øtles, it was ≈ø aid to Ananias and Saph ‚Ä¢ ra, Non vives qui locutus es mendac & confe ≈øtim occi≈øi fue ‚Ä¢ unt pro men ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ c in vendend. Agr. that is, it was told them that they ≈øhould not live any longer becau≈øe they have dealt deceitfully, and made a lie to colour their deceit in ≈øelling of a field, and they were pre ≈øently ≈ølain for it: if God did then ≈øo puni≈øh them for making of a lie, which thing is ≈øo common
now a dayes, what will he do ‚Ä¢ o them which do not ≈øtick to lie and wilfully for≈ø wear them≈ø elves? therefore it behoves us to beware and to learn to be warned by other mens harms, le≈øt we fall into the like judgement of God our ≈ø elves. In doing well, and performing your duties in this ≈øervice which you are to take in hand, you ≈øhall not only plea ≈øe God therein greatly, and do the Keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliament, and the Lord of this Leet good ≈øervice; but you ≈øhall al≈øo do good to your ≈øelves and to your po≈øterities, and therein cau≈øe the Commonwealth to ≈ølori≈øh and increa≈øe in godline≈øs and piety; but on the contrary part if you ≈øhall be remi≈øs and carele≈øs in doing of your duties, therein you ≈øhall not only offend God very greatly, and incurr the danger of the Laws of England, but you ≈øhall al≈øo embolden and incourage wicked and lew'd per≈øons to continue ≈øtill in their own wickedne ≈ø s, and to go forward √† mal ‚Ä¢ adpejus, and ≈øo to draw one ≈øin upon ≈ø in, as it were with cartropes, to their utter ruine and de≈ø trection. And I would have you to know, that if I find you carele≈øs and negligent in this ≈ø ervice, I may then by the law impannel another Jury to inquire of your concealements, the which if they ≈øhall finde, then may I ≈øet ≈øuch fines upon you as I ≈øhall think fit, according to the quality of your offence. But I hope that you will give me no ≈øuch occa≈øion, but rather that you will duly and truly inquire of and pre≈øent all ≈øuch things as I ≈øhall give you in charge.
And ≈øo I will here cea≈øe to trouble you any further by way of exhortaion, and proceed as God ≈øhall inable me and your patience to the particulars of your charge.

Your charge will be ≈øomewhat long and tedious, and ≈øtandeth upon many parts, but I will make it as ≈øhort as I can, and reduce it into five chief heads o ‚Ä¢ parts, viz.
Petty Trea≈øons.
Felonies by Statute Law.
Felonies by the Common Law.
Offences upon divers Statutes.
Laws and common annoizances.
And ≈øo of the≈øe in their order.

div.head: Petty Trea≈øon.
div.p: It is petty Trea≈øon for a woman to kill her hu≈øband, or a Clerke his Ordinary, and the puni≈øhment for the≈øe offences, is death, and lo≈øs of lands and goods.

div.head: Mi≈øpri≈øion of Trea≈øon.
div.p: Next to this is mi≈ø pri≈øion of Trea≈øon, and that is, when any one knows of the Trea≈øon afore≈øaid, or any of them, and concealeth it twenty four hours, after knowledge thereof had, the puni≈øhment for this offence is lo≈øs of goods and chattels for ever, and of lands during life and perpetual impri≈øonment.

div.head: Felonies by Statute Law, Rape.
div.p: 18. E. 2. & 1. H. 7.Next you ≈øhall inquire of Felonies by Statute Law, and therein fir≈øt of Rapes, and that is if any man have ravi≈øhed, or had carnal knowledge of any womans body again≈øt her will, or hath ≈øtolne or carried away any widow or maide again≈øt their wils, and their friends, though it was done to the intent to marry them, yet it is felony, and the offendor therein ≈øhall ≈øuffer death, and lo≈øe his lands and goods for it.

1. H. 7.Next you ≈øhall enquire of hunters by night, in any forre≈øt, park, cha≈øe, or warren, with vi ≈øards di≈øgui≈øed, to the intent not to be known, if they be apprehended and deny it afore a Ju≈øtice of Peace upon their examination, it is felony, but if they confe≈øs it, it is then but a tre≈øpa≈ø s, and ≈øo finable.

div.head: Defacers of a mans Phi≈ønomy.
div.p: Next you ≈øhall inquire if any man or woman hath defaced anothers phi≈ønomy in putting wilfully his or her eyes out, or cutting out of his or her tongue, either of both, is felony, and the offender ≈øhall ≈øuffer death, and lo≈øe lands and goods, 5. H. 7.

div.head: Servants imbe≈ø≈øelling their ma≈øters goods.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of ≈øervants which have imbe≈ø≈øelled their ma≈øters or their mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes goods, being put in tru≈øt therewith, if it amount to xl. s. and upwards, it is fellony. 21. H. ca. 7. and the offenders ≈øhall ≈øuffer death in this ca≈øe, and lo≈øe lands and goods.

div.head: Witches and Sorcerers.
div.p: Al≈øo ye ≈øhall inquire of Witches and Sorcerers, for if any of them have killed or de≈øtroyed any man, woman, or child, with Witchcraft or Sorcery, it is in them felony, and the offendor ≈øhall lo ≈øe both his lands and goods for it, 5. El.

div.head: Rebellions.
div.p:
1. &. 5. Eli.Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of Rebellions, Riots, Routs, and unlawful a≈ø≈ø emblies, and that is where per≈øons to
the number of twelve or upwards, do with ≈øorce unlawfully go about to alter Laws made by Act of Parliament, or any other Laws of this Nation, and being requ ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed by the Keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliament Officers, upon Proclamation to return to their dewllings, and yet do remain together by the ≈øpace of one hour after ≈øuch Proclamation made, or after do attempt the like thing, it is ≈øelony, 1.
‚Ä¢ uz. And ≈øo it is where any ≈øuch number have a≈ø≈øembl ‚Ä¢ d them≈øelves together to break, or digg up, or ca≈øt down any p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es, hedges, ditches, or other inclo≈øures, or to pul ‚Ä¢ up any pondheads. conduits, or pipes, to the intent to kill or de≈øtroy any Deer in any Park, Conies in any W ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ren or Fi≈øh in any Fi≈øh-ponds, or have fired my dwelling hou≈øe, or any barn, wherein any Corn was ≈øaid, or any
‚Ä¢ ick of Corn, or ring any Bell. ≈øound any Tru ‚Ä¢ p ‚Ä¢ t, o ‚Ä¢ D ‚Ä¢ u ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , winde any Horn fire any Beacon, or ≈øpeak any Rebellious words, or bring or ≈øend any money, vict ‚Ä¢ al, harne ≈øs, or weapon to any ≈øuch rebellious per≈øons, is felony, and the offenders herein ≈øhall ≈øuffer death, and lo≈øe lands and goods. Al≈øo there are concealers of the ≈øe offe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es, the which if they conceal four and twenty hours, they are to have nine moneths impri≈ø onment, without baile or mainpri≈øe; and Farmers and Copiholders ought to lo≈øe their Farms and Copiholds if they refu≈øe to go to ≈øuppre≈øs ≈øuch rebellion as is afore ≈øaid.

div.head: Felonies by the Common Law.
div.p: Next, you ≈øhall inquire of felonies by the Common Law, and that is where any doth ≈øt ‚Ä¢ al to the value of twelve pence or upwards, or doth ≈øteal any marked Swans, or their ≈øignet, or their eggs, or ‚Ä¢ ame Deer, or rob Churches, Chappels, Pigeon-hou≈øes, or dwelling-hou≈øes, or any upon the high way, though he take but the worth of a penny from him, it is felony, and the offendor ≈øhall die for it, and lo ≈øe his lands and goods, and ≈øo ≈øhall their acce≈ø≈øary.

div.head: Petty Larceny.
div.p: 18. Ed. 2.Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of Petty Larceny, and tho≈øe be ≈øuch as ≈øteal pigs, gee ≈øe, hens, chickins, corn out of fields, clothes from hedges, or out of windows, rob orchards, or go in theeves me≈ø≈øages: the offendors herein are to have corporal puni ≈øhment, and ≈øo their acce≈ø≈øaries: but they forfeit their goods if they have any.

Now I mu≈øt tell you that all tho≈øe offences which I have already ≈øpoken of unto you, are but onely to be here inquired of and pre≈øented, but not here puni≈ø hed, but they are to be puni≈øhed by the Ju≈øtices of the ≈øhire upon certificate made thereof by the Steward of a Leet or Law day.
But now follow the offences which are both here to be inquired of, pre≈øented, and puni≈øhed.

div.head: Affraies and blood-≈øheds.
div.p: And therefore becau ≈øe man is the worthye≈øt creature that God made, I will fir≈øt begin to put you in remembrance of the Law made for his ≈øafety and pre≈øervation. You ≈øhall therefore fir≈øt inquire if any man within your inquiry have broken the peace, or made any affray or blood≈øhed: if any have offended herein, you mu≈øt pre≈øent him or them, and the manner of it, with what weapon, for that it is forfeit to the Lord of this Leet, and the offendor or offendors are to be fined for ≈øuch offence.

div.head: Hue and Cry.
div.p:
Next you ≈øhall inquire whether hue and cry after theeves and robbers have been duely pur≈øued and followed as they ought to have been or no; if not, then you
mu≈øt pre≈øent him or them which made default therein, for he forfeits five pound.

div.head: Con≈øtables and Tythingmen to puni≈øh Rogues.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire how Con≈øtables and Thythingmen have executed their offices in puni≈øhing of rogues, vagabonds, and ≈øturdy beggers which have come within their charge; for if they have been remi≈øs therein, then they ought to lo≈øe twenty ≈øhillings for every default. No man or woman may be ≈øuffered to beg by the Law nor no man or woman may give any almes, upon pain of ten ≈øhillings for every time they give.

div.head: Who are ≈øaid to be Rogues.
div.p: The≈øe per≈øons by particular are ≈øaid to be by the ≈øtatute rogues, viz. Procters of Spittlehou≈øes, Parent- gatherers, or Collectors for Gaoles, pri≈øons, or Ho≈øpitals, Fencers, Bearwards, common Plaiers of enterludes, Min≈øtriles wandring abroad, Gla≈øs-men, Saylers, Souldiers, Schollers, and all other idle per≈øons which go about begging.

div.head: Stocks in every Tything.
div.p: Al≈øo for the puni≈øhment of the≈øe offendors, you ≈øhall inquire if there be in every tything a paire of ≈øtocks, according as there ought to be by the ≈øtatute or no: if there be not, then the tything do lo≈øe five pound.

div.head: Artillery to be maintained.
div.p:
33. H. 8. cap. 9.Al ≈øo you ≈øhall inquire whether every one have Bow and Arrows according to the Statute, or no; for every man-child from ≈øeven yeers old to
≈øeventeen ought to have a Bow and two Arrows, and every man from ≈ø eventeen to three≈øcore ought to have a bow and four Arrows, upon pain of ≈øix ≈øhillings eight pence for every default; and parents ought to provide them for their children, and ma≈øters for their ≈øervants with their wages, or el≈øe they ought to undergo the penalty thereof.

div.head: Buts in every Tything.
div.p: 33. H. 8.And al≈øo for the exerci≈øe of Archers in ≈øhooting at times convenient, there ought to be Buts made in every Tything, Village, and Hamlet, or el≈ø e the Tything, Village, or hamlet ought to lo≈øe twenty ≈øhillings for every three moneths wanting Buts there.

div.head: Playes or Games.
div.p: 33. H. 8.Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire if any Alehou≈øe-keeper or other per≈øon do keep any unlawful games in his or their hou≈øe or hou≈øes or el≈øewhere, as cards, dice, tables, loggets, quoits, bowles, or ≈øuch like, in this ca≈øe the hou≈øe- keeper lo≈øeth for every day fourty ≈øhillings, and every player ≈øix ≈ø hillings eight pence for every time.

Al≈øo Con≈øtables ought to ≈øearch monethly for ≈øuch unlawful ga ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es and di≈øorders in Ale-hou≈øes upon pain of fourty ≈øhillings, and they may arre≈øt ≈øuch as they find playing at unlawful games, and commit them to ward untill they put in ≈øureties not to play any more at any unlawful game.

No man may play at any unlawful game in≈øatiably, unle≈øs he can d ‚Ä¢ ≈øpend a hundred pound per annum in lands, fees, or offices, for life, at the lea≈øt: and he may not play neither in any open place where every one that will may ≈øee him, but in his hou≈øe,
‚Ä¢ or in his Orchard or Garden upon pain of ≈øix ≈øhillings eight pence for every time, except in the Chri≈øtmas time; for then all men may play. 33. H. 8.

div.head: Shooting in Guns.
div.p: 33. H. 2. cap. 6.Next you ≈øhall enquire of ≈øuch as ≈øhoot in hand-guns, or cro≈øs-bows; for no man may ≈øhoot in them unle ≈øs he can di≈øpend a hundred pound per annum in lands, tenements, offices, annuities, or fees, neither may tho≈øe ≈øhoot at any Phe≈øant, Partridge, Herne, Duck, Mallard, Hou≈øe-dove, Pigeon, Wigeon, Teal, or Heath-cock, upon pain of ten pound for every ≈ø hoot.

Al≈øo by another Law made 1. Jac. Reg. he that ≈øhoots in a Gun, Cro ≈øs-bow, or long-bow at any of the fowles afore≈øaid, or at any Hare or Deer, and cannot di≈øpend ten pound yeerly in lands, nor is worth two hundred pound in goods, ≈ø hall forfeit twenty ≈øhillings for every ≈øhoot, which ≈øhall be to the u≈øe of the poor of the Pari≈øh where ≈øuch offence is committed, if the ≈øame be either confe ≈ø≈øed or proved by two witne≈ø≈øes, or el≈øe if the offendor be not able to pay the ≈øaid penalty, or will not, then he mu≈øt have three moneths impri≈øonment without baile or mainpri≈øe. But if ≈øuch offender can di≈øpend ten pound per ann. or more, then he ≈øhall forfeit fourty ≈øhillings to the u≈øe afore ≈øaid, and find ≈øufficient ≈øureties that he ≈øhall offend therein no more.
But by the ≈øame law all ≈øuch as have plackards or licences, may kill Crows, Rooks, Choghes, Pyes, Ieyes, Ringdoves, and other ≈ømall birds for Hawks meat only, with a gun, or otherwi≈øe.

Next you ≈øhall inquire whether your high wayes be ≈øufficiently amended and made pa≈ø ≈øable, as they ought to be or no, for to that end and purpo≈øe there ought to be two Supervi≈øors cho ≈øen in every Pari≈øh, between Ea≈øter and Mid≈øomer by the Con ≈øtables and Churchwardens, and there ought to be ≈øix dayes appointed for amending of the high wayes, eight hours every day, upon pain of twenty ≈øhillings to be lo≈øt by the Supervi≈øors. And every one that hath a cart ought to ≈øend two able men with it,
with tooles fit for that ≈ø ervice, or el≈øe to lo≈øe ten ≈øhillings for every day wanting, and every hou ≈øholder ought to find an able man for that ≈øervice, or el≈øe to lo≈øe twelve pence for every day wanting. And they ought mo≈øt chiefly to amend the wayes leading to market Towns, and they may gather ≈øtones in any mans ground, and al≈øo digg pits of ten yards ≈øquare in any mans ≈øeveral for ≈øtones and rubbi≈øh (if it be needful) filling the ≈øame up again, without danger of Law. And they mu≈øt turn ≈øprings, if they can out of the high wayes; and trees and hedges which hang over the publike high wayes, mu≈øt be cut and ≈øhreded upon pain of ten ≈ø hillings for every default.

div.head: Purpre≈øtures and A≈ø≈øarts.
div.p: 18. E. 2.Next you ≈øhall inquire of Purpre≈øtures and A≈ø≈øarts, and that is where any Wall, Hedge, Ditch, or Hou≈øe is ≈øet, levyed, or abated in the publike high way, or any watercour≈øe ≈øtooped or turned into the high way to hinder the pa ≈ø≈øage of the weal publike, or any way annoy them.

div.head: Bonds and markes.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire whether any mear ≈øtones or ≈øtakes, bonds or markes, between this Lord≈øhip and any other, or between tenant and tenant, hath been removed ≈øince the la≈øt law day, or before, and not ≈øet in the u≈øual place again, if there be any which have offended herein, you mu≈øt pre≈øent them.

div.head: High-wayes or foot-≈øteps ≈øtopped up.
div.p:
Al≈øo if any high wayes or foot pathes to Church, Mill, or Market be ≈øtopped or hedged up, which have been accu≈øtomed to lie open, you mu≈øt pre≈øent him or them which ≈øhut it up, for the people of the Commonwealth
mu≈øt not be ≈øtopped of his lawful pa≈ø≈øage to Church, mill, or market.

div.head: Common Bridges broken.
div.p: Al≈øo if any common Bridges over Common Streams be broken, that by rea≈øon thereof the people of the Commonwealth cannot pa ≈øs about their affaires and bu≈øine≈ø≈øes, you mu≈øt pre≈øent tho≈øe which ought to make them, upon a pain.

div.head: Common pounds broken.
div.p: And al≈øo if common pounds be broken ≈øo that they will hold no di≈øtre≈øs that is brought to them untill they be delivered thence by order of Law, you mu≈øt pre≈øent tho≈øe which ought to make ≈ø uch pounds, upon a pain.

div.head: Sleepers by day, and walkers by night.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of Sleepers by day, and walkers by night, to ≈øteal and purloin other mens goods and Conies out of Warrens, Fi≈øh out of mens ≈øeveral ponds or Waters, Hens from Henrou≈ø e, or any other thing what≈øoever, for they are ill members in a Commonwealth, and de≈øerve puni≈øhment, therefore if you know any ≈øuch pre≈ø ent them.

div.head: Eves-droppers.
div.p: Al ≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of Eves-droppers, and tho≈øe are ≈øuch as by night ≈øtand or lye harkening under wa ‚Ä¢ s or windows of other mens, to hear what is ≈øaid in another mans hou≈øe, to the end to ≈øet debate and di≈ø≈øention between neighbors, which is a very ill office, therefore if you know any ≈øuch, pre≈øent them.

div.head: Fore≈øtallers, Regraters, and Ingro≈ø≈øers.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of Fore≈øtallers, Regraters, and Ingro≈ø≈øers, evil members in a Commonwealth.

A Fore≈øtaller is he which buyeth or cau≈øeth to be bought any victuals what≈øoever going to any Faire or Market to be ≈øold, and maketh any bargain for the buying thereof before the ≈øame be brought into the Faire or Market, or doth make any motion for the inhancing of the price of any victuals, or doth move or per≈øwade any per≈øon comming to the Faire or Market with victuals, to ab≈øent and forbear his comming hicher with any victual to be ≈øold there.

Regrator is he that getteth into his hands in any Faire or Market, any Corn, Tallow, or Candles, or any dead victual what≈ø oever, brought to any Faire or Market to be ≈øold, and doth ≈øell the ≈ø ame again in any Faire or Market, within four miles next adjoyning thereunto.

An Ingro≈ø≈øer is he or ≈øhe that doth ingro≈øs and get into his or her hands, by buying or promi≈øe taken, other then by demi≈øe, grant, or lea≈øe, of bond or bill, of Corn growing in the Fields, or any other Corn, Grain, Butter, Chee≈øe, Fi≈øh, or any other dead victual what ≈øoever to the intent to ≈øell the ≈øame again for profit.
Their puni≈øhment.For the fir≈øt offence they ought to have two moneths impri≈øonment, without baile or mainpri≈øe, and forfeit the value of the goods bought and ≈øold.
For the ≈øecond offence they ought to have half a yeers impri≈øonment, and to forfeit double the value of the goods bought and ≈øold.

And for the third offence they ought to be ≈øet upon the Pillory, and to lo≈øe all their goods and chattels, and be impri≈ø oned during the Keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliaments plea≈øure.

div.head: Cattel ≈øold with in five weeks.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of ≈øuch as u≈øe to buy Cattel and to ≈øell them again within five weeks, they ought to lo≈øe double the value of their Cattel.

div.head: Of Butchers.
div.p: No Butcher ought to ≈øell in any open Faire or Market, any other victual then that which is good and whole≈øome for mans body, and for rea≈øonable gaines, and not at exce≈ø≈øive prices.

div.head: Shoomakers.
div.p: 5. Eliz.They ought to make their Shooes, and Boots of good and well tanned Leather, and well licoured, curried and ≈øowed, to keep men dry of their leggs and feet.

div.head: Tanners.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of Tanners that have u≈øed the occupation of a Cordwainer, or a Currier, or that hath put any Leather to ≈øale, but red Leather as it came from the Tan-≈øat, or that hath put any Hide or peece of Leather to ≈øale, before it be well dryed, marked, and ≈øorted, and then ≈øold in open market, or that hath tanned any ≈øheep skins.

div.head: Glovers.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire, whether Glovers, or white Tawers of Leather, do make any other ware, than that which is good and ≈øub≈øtantiall, well tawed and dryed, and not rotten nor tainted, and ≈øell the ≈øame at rea≈øonable prices. And a White Tawer may taw no Calfe skins except they be put to him to be tanned, upon pain to loo≈øe for every Calf skin twenty pence.

div.head: Bakers.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire whether the bakers do their duties or not, in making of good and whole≈øome bread for mans body, of ≈øweet corn, and not corrupted, and that they make their bread in weight, according to the price of wheat, in three markets next adjoyning, not changing the a≈ø ≈øi≈øe of bread, but by ≈øix pence in weight in increa≈ø ing or abating, and if they do the contrary, and be thereof duly convicted, then for the fir≈øt, ≈øecond, and third time they ≈øhall be amerced after the quantity of their fault, and ≈øhall lo≈øe from time to time their bread ≈øo found too light in weight, but if they ≈øhall be found faulty herein the fourth time, then they mu ≈øt be ≈øet upon the pillory in open Market, who≈øe puni≈øhment may not be relea≈ø ed for gold or ≈øilver.
Al≈øo a Baker mu≈øt ≈øet his own proper mark jupon every loafe of bread that he maketh and ≈øelleth, to the end that if any bread be faulty in weight, it may be then known in whom the fault is.

div.head: Brewers.
div.p: 5. H. 3.58. E. 3.Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of Brewers, and Tiplers, whether they make good and whol≈øome Ale and Beer for mans body, or not, and ≈ø ell and utter the ≈øame according to the Laws and Statutes of this Nation. And al≈øo they ought not to put out their ≈øign or Ale-≈øtake untill their Ale be a≈ø≈øeyed by the Ale-ta≈ø ter, and then to ≈øell, and not before.

div.head: Fi≈øhers.
div.p:
25. H. 8. ca. 7.31. H. 8. ca. 2.Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of Fi≈øhers, whether they do their duties or no, in bringing to the Market ≈øuch Fi ‚Ä¢ h as good and whol≈øo me for mans body, and not corrup ‚Ä¢ to
or ≈øtinking, and there ≈øell the ≈ø ame at rea≈øonable prices, without taking of any exce≈ø≈ø ive gaines, but onely for every twelve-pence be≈øtowing, one penny cleer gaines over and be≈øides their charges, and if any Fi≈øher ≈øhall do the contrary, then he ≈øhall be grievou≈øly amerced from time to time, and his Fi ≈øh if it be corrupt and ≈øtinking to be taken from him and openly burned in the Market.

Al≈øo no per≈øon may kill or de≈øtroy any yong Fry of Fi≈øh, in what ≈øoever River, fre≈øh or ≈øalt; nor kill or take any Salmon or Trout, or any Pike or Pickeril, not being in length ten inches of cleer Fi≈ø h or more, nor any Barbel except he be twelve inches long in cleer fi≈øh or more, upon pain of twenty ≈øhillings for every fi≈øh ≈øo taken and killed being not of the ≈øeveral lengths afore≈øaid.

Al≈øo no man ought to fi≈øh with any Net or Engine, angling only excepted, but with ≈øuch Net or Trannel as every mea ≈øh ≈øhall be two inches and a halfe wide, except Nets onely to take Loches, Mennas, Butheads, Gudgions, Eeles, and none other Fi≈øh, upon pain of twenty ≈øhillings for every time offending, and lo≈øs of the fi≈øh and the unlawful Net.

div.head: Con≈øpiracy of victualers.
div.p:
Al ≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of the con≈øpiracy of Victualers, and that is where any Butcher, Baker, Brewer, Poulter, or Cook, ≈øhall or do con≈ø pire, promi≈øe, or make oath, that they will not ≈øell their victuals but at certain prices, or if any artifieers, or labourers do con ≈øpire, promi≈øe, or covenant likewi≈øe not to do the work which others have begun, or will do but certain work in a day, or will not work but at certain hours and times, then every ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øo con≈ø piring, promi≈øing, ≈øwearing, and offending, being thereof lawfully convicted, ≈øhall forfeit for the fir≈øt offence ten pound, if he have it to pay, then he mu≈øt pay it within ≈øix dayes after his conviction, or el≈øe he is to have twenty dayes impri≈øonment, and have
onely bread and water for his ≈øu≈øtenance, and for the ≈øecond offence twenty pound to be paid as is afore≈øaid, or el≈øe to ≈øuffer puni≈øhment on the Pillory, and for the third offence, he ≈øhall lo≈øe fourty pound to be paid as is afore ≈øaid, or el≈øe to be ≈øet upon the Pillory, and lo≈øe one of his cars, and ever after to be taken as an infamous per≈øon. 2. E. 6.And if ≈øuch con≈øpiracy ≈øhall happen to be made by any Company or Corporation, they ≈ø hall lo≈øe their Corporation, be≈øides the penalty and the particular puni≈ø hment afore≈øaid.

div.head: Fal≈øe Waights and double Mea≈øures.
div.p: 5 ‚Ä¢ . E. 3.Al≈øo if any within your inquiry, ≈øhall u≈øe any fal≈øe Waights or double mea≈øures in deceiving of the Commonwealth, in buying with a great mea≈øure, and in ≈ø elling with a le≈øs, the offender thereof therein ≈øhall be grievou≈øly puni≈ø hed and impri≈øoned untill he hath made fine with the Keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliament for his offence.

No man ought to ≈øell any corn, ale, bread, or wine, but by a mea≈øure ≈øealed with this letter H. upon pain of forfeiture for the fir≈øt offence ≈øix ≈øhillings eight pence; for the ≈øecond offence thirteen ≈øhillings four pence, and for the third offence, twenty ≈ø hillings and to be ≈øet on the Pillory, to the example of others; and the mea ≈øure not ≈øealed to be broken, all which forfeitures are to the Lord of the Liberty where ≈øuch offence is committed, and if it be in a City, or Borough, then it is to the Maior and Commonalty.

1. Jacob.Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of ≈øuch as u≈øe to trace Hares in the ≈ønow, or to kill Hares with harepipes, or other egines, by an old Law they forfeit ≈øix ≈ø hillings eight pence for every Hare ≈øo killed, but by a latter Law made in the fir ≈øt yeer of the late King James, twenty ≈øhillings

No Lay man may lawfully keep any Greyhound, or Hunting Dog, Ferits, or Nets, unle≈øs he can di≈øpend
forty ≈øhillings per annum, Freehold, nor no ≈øpiritual man unle≈øs he can di≈øpend ten pound per annum, of ≈øpiritual promotion, upon pain of a yeers impri≈øonment.

div.head: Crow net.
div.p: 5. Eliz.Next you ≈øhall inquire if there be in every Pari≈ø h and Tything within your inquiry a Crow net, provided to kill and de≈øtroy Crows, Rooks, and Choughes, according to the Statute, or no, if there be not, they ought to lo≈øe ten ≈øhillings for every default, and it is not enough to have one, but it mu≈øt be u≈øed, and ≈øcrapes made in the winter to that purpo≈øe, upon the like pain, but hou≈øedoves and pigeons may not in any ca≈øe be taken with it. 5. Jacob.

div.head: Apparel.
div.p: 24. H. 8.And you ≈øhall inquire of ≈øuch as exceed in apparel contrary to the Statute, for no man except he may di≈øpend twenty pound yeerly in lands for his life at the lea≈ø t, or is worth two hundred pounds in goods, ought to wear any ≈øilk on his hat, ho≈øe, ≈øhoes, girdle, ≈øcabberd or ≈øpurleathers, upon pain for every dayes wearing of it ten pound, and three moneths impri≈øonment; and if any man know his ≈øervant to offend herein, and do not put him away, and not take him again within a yeer after, doth forfeit a hundred pound for every ≈øuch offence by the ≈øame Statute, and the ≈øe per≈øons onely are accepted out of the Statute, viz. The Councel of State, the Barons of the Exchequer, Judges of the Law, Serjants at Law, Maiors and Recorders of Cities and Towns corporate, and their wives.

div.head: Refu≈øe to go to mu≈øter.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire if any have refu ≈øed to go to Mu≈øters, if there be any ≈øuch they ought to lo≈øe forty ≈ø hilings, and to have ten dayes impri≈øonment.
Al ≈øo no man ought to water any Hempe or Flax in any runing ≈øtream, upon pain of twenty ≈øhillings.

div.head: Drunkards.
div.p: ‚Ä¢ . Iacob.Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of Drunkards, for they ought to be pre≈øented, and to pay if they be able for every time they be drunk five ≈øhillings to the u≈øe of the poor of the Pari≈øh where the offence is committed, if not able, then after con viction thereof, they ought to ≈øit ≈øix hours in the Stockes.

‚Ä¢ . Iacob.Al≈øo an Alehou≈øe-keeper ought to lo≈øe twenty ≈øhillings for every pot they ≈øell that is not a full quart, and ten ≈ø hillings for ≈øuffering any Towne ≈øman to ≈øit drinking in their hou≈øes, except he be brought thither by a ≈øtranger, and then he may not ≈øtay there above one hour.

And Brewers by the ≈øame Law ought to lo≈øe for every barrel of Beer or Ale ≈øix ≈øhillings eight pence, which they lay into any mans ≈øeller to be ≈øold there by retaile by any that is not licened to ≈øell Ale or Beer.

div.head: Waifes, ≈ø traies, and felons goods.
div.p: 18. E. 2.Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of wai≈øes, ≈øtrayes, and felons goods. Waifes are Cattel ≈øtoln and waved out of the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of him that ≈øtole them, and ≈øtraies are Cattel ≈øtrayed out of their haunt, and they ought to be ≈øei≈øed upon to the Lords u≈øe, and to be wreathed and put into an open place, and not in a covert, to the end the owner may have the view of them, and they mu ≈øt be cryed at three Market Towns next adjoyning to the place where they are ≈ø trayed, and if they be not challenged within a yeer and a day, then they belong to the Lord o ‚Ä¢ the ≈øoile where they are, by the Law, otherwife not.

Which is all manner of felons goods which may pre≈øently after the felony is known to be committed, be ≈øei≈øed upon, but not take away but left with the town≈øhip,
for the felon mu≈øt have his finding out of it ≈øo long as he lives unconvicted or attainted, but when he is convicted or attained, his goods then properly belong to the Lord of the Leet, if he have words for it in his Charter, otherwi≈øe they belong to the keepe ‚Ä¢ s of the Liberty of Englandby Authority of Parliament.

div.head: Trea≈øure trove.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire of Trea≈øure troues, either upon the ground, or within the ground, for if any hath been found within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, it belongs to the Lord of this Leet or Law day.

div.head: Mortmain.
div.p: Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire if any man hath given any lands in Mortmain, that is, to any Religious hou≈øe, or Religious per≈øon, or to any Corporation, Guild, or fraternity, without licence, ≈øuch guift is void, and the Lord may enter by way of E≈øcheat.

Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire if the pains laid at the la≈øt Leet or Law-day be performed or no, if not, then you mu≈øt pre≈ø ent them that have made default, and then tho≈øe pains mu≈øt be read to the Jury.

And to conclude, if there ≈øhall any other thing come to your knowledge meet to be pre≈øented, and by any omitted to be given in charge, you ≈øhall as well inquire thereof, and pre≈øent it as the re ≈ø t.

Then cau≈øe the Bailiff to make three Proclamations, and ≈øay thus: If any man can inform the Stew ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d of this Leet, or his inque ≈øt of any petty Trea≈øon, Felony, petty Larceny breach of Peac ‚Ä¢ , or of any other matter or thing now given in charg ‚Ä¢ , „Äà‚óä„Äâ them come forth and they ≈øhall be heard.

And if any do come in, then ≈øwear them thu ‚Ä¢ : that the evidence which they ≈øhall give, ≈øhall be the truth, and the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, ≈øo God
them help, and the contents of this Book, then adjorn the Court till after dinner.
Then at your return from dinner, call all the Tythingmen and take their pre≈øentments.
And then that done, take the pre≈ø entments of the Jury, if they be ready with them, or el≈øe give them a day to bring in their pre≈øentments, and then commonly is the be≈øt ≈øervice done.
Then ≈øwear all the officers to their ≈øeveral offices that are then and there to be ≈ø worn.

Then adjorn the Court untill the day given to the Jury to bring in their pre≈øentments, but if they have no day given them, you may di≈øcharge the Court by Proclamation thus, viz. according as other Courts are di≈øcharged.

Then at the day when the Jury delivers in their pre≈øentments, you mu≈øt fir≈øt call them by their names to ≈øee if all be there or no, and then aske them if they be agreed of their pre≈ø entments, if they ≈øay they be, then receive their pre≈øentments in writing in Engli ≈øh, under their hands, for the Stewards warrant.

div.head: Petty Trea≈øon.
div.p: IN primis, The Jurors afore≈øaid, ≈øay and pre≈øent on their Oath, that R.S. of A. Gentleman, at A. within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, as a felon of the Commonwealth, one hundred peeces of gold, and three hundred groates fal≈øly and feloniou ≈øly coyned, and made, letters patents of, &c. thence fir≈øt not obtained, again≈øt the peace publike, and again ≈øt the form of the Statute in ≈øuch ca≈øe put forth and provided.

div.head: Felony for burning a hou≈øe.
div.p:
Al≈øo they pre≈øent that a certain T.D. Yeoman ≈øuch a day, &c. at I. within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, by force and armes, &c. voluntarily and feloniou≈øly of his malice forethought,
the hou≈øe of a certain I.S. burnt again≈øt the peace publick, therefore is it commanded the Bailiff to ≈øeize all his lands, tenements, goods and chattels, that he may an≈øwer them to the Lord of the Mannor.

div.head: Felon.
div.p: Al ≈øo they pre≈øent that W.P. of I. afore≈øaid laborer, ≈øuch day, &c. at A. within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, by force and armes, &c. and again≈øt the peace publike, the clo≈øe of a certain A.B.at I. afore≈øaid, broke and entered, and one ≈ø uite of ≈ø atten of black colour, of the goods and chattels of the afore≈øaid A. then and there found, feloniou≈øly took and carryed away, therefore is it commanded to the bailiff to ≈øei≈øe, as above.

div.head: Acce≈ø≈øary.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent thatW.S. of I. afore≈øaid Yeoman within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, councelled, in≈øtigated procured, comforted, and abetted a certain H.W. &c. one Cow of black colour of the price of thirty ≈øhillings, of the goods and chattels of a certain E. F. then and there found feloniou≈øly to ≈øteal, take, and lead away, and the fore≈øaid L.by force of the ≈øaid councel, in ≈øtigation, procurement, comfort, and abetting of the afore ≈øaid W.S. the afore≈øaid Cow ≈øuch day, &c. yeer, &c. feloniou≈øly ≈øtole, took, and led away.

div.head: Rape.
div.p: Al ≈øo they pre≈øent that A.B. of I. Yeoman, ≈øuch daye, &c.at I. within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, the clo≈øe and hou≈øe of a certain C.B. broke and entered, and upon a certain K.C.the daughter, &c. in the peace of God, and the Commonwealth being a≈ø≈ø ault made, and her by force and armes then and there again≈øt her will ravi≈øhed, and her carnally knew, again≈øt the peace, &c.

div.head: Felony.
div.p: Al ≈øo they pre≈øent that A.B. of I. afore≈øaid, Yeoman ≈øuch day, &c. at I. within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, about the hour of nine in the night of the ≈øame day, the hou≈øe and man≈øion of a certain C.D. as a felon of the Commonwealth, broke and entered, with the intention to ≈øpoile the afore≈øaid C.D. and ≈øix Angels of gold, of the goods and chattels of the afore≈øaid C.D. then and there in a certain che≈øt being feloniou≈øly took and carried away, again≈øt the peace, &c.

div.head: Robbery.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that E.F. of I. afore≈øaid laborer ≈øuch day, &c.at I. within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, by force and armes, and again≈øt the peace, &c. upon a certain T.B.at, &c. within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, in the high way, there in the peace of God, and the Commonwealth, being a≈ø≈øault made, and him T.B. then and there ≈øpoiled, and ≈øixteen ≈ø hillings, and one Angel of gold, of the goods and chattels of the afore≈øaid T.B.in a certain his pur≈øe, then and there being from the per≈øon of him T.B.feloniou≈øly took and carried away, again≈øt the peace, &c.

div.head: Hute≈ø s.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent, that the afore≈øaid T.B. being ≈øpoiled rai ≈øed a great hiew and cry, and the afore≈øaid E.F. as a felon of the Commonwealth, the ≈øaid day and yeer, from the afore≈øaid place where ≈øo ≈øpoiled he was, fre≈øhly pur ≈øued, as far as the afore≈øaid town of, &c. and that no inhabitant there the afore≈øaid felon upon the hiew afore ≈øaid followed, and ≈øo the afore≈øaid felon e≈øcaped in contempt of the keepers of the Liberty of England, and again≈øt the form of the Statute of Winche≈øt.in ≈øuch like ca≈øe put forth and provided, therefore the afore≈øaid town of,&c. is amerced, &c.

div.head: Flight he made.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent thatE.L. of I. afore≈øaid Yeoman ≈øuch day and yeer,&c. at I. within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, a certain gelding of black colour of the price, &c. of the goods and chattels of a certain A.B. in the common field there being feloniou≈øly ≈ø tole, took and lead away, therefore is it commanded to the baily to ≈øei≈øe two cows of the goods and chattels of the afore≈øaid E.L. as an e ≈ø cheat, and to the Lord forfeit, and that ≈øafely they be kept to the u≈øe of the Lord, or thus, if it be for the Commonwealth, to the u≈øe of the Commowealth.

div.head: E≈ø cape.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent, that when a certain B. R. of I.afore≈øaid Yeoman, taken was, and are≈øted, for ≈øu≈øpition of a certain felony, and in the ≈øtocks put, a certain I. F. of I. afore≈øaid laborer ≈øuch day and yeer, &c. at I. afore≈øaid, the afore ≈øaid ≈øtocks by force and armes, feloniou≈øly broke, and the fore≈øaid B.R. then and there to e≈øcape, and at large go permitted, again≈øt the peace, Therefore is it commanded to the baily as before, &c.

div.head: Felony in re≈øcuous.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent, that T.I. of I. afore ≈øaid, within the juri≈ødiction of this Court one Calf of the price, &c. of the goods and chattels of a certain I.B. then and there found, feloniou≈øly took and carried away, and that W.O. baily of the mannor afore≈øaid ≈øuch day and yeer, &c. at I. afore≈øaid, the afore ≈øaid T.I. for ≈øu≈øpition of the ≈øelony afore≈øaid arre≈øied, and that W.F. ofI. laborer by force and and armes,&c. at I.afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid day and yeer, upon the afore≈ø aid W.O. in the peace of God and the Commonwealth, being a≈ø ≈øault made, and the afore≈ø aid T. I. in the cu≈øtody of the afore ≈øaid W. then and there feloniou ≈øly took, got away, and re≈ø cued, and at large to go permitted, again≈øt the peace, &c. therefore to the baily commanded is, as above,&c.

div.head: Felon of a Dovehou≈øe.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that A.B. of I. afore≈øaid, Yeoman ≈øuch day and yeer, &c. at I. within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, about the hour of one in the night of the ≈øame day, a certain Dove-hou≈øe of a certain, &c. broke and entered, and fourty Pige ‚Ä¢ ns of the price of, &c. of the goods and chattels, &c. feloniou≈øly took and carried away again≈øt the peace, &c. therefore, &c.

div.head: Felon of a Doe Dome ≈øtick.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that I.W. of I. afore≈øaid gentleman, ≈øuch day and yeer, &c. at I.within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, a certain Doe Dome≈øtick, and bearing a caperane about her neck, of the price of, &c. of the goods and chattels of a certain, &c.then and there found feloniou≈øly took and carryed away again≈øt the peace, and therefore commanded is it to the bailiff, &c. as above.

div.head: Felon of a trunck broken.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that I.L. of I. afore≈øaid Yeoman ≈øuch day, &c.at I. afore≈øaid, within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, about the fir≈øt hour of the night of the ≈øame day, a certain trunck of a certa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , &c. broke, and entred, and ten fi≈øhes called Pykes, of the price, &c. of the goods and chattels of the afore ≈øaid, &c. from the trunck of the ≈ø ame, &c. then and there feloniou≈øly took and carryed away again≈øt the peace, &c. therefore, &c.

div.head: Petty Larceny.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent thatP.I. of I. afore≈øaid Yeoman ≈øuch day, &c.the clo ≈øe of a certain; &c. at I. broke and entred, and one towel of the value of ≈øix pence of the goods and chattels of the afore ≈øaid, &c. then and there found, feloniou≈øly took and carryed away, therefore, &c.

div.head: Selling in the Church-yard.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that W.B. and T.B. of I. afore≈øaid Butchers ≈ø uch day, &c. within the precinct of the view of Frankpledge laid out their fle≈øh, and other things venal in the Church, and Church-yard of I. to ≈øell them; which where divine ≈øervice is celebrated, and mens bodies are buryed, they ≈øold again≈øt the form of the Statute ofWinch. in ≈ø uch like ca≈øe ≈øet forth and provided, therefore are they amerced, &c.

div.head: Chattels waved.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that a certain M.S. came within the juri ≈ødiction of this Court, and hither brought certain goods and chattels by him ≈øtoln, viz. One Smock, one Petticote, and one Shirt; all which aforefaid are of the value of twenty ≈ø hillings and no more, all which and ≈øingular hither by the fore≈øaid M. were brought, and the ≈øame M. here within the jurisdiction of this mannor, the≈øe waved left and fled, by which all the goods and chattels afore≈øaid came to the Lord of this mannor upon the afore ≈øaid. Commanded it was to the Baily to ≈øeize into the hands of the Lord, as an e≈øchete, and to the Lord forfeit, and ≈øo did he, and the goods and chattels afore≈ø aid were delivered to the Lord in this Court.

div.head: Common fine.
div.p: Al≈øo they ≈øay that they give to the Lord in certain for the Common fine at this day of ancient cu≈øtome ≈øix ≈øhillings eight pence.

div.head: Default of Dec ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ iners.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre ≈øent upon their oath that I.R. R.W. and I.W. are re≈øident within the view of Frank pledge afore≈øaid, and at this day have made default, therefore is every of them amerced as it appears upon their heads.

div.head: Nu≈øance of water.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that R.C. of I. afore≈ø aid Yeoman, has diverted the common cour ≈øe of a certain rivolet, leading by the hou≈øe of a certain T.H. out of the right cour≈øe in which it u≈øed to run; therefore is it commanded him, to ≈øuffer that rivolet to run in its right and ancient cour≈øe, by the fea≈øt, &c. under the penalty, &c.

div.head: Nu≈øance of boughes, &c.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent, that there is a certain hedge of great thickne≈øs, and that the boughes thence hang beyond the venelle called the publike lane, to the Nu≈øance of carriages, beyond the ≈øame venelle, to be carryed in defect of W.C. therefore is it commanded to him to cut or lop that hedge by the fea≈øt, &c.

div.head: Nu≈øance of a gutter.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent, that there is a certain gutter, leading from the hou≈øe or Kitchin of T.I. by which the filthy or ≈øtinking water of the ≈øaid Kitchin is conveyed into the publike way, to the grevious nu≈øance of the way publike, and of all carriages beyond it, to be carried by the people of the Commonwealth; therefore is it commanded him, that to amove or ≈øtop up, by the fea≈øt,& c.

div.head: The common wayes.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent, That the common way leading by the field called Prebends field, is the common way for leading or riding, and ≈øo u≈øed was from the time who≈øe contrary in the memory of man is not, and becau≈øe the gate and the bridge beyond the further bridge, ought to be maintained and kept by the Land tenants, and now are not; therefore is it commanded, the ≈øame gate and bridge, to mend, and repaire before the fea≈ø t, &c. under the penalty, &c.

div.head: Nu≈ø ance of a dunghill.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that R.W. has erected a certain Dunghill again≈øt his hou≈øe neer the publike way, to the nu≈øance of the people of the Commonwealth; therefore commanded it is to him, that to amove and eary thence by the ≈øea≈øt,&c. under the penalty, &c.

div.head: Nu≈øance of a Ditch.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that there is a certain ditch un≈øcoured and unclean in defect of R.S. to the nu≈øance, &c. therefore is he amerced twelve pence, and commanded it is to him that to ≈øcoure and maka clean by the fea ≈øt, &c. under the penalty, &c.

div.head: An Ho≈øte≈øs of whores.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that A.B. widow, is a common Ho≈øte ≈ø s, and receiver of whores, and of women of bad fame and conver≈øation, to the grievous nu ≈øance of her neighbors; therefore is ≈øhe amerced two ≈øhillings.

div.head: A ≈øcold.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that N.C. widow, is a common ≈øcold with her neighbors, and a common breaker of hedges, and keeps a certain W.C. her ≈øon in her hou≈ø e, and he is not of good fame or government, therefore are they amerced as it appears upon, &c.

div.head: Tre≈øpa≈øs.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that a certain A.B. ≈ø ervant of W.C. Baily of the Lord, as he was leading certain cattel of a certain R G. to the pound of the Lord there to impound them, came a certain D.P. with great violence to the pound afore≈øaid, with one ≈øword of the value of five ≈ø hillings, and then and therethe afore≈øaid A.B, ≈øtruck with the ≈ø ame ≈øword on his head, and ≈øpilt blood upon the ≈øame A.B. by occa≈øion of which blow the afore≈øaid B. fel to the ground, as if dead he had been. Therefore the afore≈øaid D.P. is amerced, and affer. by the chief pledges to five ≈øhillings.

div.head: Tre≈øpa≈øs and Battery.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that I.S. made an affray within the juri ≈ø |diction of this Court, and drew blood, therefore is he amerced ≈øix ≈øhillings eight pence.

div.head: Default of a Con≈øtable.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that W.G. is Con≈øtable, and is not here at the view of Frank-pledge, to pre≈øent that which to that office belongs, but has made default, therefore is he amerced three ≈øhillings four pence.

div.head: Common appri≈øers.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that B.R. and W.G.are common appri≈øers, and ought to be here to pre≈øent that which to that office belongs, and made default, therefore are they amerced three ≈øhillings four pence.

div.head: Searchers of Victuals make default.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that R.B. and C.D. are ≈øearchers of Victuals, and ≈ø hould be here at the view of frankpledge to pre ≈øent that which to that office belongs, and made default; therefore each of them is amerced two ≈øhillings.

div.head: Scowrers of ≈øtreets make default.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that T.I. and W.I. are ≈øcowrers of ≈øtreets, and ought to be here at the view of frankpledge, and made default, therefore is each of them amerced ≈øix pence.

div.head: E≈øtray.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent upon their Oath, that the twentieth day of May, the yeer, &c. there came within this Lord≈øhip, one hor≈ø e of colour grey an e≈øtray, and remaines in cu≈øtody X.D. to be proclamed.

Al≈øo they pre≈øent that there is one „Äà‚óä„Äâ colour bay, of age four yeers or more, which came within this Lord ≈øhip an e≈øtray
the ninth day of September, the yeer, &c. of the price of twenty four ≈ø hillings, and remained in the cu≈øtody of the Baily by the ≈øpace of one yeer, and one day, after three Proclamations three ≈øeveral dayes made according to the form of the Statute, therefore the property of the ≈øame Colt is in the Lord.

div.head: Bakers amerced.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that W M. twelve pence, and R.B. twelve pence, are common Bakers of mans bread, and diver≈øe times have baked bread unwhole≈øome, and broken the A ≈ø≈ø. therefore is each of them amerced as it appears upon their heads.

div.head: Brewers amerced.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈øent that R.W. twelve pence, and I.D. twelve pence, are common brewers of Ale, and have brewed ≈øeveral times Ale unwhole≈øome, and broken the A≈ø≈ø. therefore is each of them amerced as it appears upon their heads.

div.head: Tiplers amerced.
div.p: Al≈øo they pre≈ø ent that E.W. twelve pence, and W.X twelve pence by their wives are common Tiplers of Ale, and by unlawful mea≈øures have ≈øold Ale and broken the A≈ø≈ø. therefore is each of them amerced, as it appears upon their heads.

div.head: Penatly Set.
div.p: Fir≈øt, Ordained it is that B.R. make and ≈øcour his ditch at the nether end of great hill-field, containing by e≈øtimation twenty perches, by the fea≈øt of the Nativity of Saint John Bapti≈øt next coming, under penalty for every perch there eight pence.

div.head: Penalty.
div.p:
Al ≈øo ordained it is that T.M. reform and expo≈øe a certain parcel of land lately by him incr ‚Ä¢ ched, betwixt Wa≈øh-lane
and Pickam common, before the fea ≈øt of all Saints next coming, under the penalty for every perch not reformed and expo≈øed twenty pence.

div.head: Penalty.
div.p: Al ≈øo ordained it is, that no man permit his bea≈øts, viz. his Oxener Cowes to go into or feed upon the common of this Lord, but in the lanes to this manner belonging, without a keeper, under penalty of forfeiture to the Lord for every of them every time two pence.

div.head: Penalty.
div.p: Al ≈øo ordained it is that W.I. amove his dunghill lying by the way publick again≈øt his hou≈øe, before the fea≈øt of Ea≈øter next, under the penalty of forfeiture of ten ≈ø hillings to the lord of this mannor.

div.head: Penalty.
div.p: Al ≈øo ordained it is, th ‚Ä¢ t I.F. make an ‚Ä¢ maintain a bridge in his clo≈ø e, called great Co ‚Ä¢ mans, in the way leading from Alton town, under penalty of forfeiture of ten ≈øhillings to the lord.

div.head: Penalty.
div.p: Al ≈øo ordained it is that every man yoke or ring his hogs before the fea≈øt of Saint Michael the Archangel next, and tho≈øe keep ≈øo yoked or ringed untill the fea≈øt of Saint John Bapti≈øt then next following under penalty of forfeiture to the lordfor every hog, every week three ≈øhillings four pence.
Then there re≈øts no more to be done at a Leet or a Law day, but to mini≈øter to every officer his particular oath, and fir≈øt the Maiors oath, if there be one there, and that mu≈øt be thus:

div.head: The Maiors Oath.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you well and truly ≈øhall ≈øerve the keepers of the Liberties of Englan ‚Ä¢ , by Authority of Parliament, and the Commonwealth, in one office of a Maior, and as Maior of this Town and Borough of P. for and during the ≈øpace of one whole yeer now next en≈øuing; and you ≈øhall mini≈øter equal ju ≈øtice as well to the poor as to the rich, to the be≈øt of your cunning, wit, and power; and you ≈øhall diligently procure ≈øuch things to be done, as may hone≈øtly and ju≈øtly be to the profit and commodity of the Corporation of this Town; and al≈øo endevor your ≈øelf to the utmo≈øt of your power to ≈øee all Here≈øies, Trea≈øons, Felonies, and all other Tre≈øpa≈ø ≈øes, Mi≈ødemeanors, and Offences what≈øoever to be committed within this Town and Borough, during the time of your office, to be repre≈ø≈øed, reformed, and amended, and the offenders duly puni≈øhed according to the Law. And finally you ≈øhall ≈øupport, uphold, and maintain the Commonwealth within this Town, pre≈øcribed cu≈øtomes, rights, liberties, juri ≈ødictions, tranchi≈øes, compo≈øitions, and all lawful ordinances of this Town and Borough; and as concerning all other things appertaining to your office, you ≈øhall therein faithfully and uprightly behave your ≈øelf for the mo≈øt quietne≈øs, benefit, wor≈øhip, hone≈øty, and credit of this Town, and of the inhabitants thereof, So help you God, and the holy contents of that book.

div.head: The O ‚Ä¢ th of the Recorder.
div.p:
YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you well and truly ≈øhall ≈øerve the keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of
Parliament, and the Maior, Aldermen, and Burge≈ø≈øes of this Town and Borough of P. in the office of Recorder, and as the Recordor of this Town and Borough of P. ye ≈ø halbe faithful and ju≈øt and give good advice and coun≈øel unto the Maior, Aldermen, and Burge≈ø≈øes of this Town, for & concerning any matter or cau≈øe that ≈øhal concern or touch the Franchiles, Liberties, and good orders of this Town, when≈øoever they ≈øhall require or de≈øire you ≈ø o to do, you ≈øhall not utter or di≈øclo≈øe any of their ≈øecrets or councel, touching the Fellow≈øhip or Corporation of this Town, whereby any prejudice, lo≈øs, or hindrance, or ≈ø lander, ≈øhall or may ari≈øe, grow, or be to the ≈øame Corporation: And further ye ≈øhall do to your power, wit, and cunning, all and every thing that ≈øhall appertain to your office for the mo≈øt benefit, wor ≈øhip, and credit of this Town, and of the Inhabitants thereof. So help ye God and the contents of this book.

div.head: The Oath of the Town Cleark or Steward.
div.p: YOu ≈ø hall ≈øwear that you well and truly ≈øhall ≈øerve the Maior, Aldermen, and Burge≈ø≈øes of this Town, in the Office of Steward and Town Clerk of this Town and Borrough of P. and truly to ≈øee all Plaints, Actions, Proce≈øs, and matters in the Courts to be holden before the Maior, Aldermen and Burge≈ø≈øes of this Town, and by you or your ≈øufficient Deputy, according to cu≈øtome and Liberties of this Town, to be entred and recorded as they ought to be, after the be≈øt of you cunning wit, or power, taking for the ≈øame you due fees and the perqui ≈øits, i≈ø≈øues, profits, and amerciaments of the ≈øame Courts; you ≈øhall ju≈øtly and truely write and extract yeerly, for the levying and gathering thereof; and you ≈øhall truly and diligently do and accompli≈øh all other things appertaining to your ≈øaid office after the be ≈øt of your knowledge, as neer as God ≈øhall give you grace. So help you God and the contents of this book.

div.head: The Oath of the Coroner, if there be any.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear, that you well and truly ≈øhall ≈øerve the keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliament, and the Commonwealth, in the office of a Coroner, as Coroner of this Town and Borough of P. and you ≈øhall diligently and truly do and accompli≈øh all and every thing and things appertaining to your office after the be≈øt of your cunning, wit, and power, for the mo ≈øt quietne≈øs, profit, ea≈øe, and credit of this Town, and the inhabitants thereof, taking ≈øuch fees as you ought to take by the Laws and Statutes of this realm. So help you God, and the contents of this book.

div.head: The Oath of the Receiver ‚Ä¢ .
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you well and truly ≈øhall ≈øerve the Maior, Aldermen, and Burge≈ø≈øes of this Town of P. in the office of Receiver≈øhip, and as Receivers of the ≈ø ame Town for and during the ≈øpace of one whole yeer now next in≈øuing, and ye ≈øhall rea≈øonably and hone≈øtly procure the profit of the Corporation of this Town, in tho≈øe things which touch your office; and ye ≈ø hall al ≈øo well and truly Collect, levy, and gather all and all manner Rents, Revenues, Ca≈øualties, Duties, and Profits belonging unto the ≈øaid Office, and the ≈øame ≈øhall truly pay and deliver, and true declaration and accompt thereof make at the time appointed for payment and accompt thereof to be made, without concealment: and further, you ≈øhall diligently give attendance to the Maior of this Town and Corporation according to ancient cu≈ø tome; and every other thing belonging to your office you ≈øhall well and truly do and accompli ≈øh to the be≈øt of your skil or power. So help ye God, and the contents of this book.

div.head: The Oath of the Chamberlain, and general Receiver.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you well and truly ≈øhall ≈øerve the Maior, Aldermen, and Burge≈ø≈øes of this Town and Borough of P. in the office of Chamberlain or generall receiver of this Town, and therein ≈øhall you do right to all manner of people both poor and rich in tho≈øe things which touch your office; the receit of the money due or belonging to the Maior, Aldermen and Burge≈ø≈øes of this Town and Corporation, you ≈øhall truly and ≈øafely keep, and have alwayes in a readine≈øs to the u≈øe and behoof of the Corporation of this Town when≈øoever occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerve, and not wa≈øte or di ≈øpend the ≈øame, but make true declaration and accunt thereof, when you ≈øhall be thereunto required without concealement, according to the credit and tru≈øt to you committed in this behalf, So God you help, &c.

div.head: The Oath of a Burge≈øs.
div.p:
YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you well and tr ‚Ä¢ ly ≈øhall ≈øerve the keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, and the Inhabitants of thi ‚Ä¢ Town & borough of P. as one of the Burge≈ø≈øes of this Town, and ≈øhall mini≈ø ter equall ju≈øtice to poor and rich, after the be≈øt of your cunning, wir, and power, and al≈ø o ≈øhall well and truly ob≈øerve, perform, fulfill, and keep all ≈øuch good orders, rules, and compo≈øi ‚Ä¢ ions, as are or ≈øhall be made, ordred, or e≈ø tabli≈øhed by the common-councel of this Town, for the good government thereof in all things to you appertaining, and you ≈øhall not utter or di≈øclo≈øe any coun≈øel or ≈øecret thing or matter, touching the Fellow≈øhip or corporation of this Town, whereby any prejudice, lo≈øs, hinderance, or ≈ølander ≈øhall or may ari≈øe, grow, or be to the ≈øame corporation, but you ≈øhall in all things belonging to the fellow≈øhip and corporation of this
Town, faithfully, hone≈øtly, and indifferently behave your ≈øelf, for the mo≈øt benefit, wor ≈øhip, and hone≈ø ty of this Town, and the Inhabitants thereof, So God you help, &c.
The like Oath is to be mini≈ø tred to an Alderman, muratis mutandis.

div.head: The Oath of the Con≈ø tables.
div.p: YOu and either of you ≈øhall ≈øwear, that you well and truly ≈øhall ≈ø erve ‚Ä¢ e keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, and the Maior, Aldermen, and Burge ≈ø≈øes of this Town and Borough of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ in the office of Con≈øtable≈øhip, and as Con≈øtables of this Town, for and during the ≈øpace of one whole yeer now next in≈ø uing; you ≈øhall endeavor your ≈øelves to the utmo≈øt of your powers, to ≈øee the publike peace to be kept, and watch and ward ob≈ø erved and kept in this town, as hath been accu≈øtomed, and as it ought to be: likewi≈ø e you ≈øhall indevour your ≈øelves to learn and under≈øtand the contents of the Statute of Winche≈øt. and divers other Laws and Statutes of this Nation made for the puni ≈ø hment of rogues, vagabonds, and ≈ø turdy beggers, haunting and re≈øorting within the precinct of your office, and puni ≈øh the offenders accordingly. Al≈øo you ≈øhall puni≈øh all ≈øuch per≈øons as do or ≈ø hall play at any unlawful games. according to the Statute in that ca≈øe made and provided. You ≈øhall al≈øo have regard for the maintenance of A ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ illery within your ≈øaid office, and that you ≈øhall do and accompli≈øh to the uttermo≈øt of your powers, So help you God, &c.

div.head: The Oath of the Serjeants.
div.p:
YOu and either of you ≈øhall ≈øwear, that you well and truly ≈ø hall ≈øerve the Maior, Aldermen, and Burge ≈ø ≈øes
of this Town, in the office of a Serjant≈øhip, and as Serjeants of this Town, for and during the ≈øpace of one whole yeer now next coming; and you ≈øhall well and truly ≈øerve, do, and execute all and all manner precepts, warrants, and commandments to you and either of you to be lawfully given and directed, touching or concerning any matter, cau≈øe, or proces, to be moved, had, or depending in the keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliament court, to be holden within this Town, according to the liberties thereof, or at large, and ≈ø hall make due returns and an≈øwers thereunto, and make Certificate thereof, according to the effect of ≈øuch Precepts, Warrants, and commandements, taking therefore your ordinary fees, and none other: And al≈øo you ≈øhall diligently give attendance unto Ma≈øter Maior, and waite on him, as hath been accu≈øtomed, and as you ought to do, and his commandments me≈ø≈ø ages truly to do and ≈øay, and not alter the ≈øame, ≈øo that it may be prejudicial or hurtful unto the ≈øaid Ma≈øter Maior or any other: and likewi≈øe you ≈øhall give attendance and be aiding and a≈ø≈øi≈øting unto the Con ≈øtables of this Town, in any thing that they or either of them ≈øhall rea≈ø onably and lawfully command or will you to do: and you ≈øhall diligently and truly do all other things appertaining to your ≈øaid office, to the utmo ≈øt of your power. So help you God, and the contents of this Book.

div.head: The Oath of a free-man.
div.p:
YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you ≈øhall be true and faithful to the keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliament, and to the government of the Commonwealth of England, as it is now e≈øtabli≈øhed, and to your power ≈øhall aide and a≈ø≈øi ≈øt the Maior and other officers of this Town for the time being, and to them ≈øhall be obedient and attendant concerning ≈øuch things as they or any of them ≈øhall lawfully and rea≈øonably will or
command you to do; you ≈øhall al≈øo well and truly ob≈øerve, perform, fulfil, and keep all ≈øuch orders and rules as are and ≈øhall be made and e≈ø tabli≈øhed by the Common Coun≈øel of this Town, for the good government thereof, in all things to you appertaining: you ≈øhall al≈øo give, yeeld, and be contributary to and with the Corporation of this Town, ≈øo far forth as you ought or ≈øhall be chargeable to do, and you ≈øhall not by colour of your freedom bear out, or cover under you any forrain per≈øon or ≈ø tranger, but according to the be≈øt of your skill, wit, cunning and power, you ≈øhall uphold and maintain all the Liberties, Franchi≈øes, good cu≈øtomes, orders, and u≈øages of this Town and Corporation. So help you God, &c.

div.head: The Oath of the Tithing-man or petty Con≈øtable.
div.p: THe Oath of the Tything-man or petty Con≈øtable is in all points as the the Oath of the Con≈øtable, mutatis mutandis, ≈øaving further that the Tything-man mu≈øt be ≈ø worn to be attendant on the Con≈øtable when he ≈øhall execute his office, being thereunto required.

div.head: The Oath of an Ale-ta≈øter.
div.p:
YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you ≈øhall well and truly ≈øerve the keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliament, and the Lord of this Leet in the office of the Ale- ta≈øter, or A≈ø≈øizor of this Liberty and Hundred for this yeer to come; you ≈øhall duly and truly ≈øee from time to time, that the bread brought to be ≈øold be truly weighed, and that the ≈øame to contain ≈øuch weight, according to the prices of Wheat,
as by the Statute in that behalf is provided: likewi≈øe you ≈øhall have diligent care during the time of your being in office, to all the B ‚Ä¢ ewers and Tiplers within your office, that they and every of them do make good and whole≈øome Ale and Beer for mans body, and that the ≈øame be not ≈øold before it be a≈ø ≈øayed by you, and then to be ≈øold agreeable to the prices limited and appointed by the Ju≈ø tices of Peace; and all faults committed or done by the Bakers, Brewers, or Tiplers, or by any of them, you ≈øhall make known, and pre≈øent the ≈øame at this Court, whereby due puni≈ø hment may be inflicted upon them for their offences accordingly, and in every other thing you ≈øhall well and truly behave your ≈øelf in the ≈øaid office for this yeer to come, So help you God, &c.

div.head: The Oath of fealty to a Freeholder.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear by the contents of that book, that you will be true and faithful to the Lord of this Mannor, and ≈øhall from henceforth bear, do, and pay to your ≈øaid Lord and to his heirs, at terms a≈ø≈ø igned, all ≈øuch Rents, Cu≈øtomes, and Services, as you ought to pay and do for all ≈øuch lands and tenements as you claim to hold of him, So help you God, &c.

div.head: The Oath of the Y ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gling.
div.p:
THis hear you the Steward and the Court that I ≈øhall ≈øwear, that I will true faith and troth bear to the keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, and to the government of the Commonwealth of Englandas it is now e≈øtabli ≈øhed: And I ≈øhall with all my power, wit, and endeavor, defend and maintain the
right and title of this Commonwealth again≈øt all forraine Princes and forrain Potentates, and ≈øhall no felony nor trea≈øon commit, nor thereunto a≈ø≈øent, but as ≈øoon as any trea ≈øon ≈øhall come to my knowledge, I ≈øhall make the ≈øame to be known to the keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament, or to the Ju≈øtices of the Peace publike, within four and twenty hours next and immediately after it ≈øhal come to my knowledge, and ≈øhal be obedient to all the Laws of England, and in all things I ≈øhall well and truly behave my ≈øelf like a true and faithful member of this Commonwealth during the term of my natural life, So God me help, &c.

div.head: The Oath of a De≈ønier.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you I. S. from this day during you life, ≈ø hall be faithful to the Keepers of the Liberty of England, and you ≈øhall hear of no hurt or damage that may befall them, but you ≈øhall di≈øclo≈øe it, and to the uttermo≈øt of your power you ≈øhall defend them, So God you help, &c.

div.head: The Oath of the Heyward.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear, that you ≈øhall well and truly ≈øerve the keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliament, and the Lord of this Leet in the office of a Heyward for this yeer to come; you ≈øhall duely and truely execute all ≈øuch Attachements and other Proce≈øs as ≈øhall be directed unto you from this Court: and you ≈ø hall from time to time ≈øignifie and pre≈øent all ≈ø uch Pound breaches as ≈øhall happen to be made within your office.

And likewi≈øe you ≈øhall pre≈øent all ≈øuch cattel e≈øtrayed, as ≈øhall u≈øually come within your office, and in every other thing well and truly behave your ≈øelf during the time afore ≈øaid. So God you help, &c.

div.head: The Oath of the Affiers.
div.p: YOu and either of you ≈øhall ≈øwear by the holy contents of this book, That you will truly and indifferently taxe, a≈ø≈øe≈øs, and affier all ≈øuch amerciaments as are pre ≈øented at this Court; wherein you ≈øhall ≈øpare no man for love, favor, affection, or corruption, nor rai≈øe or inhance upon any man (of malice) more grievous Amerciaments than ≈øhall be thought rea≈øonable, according to the quality of the offence, and the faults committed, and not otherwi ≈øe. So help you God, &c.

Then mu≈øt the Steward command all men to ≈ø tand by, and the two Affiers to ≈øtand as neer him as they can, and he mu≈øt read unto them every pre≈øentment that ought to be affied, and ≈øo that they may rate them accordingly untill they have done, and then di≈øcharge the Court thus:

div.head: Conclu≈øion.
div.p: The Bailiff mu≈ø t make an O yes, and ≈øay after the Steward thus: If any man have any more to do at this Court, let him come in, and he ≈øhall be heard, or el≈øe every man may depart for this time in Gods peace and the publike, and keep your day here according to cu≈øtom, if it be a cu≈ø tomary Leer, otherwi≈øe it mu≈øt be upon a new warning. And ≈ø o God ≈øave the Lord of this Leet or Law-day, and make us all his ≈øervants, Amen.
Now I will ≈øhew you how Manors took their beginning, and within what Mannors a Court Baron ≈øhall or may be kept, and within what Mannors they may not, as followeth.

Perkina fol. 127. ≈øaith, That the beginning of Mannors was, when the King gave a thou≈øand Acres of Land, or more or le≈øs, to a man and his heires for ever. And before the Statute of Quia emptores terrarum, A man ≈øei≈øed of Land, infeoffed another of ten Acres, another of twelve Acres, a third of twenty Acres, to be holden of him≈ø elf, and the Tenants to do him ≈øervice, and pay him a quit rent, and ≈øo by this means by continuance of time out of the memory of man, ≈øuch donor or feoffor had a Mannor.

Al≈øo, 33. H. 8. tit. Compri≈ø e. A man at this day cannot make a Mannor; For although that a gift in taile be made to divers to hold of the donor by his ≈øervices or ≈øuit of Court, although this be a tenure, yet it cannot make a Court, for it cannot be without pre≈øcription.

Al≈øo if a man have a Mannor, and all his free ≈øuiters but one do commit felony, or die without heirs general or ≈øpecial, whereby their land e≈øcheats, or if the Lord purcha≈øe their lands, the Mannor is de≈øtroyed; for it cannot be a Mannor without Suiters, there mu≈øt be two at the lea≈øt, as it appeereth by 35. H. 8. tit. Tenures 102. m. And in 26. H. 8.4. Two Copartners made partition of a Mannor, ≈øo that either of them had parcel in deme≈øne, and parcel in ≈øervice; in this ca≈øe either of them hath a Mannor, and either of them may keep a Court Baron, i ‚Ä¢ either of them have two Suiters; otherwi≈øe not. But 12. H. 4.15. Partition is made of a Mannor, ≈øo that one Copartener hath the demeans, and ‚Ä¢ he other the ≈øervices, ≈øuit of Court in this ca≈øe is ≈øu≈ø pended; and ≈øo long as the mannor continues ≈øo, there can be no Court kept. And 8. H. 7.4. it is held, That a Court Baron is incident to a Mannor, of common right, ≈ø o that within every Mannor there ought to be a Court Baron, although there be no ≈ø uiters belonging to it, or although by partition the ≈øuit is ≈øu≈øpended, as is afore≈øaid. And 34. H. 6.53. But note, That divers are called Mannors, where there are not free Suitors, but onely Copyholders,
Ad voluntatem Domini ≈øecunaum con ‚Ä¢ uetu
‚Ä¢ linem Manerii. And yet tho≈øe ≈ø eigniories are called Mannors, and there are Court Barons kept to grant Copihold e≈ø tates; otherwi≈øe they cannot be granted by Copy, but by lea≈øe they may, and by that means a Mannor will be utterly de≈øtroyed.

div.head: THE Manner and form how to keep a Court BARON.
div.q: ≈ø≈ø THE Court Baron of I.F. and P. his wife, there held the twelfth day of October, the yeer.&c. by me I.W. Steward there.
div.p: Then command the Bailiff to make an O yes, and ≈øay after you thus, All manner of per≈øons that have any thing to do at this Court, draw neer and give your attendance, and if any man will be e≈ø≈øoined or enter any plaints, let them come forth and they ≈øhall be heard.
Then let the Bailiff ≈øay after the Steward, E≈ø≈øoines and proffers of ≈øuit or plea three times for this Court, and if any will be e≈ø≈øoined, let the e≈ø≈øoiny for ≈øuit of Court be entred thus:
div.q: I.S. E≈ø≈øonied is for ≈øuit of Court by T.D.
div.p: And if any will enter any plaints, then let them enter their plaints thus.
div.q: W.K. plaines again≈øt I.H. a plea of debt or tre≈øpa ≈øs, or taking or inju≈øt determing of his bea≈øts, or ≈øuch like.
div.p: Then call the Freeholders, and ≈øo many as make default, pre≈øent their names and marke them over the heads thus.

Richard W. Knight Amerced two pence.
and M.B gentleman, Amerced two pence. are freeholders of this Court and have made default, therefore each of them is amerced as appears upon their heads.

div.head: The Foremans Oath.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you as Foreman of this Homage, with the re≈øt of your fellows, ≈øhall duely inquire, and true pre≈øentment make of all ≈øuch Articles and things as ≈øhall be given you in charge, and therein you ≈øhall not ≈øpare no man, for love, favor, or affection, nor pre≈øent any man for malice, hatred, or envy, but according as things here pre≈øentable, ≈øhall or may come to your knowledge, by information, or otherwi≈øe, ≈øo ≈øhall you make thereof true pre≈øentment without concealement, So God you help, and the contents of this book.

Then call the re≈øt of the Homage, and ≈øwear them by four at a time thus; The ≈øame Oath that W. Kel≈øey your Foreman hath taken before you one this part, you and every one of you ≈øhall ob≈øerve and keep of your parts, So help you God and the contents of this book.
Then let the Bailiff call them by name, and bid them ≈øtand neer and here their charge.

div.head: An exhortation to the Jury before the charge.
div.p: SIRS, You that be ≈øworn, before I enter into your Charge, I purpo≈øe by Gods a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to deliver unto you the cau≈øes of your a≈ø≈øembly here together, which are two; one is, for that you hold lands of the Lord of this Mannor, ≈øome as Freeholders, and ≈ø ome as Copiholders, and therefore by rea≈øon of your tenures you ought to appear at this Court ≈øo often as it ≈øhall be kept, and here to do your ≈øuit and ≈øervice, or el≈øe to be amerced; and the other cau≈øe of your coming hither, is to get knowledge by hearing of the Laws and cu≈ø tomes of this Court dilated upon unto you, and hereby you may be the better taught, in≈ø tructed, and enabled to know how to perform your duties in doing well and e≈øchewing evil. And for that you ≈øhall the better con≈øider and inquire of, and pre≈øent all things which are now here pre≈øentable, I have mini≈øtred unto you a corporal oath, which oath ≈øtandeth upon three parts (that is to ≈øay) upon Truth, Judgement, and Ju≈øtice: It ≈ø tandeth upon truth, for that you ought to pre≈øent nothing but the Truth, and likewi≈øe not to omit any thing that is true and pre≈øentable here unpre ≈øented; It ≈ø tandeth upon Judgement, that you do not pre≈øent any thing ra≈øhly or unadvi≈øedly, but certainly to know the truth thereof before you do pre≈øent it; And it ≈ø tandeth upon Ju≈øtice, that you do not for favor, affection, corruption of money, or other reward, for fear of any mans di≈ø plea≈øure, or for any private gaine or profit, leave any thing unpre≈øented that is here pre≈ø entable, neither for malice to pre≈øent any thing contrary to the truth. The≈øe three principal things you ought duely to con≈ø ider of, and ≈øo hoping that you will have a ≈øpecial care thereof, according to your oaths and duties, and the tru≈øt that is repo≈øed in you, I will cea ≈øe to trouble you any further at this time by way of exhortation, and proceed to your Charge.

div.head: The Charge.
div.p: FIr≈øt, you ≈øhall enquire whether all ≈øuch per≈øons as owe ≈øuit and ≈øervice to this court, be here to do the ≈øame or no: and if any make default, you mu≈øt pre≈øent their names.

And I mu≈øt tell you, If there be two Coparcenes, or two Joyntenants which do owe ≈øuit and ≈øervice to this Court for any Lands which they hold of the Lord of this Mannor, the one of them ought to be here to do the ≈øame, ≈øuit, and the other ought to be contributer to his charge.

Al≈øo if any Tenant having twenty acres of Land granteth or letteth the ≈øame to twenty ≈øeveral per≈øons, in this ca≈øe every one of tho≈øe twenty ought to do ≈øuch ≈øuit and ≈ø ervice as hath been accu≈øtomed to be done for the ≈øame Land.

Al≈øo, you ≈øhall enquire if any Tenant be dead ≈øince the la ≈øt Court, or before, and his death as yet not pre ≈øented, then you ≈øhall enquire what Land he held of the Lord of this Mannor, and by what tenure or ≈øervice he held the ≈øame, whether by Knights ≈ø ervice, Soccage tenure, or by Copy; and what benefit or advantage is faln to the Lord by his death; whether ward, marriage, relief, e≈øcheat, or any other profit, and who is his next Heire, and of what age he is, and in who≈øe cu≈ø tody he is: For if any Tenant which holds by Knights ≈øervice die, and his heir male under the age of twenty one yeers, and not married, then the Lord ≈ø hall have the ward ≈øhip and marriage of ≈øuch heir male: but if it be a female and under the age of 14. yeers, and not married, then the Lord ≈ø hall have likewi≈øe the ward≈øhip and marriage of ≈øuch heir female
‚Ä¢ and if the heir male be 21. yeers at the death of his ance≈øtor: or the heir female fourteen yeers, then the Lord ≈øhall have onely a relief, which ‚Ä¢ s, if they held by a whole Knights fee, a hundred ≈øhillings: if by the moity of a Knights fee, fifty ≈øhillings, and ≈øo according to the rate of their tenure.

Al≈øo if any tenant which held by Soccage tenure be dead, his heir being under the age of fourteen yeers, the
