Lord ought to have the value of his land for one yeer for a relief, which is due immediately after the death of the Tenant; and the next of kin to the heir to whom the inheritance cannot de≈øcend, ought to have the ward≈øhip of ≈øuch heir.
Al ≈øo if any cu≈øtomary Tenant or copiholder, hold two parcels of land by herriot ≈øervice, and by ≈øeveral copies, if ≈øuch tenant dye thereof ≈øei≈øed, the Lord ought to have two herriots.
Al≈øo you ≈øhall iniquire whether any of the Lords tenants be dead without heir generall or ≈øpecial; if there be any ≈øuch; then the Lord ought to have his land by E≈ø cheat.
Al≈øo if any Ba≈øtard hath purcha≈øed any land within this Lord≈ø hip, and is dead without i≈ø≈øue of his body lawfully begotten, then the Lord ought to have his land by E≈øcheat.

Al≈øo if any Freeholder of this Mannor hath committed felony, and thereof hath been attainted, that is, either hath confe≈ø≈øed the felony, or hath been convict by verdict of twelve men, or fled, and thereupon outlawed for the felony, in this ch≈øe the Keepers of the liberty of England by authority of Parliament mu≈øt have yeer, day and wa≈øt in his land, and after it ought to come to the Lord by E≈øcheat.
Al≈øo if any Copiholder hath committed felony, and therefore hath been attainted as is afore≈øaid, then the Lord may enter into his Copihold for a forfeiture.
Al≈øo if any Copiholders hath lea ≈øed his Copihold for any longer time than a year and a day without the Lords licen ≈ø e, is is a forfeiture of his Copihold, unle≈øs he may do it by the cu≈ø tome.

Al≈øo if any Copiholder deny to pay his rent, or deny to come to his Lords Court, or deny to be ≈øworn of the homage, or deny to go with his Lord to ≈øuppre≈øs rebels, every one of the≈øe denials is a forfeiture of his copihold. Al≈øo if any copiholder hath ≈øold any of his copihold land by deed, and made livery of ≈øei≈øin thereof according to the deed, it is a forfeiture of ≈øo much as he hath ≈øo ≈øold.

Al≈øo if any Copiholder hath cut down any Timber trees within his Copihold without licence, or lopped any Timber trees there at an un≈ø ea≈øonable time of the yeer, by rea≈ø on whereof they die, either of both is a forfeiture of his copihold.
Al≈øo if any copiholder ≈ø uffer his copihold tenement to decay and fall down for lack of reparations, it is a forfeiture of his copihold.
Al≈øo if a copiholder be a Recu≈øant, if his Lord al≈øo be not a Recu≈øant, he ought to forfeit his copihold e≈ø tate according to the ≈øtatute Law made ann. 35. El.

Al≈øo if any copiholder have ≈øurrendred his copihold tenement into the hands of two of the tenants ≈øince the la ≈øt court to the u≈øe of any per≈øon, every ≈øuch ≈øurrender ought to be pre ≈øented at this Court, or el≈øe the tenants which took ≈øuch ≈øurrender, ought to forfeit their copiholds, becau≈øe it may be thought if they do not pre ≈øent it, that they go about not only to defeat the Lord of his fine, but al≈øo to di≈øinherit the party to who ≈øe u≈øe the ≈øame ≈ø urrender was taken.
Al≈øo if any Copiholder having two Copiholds, hath impaired the one to amend the other, this is a forfeiture of the Copihold that is impaired.
Al≈øo if any Villain or Bondman of blood, hath purcha≈øed any Land within his Lord≈øhip, the Lord may ≈øei ≈øe both it and ≈øuch villains goods at his plea≈øure.

Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire whether any Tenant of this mannor hath given any of his lands in mortmain, That is to ≈ø ay, to any religious hou≈øe, religious per≈øon, and their ≈øucce≈ø≈ø ors, or to any Guild, Fraternity, or corporation, and their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, without the Keepers of the Liberty of England, by Authority of Parliaments licence, and the Lords of this Mannor, for it is here inquirable and pre≈øentable, to the end that the Lord if there be any ≈øuch grant made, may make his claim within the yeer and the day, according to the ≈ø tatute in that ca≈øe made and provided.

Al≈øo if any Tenant hath ≈øold his land by Deed, and
hath not given notice thereof to the Lord, nor he which bought it hath not done his fealty to the Lord, or ≈øuit of Court, ≈øo that by rea≈øon thereof the Lord doth not know who is his tenant, therefore you ought to pre≈øent it: for it is very needful and nece≈ø≈øary, that the lord ≈øhould know who is his Tenant, by rea≈øon of his ≈øervices and e≈øcheats which may grow due unto him.

Al≈øo if any Tenant within this Lord≈øhip hath ≈øuffered any hou≈øe of husbandry to decay by taking of the land from it to lay it to another, in this ca≈øe the Lord ought to have the moity of the profits thereof to his own u≈øe, untill it be made and maintained a Husbandry again, and this you ought to inquire of for the Lords benefit.
Al≈øo if any Tenant hath inclo≈øed any land which hath been accu≈øtomed to lie open without the Lords licence and the Freeholders, you mu≈øt pre≈øent it, for he cannot ju≈øtifie the doing thereof.

Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire whether any of the Lords lands within this Mannor be withholden from him, and held and occupied without his licence, if there be any ≈øuch thing, then you mu≈øt inquire by whom it is withholden, and what land it is, and what it is worth by the yeer, and how long it hath been withholden that the Lord may recover his damage for the withholding thereof accordingly.

Al≈øo you ≈ø hall inquire whether there be any rent cu≈øtome, or ≈øervice, behind and unpayed to the Lord of this Mannor, by whom it is due, and what rent, cu≈øtome, or ≈øervice it is, how long it hath been withholden, and where the land lieth, that the Lord may di≈ø traine for the arrearages thereof.

Al≈øo you ≈øhall inquire if any Bailiff or other officer of this Mannor, hath made any arre≈øt for any rent, cu ≈øtome, or ≈øervice, due to the Lord of this Mannor, and re≈øcou≈øe therein hath been made; you ought then to pre≈øent him or them which made the re≈øcou≈øe, and where and when it was done.

Al≈øo if any di≈øtre≈øs hath been taken and put into the
lords pound, and hath been taken out from thence without leave or authority of the law, then ≈øuch taking is a pound breach, and here inquirable and pre≈ø entable.

Al≈øo if any tenant doth ≈øurcharge the common by putting more cattel there then by the cu≈øtome he ought to have go there, or by putting of cattel there not commonable, as pigs, goats, and gee≈øe, and ≈ø uch like, you mu≈øt pre≈øent them.

Al≈øo if any Tenant of this Mannor, having two Farm ‚Ä¢ s, one in this Mannor, and another in another Mannor, doth u≈øe in the Summer-time or open time of the yeer, when Corn and Hay is hou≈øed, to bring cattel from his other farm unto his farm within this Mannor, which hath been u≈øually kept at his other farm out of this Mannor, this is called cha≈øing, and here requirable and puni≈øhable, unle≈øs the≈øe cattel be kept within his own ≈ø everal grounds, and not in the common fields.

Al ≈øo if any man hath removed any bounds or marks, meer-≈ø tones or ≈øtakes, between this Lord≈øhip and any other, or between tenant and tenant, you mu≈øt pre≈øent their names; for it is an evil o≈ø≈øice, and they de≈øerve to be puni≈ø hed for it.

Al≈øo if any man hath fi≈øhed, hawked, or hunted within this Lord ≈øhip, without the leave or licen≈øe of the Lord of this Mannor, you mu≈øt pre≈øent them, for they are the Lords Realties, and therefore no man can lawfully come here to do either one or the other without his leave.
Al≈øo if any tenant by rea≈øon of his tenure ought to grinde at the Lords Mill, if he do it not, you mu≈øt pre≈øent him.

Al≈øo if you know any man that keepeth, deraineth, or withholdeth any of the Lords evidences of this mannor, as court ro ‚Ä¢ s, rentals, or immuniments appertenant and belonging to the Lord of this Mannor, you mu≈øt pre≈øent them, for it is fit that the Lord ≈øhould have the cu ≈øtody of this Evidence him≈øelf.

Al≈øo if there was any thing pained at the la≈øt Coure
to be done, and as yet is not done, you mu≈øt enquire who have made default therein, and pre≈øent his heirs, or their names: And you ≈øhal likewi≈øe inquire of all other things which you ≈øhall think needful to be inquired of, by me omitted, and not given you in charge, a ≈øwel as if I had given you it in charge, and ≈øo bring in your pre≈øentment in writing by one of the clock in the afternoone.
Then let the Bailiff make an O yes, and adjorn the the Court till after dinner thus:
All manner of per≈øons that have an ‚Ä¢ more to do at this court, may depart for this time, and keep their hour here at one of the clock in the a≈øternoone.
And then after dinner, call the Jury for their pre≈øentments; and if they be ready, take them, and ≈øwear two Affiers to affier them, as before at the Leet.

This being done, let the Bailiff make an O yes, and di≈øcharge the court thus. All manner of per≈øons which have any more to do at this Coure, let them come forth and they ≈øhall be heard, or el≈øe they and every one el≈øe may depart for this time, and keep their day here upon a new warning, and ≈øo God ≈øave the Commonwealth of England,and the Lord of this Mannor.

div.head: Fealty to be mini≈øtred to a cu≈øtomary tenant.
div.p:
YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you ≈øhall be true Tenant, and faith and truth ≈øhall bear to the Lord of this mannor, and to his heirs, for all ≈øuch cu≈øtomary Lands and Tenements as you claime to hold of him, by vertue of your copy for term of your life: you ≈øhall al≈øo well and truely bear, pay, and do all ≈øuch rents, cu≈øtomes, and ≈øervices as are and ≈øhall be from time to time to be paid and done for the ≈øaid lands to your ≈øaid Lord, and his heires: you ≈øhall al≈øo be ju≈øtified by your Lord and his officers, in every thing as a cu≈ø tomary Tenant ought to be ju≈øtified; and you ≈øhall in every other thing well and hone≈øtly behave your ≈øelf o long as you ≈øhall be Tenant, So help you God,
and the contents of that Book. And ≈øo let him ki≈øs the Book to affirm his Oath.
But this Oath mu≈øt be mini≈øtred before the Court be ended.

div.head: The Oath of the Reeve or Bailiff of a Mannor.
div.p: YOu ≈øhall ≈øwear that you ≈øhall well and truly ≈øerve the keepers of the Liberty of England by Authority of Parliament and the Lord of this Mannor for the yeer to come, in the office of the Reeve or Bailiff of the ≈øame Mannor; and you ≈øhall duly and truly gather all ≈øuch rents, revenues, or other yeerly profits as ≈ø hal be extracted out unto you, and thereof you ≈øhall make and yeeld up a true account at the end of the ≈øaid yeer, and in every other thing you ≈øhall well and hone≈øtly behave your ≈øelf in the ≈øaid office during the time afore≈øaid, So help you God and the contents of that Book. This mu≈øt al≈øo be done before the end of the Court.
And the pre≈øentments are to be put into this form by the Steward of the Court thus, viz.next after the pre ≈øentment of the freeholders, for their defaults, the copiholders thus:

div.head: Default of Copiholders.
div.p: Al≈øo the Jury ≈øay upon their Oath, that W.I. four pence, and J.R. four pence, are tenants by Copy Rolls of the Court, and owe ≈øuit to the Court, and at this day hath made default, therefore is each of them amerced as appears upon their heads.

div.head: Death.
div.p:
Al≈øo they pre ≈øent that W.N. who of the Lord held freely one me≈ø≈øuage, and thirty Acres of medow and pa≈øture, with the appurtinances within this Lord≈øhip, by fealty and ≈ø uit of Court and by rent annual of ≈øix pence, dyed of ≈øuch e≈øtate ≈øo ≈øei≈øed
and that R.I. is the ≈øon and next heir of the afore≈øaid W.I. and is of the age of ten yeers, and to this Court came the afore ≈ø aid R.I. and paid to the Lord for relief ≈øix pence, and made fealty.

div.head: Alienation.
div.p: Al≈øo they ≈øay upon their oath, that G.B. who of the lord held freely one me≈ø≈øuage, one Orchard, and ≈øix acres of medow with the appurtinences, by his deed indented bearing date the ≈øixt day of I. the yeer, &c. gave, granted, bargained, and ≈øold, all and ≈øingular the premi≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid, with the appurtinences to R.K. of, &c. to have and to hold all and ≈ø ingular the premi≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid with their appurtinences to the afore ≈ø aid R. K. his heirs and a≈ø≈øignes of the chief lords of the fee by the rent ≈ø ervices and cu≈øtomes, &c. thence heretofore due, and of right accu≈ø tomed, and the premi≈ø≈øes he holds of the Lord of this manner by fealty and ≈øuit of Court and by rent annual of 12. pence, and at this Court the ≈øaid R.K. made to the Lord fealty.

div.head: Legation.
div.p: Al≈øo they ≈øay upon their oath that W.A. who of the Lord held freely one me≈ø≈øuage or tenement, and twenty acres of land called H. by fealty, ≈øuit of Court and by rent annual of ≈øix pence dyed ≈øei≈øed, and by his la≈øt will written made, bearing date the 28. day of Sept. the yeer, &c. devi ≈øed the me≈ø≈øuage or tenement and the afore≈øaid twenty Acres of land to certain R.A. and T.A. his ≈øons, by the name of all his lands, tenements, and hereditaments, ≈øcituate lying and being in I. afore ≈øaid, to have and hold the afore≈øaid me≈ø≈øuage or tenements to the ≈ø ame R.A. and T.A.their heirs and a ≈ø≈øigns for ever, to the proper behoof and u≈øe of them R.T. their heirs and e ≈ø≈øignes for ever. Therefore is it commanded to the Baily to de ≈øtrain the afore ≈øaid R.A. and T.A. according to the form of a Statute in that ca≈øe provided to pay relief, and al≈øo di≈ø train to do fealty.

div.head: Upon Surr.
div.p: Al≈øo they ≈øay upon their oath, that R.R.tenant cu≈øtomary of this mannor, out of Court ≈øurrended into the hands of the Lord, by the hands of W.T. and R.W.two cu≈øtomary tenants of this mannor, all that me ≈ø≈øuage and thirty acres of land medow and pa≈øture with the appurtenances now in the tenure and occupation of R.B. to the behoof and u≈øe of the afore≈øaid R.R. for tenure of his life natural, and after the decea ≈øe of the ≈øaid R.R.then to the behoof and u≈øe of T.B. and the heirs of the body of the ≈øaid T. lawfully begotten, and for defect of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue of the body of the ≈øaid T.B. lawfully begotten, to remain to I.I. the ≈øon of R.I. gentleman, his heirs and a ≈ø≈øignes for ever; and they ≈øay that the afore≈øaid R. is dead, and now to this Court the afore≈øaid T.B. comes and requires to be admitted to all and ≈øingular the premi≈ø≈øes afore≈øaid, and at this Court the Lord by I.Khis ≈øene≈øchal, has granted thence to him ≈øei≈øin by the verge; to have and to hold to him T.B. and the heirs of his body lawfully begotten; and for defect of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue, to remain to the behoof and u≈øe of the ≈øaid I.I. and his heirs for ever; and the afore≈øaid T.B. gave the Lord as for his fine four pounds, and he did to the Lord fealty and is admitted thereof Tenant.

div.head: Surrender by the Sene≈øchal taken.
div.p:
At this Court witne≈ø≈øed is by W.T. ≈øene ≈ø ch. that W.N. on his death bed lying the tenth day of A. the yeer, &c. ≈øurrendred into the hands of the Lord, by the hands of the ≈øame Sene≈øch. (ab≈øent being the Court) in the pre≈øence of R.C.R.P. and C.H one tenement calledM. in which now dwels W.G. with all his lands and tenements, within the mannor of I. to the behoof and u≈øe of M. his wife for term of her life, and after the decea≈øe of her M. to remaine thence to W. T. the ≈ø on of the afore≈øaid W the father and G the daughter of the ≈øameW. the father, and the ≈øi ≈øter of the afore≈ø aid W. the ≈øon, and to their heirs; 
                                 ‚Ä¢
                              et upon condition following, that if it happen any of the afore≈øaid W. the ≈øon or G. the daughter, to dye without heir of his or her body i≈ø≈øuing, that then he or ≈øhe which ≈øoever ≈øhall ≈øurvive,
≈øhall have and injoy the tenements afore≈øaid to his, or her and their heirs for ever; and upon this came into this Court the afore ≈øaid M. and requires to be admitted to the tenement afore ≈øaid with the appurtenances, to whom the Lord by I. K, his ≈øene ≈øch. granted thereof ≈øei≈øin by verge to have to her in form afore≈øaid, at the will of the Lord according to cu≈øtome of the mannor, and ≈øhe gives to the Lord her fine for her entrance thereupon to be had, and maketh to the Lord fealty and admitted is thereof tenant.

div.head: Death of the Copiholder.
div.p:
Al≈øo at this Court found it is by the homage that a certain W.W. one of the ≈øons and heir of R.W. decea≈øed, held of the Lord to him and his heirs according to the cu≈øtome of the mannor, the moity of two me ≈ø≈øuages or tenements, and of one garden with the appurtenances in I. and long before this Court dyed thereof ≈øei≈øed within the age of ten yeers, and in the cu≈øtody of R.W. according to the cu≈øtome of the mannor, and that S.W. is the brother and ≈øole heir of the afore≈øaid W.W. and of full age, who pre ≈øent is here in Court, and requires to be admitted to all the Lands and Tenements C ‚Ä¢
≈ø tomary of which he the afore≈øaid W.W.dyed ≈øei ≈øed viz. to the afore≈øaid moyty of two Me≈ø≈øuag ‚Ä¢ s or Tenements, a loft and garden with the appurtenances within that Mannor, to whom the Lord by I K. his Sene≈øchal, granted thereof ≈øei≈øin, to have and to hold to him and his heirs of the Lord by verg, at the will of the Lord according to Cu ≈øtome of the Mannor afore≈øaid, by the Rent, Cu≈øtomes and Services therefore heretofore due and accu≈øtomed; And he giveth the Lord for a Fine for his Entrance as it appears ovet his head; And maketht to the Lord fealty and is admitted thereof Tenant.

div.head: Surr. in Court.
div.p:
Al≈øo to this Court came I.T. and ≈ø urrendered into the hands of the Lord ten acres of land more or le≈øs, with the appurtenan ‚Ä¢ es called S.
four Acres of Land more or le≈øs called K. and four Acres of medow more or le≈ø s called C. cu≈øtomary to the behoof and u≈øe of R.B. gentleman, his heirs and e≈ø≈øignes for ever by verge at the will of the Lord, according to cu≈øtome of the mannor afore≈øaid, to which R.B.the Lord by his Sene≈øch granted ≈øei≈øin to have and to hold to him and his heirs of the Lord by the rent of ten ≈øhillings by the yeer, and other ≈øervices; therefore heretofore due, and he giveth the Lord for a fine for his entrance thereupon to be had, four pound, and made to the Lord fealty, and is admitted thereof tenant.

div.head: Death of a parcener.
div.p: Al≈øo the homage ≈øay upon their oath, that a certain R.S. who of the Lord held as parcener by cu ≈øtome of the mannor, nine acres of land cu≈øtomary, with one grange, together with T.S. his brother to him and his heirs, dyed about the la≈øt Court ≈øo ≈øei≈øed, and that a certain I.S. is ≈øon and next heir of the ≈øame R. as to the moity of the afore≈øaid land and grange afore≈øaid, and is of age eight yeers, and upon this as well the cu≈øtody of the afore≈øaid I.S. as the land and grange afore≈ø aid are committed to a certain S.I.as to his good friend, &c. And he found pledge in Court E.N. to render to the afore≈øaidI. the profits thereof, when the age of fourteen yeers he ≈øhould attain.

div.head: Enchrochment.
div.p: Al≈øo they ≈øay upon their oath that R.W.has encroched upon the wa≈øt of the Lord at C. in length ten yard lands, and in bredth one yard land, therefore he is amerced, &c. and ordained it is that he expo≈øe the ≈øame before the fea≈øt of Saint John Bapti≈øt next under the penelty of forfeiture to the Lord for every yardland two ≈ø hillings ≈øix pence.

div.head: Re≈øcuous.
div.p: Al≈øo they ≈øay upon their oathes that G. B.the Baily of the Lord ≈øuch day and yeer, &c. within that Lord≈øhip de≈ø trained H.H. for rent of the Lord then by the ≈ø aid H.H. behind and not paid, And that the afore≈øaid H. then and there re≈øcuous made upon the ≈ø ame G.B. therefore is he amerced, &c.
The form and manner of divers grants and ≈øurrenders, a≈øwell of Copiholders of inheritance, as al≈øo of Copiholds for lives, as followeth.

div.head: Broxhead.
div.p: ≈ø≈ø. TO the Court of the mannor there held the fourteen day of Febr. the yeer, &c. came N. R. and took out of the hands of the Lord one me≈ø≈ø uage and yardland with the appurtinences in B.lately in the tenure of J.A. to have to him and R.P. his ≈øon, and to A. now the wife of the ≈øaid N. for the term of life of them, and either of them longe ≈øt living ≈øucce≈ø≈øively according to the cu≈øtome of the manner afore≈ø aid by the rent and ≈øervice, before thence due and accu≈øtomed, and he giveth to the Lord for ≈øuch e≈øtate; ≈øo thereof to be had three pound, and make there the Lord fealty, and is admitted thereof tenant, and the fealties of the afore≈øaid R. and A.are re≈øpited untill, &c.

div.head: Forfeiture of Cop and retaking.
div.p: To this Court, &c. the homage pre≈øent that P.C. lately the relict of I.C. which of the Lord held, during her widowhood according to the cu≈øtome of the mannor one me≈ø≈øuage, &c.with the appurtinences in A. took for Husband R. L. by which forfeited ≈øhe has her e≈øtate in the premi ≈ø≈øes, and ≈øo remaineth it in the hands of the lord, upon which proclainat. made is, If any one, &c, whereupon came the afore≈ø aid R.L. and took out of the hands of the lord one me≈ø≈øuage, &c. with the appurtinences, to have to him for term of his life, according to cu ≈øtome of the mannor afore≈øaid, by rent and ≈øervices thereof before due, and of right accu ≈øtomed, and he giveth to the Lord for a fine, ≈øuch ≈ø tate ≈øo thereof to have, ≈øix pound and maketh to the Lord fealty, and admitted is thereof tenant.

div.head: Grant of rever≈øion.
div.p:
To the Court, &c. came W.H.and took out of the hands of the Lord, the rever≈øion of one me≈ø ≈øuage, &c. with the
in Y. now in the tenure of J.H.widow lately the wife of W.H. to have and to hold the rever≈øion afore≈øaid, to the afore≈øaid W.H.and B. his ≈øon, for term of the lives of them, and either of them longe≈ø t living ≈øucce≈ø≈øively according to the cu≈øtome of the mannor afore≈øaid, when by the death ≈øurrender or any for feiture of the fore≈øaidI. in any manner done or committed to the hands of the Lord to come it ≈øhall happen, by the rent and ≈øerzices thereof before due and of right accu≈øtomed, and he giveth to the Lord for a fine for ≈øuch rever≈øion ≈øo thereof to be had ≈øeven pound, and his fealty is re ≈øpited until, &c.

div.head: Death.
div.p: THe Jurors pre≈øent, that I.C. who of the Lord held one tenement with its appurtenances in I.in which I.C. the father of the afore≈øaid I. lately dwelt decea≈ø ed about the la≈øt Court, whence fell to the Lord for Heriot one Ox of the price of fourty ≈ø hillings delivered to the u≈øe of the lord of this mannor, whereupon proclam. made was in Court, If any man, &c. upon which came Ann the relict of the afore≈øaid I. and claimes the premi≈ø ≈øes during her widowhood, according to the cu≈øtome of the manner by rent works, cu≈ø tomes and ≈øervices thereof due and accu≈ø tomed, &c.

div.head: Surr. and retaking.
div.p:
TO this Court came C.W. who of the Lord held by Copy Rolle of the Court dat, &c. one Tenement, &c. with the appurtenances in E. ≈øometime in the tenure of R.C. and all tho≈ø e ≈øurrendred into the hands of the Lord, and all his e≈øtate title and intere≈øt in the premi ≈ø≈øes with that intention that it would plea≈øe the Lord a new grant thereof to him the afore≈ø aid C. W. and others to make, according to the cu≈øtome of the mannor afore≈ø aid; upon which ≈øurrender there fell to the Lord for He iot of agreement twenty ≈ø hillings; and into the ≈øame Court came the ≈øaid C.W. and took out of the hands of the Lord the ≈øaid tenement, &c. with its appurtenances, to have to the ≈ø ame C.W. R and I.W. his ≈øons for term of life of them and either of them longe≈øt living ≈øucce≈ø≈øively, according to the cu≈øtome of
the Manor afore≈øaid, by the rent, works, cu≈øtomes, and ≈ø ervices thereof before due and of right accu≈øtomed, and for ≈øuch e≈øtate and entrance ≈øo thereof to be had, the afore≈øaid C.W. gives the Lord for fine 26. l. and maketh to the Lord fealty, and ≈øo the afore≈øaid C.W. admitted is thereof tenant, and the fealties of the afore≈øaid R. and I. re≈øpited are untill, &c.

div.head: Grant of Copy-hold of Inheritance by the Yard.
div.p: AT this Court the Lord granted out of his hands by I.F. his chief Sene≈øch to T.D. & A. his wife, one Me≈øs, &c. with all the appurtenances lying at B. to whom the Lord by by his Sene≈ø ch afore≈øaid granted ≈øei≈øin to have to them and their heires of the Lord by the Yard, at the will of the Lord, according to the cu ≈ø tome of the Manor afore≈øaid, and they give the Lord for a fine for entrance threreof to be had, as it appears upon their heads, and he made to the Lord fealty, and is admitted thereof tenant

div.head: Grant for annuall Rent.
div.p: AT this Court the Lord granted by I.F. his Sene ≈ø chal to T.B. and M. his wife one Me ≈ø≈øuage with ≈øix Acres of land, &c. with the appurtenances, to the afore≈ø aid T. M. their Heirs and A≈ø ≈ø ignes, at the will of the Lord, according to the cu≈øtome of the Mannor, rendring therefore yearly to the Lord his heirs (and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors if the Lord be a Bi≈øhop or Dean, &c.) 6. s. 8. d. for all and ≈øingular the ≈øervices at two tearms of the yeare, viz. at the fea≈øt of S. Mich. the Archangel, and the Annunciation of the ble≈ø≈øed virgin Mary, by equall portions, and they give to the Lord for a fine, &c. and made fealty, and are admitted thereof tenants.

div.head: Court in ancient Deme≈øne.
div.p: TO this Court held there ≈øuch day and year, A. C.the ≈øon and heir of I.C. came, and ≈ø urrendred into the hands of the Lord one Me≈ø≈øuage, &c. in D. within the Juri≈ødiction of this Court, to the behoof and u≈øe of T.H. his heires and a≈ø≈øignes for ever, by vertue of bargain or partition betwixt them made, and upon this publick proclamation in the ≈øame Court made was, that if any man any right or title to the ≈øame Me≈ø≈øuage, Land, &c. or in any parcel thereof pretend will, or has, he ≈øhould come and be heard, and no man came at this Court, wherefore according to the cu≈øtom of the Mannor afore≈ø aid, the Me≈ø≈ø. and Land &c. remain ≈øhould in the hands of the Lord, untill the third Proclamation them concerning be made, whereupon day is given to the parties afore≈øaid, to be at the next Court of the Mannor afore ≈øaid, to hear thereof their judgement upon the Premi≈ø es.

And at this Court held there ≈øuch day and year, as well the afore≈ø aid A.B. as the afore≈øaid T.H. came, and hereupon the ≈øecond Proclamation made was concerning the Premi≈ø es, that if any man any right or title to the ≈øame Me≈ø≈øuage Land, &c. has or pretends, he ≈øhould come and be heard, and no man came, and upon this day was given to the parties afore≈øaid to be here at the next C. of the Manor
afore≈øaid, to hear thereof their judgment upon the premi≈øes.

And at this Court there held ≈øuch day and year, as well the afore≈øaid A.C. as T.H. came, and hereupon the proclamation made was upon the premi≈øes, that if any man any right or title to the afore≈øaid Me≈ø≈ø uage land, &c. or in any parcel of the≈øe has or pretends, he ≈øhould come and be heard, and no man yet came, whereupon the Lord by I.H. his ≈øene≈øcale granted hath, ≈øei ≈øin of the afore≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage, &c. with their appurtenances afore≈øaid to T.H. to be held to him, his heires and a≈ø≈øignes, according to the cu≈øtom of the Mannor afore≈øaid, and he gives to the Lord for a Fine for his entrance, &c. and made to the Lord fealty, and is admitted thereof Tenant.

div.head: Otherwi≈øe in ancient deme≈øne where the wife is examinned.
div.p: AT the Court held there ≈øuch day and year, T.B. of N. and E. his wi≈øe in the pre≈øence of the Court alone examined and confe≈ø≈øed, ≈øurrendred into the hands of the Lord, one Me≈ø≈øuage and half an Oxgang of land, with the appurtenances in D. called R. to the u ≈øe of W.C. of O. whence fell to the Lord one hor≈øe for Heriot, and upon this came the ≈øaid W.C. and took of the Lord the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage, &c. with the appur ‚Ä¢ enancee, to have and to hold, to him and A. his wife, and the heires and a≈ø≈øignes of him W. for ever, according to the cu≈øtom of the Mannor afore≈øaid, by the rent cu≈øtomes and ≈ø ervices thereof before due and accu≈ø tomed, and they give to the Lord for a Fine for entrance to have in the ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage and other the Premi≈øes, &c. and they made fealty, and are admitted thereof Tenants.

div.head: Surrender to the Baily out of Court.
div.p: At this Court, &c. found it is that T.C. out of the Court ‚Ä¢ urrend ‚Ä¢ ed into the the hands of I.B. Baily in the pre≈øence of D.R. and other the Tenants of the L. of this Mannor this witne ≈ø≈ø. one acre of Land in R. heretofore the Land of T.R. to the u≈øe of W.I. to whom the, Lord thereof granted ‚Ä¢ ei≈øin, to be held to him and his heires, &c.

div.head: A Surrender upon Condition.
div.p: TO this Court, &c. came I.C. and ≈ø urrendred into the hands of the Lord, one Cotage lying, &c. to the behoof and u≈øe of I.A. to be held to him and his heires of the Lord at the will of the Lord, according to the cu≈øtom of the manner, under the Conditions following, viz. if the afore≈øaid I.A. pay, or to be paid cau≈øe to the afore≈øaid I.C. xl s. at the Fea≈øt of Saint John Bapti≈øt, and all Saints next comming, after the date of this Court by equal portions, that then the pre≈øent ≈øurrender to be of ≈ø trength and effect, and if he fail in the payment afore≈øaid, in part or in whole, that then well may the afore≈øaid I.C. and his a≈ø≈øignes to reenter, and again have the afore ≈øaid Cottage, this ≈ø urrender in any thing notwith≈øtanding, and he giveth the Lord for a Fine, &c. and made fealty, and admitted is thereof Tenant.

div.head: Grant of a Copyhold forfeit.
div.p:
AT the Court, &c. held ≈øuch day and year, &c. commanded it was to the Baily to ≈øei≈øe into the hands of the Lord, one Tenement with the appurtenances lately in the tenure of I.B. called R. for that he aliened and ≈øold the ≈øaid Tenement to a certain T.V. without the Licen≈øe of the Lord, &c. And thereof ≈øhall he an≈øwer to the Lord for the i≈ø≈øues untill, &c. And in this ≈øame Court the Lord of his grace
≈øpecial hath granted the ≈ø aid Tenement with appurtenances to the afore≈øaid I.B. to whom the Lord thereof hath granted ≈øei≈øin to have to him and his heires, &c. of the Lord at will according to the cu≈øtome of the Mannor afore ≈øaid, and he giveth the Lord for a Fine, &c. and hath made to the Lord fealty, and admitted is thereof Tenant.

div.head: Copy for tearm of years.
div.p: AT this Court the Lord by I.F. his ≈ø ene≈øcale granted to E.R. one Me≈ø≈øuage, &c. with the appurtenances called A. to have and to hold to him and his a≈ø ≈øignes, from the Fea≈øt of Saint Mich. the Archang. next to come after the date of this Court, to the end and term of fourty years from thence next following, and fully to be compleated, rendring therefore annually twenty ≈ø hillings at two terms of the year, viz. &c. by equal portions; provided alwayes that during the term afore≈øaid, the afore≈øaid Lord ≈øhall finde Timber, Mertar, & Wood, as oft as nece≈ø ≈øary it ≈øhall be the ≈øaid Tenements to mend, repair, and ≈øu≈øtain, and he giveth the Lord a Fine, &c. and made the Lord fealty, and admitted is thereof Tenant.

div.head: Relea≈øe in Court of a Title.
div.p:
AT this Court held, &c. found it is that the Lord by T.P his ≈øene≈øcal, at the Court held at C. ≈ø uch day and year granted into the hands of W.P. and to his heires one piece of ground containing about three acres of Land more or le≈øs, ≈ø ometime the Land of T.C. in A. lying there betwixt the Land of A B. on the South part, and the Land of W.S.on the North part, to have and to hold, &c. at the will of the Lord, according to the cu≈ø tom of the Mannor, and after came a certain A.W. before the afore≈øaid T.P. ≈øene≈øcale of the Lord, and pretends to have title to the ≈øaid piece of Land, and here pre≈øent in the Court, remi≈ø ed, rel ea≈øed, and for ever quit claimed, to the afore≈ø aid W.P.and his heires by licen≈øe of the Lord at his right and claim which ≈øhe ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r had, or for the future have may in the afore≈øaid piece of Land, and in any parcel thereof, ≈øo that
viz. neither he A,nor his heirs, nor any other in the name of them, any right or claim in the afore≈ø aid piece of land hereafer make or challenge may, but from all action of right or claim be excluded for ever by the≈øe pre≈øent sand giveth to the Lord, &c, and maketh fealty, &c.

div.head: Grant to the heir after the Fathers death.
div.p: AT this Court held, &c. found it is, that I,Bdyed ≈øei≈øed, after the la≈øt Court, who of the Lord held to him & his heirs one tenement called E, and dyed thereof ≈øei≈øed, and they ≈øay that R.B. his ≈øonne is next heir, and of full age, or within age, if he be within age, viz. of 12 yeares, and in the cu ≈øtody of T.W. or R.M. his brother or kin ≈ø man, and pre≈øent here in Court, ≈øues to be admitted, & admitted is thereof tenant, to hold to him and his heirs of the Lord at the will of the Lord, according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor, &c. and giveth the Lord for a fine, &c. and maketh to the Lord fealty, &c.

div.head: Otherwi≈øe of an intail with remainders.
div.p: AT this Court found it is, that R.B. of A.at the Court held ≈øuch a day and year, &c. at E. ≈øurrendred into the hands of the Lord one tenement, &c. called C. to the u≈øe of R.B.the ≈øon of the ≈øame R. and A his wife, to whom the Lord granted ≈øei≈øin to hold to them and the heirs of their bodies lawfully begotten. And if the afore ≈ø aid R. and A. his wife ≈øhall die without heirs of their bodis lawfully begotten, that then the afore≈øaid tenements, &c. with the appurtenances, ≈øhall remain to the right heirs of him R.B. And now this Court is informed by the whole homage, that the afore≈ø aid R and A are dead without heirs lawfully betwixt them begotten, and the afore≈øaid R B. likewi≈øe, and hereupon comesI.B. brother and heir of the afore≈øaid R.B. and ≈øues to be admitted, and admitted is tenant, &c. and by licence of the Lord, the afore ≈øaid I.B. ≈ø ues to be admitted to the afore≈øaid tenement with the appurtenances, to whom the Lord thereof granted ≈øei≈øin, to hold at the will of the Lord according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor, and giveth the Lord for a fi ‚Ä¢ e, &c. and maketh to the Lord fealty, &c.

div.head: Otherwi≈øe. A copy for life, with divers Remainders over.
div.p: TO this Court came A.T. and ≈øurrendred into the hands of the Lord one Me≈ø≈øuage & 8 Acres of land cu≈øtomary called I, that the Lord may doe thereupon at his will, and the Lord thereof had ≈øei ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n, and of his grace ≈øpeciall he regramed the afore ≈øaid Me ≈ø≈øuage and land to the afore ≈øaid A.T. and K. his wife, during their lives, ≈øo that after the decea ≈øe of them, the afore≈øaid land and tenement ≈øhould remain to the right heirs of him A.T.for ever, to hold to the ≈øame A.T. andK. his wife during the life of them by the verge at the will of the Lord according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor in form afore≈øaid, ≈øaving the right of every man, and the afore≈ø aid A.T. and K. gave the Lord for a fine, &c. and made fealty, &c.

div.head: Surrender out of the Court and Remainder with condition upon the death-bed.
div.p:
AT this Court found it is, that R.I.langui≈ø hing on his death-bed, ≈øurrendred into the hands of B.R. out of the Court by the hands of I.H. in the pre≈øence of A.C. and B.D tenants of this Manor, this Te≈øt. one Me≈ø≈ø uage with the appurtenances, &c. to the u≈øe of A. the wife of the afore≈ø aid R.I. to hold to her by the ≈øervice therefore due according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor for term of her life, ≈øo that after the death of the ≈øaid A, the afore≈ø aid Me≈ø≈ø. ≈øhall remain to I.the ≈øon of the afore≈øaid R. and A, and the Heires of his body lawfully begotten. And if it ≈øhall happen that the ≈øaid I. ≈øhall die without Heire of his Body lawfully begotten, that then the afore≈øaid Me ≈ø≈øuage by the Executors of either of them longe≈øt
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
living be ≈øold, and the monies thence received, and ari≈øing on the poore, and other almes to be di≈øpo≈øed, and di≈øtributed, as to them be≈øt ≈øhall ≈ø eem expedient, to whom the Lord thereof granted ≈øei≈øin to hold in forme afore≈øaid, at the will of the Lord according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor, and they give the Lord for a ≈ø ine, &c. and make fealty, &c.

div.head: Supplication of the Tenant to the Lord.
div.p: TO this Court came R.C. in≈øtantly ≈ø upplicating, as he for many times bypa≈øt hath ≈øupplicated, and proffers the Lord a fine annuall, for the rea≈øon of exemption, that he of grace ≈øpecial and favour, becau≈øe of old age,, infirmne≈ø≈øe & weakne≈ø≈øe of his body, may be exonerated hereafter, from all and ≈øingular Inque≈øts, Juries and Offices what≈øoever, as well in this town as el≈øwhere within the ≈øaid Manor to be ca≈øt upon him and a≈ø≈øigned. Wherefore out of re≈øpect of his old age, together with his infirmne≈ø≈øe and weakne≈ø≈øe under the fine annuall in name of the exemption therfore proffered and his ≈ø ugge≈øtion, to the tenants ≈øeeming that truly he had te≈øtified in the premi ≈øes. Now the Lord has granted in this Court by I.F. his Sene≈ø chal to the afore≈øaid R.C. licence, his favour and exemption for term of life, & the afore≈øaid R.C. gives the Lord for an annuall rent, 4. d. payable at the terms u≈øuall.

div.head: Licence for ≈øuit of Court.
div.p: TO this Court came I.S. Villeni of the Lord, & gives for a fine for ≈øuit of Court to be re≈øpited for one year, 2. s.

div.head: Licence to marry his daughter.
div.p: TO this Court came I.S. Villeni of the Lord of this Manor, and reque≈øts licence to marry his daughter within this Lord≈øhip or without, and the Lord by I.W. his Sene ≈øchall hath granted licence, &c.

div.head: Licence to demi≈øe Tenem. cu≈øtomary.
div.p:
TO this Court came T.R. and reque≈øts licence of the Lord to demi≈øe all and ≈øingular his lands and tenements cu≈øtomary, ≈øituate, lying and being within this Lord≈øhip
to what per≈øon or what per≈øons ≈øoever it ≈øhall plea≈øe the ≈øame T.R. for the term and to the term of 21. year next following the date of this Court, to which T.R.the Lord licen≈øe hath given in form afore≈øaid, for the Fine of 10 s. paid in the Court to the u≈øe of the Lord of this Mannor.

Note, that there is no manner of e≈øtates made of free land by deed pole, or deed indented, but the like e≈øtates may be made by copie of Court roll of copihold Land of inheritance, and entred in the Court rolls: and the Steward is bound by Law and con≈ø cience to be an indifferent judge between the Lord and his Tenants, and to enter their copies truly, in the Lords Court rolls, the which are the Lords Regi≈øter to know his pre≈ø idents, cu ≈ø tomes, and ≈øervices: And al ≈øo they are a great ≈øurety to the Tenants, that if their copies by any ca≈øual means be lo ≈øt, ‚Ä¢ hey may re≈øort to the Lords Court rolls, and the Steward may make them new copies, according to the old pre≈øident in the Lords Court roll: like as at the Common Law, when a matter in variance between two men is pa≈ø≈øed by verdict, and judgement given thereupon and entred in the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parl. Records, there it re≈ø teth of Record to be found if occa≈øion ≈øerve to ≈øearch for it. And al≈øo if a Deed or a Patent be inrolled, there it remaineth of record to be ≈øeen, if need be, and any man that hath occa≈ø ion may have a copie thereof, if they ≈øue to the Judges and the officers of the place where the record lieth, and they may have it exemplified under the ≈øeal of the office of the ≈øame place where ≈ø uch record lieth, if he will be at the charge thereof. And al≈øo if a man have occa≈øion he may plead the ≈øame record in any of the Keepers of the Liberties of England by authority of Parliament Courts. And the Lords ≈øteward may do the like with his Court Rolls.

div.head: Plea≈øs of a Court Baron.
div.p:
R H. plains again≈øt C.E. and A.his wife of a plea of Land, viz. of one Me≈ø≈ø uage, two Cottages, twenty acres of medow pa ≈øture, with the appurtenances in I. within the Juri≈ødiction of this Court, and hath made prote≈øtation to pr ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ecute this plaint, in form and nature of the Writ of the Keepers of the Liberties of England, of Formd ‚Ä¢ n in remainder at the Common Law, and hath found pledges to pro ≈øecute that plaint in form and nature afore≈ø aid, viz. I.H. and R.M.and he requires proce ≈øs hereupon to be made him, according to the Cu≈øtom of the Mannor afore≈øaid, again≈øt C. and A. his wife, therefore according to the cu≈øtom of the Mannor, the contrary of which within the memory of men is not u≈øed, commanded is it to the under Baily of the Mannor afore≈øaid, and Mini≈øter of the Court afore≈øaid that he ≈øummon by good ≈øummons the afore≈øaid C. and A. that they before the ≈øuiters of the Court afore ≈øaid, at the next Court of the Mannor afore≈øaid on Thur ≈øday viz. the 20. day of Ju. the year &c. at the Mannor afore≈øaid to be held, to an≈ø wer the afore≈øaid R.H. of the afore ≈øaid plea, &c. the ≈øame day is given to the afore ≈ø aid R. here, &c. at which next Court came as well the afore≈ø aid R.H.as the afore≈øaid C. and A. by I.R. their Atturney, and the afore≈øaid Mani≈øter of the Court afore≈ø aid returned here in Court, that he by vertue of the precept afore≈ø aid to him directed, ≈ø ummoned the afore≈øaid C. and A. by good ≈ø ummons, viz. by I.C. and R.R. to be here at this Court to an≈øwer the a ‚Ä¢ ore≈øaid R.H. of the afore≈øaid plea of the afore ≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage, two Cottages, twenty acres of Land, twenty acres of Medow, and twenty acres of Pa≈øture, with the appurtenances as to him commanded was, and upon this the afore≈øaid R.H. demands again ≈øt the afore≈øaid C. and A. the Tenements afore≈øaid with the appurtenances, as his right and inheritance, ≈ø aying, that a certain W.H. was ≈ø ei≈øed of the Tenements afore≈øaid, with the appurtenances in his deme≈ø ne as of Fee, at the will of the Lord, according to the cu ≈øtom of the Mannor
afore≈øaid, and ≈øo ≈øei ≈øed being according to the cu≈øt ‚Ä¢ m of that Mannor, from the time out of the memory of men, u≈øed and approved, at the Court of the Mannor afore≈øaid, held at I. within the precinct of the Mannor afore≈øaid, Wedne≈øday next after the Fea≈øt of P. the year, &c. by I.A. and T.P. deputies of the Bailies of the Mannor afore≈øaid, in the pre≈øence of T.C. T.S. R.L. I.M. T R. and I.B. then Tenants of the Lord of the Mannor afore≈ø aid, ≈øurrendered into the hands of the Lord, the Tenements afore ≈øaid with the appurtenances, to the behoof and u ≈øe of a certain M. then wife of the afore ≈øaid W.H. to hold for the term of her life, and after the decea≈ø of the ≈øaid M. the Tenements afore≈øaid, with the appurtenances wholy ≈øhould remain to a certain I.H. the ≈øon of N.H. the brother of the afore≈øaid W.H. and the heires of his body lawfully begotten, and for defect of ≈øuch i≈ø≈øue of the ≈ø aid I. the afore≈øaid Tenements with the appurtenances wholly to remain to a certain E.H. daughter of the afore≈øaid W.H. to hold to her and the heires of her body lawfully begotten; and for defect of ≈øuch i ≈ø≈øue of the ≈øame E. the afore≈øaid Tenements with the appurtenances, wholly to remain to the right heires of the afore≈øaid W.H,and their heires for ever. By vertue of which ≈øurrender, the afore≈øaid M. was ≈øei ≈øed of the Tenements afore≈øaid in her deme≈øne as of Frank tenement at the will of the Lord according to the cu≈øtom of the Mannor afore ≈øaid in the time of peace, &c. taking thereof the explees to the value, &c.
And from the ≈øame M.remained a right by forme of the ≈øurrender afore ≈øaid, according to the cu≈ø tome of the Manor afore≈øaid to I.H. by which the ≈øame I. was ≈øeized of the tenements afore≈øaid, with the appurtenances in his deme ≈øne, as of fee-tail at the will of the Lord, according to the cu ≈øtome of the Manor by form of ≈øurrender afore≈øaid, in the time of peace in the time of the Lord Edward lately King of Englandthe ≈ø econd, taking the E≈øplers to the value, &c. and from him I. after the death of E. becau≈øe both the afore≈øaid I. and E. dyed without heir of their body lawfully begotten, remained hath the right by form of the ≈øurender afore≈øaid, according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor afore≈ø aid to this R,H, who now demands, viz. as ≈øon and heir of W.H. brother and heir of the afore≈øaid W.H, &c. and thereof produces his ≈øuit, &c.

And the afore≈øaid C and H, by T. their Atturney, come and defend their right, when, &c. and ≈øay that the afore≈øaid W,H. gave not the tenements afore ≈øaid with the appurtenances to the afore≈øaid, and the heirs of his body i≈ø≈øuing. So that if the afore≈øaid W,H, ≈ø hould die without heirs of his body i≈ø≈øuing, the tenements with the appurtenances to the afore≈øaid R H. and the heirs of his bod ‚Ä¢ i≈ø≈ø uing, ≈ø hould remain for ever in the form which the afore≈øaid R,H, by his Writ and Court afore≈øaid ≈øuppo≈øes, and of this, &c. therfore the twelve, &c.

div.head: Plaints of Mort d'ance≈øter.
div.p:
R.C. plains again≈øt W.L. and E.his wife, of a plea of land, viz. of one Me≈ø≈ø uage, thirty Acres of Medow, and one hundred Acres of Pa≈øture, with the appurtenances inL. within the juri≈ødiction of this Court, and made prote≈øtation to pro≈øecute this Plaint in form and nature of the Writ of the Keepers of the Liberties of England,&c. of a≈ø≈øi≈øe of Mort d'ance ≈øter at the Common Law, &c. and he requires proce≈øs for him to be made,
according to Cu≈øtom of the Mannor in form and nature of the Writ afore ≈øaid to be directed to the Baily and Mini≈øters of this Court, and that the ≈ø ame Baily and Mini≈øters, by Mandate and precepts of the Lord of this Mannor, and according to the Cu≈ø tome of the ≈øame Mannor ≈øum. by good ≈øum. 12 good and legall men of the homage of the ≈øame Mannor, that they be before the ≈øene≈øcal of the ≈øame Mannor, at the next Court within this Mannor to be held, ready by Oath to acknowledge, if R.C.the Father of the afore≈øaid R was ≈øei≈øed in deme≈øne as of Fee, at the will of the Lord, according to the Cu ≈øtome of this Mannor, the day he died, of and in one Me≈ø ≈øuage, 30. acres of Medow, 100. acres of Pa≈øture of Land cu≈øtome of this Mannor with the appurtenances called C. within the Juri≈ødiction of this Court the day he died, and if the ≈øame R. the Father died within fifty years now la≈øt pa≈øt, and if the afore≈øaid R. the ≈øon be next heir of the afore≈øaid R. the Father, and in the mean time the Lands and Tenements afore≈øaid let them view, and that they ≈ø um. by good ≈øum. the afore≈øaid W. and E.who the ≈øame Lands and Tenements now hold, that they be there to hear the recogn. and he found pledges to pro≈ø ecute the plaint afore≈øaid.

list.item: I. Doo.
R. Roo.

div.head: Barre.
div.p: And now here to this Court comes the afore≈øaid W.L. in his proper per≈øon, and ≈øaies that the afore≈øaid R. Father of the afore≈øaid plaintiff ≈øei≈øed was not in his deme≈øne, as of Fee at the will of the Lord, according to the Cu ≈øtome of this Mannor, the day he died of the afore≈øaid Me≈ø≈øuage, and thirty acres of Medow, and one hundred acres of Pa≈øture with the appurtenances, in manner and form as by the afore≈øaid plaintiff before is ≈øuppo≈øed, and this he requires may be inquired by the a≈ø≈øi≈øe, and the afore≈ø aid plaintiff likewi≈øe, &c.

div.head: Entre in the Per and Cui.
div.p: TO this Court comes I.N. in his proper per≈ø on, and plains again≈øt T.M of a plea of land, viz. of one Me≈ø≈øuage, one Garden, and one Orchard with the appurtenances, and he found pledge to pro≈øecute this plaint afore≈øaid, viz. I B. and R. R. and he prote≈øts to pro≈øecute his plaint afore≈øaid of one Me≈ø ≈øuage, one Garden, and one Orchard with the appurtenances in S. in nature and form of the Writ of the Keepers of the Liberties of England, &c. of Entre in the Per and Cui, ≈øaying that the ≈øame Me≈ø≈øuage, Garden and Orchard with the appurtenances, are his right and inheritance according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor afore≈øaid, and into which the afore≈øaid T.M. has not Entrie, but by E. lately the wife of W.M. and daughter of R.P. to whom the aforeaid R. P. and M. his wife tho≈øe demi≈øed, who thereof unju≈øtly, and without judgement di≈ø≈øei≈øed R.N.the father of himI.N. within 50 years la≈øt pa≈øt, &c. & he requires proce≈ø≈øe therupon for him to be made again≈øt the afore ≈ø aid T.M.according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor; therefore according to the cu≈øtome of that Manor commanded is it, to I.B. under Baily of the ≈øame Manor, & the Mini≈øter of the Court afore≈ø aid, that according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor afore≈øaid, he ≈ø ummon by good ≈øummons the afore≈øaid T.M. that he be at the next Court, viz. the fourth day of M. next to come here to be held, to an ≈øwer the afore≈øaid I.N. the plea afore≈øaid, &c. the ≈øame day is given to I.N. here, &c.

div.head: Common Recovery in right Patent by con≈ø ent.
div.p: TO this Court comes A.B. Citizen and Merchant of L. in his proper per≈øon, and plains again≈øtW.W. of a plea of land, viz. of one Me≈ø≈øuage, one Garden, and one Acre of land with the appurtenances in I. held of this manner by copy of Court Roll, and makes prote≈øtation to pro≈ø ecute his plaint a ‚Ä¢ ore≈øaid, in the Court afore≈øaid in form and nature of the Writ of the Keepers of the Lib. of Eng. &c. of right patent at the Common Law, according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor, and found pledge to p ‚Ä¢ o≈øecute his plaint afore≈ø aid here in the Court afore≈øaid, viz. Io. Den. and Ri. Fen. & requires proce ≈ø≈øe thereupon to be made, again≈øt the afore≈øaid W.W. according to the cu ≈øtome of the Manor afore ≈øaid, therefore according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor afore≈ø aid, commanded it was to I.S. Baily of the Manor afore≈øaid, and Mini≈øter of this Court, that he ≈øummon the afore≈øaid W.W. ≈øo that he be here at the next Court of the Manor afore≈øaid here, viz. Saturday the 4. of Ianuary to bee held, to an≈øwer A.B.the plea afore ≈øaid, and that then he have there the names of the ≈øummons and this writ, and the ≈ø ame day is given to the demandant here, &c. And now, viz. to this Court came the afore≈øaid W.W. in his proper per≈øon, & in ful Court here freely offered to an≈øwer the afore≈øaid A.B. the plea afore≈øaid by good ≈øummons, is to wit, I.D, R.R, according to the cu≈øtome of the Manor afore≈øaid, and uppon this now to this Court the afore≈øaid A,B, viz. in his proper per≈øon, comes and demands again≈øt the afore≈øaid W,W, the Me≈ø≈øuage afore≈øaid, Garden and Acres o ‚Ä¢ Land afore ≈øaid with the appurtenances in I, afore≈øaid held of this Manor by copy of the Rolls of this Court, as his right and inheritance, and whence be ≈øayes that him≈øelf was ≈ø ei≈øed of the tenements afore≈øaid with the appur ‚Ä¢ enances in his deme≈ø ne, as of the ≈øee and right, according to cu≈øtome of the Manor afore≈øaid in the time of peace, &c. taking thereof the explees to the value, &c. And th ‚Ä¢ t ≈øuch is his right he offers, &c.

div.head: An≈øwer.
div.p: And the afore≈øaid W.W. comes and defends his right when, &c. and ≈øei≈øin, of which ≈øei≈øin, &c. as of Fee and right, &c. and e≈øpecially of the Tenements afore≈øaid with the appurtenances and the whole, &c. and puts him≈øelf upon the homage of the afore≈øaid Keepers of the Liberties, &c. of the Court afore ≈øaid, according to the cu≈øtom of the Mannor afore≈øaid, and reque ≈øts recogn. to be made, whether he more right has to hold the Tenements afore≈øaid with the appurtenances, as he holds, or the afore≈øaid A.B.to have the Tenements afore ≈øaid with the appurtenances as he above demands, & c,

div.head: Imparlance.
div.p:
And the afore≈øaid A.B. requires licen≈øe thereupon to imparle untill the eleventh hour before noon of the ≈øame day, and he hath, &c. and the ≈øame hour is given to the afore ≈øaid W. here, &c. and after the ≈øame A.B. again came here into the Court the ≈øame day at the afore ≈øaid hour in his proper per≈øon, and the afore≈øaid W.W. though ≈øolemnly exacted, came not again, but in contempt of the Court receded and default made, therefore according to cu≈øtom of the Mannor afore≈øaid, granted is it by the Court that the afore≈ø aid A.B. recover his ≈øei≈øin again≈øt the afore≈øaid W.W.of the Tenements afore≈øaid with the appurtenances according to the cu≈øtom of the Mannor afore ≈øaid, to hold to the ≈øame A.B. and his heires
according to the cu≈ø tome of the ≈øaid Mannor quit of the afore≈øaid W.W. and his heirs for ever, and the ≈øame W.W. is amerced, &c. and now at this court the Lord in execution of the judgment and recovery afore≈øaid, by his Sene ≈øchal granted to the afore ≈øaid A. B. of the tenements afore≈ø aid with the appertinences ≈øei≈øin, to hold to him, his heirs and a≈ø≈ø ignes by the yard at the will of the Lord according to the cu ≈øtome of this Mannor, and he made therefore to the Lord a fine and fealty, and admitted is thereof tenant.

And after, to wit) to this ≈øame court afore≈øaid A.B. then pre≈øent being, came al≈øo the afore≈ø aid W.W. and ≈øurrendred into the hands of the lord the tenements afore≈ø aid with the appertinences to the behoof and u≈øe of the afore≈øaid A. B. his heirs & a≈ø≈øigns for ever. And further the afore≈ø aid W.W. hath remi ≈øed, relea≈øed, and all things for him and his heirs for ever quit claimed to the afore≈øaid A. B. his heirs & a ≈ø≈ø ignes, in his ful & peaceable po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion & ≈øei≈øin being the day of the making the pre≈øent, all his right, e≈øtate, title, claim, intere ≈øt or demands what≈øoever, which at any time he had, has or by any manner hereafter have may of or in the tenements afore≈øaid with the appertinences, or in any parcel of the ≈øame, ≈øo that, viz. neither the afore≈øaid W.W. nor his heirs, nor any of them, any right, title, e ≈øtate, claim, intere≈ø t or demand of or in the tenements afore≈ø aid with the appertinences, nor in any parcel of the ≈øame hereafter exact, claim or challenge may nor ought for the future, but from all action of right, title, claim, u≈øe, intere≈øt and demand therefore to be made, for ever be excluded, and let every of them be excluded by the ≈øe pre≈øents. And be≈øides the afore≈øaid W.W. grants for him ≈øelf and his heirs, that he does warrant the tenement afore ≈øaid with the appertinences to the afore≈øaid A. B. and his heirs again≈øt all men for ever.

div.head: Common recovery in Entrie in the Po≈øt by con≈øent.
div.p: And after (to wit) to this Court came R.M. and W.M. and plain again≈øt the fore≈øaid M.M. a plea of land, viz. of the afore≈øaid eighteen acres of meadow, and made prote ≈øtation to follow this plaint in form and nature of the writ of the Keepers of the Liberties &c. of entry upon di≈ø ≈øei≈øin in the po≈øt; and upon this the afore≈øaid R. and W.M. in their proper per≈øons demand again≈øt the afore≈øaid M.M. the afore≈øaid eight acres of meadow with the appertinences in I.within the Juri≈ødiction of this Court, as their right and inheritance, and into which the ≈øaid M.M. entry has not, but after the di≈ø ≈øei≈øin which H.H. thereof unju≈øtly and without judgment made to R. and W. within thirty yeers now la≈øt pa≈øt, &c.and whence they ≈øay, that them≈øelves were ≈øe ‚Ä¢ ≈øed of the afore≈ø aid eight acres of meadow with the appertinences in their deme≈øne, as of fee and right at the will of the Lord, according to the cu≈øtom of the Mannor afore ≈øaid, taking thereof the explees to the value &c. And into which &c. And thereof they produce their ≈øuit, &c.

And the afore≈øaid M.M. in his proper per≈ø on came, and defends his right, whence &c. and vouches thereof to warrant the afore≈øaid W.T. who pre≈øent is here in Court in his proper per≈ø on, and freely the afore≈øaid eight acres of meadow with the appertinences to him warrant: And upon this the afore≈øaid R. and W.M. demand again≈øt him W.T.tenent by his warrant afore≈øaid, the eight acres of meadow with the appertinences, whence they ≈øay them≈øelves were ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øame eight acres of meadow with the appertinences in his deme≈øne, as of fee and right, at the will of the Lord, according to the cu ≈øtom of the Mannor afore≈øaid, in the time of peace, &c. taking thereof the explees to the value, &c. And into which, &c. And thereof they produce their ≈øuit. &c.

And the afore≈øaid W.T. tenent by his warrant defends his right when, &c. and further vouches thereof to warrant C.D. who (to wit) pre≈øent is here in Court in his proper per ≈øon, and freely the afore≈øaid eight acres of meadow, with the appertinences to him warranteth, &c. and upon this the ≈ø ame R.and W.M. demand again≈øt C. tenant by warranty the afore ≈øaid eight acres of meadow with the appertinences, whence they ≈øay them≈ø elves were ≈øei≈øed of the ≈øame eight acres of meadow with the appertinences in his deme ≈øne as of fee and right, at the will of the Lord, according to the cu≈ø tom of the Mannor afore≈øaid, in the time of peace, &c. taking thereof the explees to theval, &c. and into which, &c. and thereof they produce their ≈øuit, &c.

And the afore≈øaid R. and W. M.require licence to imparle, and have it, &c. and after the ≈øame R. and W.M. againe came here into the Court, at the ≈øame Court, in their proper per≈øons, and the afore≈øaid T. though ≈øolemnly exacted he was, came not againe, but in contempt of the Court rereceded, and default made, therefore granted is it that the afore≈øaid R. andW.M. recover their ≈ø ei≈øin again≈øt the afore≈øaid M.M. of the afore≈øaid eight acres of meadow with the appertinences, &c. and that the ≈øame M.M. have of the Land of the ≈øaid W.T. to the value, &c. and that the ≈øame W. T. further have of the Land of the afore≈øaid C.D. to the value, &c. and the ≈øame C. is amerced &c. and upon this the afore≈øaid R. and W.M. reque≈øt a precept to make them have plenary ≈øei≈øin of the afore≈øaid eight acres of meadow with the appertinences, to the Mini≈øter of the Court afore≈øaid to be directed, and to them is it granted returnable here without delay, &c. And after (to wit) this ≈øame fir≈øt day of April, came here into the Court afore≈øaid, R. and W.M in their proper per≈øons, and the Mini≈øter of the Court afore≈øaid, viz. R.W. certified to the Court afore ≈ø aid, that he by vertue of the precept afore≈øaid, to him thence directed the fir≈øt day of April, to have made the afore≈øaid R. and W. M. ful ≈øei≈øin of the afore≈ø aid eight
acres of meadow with the appertinences as by the precept afore≈øaid to him commanded was, &c.

And after, to wit, to this ≈øame Court the afore ≈øaid R. and W.M. and the fore≈øaid W.T. then pre≈øent being came and ≈øurrendred into the hands of the Lord in the ≈øame Court, the fore≈øaid eight acres of meadow with the appertinences to the behoof and u≈øe of the afore≈øaid M.M. his heirs and a≈ø≈øignes, to whom the Lord by his Sene≈øchal afore≈øaid granted thereof ≈øe≈øin by the yard, to have and to hold to him and his heirs, at the will of the Lord, according to the cu≈øtome of the Mannor afore≈øaid, &c. and further the afore≈øaid R. and W.M. and W.T. have remi≈øed relea≈øed and altogether for them≈øelves and their heirs for ever quit claimed to the afore≈øaid M.M. his heirs and a≈ø≈øignes in his full and peaceble po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, being in full Court, all their right, e≈øtate, claim, intere≈øt or demands what≈øoever, which at any time they have had, have, or in any manner for the future have may of or in the fore≈øaid eight acres of meadow with the appertinences, or in any parcel thereof, ≈øo viz. that neither the fore ≈øaid R. and W.M. and W.T. nor their heirs, or any of them any right, title, e≈øtate, claim, intere≈øt or demand, of or in the fore≈øaid eight acres of meadow with their appertinences, hereafter exact, claim or challenge may nor ought for the future; but from all occa≈øion of right, title, claim, u≈øe, intere≈øt and demand thereof to be made excluded, and let every of them be excluded for ever by the≈øe pre≈øents. And further the fore≈øaid W.T. grants for him≈øelf and his heirs, that he does warrant the fore≈ø aid eight acres of meadow with the appertinences to the fore≈øaid M.M. and his heirs again≈øt all men for ever, &c.

div.head: Upon buying.
div.p:
G.B. plains again≈øt R.G. a plea of debt of xxx. s. iiii. d. for that, viz. that when the afore ≈øaid R.G. the tenth day of April the year, &c. at I. within the Juri ≈ødiction
of this Court bought of the ≈øame G.B.thirteen jars of oyle, called meat oyle, for fifteen ≈øhillings and three pence, one hundred of madder for fifteen ≈ø hillings and one penny, to be paid to the ≈øame G.B. when therefore required he was, which ≈øummes in the whole amount to the fore≈øaid xxx.s. iiii. d. afore ≈øaid. Yet R. G. though often required he was for the fore≈øaid xxx. s. iiii. d. it to the ≈ø ame G.B. hath not yet rendred, but to him to this time to render it hath refu≈ø ed, and yet refu≈øes; wherefore he ≈øayes that the wor≈øe he is, and dammage has to the value of x. s. and thereupon produces his ≈ø uit, &c.

And the afore≈øaid R.G. by A. his Atturny comes and defends the force and injury when, &c. and ≈øaith, that he ‚Ä¢ weth not to the afore≈øaid G.B. the afore≈ø aid 30. s. 4. d.
‚Ä¢ or any penny thereof, in the form which G.B. above again≈øt him plaines: therefore granted is it, that the fore≈øaid R.G. wage thereof his Law of the twelfth hand, pledg of Law I.M. and R.F. and they came with their Law
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ re at the next Court, in proper per≈øon, and ≈øaid it was
„Äà‚óä„Äâ the fore≈øaid Atturny of the fore ≈øaid R.G. that then
‚Ä¢ hey have here the ≈øame R.G. their Ma≈øter in his proper ‚Ä¢ er≈ø on, to the perfecting his Law afore≈øaid, &c.

At which day here came the fore≈øaid R.G.and perfe
‚Ä¢ ied thereof his law afore≈øaid of the twelfth hand, as it a
‚Ä¢ ove he waged: therfore granted it is that the fore≈øaid plain
‚Ä¢ if nothing take by his plea fore≈øaid, but be amerced for his ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ l≈øe clamor thence, &c. and that the fore≈øaid defendant go without day.
And as for all other actions which will lie in this Court, you ≈øhall find ≈ø ufficient pre≈øidents for them „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Hundred Court, parcell of this booke, whereunto ‚Ä¢ refer you.

div.head: Writ of Grand Cape.
div.p:
I.W. Sene≈øchal to the baily of the ≈øame Mannor greeting. I command thee that thou take≈øt into the hands of the Lord, by view of good and legal men of this Mannor the third part of one me≈ø≈øuage, and twenty acres of land with the appertinences in I. which A.I. in this Court, &c. claims again≈øt T.I. lately of I. as the dower of her, of the indowment of the fore≈øaid C.I. ≈øometime her husband by writ of dower, whereof nothing ≈øhe has for defect of him T. and the day of taking make known to me, and ≈øummby good ≈øumm the ≈øa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
T. that he be here at the next court, thereof to an≈ø wer, a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øhew why he was not here at the la≈øt court, as ≈ø ummoned „Äà‚óä„Äâ was, and leave there the names of tho≈øe by who≈øe view this thou ha≈øt done, the≈ø umm witne≈ø≈øe, &c.

div.head: The entre of the Grand Cape.
div.p: A. Which was the wife of C.L. by A.B. her Attur ‚Ä¢ offered her ≈øelf at this Court again ≈øt T.I. concerning a ple ‚Ä¢ of the third part of one me≈ø ≈øuage & twenty acres of „Äà‚óä„Äâ with the appertinences in I.which the ≈øame A. in this court here claimes as her dower of the indowment of the fore≈øaid I.C. ≈øometime her husband, becau≈øe the tenements afore≈ø aid are within this Lord≈øhip, and women which after the death of their husbands of tenements in I. fore≈øaid being, dowable are, according to the cu≈ø tome of the ≈øame Manner of A. time in which there is not memory of men u≈øed, of the third part of the ≈ø ame indowed ought to be, &c. and he came not and is ≈ø ummoned, &c. therefore by judgment of the court let the third part afore≈øaid with the appertinences b ‚Ä¢ taken into the hand of the Lord, &c. and the day, &c. the fore≈ø aid ≈øumm that he be here at the next court, &c.

div.head: Petit Cape.
div.p: I.W. Sene≈øchal to the baily of the ≈øame greeting. Thee I command that thou take≈øt into the hand of the Lord by the view of good and legal men of this Mannor one me≈ø≈øuage with the appertinences which A.C. in this Court claims as his right, again≈øt B.R. by plaint of formdon in remainder, for defect of him B. and the day of taking known make to me at the next Court, and≈øumm the fore≈øaid B.R.that he be here before, &c. ≈ø uch day, thereof to an≈øwer and ≈øhew, why he was not here in this Court before, &c. ≈øuch day next pa≈øt as ≈øumm he was, and have there this precept, and how, &c.

div.head: Entre of the Petit Cape.
div.p: T.Q.E≈øq. and I. his wife by their Atturney oppo≈øe them≈øelves the fourth day, again≈øt H.B. of I. and A. his wife, concerning a plea of land of the third part of eight me≈ø≈øuages, and eight yardlands of land with the appertinences in I. which the fore≈øaid T.and I. in this Court claim as their dower of her A. of the indowment of G.S. ≈øometimes her husband, again≈øt them, and they came not: And they had therefore day here untill this day, to wit, the tenth day, &c. after at another time they had appeared in Court; therefore by judgement let the third part afore≈øaid with the appertinences be taken into the hand of the Lord, and they be ≈øumm, &c. that they be here the day, &c. to hear thereof their judgment, &c.

div.head: Habere facias ≈øei≈øinam.
div.p:
I.W. Sene≈øchal to the baily of the ≈øame greeting. Know that A.B. in the Court held ≈øuch day, by con ≈øideration of the ≈øame Court recovered his ≈øei≈øin again ≈øt B. C. of
eight acres of land with the appertinences in I. by default of the afore≈øaid B. And therefore I command thee that to the ≈øame A.B. plenary ≈øei≈øin of the tenements afore≈øaid, with the appertinencies, without delay ≈øei ≈øin thou make to have. And have there this precept, and how, &c.

div.head: The manner and form how to keep an Hundred Court, or Court Baron, commonly called a three-weeks Court, and a Court of Ancient Deme ≈øne, as followeth.

div.p: FIr≈øt the Steward mu≈øt enter in his Court book the Stile of the Court thus:
div.q: The Court of R.T. Knight, of the Mannor or Hundred of A. We≈øtbrook, held there ≈øuch day and yeer, &c. before A.B. and C.D. ≈øuitors of the ≈øame Court.
div.p: This done, then the bailif mu≈øt ≈øay O-yes; that is, he mu≈øt make an O-yes, and ≈øay E≈ø≈øoines and proffers before the Court three times, and then ≈øay. All manner of per≈øons that have any thing to do at this Court, draw neer, and give your attendance, and if any man wil be e≈ø ≈øoined, let him come forth and he ≈øhal be received; or if any man will enter any plaints, let him come and he ≈øhall be heard.
This done, if any man will enter any plaints, you mu≈øt enter them after this manner:
div.q: A.B. plains again≈øt C.D. a plea of debt, or a plea of tre≈øpa≈øs, or a plea of ‚Ä¢ aking and unju≈øt deteining his cattel, or ≈øuch like &c.
div.p: And if any man will be e≈ø≈ø oined, you mu≈øt enter their e≈ø≈øoines thus.
div.q: I.S is e≈ø≈ø oined for ≈øuit of Court by W. D.
div.p:
Al≈øo there be four other manner of e≈ø≈øoins which are
≈øeldome u≈øed to be ca≈øt, and the≈ø e be they, viz. If a man be in the warres of the Parliament of England, or Emba ≈ø≈øage, or in any other of the Parliaments of Englands bu≈øine ≈øs, or beyond the ≈øeas, or if any man be ≈øick in his bed, or if any man be letted or hindred by water, ≈øo that he cannot come to the court: which e≈ø ≈øoines mu≈øt be entred after this manner.
div.q: I.S. e ≈ø≈øonied is becau≈øe he is in the ≈øervice of the Parliament, &c.
A.S. is e≈ø≈øoined becau≈øe he is beyond ≈øea.
T.S. is e ≈ø≈øoined becau≈øe he is ≈øick in bed.
W.G. is e≈ø≈øoined becau≈øe he could not come for the overflow or height of water.
div.p: And there be other two manner of e≈ø≈øoines which are in plea, the one after ≈øumm, or attachment, and the other after i≈ø≈øue joyned, are to be entred after this manner.
div.q: I.S. who ≈ø ummoned was, or attached was to be here at this court to an≈øwer to T.K. a plea of debt, or ≈øuch like, now e≈ø≈øoined is by W.D. &c.
div.p: And the other mu ≈øt be entred after this manner.
div.q: I.S. who hath day until this court, who the i≈ø≈øue joyned betwixt T.K. plaintif and I.W. defendant, now e≈ø≈øoined is by D.W. &c.
div.p: And if it be upon a wager in Law, then it mu≈øt be entred after this manner.
div.q: I.S. who hath day to this court to make his law again≈øt T.K. plaintif in a plea of debt now e≈ø≈ø oined is by W.D.
div.p: And in like manner the plaintif may be e≈ø ≈øoined if he will; and if the one party be e≈ø≈øoined at one Court, the other party may be e≈ø≈øoined at the next Court following.
And you mu≈øt under≈øtand, that who≈øover will ca≈øt any e≈ø≈øoin in the≈øe Courts, he mu≈øt come at the beginning of the Court when proclamation is made, or el≈øe he ought not to be received.

And note al≈øo, that in all the≈øe ca≈øes following, the party cannot be e≈ø≈øoined: fir≈øt if he have an Atturney in the ≈øelf ≈øame plea pre ≈øent in the Court, or if the party him≈øelf be ≈øeene in the Court, or if there be no plea, if the party made default at the la≈øt Court before, then he cannot be e≈ø≈øoined, or if he come in by Cepi corpus, or di≈øtre≈øs, or if he come in the end of the Court, he cannot be e ≈ø≈øoined, as appeareth by the ≈øtatute of E≈ø≈øoines made in the 21. yeere of E. 2.

And you mu≈øt al≈øo under≈øtand, that for every default that the defendant maketh after this appearance, and day given to an≈ø wer or do his Law, and then make default at any day, he ≈øhall be called non-≈ø uit, and he and his pledges amercied, and that is where the plaintif is a ≈øtranger dwelling out of the juri≈ødiction of the Court, where he finds pledges, if the ca≈øe ≈øhould pa≈øs again≈øt him, his pledges mu≈ø t then pay the defendants co≈øt, which is a thing ever rea≈ø onable, but ≈ø eldome or never u≈øed.

And the Steward of the Court, at the beginning of the Court mu≈øt inquire of the Bailife how he hath ≈øerved the attachments and di≈øtre≈ø≈øes, and other precepts to him directed, and if he ≈øay that they were ≈øerved, then call the parties, and if the plaintife have not his declaration ready when the defendant appeareth, he mu≈øt be called non-≈øuit, thus. A.B. come forth and pro≈øecute thy Action again≈øt C.D. or el≈øe thou wilt be non-≈øuit: and if he come not forth ≈øitting the Court, or ≈øome for him to crave further time to declare, which the Court in di≈øcretion may grant him, then he ≈øhall be non-≈øuit of cour≈øe: and if the defendant make default, proce≈ø≈øe mu ≈øt goe forth again≈øt him: and in a per≈øonall Action the proce≈ø≈øe are ≈øummons, attachment, and di≈øtre≈ø≈øe infinite, which attachments and di≈øtre≈ø≈øes mu≈øt be rea≈øonable, and not outragious, according to the ≈øtatute of Marlebridge cap. 4. And if the defendant
make default upon the attachment or di≈øtre≈øs, they being ≈øerved, and ≈øo returned by the bailif, then the goods ≈øo taken by attachment or di≈øtre≈øs be forfeit to the Lord of the Court, and the defendant ≈øhal al ≈øo be amerced, and a new Di≈øtringas ≈øhall go out again≈øt him. And if the defendant appear and then after make default, he ≈øhall be condemned by default, and a nihil dicit entred again≈øt him, and the Steward mu≈øt enter both the effect of the declaration for the plaintif, and of the plea or an≈øwer for the defendant.

And if the parties plead to an i≈ø≈øue triable by an Inque≈øt, proce≈øs mu≈øt be made to ≈øummon the Jury, viz. a venire fac, and if the defendant be condemned either by default or by verdict, then a Levare fac ≈ø hall be awarded to make levie of his goods, and thereupon the defendants goods ≈øhall be taken, prai≈øed, and ≈øold to ≈øatisfie the party plaintif, and if the defendant have no goods whereupon levie may be made, then the plaintif is without remedy, except it be by a private cu≈øtome, which is u≈øed in ≈øome places, to take the body, then the body may be taken by a Capias ad ≈øatisfac and laid in pri≈øon, there to remain untill the plaintif be ≈øatisfied: but you mu≈øt under≈øtand that in a county Court, hundred Court, or court Baron, there can be no plea held where the debt or damages amount to ten ≈ø hillings or above.

And it is a maxim in law, that in all courts which are not courts of record, the matter if it be for debt, ought to be tryed by oath, that is, by wager of law by the defendant and not otherwi≈øe, unle≈øs it be by a≈ø ≈øent of both parties.

div.head: The forme of Proce ≈ø≈øe in ba≈øe Courts, which are Courts of Record.
A Summons.
div.p: COmmanded it is to the Baily there that ≈øumm he make C.D.that he be here at the next Court to an≈øwer A.B. in a plea of debt, detinne, tre≈ø pa≈øs, or ≈øuch like.

div.head: An Attachment.
div.p: Commanded it is to the Baily there, that he attach C.D. by his goods and chattels, that he be at the next court, to an≈øwer A.B. of a plea of debt, or ≈øuch like.

div.head: A Di≈øtringas.
div.p: Commanded it is to the Baily there that he di≈øtrein E.D. by his goods and chattels, that he be here at the next Court, to an≈øwer A.B. a plea of debt, &c. witne≈øs I.W. Gent. Sene≈øc. there.

div.head: Al di≈ø tring & plur. di≈øtring.
div.p: Commanded it is to the baily there as el≈øe, or many times to thee commanded was that thou di≈øtrein &c. as above.

div.head: A Venirefac.
div.p: Commanded is it to the Baily there, that to come he cau≈ø e twelve good and legall men of his bailywick, that they be here at the next Court, to try the i ≈ø≈øue joyned betwixt A.B. plaintiff, and C.D. defendant, of a plea of debt, or ≈øuch like.

And if a full Jury do not appear, then as many as make default, and be not e≈ø≈øoyned, ≈øhall be amercied, and a Decem tales awarded to ≈øummon ten more, as followeth, and the ≈ø ame day given to the fir≈øt Jury.

div.head: Decem tales.
div.p: Commanded it is to the Baily there, that he to come cau≈øe ten ≈øuch good and legall men of his bailiwick, that they be here at the next Court with others, who to them and there may be a ≈ø≈øociated, to try the i≈ø≈øue joyned betwixt A.B. Plaintiff, and C.D. Defendant, concerning a plea of debt, or ≈øuch like.
At which day as many as make default, and be not e ≈ø≈øoyned, ≈øhall be amercied; and then an Octo tales ≈øhall be awarded; and after that, if need be, a Sex tales.

And if there appear a full Jury, then both the parties ≈øhall have their challenges lawfull to the Jurors; and if the Jury finde for the plaintife, then they mu≈øt give co≈øt of ≈øuit and damages: and in the like manner they ≈øhall a≈ø≈øe≈øs damages, if they find for an Advowant in a Replevin, &c.

div.head: A levare fac.
div.p:
Command the baily there that of the goods and chattels
of G.D. to be levied he cau≈øe xx. s. which A.B. in this Court recovered again≈øt him, in a plea of Debt, or ≈øuch like, and for his mi≈øes and Co ≈øts 12. d. So that tho≈øe monies he have here at the next Court, to render to the fore≈øaid A.B.Witne≈øs, &c.

And if the bailife returne that he can find no goods of the ≈øaid C.D. then if the cu≈øtome ≈øerve, he may have a Capias to take the body and lay him in pri≈øon, untill ≈øuch time as he hath ≈øatisfied the party. The forme of which precept is thus:

div.head: ACap ad ≈øatisf.
div.p: Commanded it is to the baily there that he take C. D.and him in his pri≈øon ≈øafely to be kept cau≈øe, untill he has ≈øatisfied A B. as well of the xx. s. for debt which the fore≈øaid A.B. recovered again≈øt him, as of the 12. d. for his mi≈øes and co≈øts, &c. witne≈øs, &c.
And if any goods be taken wrongfully, then the party grieved may have a replevin, which mu≈øt be made after this manner.

div.head: A replevin.
div.p:
I.W. Gent Sene≈øch. of R. T. Kn. to R.F. baily of the hundred of A. greeting. Becau≈øe A.B. has found me ≈øufficient ≈ø ecurity, as well his clamour to pro≈øecute, as for his bea≈øts, viz. one oxe which C.D. took and unju≈øtly deteins as it is ≈øaid, to be return, if the return thereof be adjudged, therefore thee I charge and al≈øo command, that the ox afore≈øaid to the afore≈øaid A.B. without delay replevied to be and delivered thou cau≈øe≈øt, and put by ≈øurety and ≈øafe pledg the fore≈øaid G.D. that he be at the next court at A.afore≈øaid to be held, to an≈øwer the fore ≈øaid A.B. a plea of taking and
unju≈øt deteining of his ‚Ä¢ oxe afore≈øaid, and how this my precept ≈øhall be executed, to me at the next Court at A. afore≈øaid to be held make known, under perill incumbent, together with this precept given under my ≈øeal the tenth day of April, the year, &c.

And if the Bailif do not deliver the plaintif his cattell by vertue of the ≈øaid Replevin, then the plaintif may have an Alias replevin with the≈øe words, vel cau≈øam mihi ≈øignifices,which Replevin mu≈øt be made after this manner.

div.head: Alreplevin.
div.p: I.W. Gentleman Sene≈øchal of R.T. to R.F.baily of his Mannor or bund of A. greeting. Becau≈øe A.B. hath found me ≈ø ufficient ≈øecurity, as well his clamour to pro≈øecute, &c. (as in the other replevin) therefore I charge and al≈øo command thee as el≈øe thee have I commanded, that the oxe afore≈øaid to the ≈øame A.B. without delay to be replevied thou cau≈øe≈øt, or the cau≈øe to me thou ≈øignifie≈øt wherefore my mandates to thee therefore directed execute thou woulde≈øt not or mighte≈øt not, and put by ≈øuerties and ≈øafe pledg, &c. as before in the other replevin.

And if the Bailif do not deliver the plaintif his cattell upon this Replevin, nor ≈øhew ≈øufficient cau≈øe why he did not, then the party may have a Pluries replevin, vel cau≈øam mihi ≈ø ignifices, which mu≈øt be made verbatim as the alias Replevin was made, onely changing this word alias into Pluries. And if the bailif return upon any of the≈øe Replevins; quod averia elongat ≈øunt ad loca ≈øibi ignot, Ita quod a veria ill pref. C.D. deliberar non potuit, then the plaintif may have a Withernam, which mu≈øt be made in this manner.

div.head: A Withernam.
div.p: I.W. Gent Sene≈øchal of R. T. Knight, to R.F. Baily of his Mannor or Hundred of A. greeting. Since that A.B. hath found me ≈ø ufficient ≈ø ecurity as well his clamour to pro≈øecute, as for return to be had of one ox, &c. if the return thereof be adjudged, which E.D. at C. took, and unju≈øtly detains, as it is ≈ø aid, and the afore≈øaid baily upon divers my precepts for replevie to be made to the ≈øame baily directed, me hath certified, that the ≈øame oxe eloygned is to places to him unknown, ≈øo that view of the ≈øame have he could not. Therefore thee I charge and al≈øo command, that thou take≈øt in Withernam chattels to the value of the ≈øaid Ox, of the chattels of the ≈øaid C.D. to be delivered to the fore≈øaid A.B. for the Ox afore ≈øaid ≈øo eloigned, and put by ≈øureties and ≈øafe pledges the afore ≈øaid C.D. as above in the fir≈øt replevin, &c.

div.head: Deliverance.
div.p: I.W. Gent Sene≈øchal of R. T. of the Court of his Mannor or Hundred of A.to R.F.baily of the Mannor or Hundred afore≈øaid; as al≈øo to R.B.and I.S. bailies this time onely, greeting. Of the part of the Keepers of the Libert of &c. you and every of you, joyntly and ≈øeverally I command, that to be delivered you cau≈øe, or one of you to be delivered cau≈øe to C.D. his bea≈øts, which A.B. took and unju≈øtly deteined again≈øt ≈øurety and pledg, as is ≈ø aid. And that you put, or &c. the fore≈øaid A.B. that he be here at the next Court to be held, the fore≈øaid C.D. to an ≈øwer concerning the plea afore≈øaid, and the an≈øwer of this precept make known to me, or &c. at the next Court. Given, &c.

div.head: Al Capias in Withernam.
div.p: I.W. Gent Sene ≈øch of R.T. knight of his Mannor or hundred of A. to the baily of the hundred of A. as al≈ø o to A.D. and C.B. my bailies for this time Itinerant, greeting. Becau≈øe R.
