E. baily of the hundred afore≈øaid, at the Court of this hundred before me held at A. ≈øuch day and year, &c. to me hath returned that by vertue of my warrant to him many times directed, he came to the pound of I.D. to ‚Ä¢ he place where the bea≈øts afore≈øaid impounded and deteined were by the ≈øame I.D. and the≈øe bea≈øts going and eloigned were before his coming, out of the hundred afore≈ø aid, to places to him unknown, by the afore≈øaid I.D. for which the bea≈øts afore ≈ø aid the baily fore≈øaid replevie could not; wherefore con ≈ø idered it is by the Court, willing the malice of him I. to meet with, that the bea≈ø ts of the fore≈øaid I. be taken in Withernam to the value, &c. and tho≈øe to the fore≈øaid A.B.be delivered ≈øafely and ≈øurely to be kept, untill to the ≈øame A.B.his bea≈øts afore≈ø aid, according to Law, replevie you can, and according to the tenor of my mandate afore≈øaid: therefore you and every of you, jointly and ≈ø everally I command, that ye take, or, &c. the bea≈øts of the fore ≈øaid I. D. to the value, &c. in Withernam, and tho≈øe to the fore≈øaid A.B. to be delivered you cau≈øe, or, &c. ≈øafely and ≈øurely to be kept untill, &c. and di≈øtrein ye, or, &c. the afore≈øaid I.D. ≈øo that he be at A. at the next Court there to be held, to an≈øwer the fore≈øaid A.B. the plea fore≈øaid, and the an ≈øwer of this my precept known make ye, &c. at the next Court. Given under the ≈øeal of my Office ≈øuch day and year, &c.

Note that when the ≈øaid Replevin is granted, there mu≈øt be a bond taken of him to whom it is granted,
or of ≈øome other for him, to appear at the next Court, and to pro≈øecute his ≈ø uit with effect, or el≈øe it may be prejudiciall both to the granter of the Replevin,and to the executioner thereof: and the form of that bond and condition thereof is this:

div.head: An Obligation upon a Replevin.
div.p: Know all men by the≈øe pre≈øents, that I. Anton. D.of A. in the County of S.Gent. am held and firmly obliged to Richard T. Kn, Lord of the hundred of A. in ten pounds of good and lawfull money of England, to be paid to the ≈øame R. or his certain Atturney, his executors or A≈ø≈øignes: to which payment well and truly to be made, I bind me, my heirs, executors and admini≈øtrators firmly by the≈øe pre≈øents with my ≈øeal ≈øealed. Dated the tenth day of February, the year, &c.

The Condition of this Obligation is ≈øuch, That if the above bounden A.D.do appear the next Court of the above named Sir R. T. to be holden within this Mannor of A. in the Countie of South-hampton, and then and there pro≈øecute with effect his ≈øuit or action again≈øt A.B. for the wrongfull taking and detayning of his cattell, as he hath alleaged, and do make return thereof, if returne thereof ≈ø hall be adjudged in the ≈øaid Court by cour≈øe of Law, and al≈øo do ≈øave and keep harmle≈øs the ≈ø aid I.W. Steward of the ≈øaid court, and the balifs in all things touching or concerning the granting or execution of the ≈øaid Replevin, without fraud, covin, or delay, That then this pre≈øent obligation to be void, and of none effect, or el ≈øe the ≈ø ame to ≈øtand, remain, and continue in force, ≈øtrength, and vertue.

And if it be Ancient Deme≈ø ne, then they u≈øe to acknowledg Fines, and ≈øuffer recoveries of their land which they buy and ≈øell within Ancient Deme≈øne, and that is by the Keepers of the Liberty of England by authority of Parliament their Writ of Right Clo≈øe, i≈ø≈øuing out of the Chancery, directed to the bailif of the court, and they are entred in the court book after this manner:

div.head: Alton We≈øtbrook, the form and manner of a Fine there.
div.p:
The Court of Richard T. and H. his wife, there held Thur≈øday the tenth day of I. the yeer &c. before Richard B. and I. ≈øuiters of the ≈ø ame Court, according to the cu≈øtom of the ≈øame Mannor, from the time who ≈øe contrary in the memory of man is not. To this Court came I.M. in his proper per≈øon, and brought here into the Court the Writ of the ≈ø aid Keepers of the Libert of &c. of Right Clo ≈øe, again≈øt I.F.and S. his wife, to the baily of R.T.Knight and H.his wife, of his Mannor of Alton We≈ø tbrook directed, and in form of right according to the cu≈øtome of the Mannor afore ≈ø aid, to be executed and determined: of which Writ the tenor followeth in the≈øe words: The Keepers, &c. and ≈øo reciting the whole Writ word by word, &c. Upon which the fore≈øaid I.M.according to the cu≈øtom of the Mannor afore≈øaid, hath made prote≈øtation to pro≈ø ecute his Writ afore≈øaid again≈øt the fore≈øaid I.F. andS. his wife, in form and nature of the Writ of the Keepof the Lib &c. of covenant at the common Law, a Fine thereupon betwixt them of the tenements afore≈øaid with the appertinences in the writ afore≈øaid ≈øpecif. to make and levie, requiring that I.F. and S. his wife may keep to him the covenant of the tenements afore≈øaid, with the appertinences in Alton We≈øtbr. and he found pledgto pro≈øecute his Writ afore≈øaid, viz. I.D. and R.R. Upon which the ≈øame I. F. and S. his wife
≈øolemnly exacted are, and appeared; and upon this the ≈øame I.F.and S. his wife reque≈øt licence to concord with the fore≈øaid I.M.the plea fore≈øaid, and they give the Lord for ≈øuch licence 3. s. 4. d.

And the concord is ≈øuch, viz. That I.F. and S. his wife do recognize the tenement afore ≈ø aid with the appertinences to be the right of him I.M. as tho ≈øe which the ≈øame I.M. hath of the gift of the fore≈øaidI.F.and S. his wife, and tho≈øe have remi≈ø ed and quit-claimed from them and their heirs, to the fore≈øaid I.M. and his heires for ever: And further the ≈øame I.F. and S.his wife have granted for them and the heirs of I.F. that they do warrant the tenement afore≈øaid with the appertinences to the fore≈ø aid I.M.and his heirs, again≈øt the fore≈øaid I.F. and S.and the heirs of the fore≈øaid I.F. for ever: And for this recognizance, remi≈ø ion, quit-claim, warrant, fine and concord, the ≈øame I.M. hath given the fore≈øaid I.F. and S. his wife xl.Mark ≈ø terling, &c.
The ≈øtile of the Court mu≈øt be ≈øet down as it is before in the fine, mutatis mutandis, and is as occa≈øion ≈øhall ≈øerve. Then thus:

div.head: The form of a Recovery there.
div.p:
TO this Court came R.H. and T.S. in their proper per≈øons, and they brought here in the Court the Writ of the Keepers of the Libert of Right Clo≈øe again≈øt I.M. to the Baily of R.T. Knight, and H. his wife, of their Mannor of Alton We≈øtbrook directed, in form of right, according to the cu≈øtome of the Mannor afore≈øaid, to be executed and determined, of which Writ the tenor followeth in the≈øe words: The Keepers, &c. and ≈øo reciting the Writ word by word (as above in the Fine.) Upon which the fore≈øaid R. H. and T.S.according to the cu≈øtom of the Manor afore≈øaid,
made prote ≈ø tation to pro≈øecute this writ afore≈øaid again≈øt I.M.in form and nature of the Writ of the Keepers of the Liberties, &c.of right at the common law, and they found pledg to pro ≈øecute their Writ afore≈øaid, viz. I. Doo. R. Roo. and they require proce≈ø≈øe for them to be made again≈øt the afore≈øaid I.M.according to the cu ≈øtome of the Mannor afore≈øaid, and the fore≈øaidI.M. ≈ø olemnly exacted, appeared, and came here into the Court in his proper per≈ø on: whereupon the ≈øame R.H. and T. S. demand again ≈øt the fore≈øaid I.M. the tenements afore≈øaid with the appertinences as their right and inheritance, and into which the ≈øame I.M. had not entrance, but after the di≈ø≈øei≈øin which H.H. unju≈øtly and without judgement made to the fore≈øaid R.H.and T.S. within thirty years, &c. and whence they ≈øay that them≈øelves were ≈ø ei≈øed of the tenements afore≈øaid with the appertinences in their Deme ≈øne as of fee and right, in the time of peace, taking thereof the explees to the value, &c. and into which, &c. And thereof they produce their ≈ø uit, &c.

And the fore≈øaid I.M. in his own per≈øon came, and defends his right, when, &c. and vouches thereupon to warrant I.F. who pre≈øent is here in Court in his proper per≈øon, and freely the tenements afore≈øaid to him warrants, &c. And upon this the ≈øame R.H.and T.S. demand again ≈øt himI.F. by his warrant, the tenements afore≈øaid, with the appertinences in form afore≈ø aid, &c.and whence they ≈øay that them≈øelves were ≈øei≈øed of the tenements afore ≈øaid in their Deme ≈ø ne, as of fee and right in the time of peace, taking thereof the explees to the value&c. into which &c. and thereof they produce their ≈øuit. And the afore≈ø aid I.F.tenant by warranty defends his right, when &c. and vouches thereupon to warranty I.P. who in like manner pre≈øent is here in Court in his proper per≈øon, and freely the tenements afore≈øaid to him warrants: and upon this the ≈øame R.H. and T.S. demand the tenements afore≈øaid with the appertinences, in form afore≈øaid, and whence
they ≈øay that them≈øelves were ≈øei≈øed of the tenements afore≈øaid, with the appertinences in their deme≈øne as of fee and right, in the time of peace, &c.taking thereof the expleces to the value &c.

And the fore≈øaid I.P.tenant by his warranty defends his right, when, &c. and puts him≈ø elf upon the great a≈ø≈øi≈øe of the Keep of the lib. &c. and praies recogni≈ø to be made whether he more right hath to hold the tenements afore≈øaid, with the appertinences as tenent thereof by his warranty as he holds, or the fore≈øaid R.H. and T.S. to have the ≈øame tenements with the appertinences as they above demand, &c. and the fore≈øaid R.H. and T.S.pray licence thereupon to imparle, and they have it, &c.

plaintif before the time in which ≈øuppo ≈øed is the tre≈øpa≈øs afore≈øaid to be, one cow of his the def at G. afore≈øaid found, without cau≈øe rea≈ø onable took, and her into the clo≈øe afore≈øaid drove, and her there impounded, for which the ≈øame def. that cow again to have, the clo≈øe afore≈øaid the afore≈øaid time in which &c. entred, and her then and there took and brought away, as well he might; and this ready is he to verifie; wherefore he prayes judgment whether the fore≈ø. pl. his action afore ≈øaid therefore again≈øt him to have ought, &c.

div.head: Replication of his own wrong without ≈øuch cau≈øe and i≈ø≈øue upon it.
div.p: And the fore≈øaid plaintif ≈øaith that he for any things prealledged from his action afore≈øaid of breaking the clo≈øe afore≈øaid again≈øt the def. afore≈øaid praecluded ought not to be, becau≈øe he ≈øaith that the fore ≈øaid def. the day and year above≈øaid, of his own wrong, and without the cau≈øe by him the def. praealledged, the clo≈øe of him the pl. at C. afore≈øaid broke, as he above again ≈øt him plaineth, and this be prayes may be inquired by the country, and the fore≈ø. def. likewi≈øe: therefore 12. &c.

div.head: Barre in tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe by offer of rea≈øonable amends.
div.p:
And the fore≈øaid def. by I. W. his atturny came, and defend the force and wrong, when, &c. and ≈øaith that the fore≈øaid plaint his action afore ≈øaid again≈øt him to have ought not, becau≈øe he ≈øaith that he immediately after the fore≈øaid time of the tre≈øpa≈ø≈øe afore≈øaid to be ≈ø uppo≈ø ed, viz. the 10. day of Jan. the year &c. at N. afore ≈øaid, by the proper hands of him the def. offered to pay to the fore ≈øaid pl. xi. s. for his damages with the cowes afore≈ø. in the fore≈ø. place in which, &c. to the fore≈ø. pl. done, which xi. s. were ≈øuffic.
amendment for the dammages with the Cows afore ≈øaid, in the fore≈øaid place in which, &c. the ≈øame time which, &c. done, which xi.s. the fore≈øaid pl. of the ≈øame def. to receive then and there altogether refu≈øed. And this ready is he to verifie; wherefore he prayes judgement, whether the fore≈ø. plaint the action afore ≈ø. therefore again≈øt him to have or maintain ought, &c.
Tender of ≈øufficient amends is a good plea in repleg before impounding the bea≈øts, not after.

Note, that if any man pl. or def. be minded to remove any action out of this Court, he mu≈øt do it by the Keepers of the liberty of England by authority of Parliaments writ, called an Accedas ad cur, which i≈ø≈øueth out of the Chancery; and it mu≈øt be made by a Cur≈øiter of that Shire where the action lieth, and directed to the ≈øherife of the ≈øame County, who will make his warrant to the bailife of that Court, and the bailife mu≈øt take his return of the warrant, thus; Fir≈øt the bailife ≈øends or delivers to the ≈øherife a copy of the entrance of the Court when the cau≈øe was removed, thus:

div.head: Alton VVe≈øtbrook.
div.p: The Court of R.T. Knight, thereheld on Thur≈øday, viz. thex. day of May the year, &c. before I.W. G.S. R.H. and T.D. ≈øuiters of the ≈ø ame Court.

div.head: The Copy of the plaint.
div.p: I.S. plaineth again≈øt W.W. a plea of taking and unju≈øt deteining of his bea≈øts.

By certue of this precept to me directed, taking with me I.VV &c. four di≈øcreet Knights of the hundred of A. fore≈øaid, I came to the Court of R.T.Knight, and to be recorded cau≈øed the plea which is in the ≈øame Court betwixt
I.S. pl and W.W.defen, and that record ready I have under my ≈øeal and the ≈øeals of the fore≈øaid 4. Knights of the ≈øame Court, of tho ≈øe who at that record pre≈ø ent were, and to the parties afore≈øaid the ≈ø ame day have I prefixed as to me commanded was, In te≈øtimony of which matter as well I R.F. baily of the Hundred afore≈øaid, as the fore≈øaid I.W.&c. 4. legal Knights of the Hundred afore≈øaid to the≈øe pre≈øents our Seal have put.
Thereupon the ≈øherife maketh his returne, as to the ≈øaid writ appeareth.
